 At the Pickering Creek Audubon Center's annual donor Pig Roast this autumn, Pickering debuted the first trail loop in the new woods they acquired in fall of 2022.Thanks to the generosity of many community members, the Center was able to purchase 63 acres of woods adjacent to the Center's main campus in September of 2022. Over the course of the past year, staff and stakeholders have enjoyed free-form walks in the new woods as they considered potential trails and highlights along those trails.The first result of that effort is the New Woods Loop.The loop begins at the conclusion of one of the Center's wetlands boardwalks, following a path along the wooded shoreline overlooking the head of Pickering Creek.After a short walk, hikers enter the new woods, dominated by mature oaks, tulip poplar, beech and hickory.The first stop along the walk is Barred Owl Circle, a delightful set of benches built by the Center's volunteer crew that are set up in a natural clearing in the woods that provide a wonderful place to rest and contemplate the quiet around you.It is aptly named for the regularity that you hear Barred Owls calling.Summer EcoCamp groups enjoyed this location all summer as one of their starting points for exploration of the new woods. Camp groups began exploring the new woods with their group leaders during the second week of the Center's seven-week camp.It quickly became the most popular place that campers wanted to go.They have adopted their own name for it, Echo Woods Circle, because of the interesting echo of voices that occurs as sound bounce across the creek and back. The circle is slightly short of the halfway point of the walk.The trail continues and casually meanders amongst big trees and runs alongside a wooded wetland. A small bridge crosses a seasonal stream as the trail curls left beneath towering tulip poplars.From here hikers enter a grove of American Holly before exiting the woods into the Center's meadow.The trail links up with the center's next newest trail, the meadow loop.Hikers can turn right and continue on for further adventure through the meadow and onto the meadow viewing platform or head towards the farm pond and back to the parking lot."I've seen something new every time I taken this walk," said Pickering Board President Tom Sanders.This is the first of several planned trails that will enable community members to explore the woods over the next few years. The debut of the next section of trail is planned for mid 2024.The trail is three quarters of a mile long from the parking lot, through the woods and back along the meadow trail to the parking lot. Allow 40 minutes for the walk.During the winter months Pickering is open daily from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m.If you would like to sign up for a guided walk in the new woods, visit pickeringcreek.org.

title: Investors consider climate change before buying homes
content:
Investors consider climate change before buying homes

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 908
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A recent Forbes survey reveals nearly a third of Americans cited climate change as a reason to move last year.For aspiring homeowners, climate has transitioned from a selling point to a critical risk factor.Prospective home buyers must educate themselves on the tangible impacts of climate change to safeguard their property investments from potential catastrophic events.When sizing up a property, environmental considerations used to be a matter of taste. Does the buyer prefer warm, sunny summers on the coast or the snug, cool, white winters of the northern interior? Now, aspiring homeowners must consider how climate change will affect their property over the long run and what costs they may incur as a result."As awareness of risk grows, the financial value of risky places drops," says climate futurist Alex Steffen. The rising costs of climate change will make some properties indefensible."[They] will be unofficially abandoned. That will then create more problems. Bonds for big projects, loans, mortgages, business investment, insurance, talented workers - all will grow more scarce then, the value will crash," Steffen predicts.Coining the term " brittleness bubble," Steffen wants to raise awareness. These brittle properties, prone to sudden, irreparable climate-fueled failure could create unrecoverable losses for their owners. The climate crisis poses dire choices, especially for those buying a home for the first time.Yet being forewarned is being forearmed. The sooner investors and home buyers alike bone up on the ground facts of climate risk, the better they can mitigate their property portfolio against the perils of extreme weather.FEW GOOD OPTIONSAs a global phenomenon, climate change impacts human populations everywhere. No region in America is truly immune from the fallout. When disaster strikes one part of the country, everyone suffers since they depend on the supply of goods and services nationwide.However, some regions are being hit sooner and harder than others. This information can help those buying land as an investment navigate the ever-changing climate map.Data from First Street and Moody's Analytics shows that Texas, Florida, New Jersey, and California, four of the country's largest and most populous states, are all likely to face more climate change risk sooner.With its vast coastline and wetland ecosystem, Florida is most vulnerable to rising sea temperatures and exacerbated tropical storms. The state has been a favorite destination for "snowbirds" from the North, especially among Canadian homebuyers. Florida accounts for almost half of all Canadian property purchases in the United States.According to the 30-year forecast by Moody's, climate change events will continue to affect communities up and down the East Coast and, at some point, will impact the livability of states such as Florida and the Carolinas. In the Southwest, e.g., Arizona, record heat and fires increase weather dangers and threaten reliable water supplies.The nation's interior is also feeling the climate stress, with intense heat and unprecedented rainfalls recorded in recent years. As the weather becomes more extreme, smaller, less exposed cities such as Boise, Idaho, are poised for an influx of newcomers seeking shelter from climate catastrophe.FLOODS AND FIRESOf all the natural disasters impacting home valuations in the U.S., wildfires and flooding are among the most damaging.As more study on climate change risk is undertaken, the potential effect on the American real estate market becomes apparent. For instance, the journal Nature Climate Change recently published a study that claims property prices in flood zones are overvalued by $121 to $237 billion."Increasing flood risk under climate change is creating a bubble that threatens the stability of the U.S. housing market," said lead author Dr. Jesse Gourevitch, a postdoctoral fellow at the Environmental Defense Fund."These risks are largely unaccounted for in property transactions, encouraging development in flood-prone areas.Accurately pricing the costs of flooding in home values can support adaptation to flood risk, but may leave many worse off."Unfactored environmental risks bode poorly for low-income households. The study found this demographic may lose up to 10% of their property's market value to the risk of significant flooding."For many people, their most valuable asset is their home. We need policy approaches that improve the transparency of climate risk in markets while providing increased support and protection for frontline communities," said co-author Dr. Carolyn Kousky, Associate Vice President for Economics and Policy at the Environmental Defense Fund.INSURE YOURSELFThe rising risks will make home ownership, already out of reach for most Americans, even more unaffordable. The increasing costs of covering the damage from natural disasters are unsustainable for homeowners and insurance companies.Huge claims from natural disasters in states such as California and Florida leave companies rethinking their risk and opting out of insuring susceptible regions.State-backed insurers cover some gaps in this landscape, but the premiums only sometimes cover the bills that homeowners are forced to pay. This situation worsens as climate change continues to upend the weather patterns and wreak havoc through extreme weather events.Slowing the impact of climate change is a global effort requiring deeper coordination between governments, corporations, citizens, and the world. Unfortunately, the average American can do little to change the broader trends However, by being informed of the dangers posed by climate catastrophe, homeowners can prepare for the worst and safeguard their families' future. Real estate remains many Americans' primary investment vehicle, so contingency planning is urgent. Without it, a local extreme weather disaster could bring untold financial ruin.

While economic implications are discussed, the core theme revolves around environmental factors and their long-term effects on property values and investment decisions.

title: Chesapeake dead zone smallest since 1985
author: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com
content:
Chesapeake dead zone smallest since 1985

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 434

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS - The dead zone in the Chesapeake Bay this year is the smallest since monitoring began in 1985, according to data released today by the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, Old Dominion University and the Virginia Institute of Marine Science.The dead zone appears annually in parts of the Bay and its tidal rivers during warmer months, creating areas where oxygen levels are so low that the water cannot support fish, blue crabs, oysters and other aquatic life. The dead zone is caused by algal blooms that are fueled by nitrogen and phosphorus pollution. These cloud the water and cause damage, mainly during the warmer months.The extent of each year's dead zone is dependent on several factors, including how much nitrogen and phosphorus pollution enters waterways. High precipitation can contribute to the dead zone because it leads to more polluted runoff washing into rivers and streams. Precipitation was below average for most of 2023."It has been a good year," Matt Pluta, Choptank Riverkeeper, said."A big influence has been a lack of rain run off. We have been in a three year drought."Chesapeake Bay Foundation Virginia Senior Scientist Joe Wood said, "While the smaller dead zone this year is a promising sign, we must remember the major challenges that lie ahead. The mere existence of a dead zone in the Bay is cause for alarm, and a sign that we must still dramatically reduce pollution flowing into the Bay."Pluta said there are three ways to reduce runoff from the land. These are riparian buffer zones, rain gardens and healthy wetlands. He pondered why they cannot have this good news all the time even in wet years.Getting specific about locating the pollution is integral to helping the Bay. The watershed includes more states that just Maryland.The water comes from New York, Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Delaware, Virginia and Washington, D.C."Most of the pollution-reduction progress so far has come from wastewater treatment plants," Wood said.States in the Bay watershed are still lagging far behind in reducing polluted runoff from agriculture as well as urban and suburban areas.In fact, urban and suburban pollution is increasing.Industry that uses pipes to flow unhealthy ingredients into the Chesapeake Bay, have gotten better kind of like cars have gotten better at reducing emissions, said Pluta."Wastewater treatment plants have gotten good with technology mandates out of their pipes," Pluta Said. "The bigger issue is nonpoint source pollution. Urban and agriculture pollution are increasing. We need to control fertilizer and figure out the input and output."A dead zone for aquatic life in the Chesapeake makes life impossible.

title: ShoreRivers' efforts prevent waste from entering local rivers

 As part of its efforts to protect and restore Eastern Shore waterways, ShoreRivers regularly works to identify and address all pollution sources, including nutrient pollution and harmful bacteria that can be introduced from recreational boaters' waste.Boat discharge - especially in marinas, high boat traffic areas and sheltered coves - can lead to pollution hotspots that pose serious health risks to humans and animals.ShoreRivers' pumpout boat, a convenient way to properly dispose of marine waste, recently wrapped another season on the Miles and Wye rivers, assisting local boaters committed to more river-friendly boating practices.The 2023 season saw 16,245 gallons of waste pumped out of 291 tanks, bringing the boat's total to 129,962 gallons kept out of our rivers since the program began in 2016."It's important that we all work together to make our waterways cleaner and safer for swimming, fishing and recreation," said Ben Ford, Miles-Wye riverkeeper."Using the free pumpout service is a great way for boaters to enjoy the beautiful Miles and Wye rivers and eastern Bay while doing their part to keep harmful nutrients and bacteria out of our rivers."The pumpout boat program operates with funding from the Maryland Department of Natural Resources and in partnership with Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum in St.Michaels.CBMM donates free dockage, storage and use of their land-based pumpout station to offload the waste from the boat. The sewage then goes directly to the St. Michaels wastewater treatment plant.

title: Maryland military facilities probing groundwater for 'forever chemicals'
author: Fatema Hosseini And Cecelia Shilling
content:
Maryland military facilities probing groundwater for 'forever chemicals'

 December 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Fatema Hosseini And Cecelia Shilling | Page: 10 | Section: News 
 
 794
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - Maryland military facilities are in the early stages of remedial investigations into "forever chemicals" that jeopardize drinking water supplies in groundwater after a September report by the Department of Defense identified hundreds of military sites across the country as at risk for such chemicals.The facilities include high-profile Joint Base Andrews, home to Air Force One, as well as Aberdeen Proving Ground, Fort Meade, Fort Detrick, Patuxent River Naval Air Station, and the Naval Research Laboratory-Chesapeake Bay Detachment in Calvert County.The potential contamination involves chemicals known as per-and poly-fluoroalkyl substances, or PFAS, which are a family of thousands of chemicals used in firefighting foams, heat-resistant products and many other items.The DOD has initiated remedial investigations at 275 Defense Department and National Guard sites for potential PFAS contamination, 245 of which, including 11 locations at 10 Maryland sites, are close to groundwater aquifers.Military bases often use firefighting foam in emergencies and training exercises.Foam that still contains PFAS can seep into soil, evaporate into the air or run off into waterways.PFAS run-off can also contaminate fish and harm people who eat the contaminated seafood.In 2021, the Maryland Department of the Environment found elevated concentrations of perfluorooctane sulfonic acid, or PFOS, a chemical in the PFAS family, in redbreast sunfish, yellow bullhead catfish, and largemouth bass in Piscataway Creek, a tributary of the Potomac River."Cleanup efforts are challenging and costly," said Dr. Arthur Daniel Jones III, a professor in Michigan State University's Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology and associate director of the MSU Center for PFAS Research.Such chemicals are difficult to remove from the environment after contamination and have very few natural processes to break them down, he said."Part of the challenge is that we certainly don't know very much about how the mixtures of PFAS are toxic," Jones said. "There are PFAS in foods, household products Almost every person on the planet is already contaminated by PFAS."Exposure or consumption of PFAS has other potential health risks, including fertility and immune system issues, developmental delays in children, increased cancer risks and hormone interference.The Aberdeen Proving Ground, an Army facility, states on its website that tests of its drinking water showed PFAS contaminants below the Environmental Protection Agency's advisory level of 70 parts per trillion."The Army is committed to ensuring quality drinking water is provided to its soldiers, family members, and civilians," the website says. "We continue to work with our state and federal partners and will ensure the community is kept updated on the status of our investigation."The Army site is in the planning stages of the remedial investigation, said Quentin Johnson, Aberdeen's director of public affairs.Two sites at the Naval Research Laboratory - Chesapeake Bay Detachment will be investigated by the Navy's Environmental Restoration Program for PFAS: a fire testing area and a former firehouse, according to a statement from the Naval Facilities Engineering Systems Command Atlantic.The fire testing area is already under investigation, and the firehouse will be studied in 2024 to "investigate the nature and extent of the PFAS and assess potential human health and ecological risks," the statement said.In 2018, the Navy's offbase water sampling in communities near the Chesapeake lab revealed no perfluorooctanoic acid, also called PFOA (another chemical in the PFAS family), or PFOS levels above the EPA limit of 70 parts per trillion."The Maryland Department of the Environment and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency provide regulatory oversight on the remediation of contamination, whether from PFAS or other contaminants, at military sites within the state," said Jay Apperson, a representative from the Maryland Department of the Environment.The state, EPA, Navy personnel and community members are actively involved in Restoration Advisory Boards, ensuring that families living near these facilities are informed about environmental issues and the steps being taken to address them.Rep. Jamie Raskin (D-Maryland), a member of the Congressional PFAS Task Force, emphasized the urgency of addressing PFAS contamination in a recent statement to Capital News Service."I recently joined my colleague Rep. Chrissy Houlahan (D) of Pennsylvania and many others in urging the Department of Defense to swiftly address its growing backlog of military sites contaminated with PFAS," Raskin said. "We also urged the DoD to adequately fund cleanup efforts at contaminated sites across the country, including the White Oak Naval Surface Warfare Center in my district and several other sites in our state."Jones said there aren't many "good" ways to get rid of PFAS."Even if you're drinking water that has very low levels of PFAS in the water, most of what you drink today is going to be with you for years," he said. " And there are very few natural processes that break down PFAS, so in essence, that's why they're called forever chemicals."

title: Strand Beach Project To Be Completed By Summer
author: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub.Com
content:
Strand Beach Project To Be Completed By Summer

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub.Com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 839
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD - With the first phase of construction complete, Oxford's Shoreline Improvement project along the Strand is expected to be complete by summer.Oxford Town Manager Cheryl Lewis said the first part of the project, to build the shoreline infrastructure, "touched on nearly all parts of the project."
This part, which was completed before Thanksgiving, included building a berm between the road and the water, placing hooks along the east and west areas of the Strand to help bring sand in and creating small islands in the water to reduce the waves that come onto the beach.
Lewis said these island structures were built using a combination of rock, wood chips and other components.
"(The structures) will sit over the winter months, which allows them to stabilize," Lewis said. "It allows them to go through weather, high tides, we just had a fairly substantial storm, that sort of stuff."
Oxford Police Chief Eric Kellner said the construction brought in extra traffic, particularly with all of the materials that were brought in using larger vehicles like dump trucks.
In order to allow space for workers to do their job and to prevent damage to civilian vehicles, Kellner said that the police department, with the help of Public Works, closed the beach parking lot.
There were some concerns from residents about the large construction vehicles speeding in the area, Kellner said.
"In response to that, we did a few things," he said.
"One was, obviously, we ran radar to enforce the speed limits. And we also deployed our speed sign to remind the vehicles of their speed in hopes of calming any potential speed issues."
Kellner said that in running radar and collecting data from the speed sign, the police department really sees an issue with speeding.
He said that large and loud vehicles driving down a small, narrow street can sometimes give off the perception that the driver is speeding.
"Our findings were that most of those larger vehicles were following the rules of the road," he said.
In the spring, the second part of the project is set to begin.
"We're estimating April," Lewis said. "I mean a lot of this is dependent on weather temperatures, asphalt, plants, a lot of factors."
Lewis said the second part will include adding plants to the new structures, adding signage, elevating land on the far east end and making improvements to the parking lot.
"The whole concept is to build a higher area all along the Strand to protect it from the stormwaters off the river," Lewis said.
The parking lot will be built with storm management areas underneath it so that storm water can enter it and be filtered before going back out. The parking lot will be paved with asphalt, with a cobble layer underneath it.
"There's a lot of - not just tidal water coming from the river - but also stormwater settling along that road in the parking lot," Lewis said.
"So bringing all of that elevation up to prevent that and allowing the water to go under the road and then back out into the creek will basically build resilience for that whole area."
Lewis said that as the sea level rises and the intensity of storms increase, infrastructure along the Strand becomes more vulnerable.
"Keep in mind, this is the only road we really have that runs along the water," she said. "This area here, it's worthy of this type of resilience protection because a breach in any place, especially up near the parking lot, would be so difficult to repair."
Lewis called it a project for the future.
"With the impacts of sea level rise and stormwater and tidal water management that we're seeing currently," she said, "it's necessary to look at how to build in these areas with natural infrastructure that will help to protect it in the future."
David Ghysels, who walks along the Strand every day, said he thinks the project will be nice when it is complete, particularly if it helps with flooding.
Lewis said she has received positive and negative comments from residents on the project.
"I think the closer you are to the project physically, the more involved you may have been over the last five years," she said. "So I think that one of the impacts will be people who don't go there regularly or aren't involved in the government regularly all of a sudden want to know what happened. So it's really just a continued educational process."
Mac Sommerlatte, who lives next to the beach, said he thinks the project should, when finished, positively impact the town by minimizing shoreline erosion and mitigating the impact of sea level rise. He said the project is a complicated one.
"I think one of the problems is that there are several projects here," he said.
"It's not just one. And people don't seem to have the complete information on all of them. And they may disagree with parts of it."

title: St. Michaels Mulls Proposed Flood Mitigation Improvements - Coastal Engineer Presents Findings Of Study Investigating Town'S Current, Future Flooding
author: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub. Com
content:
St. Michaels Mulls Proposed Flood Mitigation Improvements - Coastal Engineer Presents Findings Of Study Investigating Town'S Current, Future Flooding

 December 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub. Com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 672
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS - To mitigate increased flooding from sea level rise and stormwater runoff, the Commissioners of St. Michaels are considering investing in improvements to vulnerable shorelines and infrastructure.At the commissioners' Wednesday meeting, BayLand project manager and coastal engineer Anna Johnson presented the San Domingo Creek and West Side stormwater and harbor infrastructure assessment and flood mitigation study.
The study, performed by BayLand, an environmental engineering firm, focused on San Domingo Creek, which hugs the west side of town and opens into Broad Creek. It aimed to examine the town's current flooding sources and investigate what flooding will look like in the future.
The study came as another effort by the town government to address stormwater and coastal flooding. In 2021, the town created the Climate Change/Sea Level Rise Commission, which then worked with the Maryland Department of Natural Resources to obtain a grant for a study.
Much of Maryland, including St. Michaels, is experiencing both global and relative, or local, sea level rise, Johnson said. And according to historic water level measurements taken from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration tide station in Cambridge, sea levels in the lower Chesapeake Bay have risen just over a foot in 80 years.
After the BayLand team assessed existing conditions, current stormwater infrastructure and sea level rise data, further modeling was performed to identify the six most vulnerable areas along San Domingo Creek.
Grace Street was determined to be the highest priority area, Johnson said. The culvert bridging over the creek is undersized, she said, and its low elevation means that by 2050, standing water could occur daily on the road.
A county pump station is also in close proximity to the Grace Street culvert, and that area is also likely to experience daily flooding.
Back Creek Park was ranked as the second highest priority, primarily due to the condition of the bulkhead on its southern shoreline.
West Chestnut Street at Tilden Street, Canton Street at Glory Avenue, the St.
Michaels Nature Trail and Thompson Street were also identified as priority areas.
As for risk mitigation strategies, nature-based, passive solutions are preferred, Johnson said.
"Marshes rebound. A marsh may flood, but then six months later, it's back to being a marsh, whereas if a house floods, it all has to be replaced, or major construction has to be done to fix it," she said.
Nature-based solutions are also grant-friendly, Johnson said.
According to Roy Myers, chair of the town's Climate Change/Sea Level Rise Commission, grant requests are underway for expansion of the living shoreline at Back Creek Park and completion of an assessment and preliminary design for a tide gate under the nature trail bridge.
Once the BayLand team compiled a list of projects based on the needs for mitigation, an implementation plan was developed to determine a timeframe for addressing the needs.
Because of the failing bulkhead, the Back Creek Park living shoreline improvement project was designated as an immediate implementation project.
The project is estimated to cost $204,000.
Installing a tide gate where the St. Michaels Nature Trail bridge crosses San Domingo Creek is another project proposed for immediate implementation.
If installed, the tide gate could prevent coastal flooding in the surrounding area.
However, assessment, preliminary design and implementation for a tide gate come with a hefty price tag - just over $2.4 million.
Johnson recommended the town look into applying for a Federal Emergency Management Agency grant to offset the cost.
Johnson warned of the risk of waiting to implement improvements, pointing out that prices will increase over the next few years.
Improvements to the Grace Street culvert, pipe outfall improvements at the West Chestnut and Tilden Street retention area, stormwater infrastructure replacement along the St. Michaels Nature Trail and raising boating infrastructure at Back Creek Park were listed as shortterm implementation projects.
The total cost for those four projects is estimated at $1.07 million.
Long-term implementation projects, like monitoring flood risk for assessed areas and nourishing living shorelines along Back Creek Park, are designated as such to see if a stronger need develops over time.

title: Mallows Bay Sanctuary gears up for new year - New 'Terrain360' website among planned initiatives
author: Eleanor Pratt; Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Mallows Bay Sanctuary gears up for new year - New 'Terrain360' website among planned initiatives

 December 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Eleanor Pratt; Special to the Star Democrat | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 679

 Read News Document

 At their Dec 4, meeting, the Mallows Bay Sanctuary Advisory Council introduced a few updates for the new year.Located along an 18-mile stretch of the Potomac River in Charles County, Mallows Bay-Potomac River Marine Sanctuary protects a collection of almost 200 historic shipwrecks known as the "Ghost Fleet." The sanctuary advisory council is a community-based group consisting of representatives from various groups and agencies to provide advice on the operation and protection of Mallows Bay. Members include those representing education, maritime archaeology, tourism, the local community, indigenous tribes and more.
Council member and research specialist Megan Mccabe presented new efforts to make volunteering at Mallows Bay more accessible.
A newsletter is in the works to showcase volunteer opportunities and upcoming events associated with the sanctuary.
Mccabe noted that a volunteer interest sheet would also be launching soon, which will make it easier to collect the contact information, availability and interests of potential volunteers in one place.
For those interested in getting involved sooner, Mccabe told Southern Maryland News, "For right now, if you'd like to hear about our volunteering opportunities and upcoming events, follow us on social media or check our website.
But once we get that volunteer newsletter up and running, that will definitely be the best way to stay up to date." Currently, the team is aiming for the newsletter and interest form to be available in spring 2024.
In the meantime, people can follow Mallows Bay on Instagram at mallowsbay potomacrivernms, on YouTube@MallowsBay-Terrain360 and on Facebook at Mallows Bay-Potomac River National Marine Sanctuary.
Next spring will be a busy time for the sanctuary.
Research, Resource Protection and Permit Coordinator Tane Casserley introduced updates to the sanctuary's new Terrain360 website and resources that will be rolling out in the coming months.
According to its website, Terrain360 is a company that provides "street level imagery for thousands of hiking/biking trails, waterways, and ecologically sensitive locations." The new website will not only house immersive 360 hiking and water trail experiences, but will also feature informational videos featuring cultural and ecological information, interactive maps, safety tips and information, directions, current weather and water conditions.
In an effort to create an even more rounded experience, Mallows Bay has also been working with East Carolina PhD candidate Allyson Ropp on a Sketchfab site.
Using this 3D modeling platform, Ropp has created 16 models of the World War I era ships in Mallows Bay before they sank. Visitors now fully can grasp the history and size of the shipwrecks they see at the Sanctuary using this technology.
Those interested can access these models now on the Mallows Bay Sketchfab site.
When asked what prompted this new site, Casserley explained, "It was actually a congressional appropriation. We got funds from Congress focused on a virtual trail experience for Mallows Bay." With this funding, Terrain360 was contracted to build out the website for the Sanctuary.
Casserly noted that it can be difficult to get to Mallows Bay if you do not have a car or the economic means to visit. The goal of using Terrain360 was to create a product that could be shared with the public that removes economic barriers somewhat.
Those with mobility issues may also benefit, according to Casserly.
"We see this as almost an ADA type of experience where you could be anybody anywhere in the world and we still can show you the beauties of Mallows Bay and celebrate the history and culture," he said.
Currently the new website is being evaluated by the Sanctuary Advisory Council members, but the current plan is to give the public access by next spring.

title: Delmarva ecologist seeks old growth designation for local forests
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Delmarva ecologist seeks old growth designation for local forests

 January 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 921
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TUNIS MILLS — There is a centuries-old private land forest past Tunis Mills that has just been designated old growth. It is chock full of oak, beech and loblolly pines. Towering to the sky, these trees will outlive us all.The Old-Growth Forest Network is an Easton-based national nonprofit that focuses on preserving the oldest trees in each county. To them, the Tunis Mills forest is part of a border mission.
The founder of the network is a former professor of ecology, Joan Maloof. She peeled the bark off of a fallen tree Friday afternoon, while strolling the forest, and a lesson began.
Maloof pointed out lichen, mushrooms and mycelium that all thrive in the warm, decomposing darkness. Life is still very much in session at the bottom of the forest, she said.
"The mission of the Old-Growth Network is to make sure there is at least one forest in each county that is protected from logging and open to the public nationally," Maloof said. "In addition to that, we realized there were private owners that wanted to protect their forests but didn't necessarily want to make them open to the public. We wanted to recognize these people for their commitment to forgo the money from logging."
While there is some disagreement over the qualifications of an old-growth forest, generally, they are over 150 years old, having survived the rapid deforestation of the 19th and 20th centuries.
Maloof noted that the state with the most registered stands is Ohio. There are lots of farms there, and many of the owners preserved a forest plot.
There are four full-time and four part-time people working in the Old-Growth Network. They also have hundreds of volunteers called county coordinators, who walk through the oldest woods in each county.
Part of the culture of the network is that it brings forest-loving people together, Maloof said.
She met Easton local and former University of Maryland geology professor Peter Stifel, the owner of the Tunis Mills forest land, while giving a talk at Pickering Creek Audubon Center.
This meeting helped Stifel get a no-log conservation easement, which is very rare. There is an Old-Growth Forest Network sign placed in Stifel's woods. Maloof said he is proud of it.
In Steifel's intact woods, there are bald eagles and woodpeckers. There are foxes and big Delmarva fox squirrels. There are snakes and rabbits. There are moths and praying mantises. There is chlorophyll and light. Green orchids poke up from the floor of decomposing leaves.
Maloof said forging community connections is key to improving knowledge of the Old-Growth Forest Network's work.
"We would love to encourage other people to add their forests to the private Old-Growth Network. You could do it through us directly by signing a memorandum of agreement saying you always want to protect your forests," she said. "If you wanted to do it only legally, you would do it through a land trust like Eastern Shore Land Conservancy and request a no logging easement. There are tax benefits."
But beyond private forest land, Maloof said the organization is searching for publicly accessible lands that can be preserved from logging, a daunting task in Talbot County.
Unlike elsewhere in the United States, where there are larger tracts of government-owned land, Maryland forests are mostly on private property.
"There is no federal land in Talbot County, no national forests in Maryland, no (Bureau of Land Management) land, no national parks in Talbot County, very little state land," Maloof said. "Talbot County has the least state-owned land (in Maryland) — only 236 acres. Queen Anne's County has Wye (Island Natural Resources Management Area), which is true open to the public old-growth forest. Fourteen acres of Schoolhouse Woods got protected (there)."
"Somehow we need to get more forests in Talbot County set aside for the future," she said.
Maloof wrote a coffee table book with color photographs by Robert Llwellyn called "The Living Forest." From the birds in the canopy to the salamanders under bark, she has knowledge of the many facets that make a healthy old forest.
"I think I was born loving plants. I am an ecologist," she said. "As I went on with my training, I got to love bigger and bigger plants and then realized how important (it is) to have forested ecosystem there for all these other organisms to survive.
"What is to prevent all the woods from being cut again? And you find out, nothing in the whole county is protected. So that got me sharing information and writing books. My first book was 'Teaching the Trees.' I wrote my second book about visiting old-growth forests in the East. I realized they are so rare and so precious. Who is going to make sure they are not getting cut?"
Right next to Stifel's forest to the north, there is another forest that has just tied orange markers on the tree limbs. This usually is the mark that precedes logging.
Maloof said she is not opposed to all timber cutting. She just wants to preserve the oldest forests for future generations.
"So who suffers a cut? Future generations, the wildlife and the whole planet. We are not radicals. Can't we get at least one in each county that won't be cut? Where is the forest in Talbot County that can never be cut and is open to the public? We have not identified that yet," she said.
Although she doesn't look like the Lorax, she said her mission is the same as the beloved Dr. Seuss character.
"I speak for the trees. I am proud to be the Lorax," she said.
To learn more about the Old-Growth Forest Network, visit oldgrowthforest.net/.

title: Solar on Eastern Shore farmland raise concerns
author: STEVE KLINE
content:
Solar on Eastern Shore farmland raise concerns

 January 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEVE KLINE | Section: Columns 
 
 497
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For 33 years, Eastern Shore Land Conservancy has welcomed each new year with a strong spirit of mission, to work each day to conserve this special place we all hold dear. This year is no different, as we return to the office after a restful break among family and friends.We are proud of our accomplishments in 2023 and move ahead focused on the many opportunities to protect the Eastern Shore in 2024.
This particular new year dawns with an urgent issue on the horizon: the siting of commercial-scale solar on Eastern Shore farmland. As the General Assembly prepares for the 2024 legislative session, solar siting policy is a high priority for many, as the state seeks to meet aggressive renewable energy goals, while also continuing to make progress on land conservation.
Ground-mounted solar projects can run from a few dozen acres to several hundred, and across the Potomac in Virginia, some individual solar projects are slated to consume thousands of acres of farmland, forest and open space. Some look to Maryland's Eastern Shore and see similar possibilities, with acre after acre of generally flat agricultural land suited perfectly for solar energy generation.
But Eastern Shore Land Conservancy is encouraging state lawmakers to move ahead cautiously. The University of Maryland estimates that our state has lost about half of its agricultural land in the last 50 years, and the American Farmland Trust estimates that in the coming decades, Maryland will likely lose more than 100,000 additional acres.
While estimates vary widely, the legislated renewable energy goals that already exist seem likely to require between 10,000 and 20,000 acres of ground-mounted solar on agricultural fields. This doesn't include the acreage that could be affected by expanded transmission lines, substations, and other energy grid infrastructure.
Given the state landscape, one can imagine the majority of those acres — and perhaps the vast majority — could fall on Eastern Shore farmland, unless steps to ensure regional equity are taken. This is why, as legislators prepare to gather and address the business of the state, ESLC is advocating for a few priority policies related to solar siting.
First, commercial solar development should never be allowed on state-held or co-held conservation easements.
Second, solar siting should be prioritized for the built environment. We shouldn't be losing some of the most productive soil in the world while warehouses and parking lots go unutilized.
Third, for every acre taken out of production for solar development, solar companies should be paying a mitigation fee to conserve lands via permanent easement elsewhere.
Lastly, policies should be enacted to ensure Maryland's Eastern Shore counties aren't expected to bear a disproportionate burden of solar development in the coming years.
As we navigate the changing climate, the need to decarbonize our economy and transition to a renewable energy future is abundantly clear. But what is also abundantly clear is that climate change will make Eastern Shore food production even more globally important.
We should think long and hard before we place too much Eastern Shore farmland under a solar panel.

title: Gut-wrenching stench
author: Staff Writer
content:
Gut-wrenching stench

 January 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 394
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Gut-wrenching stenchThank you for shedding light on a practice that is ravaging the Eastern Shore in reporting Caroline County's steps to regulate "dissolved air flotation" (DAF) storage. I personally know this problem is not isolated to Caroline County. The Eastern Shore is becoming a dumping ground for these materials.
The neighboring farm has become an unregulated year-around storage facility. Under the guise of "ag use", DAF from seafood and chicken processing and municipal wastewater plant sludge from outside of Talbot County was dumped in heaping mounds, permitted to sit in the open, rotting from exposure, with unregulated runoff entering our waterway. The stench was gut wrenching.
This was not a 'farming' smell, which as farmers we clearly understand. This was an unbearable odor that you could not escape, even within the confines of your home. After nearly a year, some of the product was applied to the fields, resulting in the hatching of unbelievable swarms of midges (tiny flies), so thick we were inhaling them.
With a background in government and wastewater treatment, I am familiar with municipal operation regulations. What's happening here is wrong, and people are looking the other way. Heart wrenching testimony by my neighbors was given at a 2022 Talbot County Agricultural Resolution Board hearing, only to be told it was a "normal and acceptable" agricultural practice.
How can a practice that was not normal over the last 70 years, suddenly be considered acceptable. The air is thick with the smell of rotting waste as I type this letter and as my personal legal battle against this irresponsible practice continues.
No longer isolated incidents, the effects of improper industrial sludge storage are being experienced across the Shore. It should not be up to every individual county to regulate this storage or to individual citizens to fight corporate attorneys. What may be my problem today, could be your problem tomorrow.
The University of Maryland predicts more than half of Maryland's DAF supply is coming from out of state. When it's cheaper for producers to haul in their sludge from Delaware and Virginia (which require sludge spreading permits), it's clearly a state issue. The MDE and MDA need to regulate how this material is being stored and applied.
Please support the Chesapeake Bay Foundation and partners as they propose regulatory legislation to the Maryland General Assembly before the "industrial sludge industry" destroys our shore way of life.
CHERYL LEWIS
Trappe

title: Tree planting project fosters community in Cambridge
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Tree planting project fosters community in Cambridge

 January 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 650
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Over the past two years, Carlos Estin has noticed more children playing at the park off Academy Street in Cambridge.The reason for this increased activity at Meadows Park traces back to the trees.
Two years ago, Estin, a tree steward through ShoreRivers' Tree Stewards program, helped coordinate the planting of trees there. And although those trees today aren't but a handful of feet taller than Estin, they have acted as a catalyst to revitalizing the park.
"Fortunately, when we brought it to the attention of the city and the local councilman, which for this ward is Jameson (Harrington), he was very involved in helping," Estin said.
Harrington, along with the City of Cambridge, was supportive of the project. Volunteers came to help clean up the park. On Earth Day that year, in 2022, students from Cambridge-South Dorchester High School came to help plant new trees.
Harrington, who was there that day as well, said it was a "fantastic" day.
"I think they all really enjoyed getting out there and helping," he said about the students.
Over the last two years, the park has been cleaned up, bushes have been planted and more trees have been planted. In the spring, Estin said they will place flower pots at the entrance.
"As you see things progress, and everybody's seeing positive results," he said. "It encourages everybody to do more."
Estin said before this project, the park was "a little bit neglected" with graffiti, trash and play areas in "disarray."
"Not a lot of kids were using it," he said.
Now, more kids are going to the park, using the playground and basketball court, Estin said. And that's not all he has noticed.
"Around the perimeter of the park, there was a lot of trash, a lot of overgrowth," he said. "Slowly as (neighbors) saw the park improve, they started to clean up their properties."
Estin has been a tree steward for the last two and a half years. The program is a partnership between Alliance for the Chesapeake Bay, the Maryland Forest Service and local groups, including ShoreRivers on the Eastern Shore.
According to the Chesapeake Tree Canopy Network, the program was created to promote, enhance and increase tree canopy coverage.
As a tree steward, Estin coordinates different projects to get more trees planted in the area. Currently there are three projects in Cambridge: Meadows, Long Wharf and Great Marsh parks.
Estin said tree loss often occurs because new trees aren't planted when trees die. Planting trees to replace the old ones has multiple benefits, including improving soil conditions, lowering flooding risks, improving curb appeal and keeping the temperature cooler, he said.
Harrington said urban tree planting also helps with air pollution.
Meadows Park, specifically, he said, is at the top of a hill that slopes down toward Cambridge Creek, "So having more trees there helps absorb some of that runoff."
Estin said the City of Cambridge has committed to maintaining 200 new trees that will be planted in the city through a grant from ShoreRivers.
Although it hasn't been determined where each of these new trees will go, Estin said some will be planted at Long Wharf Park.
Along with the city, Estin and fellow Cambridge tree stewards have worked with other local groups, including the Dorchester Garden Club and the Sierra Club, to realize their goals.
"Now we're pooling our resources together and we're talking with each other," he said.
Similar to two years ago, Estin is planning to get students from Cambridge-South Dorchester High School to help plant trees again on Earth Day this year.
Harrington said planting trees is a great way to get the community involved.
"I'm always for more trees," he said.
Looking into the future, Estin hopes Cambridge will be a model for other cities and towns.
"I want Cambridge to be an example of how green spaces bring communities together and also improves the quality of our life," he said.
Those interested in volunteering and getting involved with the tree projects in Cambridge can email Estin at carlosestin@gmail.com.

title: New Year ushers in single-use plastic bag ban in Town of Centreville
author: Staff Writer
content:
New Year ushers in single-use plastic bag ban in Town of Centreville

 January 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 489
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The town of Centreville instituted a single-use plastic bag ban that went into effect on Jan. 1.Centreville joins Anne Arundel and Prince George's counties and the City of Frederick whose plastic bag bans also started the first of the year. According to the Maryland Retailer's Alliance, more than 70% of Marylanders now live in jurisdictions with carry out bag policies in place.
On July 20, 2023, Centreville Town Council passed the ordinance to ban single-use plastic carry out bags within Centreville town limits.
For Town Council President Ashley Kaiser while the ban addresses single-use plastic bags the spirit of the ordinance is to encourage the use of reusable bags and eliminate the reliance on plastic bags, many of which end up polluting our highways and waterways.
"Consumers have an opportunity to play a significant role in the implementation of this bill. I don't think that anyone who is shopping at a local business wants to burden a local business, but instead wants to support them. If a paper bag fee is going to be a problem for you, decline the bag," says Kaiser. "There are things people can do to change their behavior like making a point to remember to always carry reusable bags with them," she adds.
Following that philosophy, the Town of Centreville launched a "Bring Your Own Bag" campaign in October in coordination with Plastic Free QAC. The campaign included specially designed reusable bags with a rack card featuring information on the bag ban as well as tips for how to remember to bring your bag to your next shopping trip.
Bags were handed out at Centreville Day in October and at the Centreville Farmers' Market Heck with the Malls market day in December and were made available at Town Hall. A limited supply of Town reusable bags and vintage farmers' market reusable bags are currently available for consumers to pick up at Centreville Town Hall from 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Monday through Friday.
The Centreville single-use plastic bag ordinance stipulates that retail establishments with the exception of food service facilities "shall charge, collect and retain at least 10 cents for each paper carry out bag that it provides to a customer."
Exceptions to the ordinance includes, but are not limited to:
Nonprofit fraternal, civic, war veterans, religious, or charitable organizations and fire companies can still use plastic carry out bags.
Due to cross contamination concerns restaurants may not allow customers to use their own reusable bags. Restaurants will provide paper bags, but will not charge a paper bag fee.
The Centreville Market's Market and cottage food businesses can continue to use plastic.
Pharmacies and opticians will not charge a paper bag fee for prescription items.
Consumers and business owners who want to read the full text of the ordinance and frequently asked questions can visit townofcentreville.org and type "plastic bag ban" in the search window. For more information, please contact Carol D'Agostino, mainstreet@townofcentreville.org or 410-758-1180, ext. 17.

title: Rural Legacy Areas priority status approved for Caroline County
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Rural Legacy Areas priority status approved for Caroline County

 January 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 358
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline County Planning Commission approved a letter of support for prioritizing two rural legacy areas during its meeting Jan. 10 in Denton.Newly elected Commission Chairman Jeff Jackson, Vice-Chairman Hannah Cawley, Member Roger McKnight and Caroline County Commission President Travis Breeding voted unanimously to approve a letter prioritizing the Tuckahoe Rural Legacy Area/Agriculture Security Corridor in Caroline County. Commission Member Keith Bilbrough was absent.
The Maryland Department of Natural Resources' Rural Legacy Program "provides funding to preserve large, contiguous tracts of land and to enhance natural resource, agricultural, forestry and environmental protection while supporting a sustainable land base for natural resource based industries," according to DNR's website.
The grant program has conserved more than 120,800 acres of land on over 885 easements throughout the state. In fiscal year 2023, the program received over $7.1 million for conservation easements.
The Eastern Shore Land Conservancy manages the State's two RLAs in Caroline County.
According to Elizabeth Beales, Caroline County Department of Planning and Codes board administrator, the Eastern Shore Heartland RLA in the southern part of the county has been doing very well with over 20 interested landowners on the list of applicants. However, the Tuckahoe RLA in the northern part of Caroline currently has only five interested landowners.
The two RLAs are consistent with the county's comprehensive plan.
The state's RLA program's goals are:
To establish greenbelts of forests and farms around rural communities in order to preserve their cultural heritage and sense of place.To preserve critical habitat for native plant and wildlife species.To support natural resource economies such as farming, forestry, tourism and outdoor recreation.To protect riparian forests, wetlands and greenways to buffer the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries from pollution run-off.
"Over the past year, Rural Legacy has completed multiple projects in Caroline County," according to a Planning Commission staff report. "They also have a couple of ongoing projects from past funding."
The commissioners voted to submit the annual letter designating the Tuckahoe RLA as a priority "with an additional comment urging funding of both proposed RLAs if possible."
The Commission's meeting video and agenda, with a link to the 2024 Rural Legacy Area Prioritization packet and additional maps can be viewed at carolinecountymd.new.swagit.com/events/21730.

title: Van Hollen discusses blue catfish, H-2B visas with Eastern Shore Delegation
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Van Hollen discusses blue catfish, H-2B visas with Eastern Shore Delegation

 January 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 530
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — During an Eastern Shore Delegation meeting Friday, U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.) updated legislators on policy issues relating to the Eastern Shore that are "on the horizon."Van Hollen told Eastern Shore legislators that the issue of blue catfish, an invasive species in the Chesapeake Bay, has received a lot of attention in Congress.
"We know that we've got to deal with this invasive species," he said. "And probably the best way to deal with it is to eat our way out of it."
Along with U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin (D-Md.) and U.S. Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md. 1st), Van Hollen said that he has been working to make it so that blue catfish are inspected by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration — like other fish products in the country — rather than by the U.S Department of Agriculture.
Van Hollen said they are also trying to get additional funding for the prevention of more blue catfish in the Bay. He said a $750,000 grant for this was included in an appropriations bill that has been passed by the U.S. Senate but not yet passed by the U.S. House of Representatives.
Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) voiced his concerns with the the U.S. Department of Commerce's recent rejection of the state's request for a "fishery resource disaster" declaration. The request was made to address the damages caused by blue catfish and northern snakeheads in the Bay.
"These fish are growing so fast, and they're so aggressive that by the time everybody sees the financial disaster, it may be too late," Jacobs said.
Jacobs told Van Hollen that he hopes Van Hollen can "keep the pressure on" in the Senate.
Van Hollen thanked Jacobs, saying he agreed with him about the risks and dangers of the invasive species.
"We are in the aftermath of the administration's decision on the disaster assistance," Van Hollen said to Jacobs. "We are going back to them. We may reach out to you and your colleagues to get some additional information as we circle back."
At the meeting, Van Hollen also spoke about H-2B visas, which are important for seafood processing companies in the state.
Van Hollen said that for fiscal year 2024, the number of these visas, which are for temporary nonagricultural workers, has increased to more than 130,000.
"The challenge remains that it's a lottery system," he said. "And that it's impossible to run a business with certainty if your labor depends on a lottery system."
To address this, Van Hollen and Cardin have introduced a bill that would exempt seafood processors from the H-2B annual worker cap. Van Hollen said that although the bill has bipartisan support, it also has bipartisan opposition.
"And so we are trying to work that through the system and address concerns that have been raised on both sides of the aisle," he said.
Van Hollen also spoke about infrastructure and the 2018 Farm Bill at the meeting Friday. He said $18 million has been secured for different projects on the Eastern Shore, including various infrastructure projects.
On the Farm Bill, Van Hollen said the Senate has extended the bill through September of this year. He said the bill has important provisions for farmers such as crop protection.

title: Greensboro may get funds to move pump station, restore site of old wastewater treatment plant
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Greensboro may get funds to move pump station, restore site of old wastewater treatment plant

 January 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 655
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Though she wasn't on the agenda, Caroline County Assistant Director of Planning Leslie Grunden reported a positive development in protecting a stream flowing into the Choptank River north of Greensboro.Leading off the Jan. 23 meeting of the Caroline County Commission, Grunden said state funding was available to shore up "erosion at the town's pump station at the site of the old treatment plant located on a small tributary that feeds directly to the Choptank River," she said.
Greensboro Director of Public Works Brandon Cunningham alerted Commission President Travis Breeding about the "severe erosion" after recent significant rainfall.
"When he called me, and I went to look at it, I was like, 'Oh, yeah, this is a big deal,'" Breeding said.
Grunden said Cunningham told her he noticed "some erosion had been increasing" over the past several months.
"I think that was part of the old outfall for the old treatment plant, but the sides and the bottom are lined all the way down to the river — under the overpass into the river," Grunden said. "And over time, because it was probably put it in in the '60s, … it's broken up and starting to collapse and that's exacerbating the erosion."
A short-term solution in the form of an emergency grant was already in the works to add rocks and rebar and help hold the bank in place "while we went looking for funding for the long-term solution," to move the pump station farther uphill, Grunden said.
The aim is to remove the infrastructure and convert the stream location to a natural floodplain.
"Bringing the pump station up the hill (on town property) keeps it out of harm's way from erosion but also from eventual rising water from the Choptank," she said.
"This pump station takes flow from the town to the plant, so for that to be in jeopardy kind of keeps me up at night," Grunden said. The north county wastewater treatment plant is located on State Route 313, just north of Greensboro Volunteer Fire Company's community hall.
Grunden said her usual funding sources could support either the infrastructure or stream and floodplain restoration but not both. "So, I kind of put the word out saying we need money for both," she said.
However, the Maryland Department of the Environment gave her a call a week or two ago, "essentially (saying), 'We think we found the money to do both,' which is … almost a miracle," Grunden said.
MDE had "actually never done this grant. It's a grant they get from EPA that they've never had interest in," she said. "They would actually be the recipient, and then the county would be the sub-recipient. (MDE) would actually have to do all the reporting up to EPA, and I would provide them status reports and invoices."
She is currently putting together a project budget. Preliminary estimates put the pump station relocation at $1.3 million, and Grunden's guess is removing the structures would be half a million, with stream and floodplain restoration another half a million.
"And then I always have a contingency plan because nothing ever goes the way you want," she said. "So, we're at about $2.4 million. (The Department of Natural Resources) has reached out to say they'd be interested in helping with the stream and floodplain component, which would give us more money if we need more to deal with on the pump station side."
Grunden said she was "pretty confident" that enough funding would be available for the two-phase project, "where the first phase would be moving the pump station and demo-ing the old buildings, and the second phase would be going in and doing the stream and the floodplain restoration."
Although the project is "not a sure thing," she said MDE reaching out to her was "a really good sign that they're serious about providing the funding."
"I can't think of a better move that we can make there environmentally other than to get that stuff out of the floodplain," Breeding said.

title: Tri-Gas & Oil Co. to pay $600K penalty for groundwater pollution
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Tri-Gas & Oil Co. to pay $600K penalty for groundwater pollution

 January 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Environment 
 
 573
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE — A newly settled lawsuit against Tri-Gas & Oil includes a $600,000 penalty for pollution to groundwater and a nearby creek, the Maryland Department of the Environment and the Maryland Attorney General announced Wednesday.The settlement resolves a lawsuit brought against the Federalsburg-based company last year by the Attorney General's Office on behalf of the Maryland Department of the Environment.
Though the company has long been known as Tri-Gas & Oil, its acquisition of Pep-Up Inc. in 2022 meant that as of 2023, it now operates all of its energy brands under the PepUp name, with acknowledgment of it being a Tri-Gas Family Company.
The terms of the settlement, outlined in a consent decree finalized in Caroline County Circuit Court on Tuesday, require the company to continue work to clean up the fuel that leaked from storage tanks at its Federalsburg location several years ago.
"The significant financial penalty and the required cleanup actions contained in this settlement reflect how serious it is to ignore environmental regulations and pollute our waterways," said Maryland Department of the Environment Secretary Serena McIlwain.
"Overburdened and underserved communities disproportionately bear the burden of environmental hazards," she added in a Wednesday news release. "We will hold those entities accountable who are found to be non-compliant with the applicable environmental laws and regulations."
The lawsuit describes a series of events, beginning with the company's 2018 application to renew its oil operations permit for the facility, according to a news release from the Office of the Attorney General.
As part of that process, the state environmental department inspected the facility and found numerous problems, including a lack of documentation of supposed repairs to two aboveground storage tanks and vegetation and cracks in a containment dike.
The facility's permit was issued in March 2019, but it included more than 20 special conditions requiring the facility to address the concerns identified in the prior inspection.
In July 2019, the Tri-Gas & Oil facility observed an oil stain adjacent to a storage tank. Its contractors removed the oil from the tank in the following months.
The company alleged that it did not realize that the stain was associated with a larger release until March 2020, following a report of an oily sheen moving through the Faulkner Branch originating from the facility.
The Maryland Department of the Environment has overseen subsequent investigations and cleanup at the property.
The company discontinued its use of the property for fuel storage a few months later.
An investigation found oil in the subsurface between the facility's storage tanks and the nearby stream. And in July 2021, the company and its environmental consultant discovered evidence of previously unknown oil contamination.
Tri-Gas & Oil estimates that it lost roughly 26,000 gallons of fuel, according to the news release.
Under the settlement, the company must continue to comply with the provisions of an interim cleanup plan from 2022 to return contaminated groundwater at the site to acceptable conditions.
The fuel leak occurred in a community that is overburdened and underserved, according to the department's environmental justice screening tool.
Communities like Federalsburg "bear a greater burden of environmental hazards compared to other communities," the release said.
"Marylanders have an expectation that the water they use will be safe no matter where they live," Attorney General Anthony Brown said in the news release.
"Businesses must follow regulations designed to protect our people and the environment, and I will hold every company doing business in Maryland accountable for its impact on our communities and the people who live here," he added.

title: Master plan, grant application approved for St. Michaels park
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Master plan, grant application approved for St. Michaels park

 January 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Environment 
 
 676
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Months of work came to a happy conclusion Wednesday evening with the Commissioners of St. Michaels' unanimous approval of a final master plan for San Domingo Creek Park and a $1.7 million open space grant application.The final master plan for the park, previously referred to as the Boundary Lane Waterfront Park, includes nature trails, expanded wetlands, a living shoreline, a fishing pier, a comfort station and associated parking.
A long-wanted dog park was initially included in draft park plans, but following extensive debate, it was ultimately removed to extend the area of the park's pollinator meadow, said Scott Scarfone, an associate principal at Mahan Rykiel Associates who worked on the park design.
Leashed dogs will still be allowed to walk through the new park.
Plans for a defined dog park are still in the works, according to Town Manager Rob Straebel. A 2.4-acre parcel next to Bradley Park was identified as a likely location, and the town is working on a purchase or lease agreement for the site.
A viewing mound, a 10-foot hill with an accessible path to give visitors an elevated view of the creek, was also eliminated from the new park's final master plan.
The viewing mound will be replaced by a circular loblolly pine grove, with views of the creek still visible. The expansive pollinator meadow will extend into the center of that space.
Scarfone called the town's decision to buy the property and develop it into a park "wise" and "visionary."
"I can tell you that generations of people who visit this park are going to enjoy it in the future, so congratulations to the town for acquiring an amazing piece of property," he said. "I think it was a very smart decision."
The town purchased the 7.6-acre property on Boundary Lane, which is adjacent to San Domingo Creek, for $2.9 million last year. Formerly owned by nonprofit Environmental Concern, the property also includes an administrative building, which is slated for use as the town's new office.
Because most of the park is intended as open space, opportunities to receive state grant funding through Program Open Space are available to help offset the purchase price.
Nearly six acres of the property were designated by Talbot County as potential open space.
Appraisals of the open space acreage came in at $1.6 million and $1.8 million, according to Town Planner Steve Ball, leading to town staff seeking approval to apply for a $1.7 million grant for reimbursement of acquisition costs.
The request was approved unanimously. The grant application, due in the next few weeks, was set to be submitted Thursday.
Though master plan approval and the submittal of the grant application mark important steps forward in bringing San Domingo Creek Park to reality, more regulatory work remains to be done.
While the town owns the property, and over half of it is located within town limits, nearly three acres remain under the county's zoning jurisdiction.
The town is seeking to annex the remainder of the property into its limits, including Boundary Lane itself, which includes the property in front of the park's entrance. St. Michaels Police Chief Jeff Oswald also requested to include the road in the annexation, Ball said.
Neighboring resident Langley Shook and Commissioner Tad DuPont raised concerns about bringing Boundary Lane into the annexation.
"I'm leery about taking on the expense of maintaining a road when we are really pinched on every single front," DuPont said.
If the annexation is approved, the new portion will also need a town zoning designation.
St. Michaels doesn't have designated zoning for parks, and the part of the park property already within the town limits is zoned residential, Ball said.
The remaining area would need to be zoned as residential, and that's in part due to many state grants requiring the property to be in a priority funding area, an urban area where the state will invest money for infrastructure, Ball said.
The annexation request will be heard by the St. Michaels Planning Commission next month.
The town's board of zoning appeals will also consider a special exception to use the existing offices on the property as town administrative offices in February.
