title: Harris: No offshore wind turbines
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Harris: No offshore wind turbines

 January 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 1914
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OCEAN CITY — Outside the doors of the Roland E. Powell Convention Center in Ocean City, two masked protestors stood quietly with posters criticizing U.S. Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.).Just inside, two volunteers handed out postcards stating, "Stop Offshore Wind" and "Join Facebook group 'Protect Ocean City.'"
In the auditorium, Worcester County residents slowly filed in. At least 300 people came out in below freezing temperatures Saturday afternoon, Jan. 20, for a congressional hearing held on their sandy turf.
Warning of dire consequences if offshore wind industrialization is allowed off Maryland's Atlantic coast, three legislators called on experts to bolster their call to halt construction of wind turbines off the mid-Atlantic coast. Harris was joined by New Jersey Congressmen Jeff Van Drew (R) and Chris Smith (R).
EXPERTS WARN OF DANGERS
Six experts testified and answered questions from the legislators. whose districts "are directly impacted" by "offshore wind industrialization," according to news releases issued by the congressmen's offices.
The panel of experts focused on the negative impacts of offshore wind energy to the fishing industry, environment and energy policy, national security, tourism, the local economy — including the Mid-Shore counties — and even the medical value of horseshoe crabs.
While the general economic impact of offshore wind development was explored, Harris told The Star Democrat following the hearing that allowing wind turbines off the coast of Ocean City to generate power would increase energy costs for all Eastern Shore residents.
Harris doubted that "the average person would be willing to pay the extra taxes and extra rates in order to develop a source of energy that … is roughly four times as expensive as what your current source of energy is," he said. "That impacts everyone whether or not you live on the Shore."
Harris lives in Dorchester County.
"Most people I know who open their electric bills this year say, 'Wow, I can't believe it's that much higher than it was last year," Harris said. "It will get even higher if we insist on producing very high-cost sources of energy."
"We might be willing to bear the costs, but are we ready to industrialize the ocean floor?" he said.
One of those costs is the increase in deaths of whales and dolphins, which the legislators attributed to the construction of wind turbines. Smith called them the "canaries in the coalmine" and blamed the Biden administration and New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy for their "(refusal) to even listen to the numerous warnings from local leaders, mayors and state senators" and "continuing with false promises."
Smith said the construction of 3,400 offshore wind turbines across 2.4 million acres was being "fast-tracked."
Lisa Linowes is executive director of WindAction Group, which studies and provides information on "the potential harmful impacts of large-scale wind energy facilities on wildlife and the natural environment."
Although Linowes has been concerned about the dangers posed to marine life, She expressed concerns about maritime safety, and the Biden Administration's relaxing of regulations designed to protect baleen, right and humpback whales, sentiments echoed by others on the panel.
For instance, radar interference, physical obstacles and turbulence caused by wind turbines pose dangers to aircraft, according to the Coast Guard and Air Force, she said, and no "comprehensive assessment" has been conducted.
Other panelists agreed with Linowes' assessment of the dangers, and Harris said radar interference constituted a national security concern.
Meghan Lapp of Seafreeze, a Rhode Island commercial fishing company, said offshore wind turbines would interfere with "all classes of U.S. radar."
In December 2023, a new series of leases were proposed farther off the Maryland coast, Harris said, but were "withdrawn from consideration by the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management because of protests from the Department of Defense and from NASA, who said that those leasing areas would adversely affect our ability to maintain national security and, in the case of NASA, … interfere with the Wallops Flight Center."
In addition to maritime safety concerns, Linowes said the "discrepancy between federal treatment of ocean industries is staggering," citing federal agencies' downplaying correlations between "last year's surge of large baleen whale deaths on the East Coast coinciding with unprecedented offshore wind seismic surveys."
"Had the whale deaths coincided with oil and gas surveys instead of offshore wind surveys, the pause and investigation requested by the congressmen would have been standard procedure," she said.
Robert Rand of Rand Acoustics LLC in Brunswick, Maine, said underwater testing and sonar surveys by offshore wind development was damaging the hearing of marine mammals, which is vital to their survival.
"I know how to measure sound," Rand said. "More than that, I care about whales."
His independent surveys of whale populations off the coasts of Hawaii and Cape Cod revealed stark contrasts in their communication patterns, suggesting that, even with NOAA's noise mitigation requirements, whales were adversely affected by high decibel sounds associated with offshore wind development, he said.
Panelist Travis Fisher is the director of energy and environmental policy studies at the Cato Institute. With wind turbine power, he said Marylanders would end up paying more for wind, in addition to a backup source of power, hitting lower income residents harder.
Observing the results of California and Germany's green energy policies has been instructive, he said.
"Both places have chosen to embrace intermittent energy at the expense of reliable energy," he said. "Germany's energy transition has caused its residents to pay three times more for electricity than we pay in the United States. California has higher electricity prices than any other state in the lower 48."
"It's not too late to recognize the folly of a forced energy transition," Fisher said. "There is no justification for an off-shore wind mandate."
Also testifying was Bonnie Brady of the Long Island Commercial Fishing Association.
LOCAL LEADERS UNIFY
Although Danish company Ørsted canceled two off-shore wind projects in fall 2023, it was continuing to develop Skipjack Wind 20 miles off the Maryland coast.
However, on Jan. 25, Ørsted announced it had "withdrawn from the Maryland Public Service Commission orders approving the Skipjack 1 and 2 projects" following "consultation with the State of Maryland" and "an extensive review of the orders." It cited "challenging market conditions, including inflation, high interest rates and supply chain constraints" as reasons for the decision.
The company "intends to continue advancing development and permitting for the combined project, including submission of its updated Construction and Operations Plan to the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management," according to a press release.
Harris said another company besides Ørsted holds a Maryland offshore lease, a "cleverly named U.S. Wind, which is a wholly owned subsidiary of an Italian company."
The project doesn't sit well with Worcester County and Ocean City's leaders, four of whom spoke during the hearing.
"The Bureau of Ocean Energy Management's own environmental impact statement study further convinced me that the potential negative impacts of offshore wind industrialization off Maryland's Coast outweighs the many promised benefits by European-based offshore wind developers," said state Sen. Mary Beth Carozza (R-Somerset, Wicomico, Worcester).
"With my prior work experience at the Pentagon and the U.S. Senate Homeland Security Committee, I especially am sensitive to the security and safety concerns raised by the Department of Defense, including the detrimental effect of wind turbines on existing radar systems by false alarms and missed detection of real targets," Carozza said.
Mainly concerned with tourism, they warned of potential hazards caused by strong storms, and even the health of the horseshoe crab population.
Del. Wayne Hartman (R-Wicomico, Worcester) said the "vast majority" of constituents who had contacted him were "adamantly opposed to the implementation of offshore wind projects."
"According to a study from North Carolina State University, 55% of vacation renters would not return to the vacation destination if turbines were visible," he said. "This is very concerning for the future of economic development in Ocean City as tourism accounts for the largest percentage of the local economy."
"We have a horseshoe crab harvest here critical for the safety of injectable medications, yet there were plans to put turbines right in horseshoe sanctuary areas," Pat Shrawder of said. She is district representative for state Sen. Mary Beth Carozza (R-Somerset, Wicomico, Worcester).
"My understanding is that the horseshoe crab industry is centered in the mid-Atlantic here," Harris said. "As a physician I'll tell you, a lot of people don't know when you get an intravenous medication of any kind — something that comes out of a sterile intravenous vial — that batch has been tested against a derivative of horseshoe crabs to make sure it doesn't have bacterial endotoxin — something that would kill you."
Electromagnetic fields and underwater cables would also interfere with horseshoe crabs' migration paths.
The effect of strong storms on wind turbines has not been adequately studied, Harris said.
"Our residents are fearful of the effect of hurricane force winds on wind turbulence," Schrawder said. "Ocean City is subject to strong northeasters or hurricanes. Even the EIS (Enterprise Infrastructure Solutions of the U.S. General Services Administration) report states that a hurricane could result in the loss of a blade and or turbine collapse. We worry about a football field-sized blade hurtling (sic) through the air."
Ocean City Mayor Rick Meehan, a Republican who has served as mayor since 2006, galvanized the mostly local audience. He said he represented 26,000 property owners, residents and a million visitors who stand in "total opposition to the proposed U.S. Wind project."
"The discussion on wind turbines off the coast of Ocean City goes back as far as 2010," Meehan said. "Yet this is the first time a committee from the federal government has actually held a hearing here in Ocean City."
Meehan said the wind turbines would mar the resort's vista. "The sunrise over the Atlantic would look like a backdrop from Star Wars," he said.
"The first time I saw the renderings of what U.S. Wind was proposing — and at the time, those were four megawatt or possibly six megawatt turbines approximately 450 feet tall — I had stated our opposition to the size and locations of those turbines at that time seven years ago. Our concerns fell on deaf ears," Meehan said. "Today, those same turbines are now 18 megawatt turbines at … maybe 1,065 feet in height, and they're proposing the same locations. Our concerns continue to fall on deaf ears."
"What has also been ignored is the revenue that Ocean City sends: Millions of dollars to both the state and the federal government each year," Meehan said. "We only have one industry in Ocean City, and that's tourism. Why would the state or the federal government want to unnecessarily jeopardize our future?"
"What I can assure you is that the Town of Ocean City will not back down from our opposition to these projects and to our future here in Ocean City," Meehan said as the audience applauded and cheered.
FIGHT CONTINUES
U.S. Wind, the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration were invited to attend the hearing. U.S. Wind did not respond and the federal agencies "declined to attend," Harris said.
Smith said "calls for an honest review of offshore wind industrialization has left unaddressed and unanswered so many questions; so much so, that in March of last year, Andy Harris, Jeff Van Drew and I offered an amendment that passed 244 to 189 to have the watchdog of Congress, the Government Accountability Office, investigate the impacts of wind turbines, and their audit will be coming out very soon."
The bottom line for Harris: "I believe it's time to reconsider whether offshore wind is the right approach for Maryland."
Van Drew was more pointed. "We have a war to win," he said. "Do not succumb, do not be weak, and we will prevail."
To watch the entire hearing, go to www.youtube.com/watch?v=1ThWS1FT1Qo

While economic and local government aspects are mentioned, the primary emphasis is on environmental risks and ecological debates.

title: 'A complicated matter with a lengthy history:' Lakeside resolutions remain pending
author: Natalie Jones
content:
'A complicated matter with a lengthy history:' Lakeside resolutions remain pending

 February 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Environment 
 
 2194
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Although construction for the first set of homes in the Lakeside at Trappe development is well under way — and in some places, complete — project clarifications and efforts to implement county oversight remain to be done.The long-proposed and often contentious development has been the subject of numerous legislative measures since receiving approvals on its plans for wastewater treatment in the last few years.
And now, even with homes already built within Lakeside's first phase, county and state officials are still attempting to clarify some aspects of the development while trying to supervise its impacts on Talbot County as a whole.
Three pieces of county legislation, each with at least one amendment, remain pending approval from the Talbot County Council.
Two are waiting for a finding of consistency from the county's Planning Commission and a recommendation from the county's Public Works Advisory Board, and are set to be discussed at a joint meeting of both bodies on Wednesday, Feb. 7, at 11 a.m.
Under state law, the Planning Commission is required to review and certify any amendment to the county's comprehensive water and sewer plan before the Talbot County Council can adopt the measure.
But if the Planning Commission can't find the legislation consistent, the council will further delay an already lengthy process of replying to requests from the Maryland Department of the Environment for specific information relating to the development.
If adopted, the council will submit the amendments to MDE for final review and approval, fulfilling the request to address the needed information and correct mapping errors in the original legislation approving Lakeside's wastewater treatment plant.
In January, Talbot County Council President Chuck Callahan acknowledged the difficulty in following the pending legislation relating to Lakeside, calling it "a complicated matter with a lengthy history."
The council is set to hold public hearings on all three pieces of legislation at its Tuesday, Feb. 13, meeting, giving county residents an opportunity to weigh in on the unresolved measures.
WHAT IS LAKESIDE?First proposed over 20 years ago, the planned 2,501-unit Lakeside development spans more than 850 acres off of U.S. Route 50.
The property was annexed into the Town of Trappe in 2003 and approved as a planned unit development in 2006.
Owned by Trappe East Business Holdings Trust, the development is slated to have a mix of housing types, including single-family homes, townhouses and apartments, and a commercial and retail space.
The project's developer, Rocks Engineering, based in northern Virginia, is no stranger to building on the Eastern Shore. The company developed the Easton Club, a 342-unit neighborhood of single-family homes and townhouses.
Easton-based Rauch Inc. also is working on the development.
Passing by the site's entrance on Route 50, it's clear that construction is underway, and some homes are already lived in.
According to Erin Braband, Trappe's town clerk, 114 building permits have been issued and 109 connections have been made to the town's existing wastewater treatment plant.
Trappe's existing plant has the capacity to take on wastewater from the development's first 120 homes.
That flow will eventually be diverted to a new wastewater treatment plant serving the development, a plan approved in county legislation and via an MDE wastewater discharge permit.
RESOLUTION 281Introduced in December 2019, Resolution 281 amended the county's comprehensive plan to reclassify certain portions of the development's property for immediate priority for water and sewer service.
It included capital improvements — upgrading Trappe's existing wastewater treatment plant from biological nutrient removal treatment to enhanced nutrient removal treatment to minimize nutrient discharge to the Chesapeake Bay, along with building a new wastewater treatment plant to serve Lakeside.
The new plant, set to be built with enriched nutrient removal technology, would use a spray irrigation system to discharge treated wastewater onto nearby fields.
Residents were uneasy about the then-proposed legislation, which was brought forward based on a draft permit from MDE. Concerns were voiced with water quality, health and environmental impacts and the spray irrigation system.
But in June 2020, the Talbot County Planning Commission found the measure to be consistent with the comprehensive plan in a 3-2 vote. And in August 2020, the Talbot County Council voted 4-1 to approve the legislation with an amendment, which split the property into two sections for differences in water and sewer classifications.
Current Council Vice President Pete Lesher was the lone holdout in approving the resolution, citing concerns with connecting the first 120 homes in the development to the town's existing plant, which has been in operation since 2002, before it received an upgrade.
MDE approved the resolution that November.
But in a letter sent that month, the agency told the county that Resolution 281 did not provide the number of equivalent dwelling units for the different phases of the development — information needed for further assessment.
No deadline was initially specified for providing the agency with that information, though a push came later.
In December 2020, MDE issued a final wastewater discharge permit for Lakeside's new wastewater treatment plant, approving a flow of 540,000 gallons per day — the number the developer requested in its application.
PUBLIC OUTCRYOpposition to the fully approved wastewater discharge permit came swiftly and strongly.
The Chesapeake Bay Foundation and ShoreRivers filed separate petitions for judicial review of the permit, citing concerns with spray irrigation of treated wastewater and specifics of a nutrient management plan not being made available during the permit's public comment period in 2020.
A form of relief came in the ShoreRivers case in late April 2021 when a Talbot County judge ruled to remand the permit to MDE to hold another public comment period.
But the outcry didn't stop there. In May 2021, Easton resident Dan Watson began pushing a petition calling for the council to rescind Resolution 281 without prejudice, meaning that Lakeside's developer could come back and ask for water and sewer approval again.
Resolution 308, the formal legislation proposing the rescission of immediate priority water and sewer approval for Lakeside, was introduced by Lesher in August 2021.
MDE's public hearing on the draft discharge permit in October 2021 drew more than 100 upset residents to Easton to speak on the development's environmental, pollution and water quality issues.
The issue was made more complex when the Talbot County Planning Commission rescinded its approval of the amendment to Resolution 281 in November 2021.
While the legislation to rescind Resolution 281 remained on the table, attempts were made to come to a compromise by proposing ways to lighten the burden of connecting homes to Trappe's existing wastewater treatment plant, ensure that the treated wastewater would meet enhanced nutrient removal standards and give the developer more flexibility in ways to treat the effluent.
But ultimately, Lesher pulled his support from Resolution 308 to void the previous legislation, and efforts to compromise failed to garner enough support from the council.
Frustrated by perceived inaction, county residents, led by Watson, the original petitioner behind legislation rescinding Resolution 281, filed a lawsuit against the Maryland Department of the Environment in May 2022.
The lawsuit asked the court to compel the agency to stand behind the Planning Commission's decision of inconsistency and revoke the permit and suspend any work with a sewerage system inconsistent with the county's comprehensive plan.
The lawsuit, filed in Talbot County Circuit Court, was dismissed last June.
In late October 2022, MDE made a final determination to issue a revised discharge permit for Lakeside, approving a significantly smaller wastewater treatment plant.
The revised permit allows for an average flow of 100,000 gallons per day — a sharp decrease from the 540,000 gallons per day initially requested by the developer.
The limited flow will allow for only 400 residential units to be built, only a small portion of Lakeside's planned development. Any future expansion of the facility will require a major permit modification.
The Chesapeake Bay Foundation's 2021 challenge to the permit was revived after the newly revised permit was issued, but in August 2023, a Talbot County judge upheld the permit's issuance. An appeal of that decision is pending in a higher court.
In spite of the permit's final approval, members of the Talbot Integrity Project repeatedly requested the council introduce legislation "resetting" the development by recognizing the county planning commission's authority to determine consistency of amendments to the comprehensive plan.
Lesher, who had been asked to introduce the legislation, declined to do so in January 2023.
The legislation would not have had majority support from the council, he said, and because the Planning Commission's reversal of its consistency finding on Resolution 281 came after the measure was approved by the council, there would be no effect on what had already occurred.
However, Lesher emphasized the limitations of the final permit dealing a significant setback to Lakeside — a significant win for those concerned about the project's scale and environmental impacts.
OVERSIGHT EFFORTSWith efforts to "reset" Lakeside shut down, attention turned to working on ensuring county oversight to what was already approved.
Last February, Talbot County Council member Lynn Mielke introduced legislation, known as Resolution 338, amending the county's comprehensive plan to be consistent with the provisions of Lakeside's wastewater discharge permit.
Under the amendment, any expansion of the new wastewater treatment plant would also require a new change to the county's comprehensive plan.
Attorneys for Trappe and the developer opposed the requirement for the developer to come back before the county for future expansion.
Lesher and Mielke introduced an amendment to Resolution 338 in November, which adds language requiring a certification from the Talbot County Planning Commission of an expansion amendment's consistency with the comprehensive plan.
Amended Resolution 338 was found consistent with the county's comprehensive plan in December, with commission Chairman Chip Councell saying it would be the county's only chance for review of potential expansion.
But even though construction is underway, thanks to Resolution 281 and the issuance of the revised discharge permit, the Maryland Department of the Environment is still seeking clarification on some specifics of the development.
In a series of letters sent last year, the agency reemphasized the need for the county to provide the number of equivalent dwelling units in each phase of Lakeside to assess the adequacy of the water and sewer system to accommodate and serve the development.
Two of the exhibits to Resolution 281 — maps displaying updates to Trappe's proposed water and sewer service areas — were in need of correction, MDE said. The maps showed additional properties not part of the Lakeside development to have incorrect water and sewer classifications.
The mapping issues were requested to be addressed in the form of a comprehensive plan amendment.
The county debated over the best way to address MDE's requests last summer, eventually settling on tackling them via comprehensive plan amendments, known as Resolution 347 and Resolution 348.
The original version of Resolution 347 provides the number of equivalent dwelling units — 2,874 in total across all six phases, with just over 1,200 designated for immediate water and sewer service.
It specified that the phases only represent land uses, not timing or sequence of development, and any changes in phasing or allocation will need to be included in amendments reclassifying any phase's water and sewer service.
The resolution's first amendment, introduced last November, struck the language on the phases only representing land use, clarifying that all phases not designated as immediate priority for water and sewer service will need to be reclassified before receiving service from Trappe.
A second amendment, introduced Jan. 23, adds the provisions of Resolution 338 into the legislation.
Lesher described the inclusion of that language as an alternative to help the Planning Commission find Resolution 347 consistent with the comprehensive plan. Without that finding of consistency, the resolution can't be approved by the council, further delaying fulfillment of MDE's requests.
Resolution 348, introduced last September, was described by County Attorney Patrick Thomas as simple clarification and confirmation of the water and sewer classifications of certain parcels unrelated to Lakeside, which were incorrectly shown in two exhibits to Resolution 281.
A resolution introduced Jan. 16 by all five council members shed light on more than just the unrelated parcels — it clarified the changes in water and sewer service status for some of Lakeside's parcels that weren't clearly specified in Resolution 281.
More specifically, the amendment clarified that prior to the council adopting Resolution 281, the comprehensive plan depicted a portion of Lakeside's property as immediate priority for water service, with the remainder designated as unprogrammed.
However, Resolution 281 actually stated that some parcels within that portion were being redesignated from their "current" classification of W-2 to W-1, or immediate priority for water service.
And prior to Resolution 281's approval, maps of sewer service areas in Trappe showed Lakeside's parcels as unprogrammed, the amendment said.
But Resolution 281 remapped a portion of Lakeside's parcels from their "current" classification of S-2 to immediate priority status for sewer service.
Intended to resolve confusion and uncertainty from the state environmental agency surrounding the classifications, the amendment confirms Resolution 281 amended certain parcels on the town's water and sewer service maps from unprogrammed status to W-2 and S-2 status.
With review of Resolution 347 and Resolution 348 by the Planning Commission and the Public Works Advisory Board imminently approaching, the County Council could soon be facing a tough task.
If the resolutions, with or without amendments, are found consistent with the comprehensive plan, the council could soon grant approval, finally completing MDE's requests.
But if more questions remain, or if the legislation is found inconsistent, the county will return to the drawing board for further consideration and changes.

title: 'Plenty of shell'
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
'Plenty of shell'

 February 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 1066
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — In July, Maryland Gov. Wes Moore signed an executive order to establish an Oyster and Shell Substrate Task Force, created to develop a "proactive plan to keep and purchase oyster shells to ensure the state has enough hard surface to increase oyster abundance in the bay."This was tied in with another executive order of Moore's with the goal to create, "healthy watersheds that benefit the environment, the economy and communities."
Realizing a hearty oyster production creates cleaner water by filtering excess nutrients and sediments from the water, the task force now meets monthly. They discuss how to produce more oysters, transport oyster shells or talk about using alternative substrate in the water.
During their meeting on Jan. 18, Kent County Commission President Ron Fithian responded to Chesapeake Bay Foundation Executive Director Allison Colden.
In a previous meeting Colden said the seed and shell program, which lasted for 46 years, was reported to be a waste of the state's resources.
Fithian refuted that, having observed the success of Maryland's past oyster program, the Maryland Seed and Shell Program, from 1960-2006.
"There's no copy of such a report or any facts to back up her statement," he told the task force.
He drew from his history on the Eastern Shore, urging the members to not accept her research as fact.
Fithian stated during the 46 years of the seed and shell program, the state spent $48 million, planting 190 million bushels of shell. That averaged out to 4.2 million bushels per year. Maryland harvested approximately 60 million bushels of oysters with a dockside value estimated between $400 million to $1.2 billion.
Doing the math, Fithian said the program was "hardly a waste."
While he had their attention, he warned some groups deliberately deceive the public claiming there's not enough oyster shell in the Bay to place in the water — alternative sources are needed.
Fithian declared that false.
"The Bay is loaded with oyster shells from one end to the other."
He described the process. You find an area with shells with low oyster production and place them in productive areas.
Fithian pointed out there is a great supply of these shells at Man O'War Shoals in the upper bay. A 25-30 year supply even if Maryland decided to plant a million shell per year, he added.
"The transportation cost to the state, would be $2 or $4 a bushel."
But of late, he said, certain groups have taken away "twenty-five percent of the most productive oyster bottom from commercial fishers."
They build sanctuaries — areas where the wild harvest of oysters is prohibited, Fithian said.
Although, that may seem like a protective idea, it is not he told the task force.
Declaring an oyster bottom a "sanctuary," means oyster bars sit undisturbed. This does not lead to oyster production. Oysters cease production and die of old age, Fithian emphasized.
An inactive oyster bed invites filth too, said the commissioner.
"Oyster larvae needs a clean shell to attach itself. That's why areas still harvested will generally have a higher spat count (oyster larvae that attach to the shell) more than closed areas."
Fithian brought up Harris Creek as a prime example of going from an open seeding area to a sanctuary.
"During the seed and shell program, the state would place dredge shell in Harris Creek. Then mother nature would provide it with oyster larvae. Some years the spat count would be between 800-2,000 a bushel. Shells at a specific size, were transplanted to other areas, with a survival rate of 97 percent."
Since it was a highly successful spot, Fithian added, the Chesapeake Bay Foundation turned the area into a sanctuary thinking they'd also be a success.
Fithian called it a failed project.
"Spat count is less than 100 per bushel."
The site sits untouched, collecting sediment, making it unattractive for larvae.
He said the foundation was responsible.
"They supported spending $35 million and took the greatest natural oyster hatchery on the Bay and ruined it so it can never be a hatchery again."
Fithian posed a question to the task force, "What's more wasteful? $48 million to produce 60 million bushels of oysters over a 47 year span and a dockside value too large to count? Or $38 million for the Harris Creek project alone?".
Despite these comments, Fithian remarked he's not completely opposed to sanctuaries. They need to be created using the right substrate, he added.
This is not happening and those who are creating sanctuaries continue to repeat the same mistakes.
Mistakes leading to more pollution.
Fithian claimed the foundation applied for a permit to create three oyster reefs in Lynnhaven River. After they did, waterfront residents reported plastic and paper waste. Also the Virginia Institute of Marine Science found, "polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons."
He said that the foundation was ordered to remove all the junk at the bottom.
"Someone needs to explain to these government agencies the Chesapeake Bay is not a landfill. It's the greatest resource the state has and should be treated as such."
He challenged the task force with a call-to-action.
Stop spreading falsehoods about the lack of natural shell.
Allow the Department of Natural Resources to open up more areas.
Provide ample amounts of substrate needed for aquaculture, the oyster industry and restoration.
"Stop experimenting with far-fetched ideas that continue to fail time and time again."
After his remarks, Colden said she was taken aback, not expecting the commissioner to have so much time for a "soliloquy."
She said he wasted everyone's fifteen minutes and encouraged Fithian to look through her research, evidence of her claims, in a Google Drive she shared with the task force.
Later when Kent County News reached out to the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, concerning Fithian's comments, they offered this statement.
"The Oyster Shell and Substrate Task Force was created to identify ways to increase the number of oysters in Chesapeake Bay across all sectors — restoration, aquaculture, and the public fishery by addressing the shortage of oyster shell. It will take expertise and cooperation across all groups and stakeholders to create innovative and durable solutions to this challenging problem. CBF looks forward to serving an important role in the task force moving these conversations forward."
There's no argument that oyster production is good for water health. But there is an ongoing debate about the manner of which that happens, and who gets to decide what's best for the bay.
Chair of the Delmarva Fisheries Association, Rob Newberry, backing Fithian's statements, said his facts and figures can be found in Maryland Department of Natural Resources Shellfish Monitoring and Assessment Program.
The task force will continue to meet monthly at: https://go.activecalendar.com/doit-md/event/oyster-shell-and-substrate-taskforce-meeting-3/.

title: State lawmakers introduce sludge permit bills
author: Connie Connolly
content:
State lawmakers introduce sludge permit bills

 February 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 814
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Maryland state legislators introduced bipartisan bills this week to address a loophole in defining industrial sludge and overseeing what happens to it after it's created, especially when it's applied to farmland.House Bill 991, introduced by Del. Sara Love (D-Montgomery) is co-sponsored by four Republican legislators from Carroll and Frederick counties. It is cross-filed with Senate Bill 1074, introduced by Sen. Justin Ready, (R-Frederick, Carroll) and co-sponsored by two Democrats and a Republican.
The legislation aims to establish an "industrial sludge utilization permit" authorizing the Department of the Environment to issue the permits, develop a fee schedule and "inspect any site where industrial sludge is utilized."
Although the legislation's sponsors represent western shore counties, the bill aims to close a loophole of particular concern to Mid-Shore county residents, particularly in Caroline County, where concerns have been raised about the storage of dissolved air flotation residuals, or DAF, and other waste materials.
"Industrial sludge that's generated by DAF is the leftover material from poultry, fish and other protein products that rendering companies need to dispose of," said Alan Girard, Eastern Shore director at the Chesapeake Bay Foundation.
"The material is tested far less rigorously than other waste like sludge or biosolids from municipal wastewater plants, and its makeup when land-applied is not well understood," he said. "In other words, we don't truly know what's being dumped on our state's farmland and what's ultimately running off into the Chesapeake Bay."
In mid-December, residents complained to the Caroline County Commissioners about the odor and flies emanating from a DAF storage pit near Greensboro and their fear of contamination of groundwater and waterways.
Subsequent inquiries and investigation by county staff resulted in a proposed moratorium of DAF residual storage in the county, prompting hundreds of residents to attend a Jan. 23 public hearing in Denton.
Much of the DAF residual material is generated and trucked in from poultry and seafood processing plants outside the county. In Maryland, it is an approved soil amendment, or fertilizer.
The Caroline County commissioners introduced legislation Feb. 6 to establish four moratoriums relating to DAF residuals, vegetable processing wastewater and the storage of biosolids not permitted by the Department of the Environment.
Commission Vice President Larry Porter said he met with Love, Girard and a representative from Caroline County Department of Planning and Codes about three weeks ago to discuss the draft legislation.
"The biggest concern that I have, and I think I speak for the other (commissioners), is we do not want to get preempted on the issue of storage," he said.
"Anything that deals with the application of the materials strictly falls within the state purview under the nutrient management plans," Porter said Feb. 7. "I don't want to get that involved in what farmers are putting on their fields. It's up to them, and it's up to the state for them to work within those plans."
"At the time we reviewed it with Del. Love, we were insistent that they run this by the Maryland Farm Bureau," he said. "I want our local Farm Bureau to see it as well."
Commission President Travis Breeding said, "We want to make sure that the county retains control over the actual siting of any storage facility and ... whether or not open air storage is allowed."
Del. Chris Adams (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said he wants to see a "more final version" of the bill, but for now "the Maryland Department of Agriculture is better able to represent the agricultural community" than MDE in overseeing the permitting process, he said.
"Ultimately, Secretary (Kevin) Atticks and (MDA) are on the ground, and they're best suited for the task now," Adams said.
Breeding said he got "a little insider information" Wednesday in Annapolis, where he attended Gov. Wes Moore's State of the State Address.
"Some amendments are already being discussed at the governor's office where MDA ... would be the permit issuer or as opposed to MDE," Breeding said, adding, "I think very few things probably get introduced this late and actually make it all the way through session."
House Bill 991 addresses key concerns of several environmental groups, including the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, ShoreRivers and Chesapeake Legal Alliance.
"Other states, like Delaware and Virginia, require a permit to transport and spread industrial sludge," a Feb. 6 press release by the Chesapeake Bay Foundation said. "Since Maryland does not, the state's farmland has become an attractive dumping ground for the material's generators. According to a 2023 study by the University of Maryland, more than half of the industrial sludge land-applied in Maryland in recent years came from other states."
"There's more sludge coming into Maryland than there are places to safely store it, which is why we're seeing such blatant mishandling and irresponsible land application," said Matt Pluta, Choptank Riverkeeper. "In most cases this isn't farming, it's dumping."
Both bills were referred Wednesday to their respective committees, with a hearing for HB991 scheduled for 1 p.m. Wednesday, Feb. 28.
To follow Maryland legislation, visit mgaleg.maryland.gov.

title: Oxford Residents learn more, ask questions about Strand Beach project
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Oxford Residents learn more, ask questions about Strand Beach project

 February 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 565
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — Residents packed the Oxford Community Center Wednesday evening to hear about a local shoreline improvement project.The project, also known as the Strand Beach project, was approved in April 2021 and is intended to create a living shoreline.
A berm has been created, hooks have been placed along the east and west areas to bring sand in, and small islands have been created in the water to reduce the waves that come onto the beach. Low marsh grasses will be planted on the islands.
Expected to be completed by summer, the project also includes elevating the lowest-lying areas of Strand Road and improving the parking lot by paving it and building storm management areas underneath it.
At the Oxford Town Talk event Wednesday, representatives from the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, the National Wildlife Federation and the engineering firm Underwood and Associates gave presentations and answered questions. All three of these organizations have partnered with Oxford on the project.
Nicole Carlozo of Maryland DNR, talked about the Resiliency through Restoration initiative. Carlozo said this program, which she manages, helps communities "become more resilient to climate change" by providing support for project design and implementation.
She said the program focuses on using nature-based solutions to address the impacts of climate change.
Oxford's shoreline improvement project was selected to receive funding for both the design and construction phases through this program. Additional funding for the project has been obtained through a grant from the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation.
In an interview, Town Manager Cheryl Lewis said the town is still working to get additional funding for the project from the state.
Amanda Poskaitis, coastal resilience program manager with the National Wildlife Federation Mid-Atlantic Regional Center, said elevating the lowest lying areas of Strand Road and the parking lot will really help reduce flooding. She said the living shoreline is still in place and "working pretty well" following intense storms this winter.
"I think it's really going to end up benefitting the town in the long run," Poskaitis said.
Underwood and Associates Partner Chris Becraft delved further into the details of the project, discussing the reasons behind certain design choices. He gave examples of similar projects the engineering firm has worked on, including the living shoreline at Assateague State Park.
During his presentation, Becraft said Underwood and Associates are not going anywhere.
"We are here," he said. "And we look forward to hearing from you and working with you all for a successful project."
After the presentations, many residents asked questions about the project. Questions ranged from specific design details, to how the project is being financed to how effective living shorelines are.
Multiple residents asked about the wood placed on the points of the islands to accrete sand over time. One resident expressed concern that the logs could be a safety hazard for kids or for boats.
Becraft said these logs are an added feature, not an engineering requirement. He said they can go if the community doesn't want them.
Becraft also said the wood is beneficial when it comes to tidal events.
"They're that extra wave attenuater," he said.
One resident asked about the stability of sand accretion in this project.
Becraft said that in 30 years, these types of shorelines have "stood the test of time" when it comes to sand. He said this is because the design imitates a naturally occurring process.
"So that formula — the distance between the island and the beach — that's a natural system," he said.

title: Maryland Department of Agriculture working to address ongoing DAF issues
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Maryland Department of Agriculture working to address ongoing DAF issues

 February 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Environment 
 
 735
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — The Maryland Department of Agriculture is doing "everything within its powers" to address recent concerns with the storage of dissolved air flotation residuals, according to Maryland Secretary of Agriculture Kevin Atticks.Speaking to the Eastern Shore Delegation Friday morning, Atticks touched on the agency's efforts to handle the growing worries with responsible handling and storage of the sludge — an issue that has garnered extensive attention in Caroline County over the last few months.
Dissolved air flotation, or DAF, is a method used to process wastewater from food processing plants. The method leaves behind a sludge-like byproduct, or DAF residuals.
On the Shore, much of the material generated from DAF comes from poultry processing plants, though some comes from industrial and wastewater treatment sludge.
When used, managed, stored and transported correctly, there are no issues with DAF, Atticks said. But when it's used against MDA's regulations, issues arise with the smell, making neighboring residents concerned.
"What we're learning, what we're all collectively learning, is that for better or worse, one or two bad actors can ruin the entire setup," he said.
Atticks said the agency is working on legislation to answer the concerns, but it's also doubling down on enforcement within its powers. The department is working with the Maryland Department of the Environment as well.
On Feb. 5, several state lawmakers introduced legislation aiming to establish an industrial sludge utilization permit. The legislation would authorize MDE to issue the permits, develop a fee schedule and inspect and enter any site where industrial sludge is utilized.
According to the bill, industrial sludge includes material separated from liquid waste through a DAF process.
"We've been cooperating with Caroline County and in other parts of the state … to make sure that we're leaving avenues open for this product to be used responsibly and appropriately —where appropriate, when appropriate — but then putting the guardrails on it so that it's not going to cause the problems that it's causing in these minor incidents," Atticks said.
Del. Steve Arentz (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil and Caroline) asked if the Department of Agriculture would look at processes that could turn DAF residuals into energy.
Atticks said the department is actively exploring the idea.
"The poultry producers and other manufacturers who have food residual waste need a place to go, and it's not the landfill, and it's not the rivers," he said. "If it's through this DAF process, that's an option, if it's through a bioenergy generator, even better."
Arentz said he'd prefer internal work to solve the problems as opposed to more regulations — a statement the secretary agreed with in part.
"The last thing we want is more regulation. We certainly don't mind better regulation," Atticks said, adding, "We have limitations to what we can do and what we can't do, and this is an instance where we have industry come to us to say, 'We need more regulation to ensure that we can do what we're doing responsibly better,' and we can make sure that those who are bad actors are out of the business."
Del. Jefferson Ghrist (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil and Caroline) emphasized that the application of DAF isn't an issue due to the department's nutrient management plans. The unregulated storage is the problem, he said.
A former Caroline County Commissioner, Ghrist introduced a bill Friday that would give local governments that own or operate a water or sewer system the authority to enact local legislation relating to DAF storage that is equal to or greater than the state permit requirements for sewage sludge utilization.
To Atticks, the goal is to get something "on the ground" as fast as possible, whether it's to the counties or state agencies.
"...More is not better here, but clearer would help — figuring out a process so that we've actually got the controls that the community feels we should have, and that our industry feels that we should have," he said. "We're doing everything we can to work with the industry on this."
A separate bill involving fines and fees with MDA's programs did have support from the industry, Atticks said, because those who aren't doing anything wrong don't face fines.
"This is one of those instances where what we need is clarity, what we need is to run the groove to make sure that we've got the authorities that we need, that MDE has the authority that they need and (that) the counties have the authority they need."
Star Democrat reporter Connie Connolly contributed to this report.

 February 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: State News

 NEWARK, Del. — A controversial project to restore a manmade pond just over the Delaware border in White Clay Creek State Park has doubled in cost after engineers determined that more would need to be done to mitigate the risk of a dam break.Last week, the Delaware Department of Natural Resources hosted a virtual meeting to provide an update on the project. More than 70 people attended, including advocates who want the pond to become a fishing destination and opponents who question the logic of spending millions of dollars to rebuild a pond that is not naturally occurring.
Big Pond, as it is known, is located between Paper Mill Road and Pleasant Hill Road. The pond and surrounding property were once part of a du Pont estate, and the state purchased it in 1993 to become part of White Clay Creek State Park.
S. Hallock du Pont created the 5-acre pond in the 1950s by damming a stream called Middle Run with the intent to attract waterfowl for hunting. The dam eroded in 2015, and the pond drained.
A group of citizens, including du Pont's son Richard and longtime park champion Don Sharpe, has fiercely lobbied park officials to rebuild the dam and restore the pond. They envision an area that would attract anglers and bird watchers and proposed making the site handicapped accessible so that disabled veterans can fish there.
Park officials were less enthusiastic, and Big Pond was excluded from a master plan for the park that was finalized in 2019. At the time, officials said it wouldn't make sense to spend time and money restoring an artificial pond when there are other areas of the park with greater needs.
However, responding to public pressure, the state legislature allocated more than $3 million for Big Pond, and DNREC began preliminary engineering to build the project.
During that process, it was determined that the size of the pond would trigger dam safety thresholds, classifying the dam as either significant or high hazard, said Brooks Cahall, planning preservation and development section manager for DNREC.
"This really changes the scope of the project," Cahall said. "It becomes a much different project, and the design changes significantly."
The old dam was just an earthen embankment, but regulations require that a new dam would need to have a wider footprint, flatter slopes, a clay core and riprap to prevent erosion. Once built, the dam would require regular inspections.
The changes push the total cost of the project to $6 million, double the original budget, officials said.
Jason Coleman, from the consulting firm RK&K, said a high-hazard designation doesn't mean that there is a high risk of the dam failing but rather that if the dam were to break, there is a risk of damage downstream.
Modeling shows that in a catastrophic storm, such as a hurricane, a dam break could trigger flooding on Paper Mill Road, Paper Mill Park and a small portion of the Middle Run Crossing neighborhood.
Regulations would require the dam to have an emergency action plan and a plan for ongoing maintenance.
"Not only do we have to understand the risk, but we have to plan for emergencies and how we're going to deal with that," Cahall said.
The project would also require significant tree removal because trees and their roots can damage the structure of a dam.
Several people who attended last week's meeting spoke passionately about their desire to see the pond restoration come to fruition.
"This pond would provide enough water that you could actually have good populations of sport fish," said Desmond Kahn, a retired fisheries biologist. "The other ponds in the park, except for one, are tiny. They're too small. They don't support populations of fish."
While the state park is popular for trout fishing in the spring, Big Pond would provide fishing opportunities in warmer weather. Kahn noted that several years ago, more than 2,000 people signed a petition in favor of upgrades to the park, including Big Pond.
"The goal was that once it was constructed, the programs for handicapped people to fish could use this pond," he said. "Right now, they have very limited, tiny ponds. It's actually dangerous, because there's so many of them who are casting over each other's heads."
Others, however, questioned the need for the pond and whether it is the best use of resources in the sprawling state park.
"It's been mentioned that there's a lot of public support for this. I do not see that. I think there's strong opposition to this from everyone I've talked to, including a lot of the park staff, who probably are keeping their mouth shut," said Ken Cox, a longtime park volunteer. "Given how much effort we've put into trying to keep the park naturalized, and I'm out there ripping invasive species out, the idea of losing that many trees, I don't even know why this is being considered."
He and others asked why Big Pond has received so much money from the state while there are a number of higher-priority White Clay Creek State Park projects still waiting for funding.
"I would love to know who is pushing for this funding so that I can bother them. Because it's obviously not you," Cox told the DNREC officials. "Someone needs a talking to."
DNREC officials repeatedly dodged those questions, saying only that they are doing as directed by the state legislature. They also sidestepped a question about whether they think recreating an artificial pond is as environmentally responsible as letting the area revert to its natural state.
"This is one of those situations where, from a parks perspective, we've been given a project and a task to do and we're just working toward that direction," Cahall said.
He said engineering and design will continue on the project, but construction cannot begin unless additional funding is secured.
"We wanted to be transparent and clear with you all, the local residents and park users, about where we are and some of the challenges we see with this project," Cahall said.

title: Local birders count for global event
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Local birders count for global event

 February 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 793
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County birders brought out both binoculars and spotting scopes to help them identify grackles, eagles and wood ducks near Kingston Landing Launch on the Choptank on Sunday.They identify different species using many criteria, like song, flight pattern and distinctive markings.
Some birders even brought long-lensed cameras to back up their identifications with photographic evidence.
The international Great Backyard Bird Count took place from Feb. 16 to 19. Birders from all over the world went out to see what was flying and then sent the data via eBird, the world's largest database of birds, back to Cornell University.
Birders identify different species using many criteria, like song, flight pattern and distinctive markings.
The birds rarely sit still to be counted, but bird counting efforts can help indicate species health and range, birders said.
Birding discoveries can reflect climate change and loss of habitat. For example, for the first time ever, it is warm enough to find glossy ibis in Maryland. This bird is more commonly found in Florida.
"Good data goes to eBird. It is an international database that is free for the use of the scientific community. What we are doing as citizens goes to enrich the scientific information. eBird started roughly 20 years ago. This weekend is a citizen science weekend. There are maybe 50 people from Talbot County participating. Some on walks like this — we had 24 at Pickering Creek on Friday. And some just in their backyard," said Wayne Bell, PhD, as he ventured out with the group Sunday.
Bell, who teaches a class on Birds and Birding on the Eastern Shore at the Chesapeake Forum, likes birding because it gets him outside with a bunch of nice people.
What looks like a brown lump in deep camouflage is an identifiable species to him. There is a skilled eye and ear to develop in birding.
What birders discover varies greatly based on location and season, he said.
"We are right in the shoulder. The waterfowl are leaving and the spring migration hasn't quite started yet. We are looking at the dead of winter," Bell said.
By coming together globally, birding groups help gather useful local data that is aggregated by eBird into a global picture.
"There is a paper that came out in 2019 that got a lot of traction that documents the decline in North American bird populations by a third. We have lost 30% of our birds in the last 50 years. Loss of habitat. They didn't go anywhere, they are gone," Bell said. "The global warming thing is kicking in in the last 50 years. Most of it is loss of habitat. One exception to that has been waterbirds."
The person leading the frigid morning count Feb. 18 was Bettye Maki, president of the Talbot Bird Club.
"The Great Backyard Bird Count lasts for four days. For all the four days, you could do it everyday. I have gotten feedback from the eBird people. They have people who monitor, and if they don't agree or they think you are wrong about something, they let you know. They are very helpful. They give me more information," Maki said.
She has traveled all over the world to see birds and has 700 species identified. She saw around 30 to 40 on this bird count.
Maki said she likes to encourage new birders. She will give a talk at the Chesapeake Forum in the spring about her trip to Borneo.
"You have to like to be outdoors. There is the camaraderie and the ability to learn while seeing and doing this. There is the diversity of what you are seeing. It is like an Easter egg hunt. It is just fun," Maki said. "It is like fishing — some days are good and some days it isn't. But you always have a wonderful day outdoors. I always feel better for doing it."
Talbot County Bird Club has 80 members.
Another member of the Bird Club is Dave Burgevin. Not only was he geared up with a 500mm lens and binoculars, but he could convincingly call out to the birds in their songs, chirps and shrieks.
"I started learning the calls when I was 10 with Cornell birders. So it was like learning an instrument early. My dad got me into birding before I was six. I learned to tell the difference in the calls. I have continued to lead bird walks over the past 30 years in Maryland and Northern Virginia," said Burgevin.
He said the bird count is important.
"It is a worldwide effort to learn about migration and species decline or increase," he said
He has numbers backing up his passion.
"There are about 400 species available in Maryland including migration. There is about 888 available in the US. The country with the most is Columbia at about 1,800. There are just under 10,000 worldwide," said Burgevin.

title: Maryland lawmakers urge Congress to spend more on Chesapeake Bay restoration
author: YESENIA MONTENEGRO and BRENNAN STEWART Capital News Service
content:
Maryland lawmakers urge Congress to spend more on Chesapeake Bay restoration

 March 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: YESENIA MONTENEGRO and BRENNAN STEWART Capital News Service | Section: National 
 
 608
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Citing encouraging signs of improvement, five Maryland lawmakers expressed their support Wednesday for increased funding of the federally-backed Chesapeake Bay restoration program."We've made progress," Sen. Ben Cardin (D-Md.) said at a luncheon hosted by the Choose Clean Water Coalition. "We have the least amount of dead zones that we've seen since the 1980s on the bay. We have underwater grasses that are coming back in the Chesapeake Bay. We have oyster crops that we never thought we'd be able to see starting to bloom in the Chesapeake Bay. We're not at our historic levels, not even close. I understand that. But we've made progress."
The coalition, which was started in 2009, hosted its 13th annual Chesapeake Bay Day on Wednesday with nearly 100 of its members and nine members of Congress in attendance. Made up of over 290 nonprofit organizations from the Chesapeake Bay region, the non-profit advocates maintaining or increasing spending on clean water programs.
"I think the Chesapeake delegation in Congress is just so passionate about this work, and they understand the benefits to their districts and the people that live there," Kristin Reilly, director of the coalition, told Capital News Service.
"I think that's also why there's such wide bipartisan support for these programs because they can actually see the benefits in their communities," Reilly added.
The Chesapeake Bay Program, which receives funding from the Environmental Protection Agency, was started in 1983, with its main efforts directed towards reducing pollution and restoring the bay's ecosystem.
The program encompasses six states that surround the bay as well as the District of Columbia, and its funding needs were at the forefront of the coalition's lobbying day. Over 70% of the program's funds are spent on projects in the Chesapeake Bay watershed, including planting trees, reducing runoff from farmland and boosting the crab and oyster populations.
The coalition highlighted the recent introduction of the America's Conservation Enhancement Reauthorization Act of 2024, which authorizes funding for various programs, including $93 million in funding for the EPA Chesapeake Bay Program for the 2025 fiscal year and $100 million for 2026 and beyond.
"This bill (the ACE Act) is going to get the bay on track," Rep. Dutch Ruppersberger (D-Md.) said. "Some of the things that these grants do, like sediment reduction, really make a difference in helping the Chesapeake Bay."
The coalition also is backing $15 million for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's Watershed Investments for Landscape Defense program, which provides grants to local organizations in the Chesapeake region that focus on restoring or protecting wildlife habitats.
The coalition recognized Ruppersberger, Cardin and Rep. John Sarbanes (D-Md.) as "Chesapeake Champions" for their contributions to the restoration efforts throughout their careers.
Rep. David Trone (D-Md.), who is running for the U.S. Senate, said he plans to continue working to protect the bay if he wins the seat.
Pollutants need to be kept out of the bay and the efforts towards no-till farming have not been as successful in Pennsylvania and Virginia as in Maryland, Trone said. No-till farming is a technique used to grow crops without disturbing the soil.
"The environment is top of the list," Trone told CNS. "So the environment and the bay, that's the very very top of the list. If you don't get that right, nothing else matters."
After the luncheon, coalition members had scheduled 44 meetings with members of Congress, presenting letters from 169 organizations that endorsed the coalition's appropriations requests.
"We have to both maintain the momentum, but we also need to accelerate our efforts even further," Sen. Van Hollen (D-Md.) told CNS. "That means making sure that we protect and expand the resources that go to protect the bay from all the federal agencies."

title: House Environment and Transportation Committee hears proposed DAF storage bill
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
House Environment and Transportation Committee hears proposed DAF storage bill

 March 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 530
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Del. Jeff Ghrist has withdrawn a bill that would have given local jurisdictions the authority to regulate the storage of dissolved air flotation by-products, or DAF residuals.Dissolved air flotation is a method used to process wastewater from food processing plants. The method leaves behind a sludge-like byproduct, or DAF residuals.
On the Shore, much of the material generated from DAF comes from poultry processing plants, though some comes from industrial and wastewater treatment sludge.
In a letter to Del. Marc Korman (D-Montgomery), the chair of the Maryland House of Delegates Environment and Transportation Committee, Ghrist (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) withdrew the bill he had introduced, House Bill 1404, and said he believed another bill, House Bill 991, would accomplish the same goals he is seeking if it is amended.
House Bill 991, which is sponsored by by Del. Sara Love (D-Montgomery), would establish an industrial sludge utilization permit administered and enforced by the Department of the Environment.
In his letter, Ghrist said the current amended version of HB991 clearly "aims to give the necessary control to local governing bodies."
Ghrist took issue with how DAF is defined in this version of the bill. He said in the letter that DAF is being defined as an agricultural food processing residual, and as an agricultural operation, when it should be defined as industrial waste.
"This definition is important because any agricultural operation falls under the protection of the state's Right to Farm statute, and restrictions imposed by the local governing body could be challenged in court based on the protections granted by the Right to Farm," Ghrist said in the letter.
Ghrist said he he would like HB991 amended to separate DAF from other agricultural waste products "because it also includes other waste products that are not generated within the agricultural industry."
A hearing on HB991 was held Feb. 28, according to the Maryland General Assembly website. A second reading of the bill has not yet occurred. A hearing was held Tuesday for a cross-filed version of the bill, Senate Bill 1074, according to the General Assembly website. A second reading of that bill has not yet occurred either.
In an interview Thursday, Ghrist said he suspects the HB991 will get passed in the House before the 2024 legislative session ends on April 8. There has been a commitment from the Environment and Transportation Committee regarding this bill, he said, and when bills get support from the committee, they usually pass in the House.
In a Feb. 21 interview with the Star Democrat, Ghrist said he had introduced HB1404 to make sure that local governing bodies could put restrictions on the storage of DAF residuals "without any ambiguity." He said he wanted to ensure that if anybody decided to sue Caroline County, the case would not have any standing in court.
Caroline County Commissioners have been dealing with concerns regarding DAF storage since December. According to previous Star Democrat reporting, in late February, the commissioners voted to adopt four resolutions designed to give them time to study the issue of storing DAF residuals and other materials in the county.
The moratoriums address issues the County Commissioners learned about in December, when residents complained of possible illegal storage of DAF residuals.

title: Easter fun that doesn't end up in the landfill
author: Tamara Tsaturyan Food Drink Life
content:
Easter fun that doesn't end up in the landfill

 March 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tamara Tsaturyan Food Drink Life | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1037
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Spring has sprung, bunnies are hopping, but wait a minute — where has all the plastic gone? This time around, have Easter fun that leaves a mark on memories and not on the planet.What goes into creating memorable Easter fun? Plastic eggs and baskets, fake grass and candy wrappers probably aren't at the top of the list. If you're buying disposable plastic every year only to throw it away once Easter is over, then you might want to learn about alternative, fun and eco-friendly Easter festivities.
Say no to single-use plastic
For many Americans, spring flowers or warmer weather may not be the first signs of Easter's approach. Instead, your initial reminder about the upcoming holiday likely comes from the shelves of your local Target. As retailers begin stocking Easter-themed holiday items, you might feel tempted to pick up a bunch of cheap plastic eggs and Easter decorations while running other errands. It's hard to resist the allure of making your Easter egg hunt a little bit easier to plan.
Unfortunately, what begins as an impulse purchase often ends up in the landfill. Those plastic eggs, which look so tempting on display in stores, lose their appeal once the holiday is over. Many families may not have the space to store bulky Easter baskets or piles of crumpled plastic grass. Since most of that plastic can't be recycled, according to Nature World News, families simply throw it away.
With 81% of Americans celebrating Easter, according to Statista, those individual choices can add up quickly. UN experts are sounding the alarm about the toxic tidal wave of plastic, such as toys, bags and other products that end up contaminating the environment. In a recent statement, UN's David R. Boyd and Marcos Orellana warned that "the contribution of plastic pollution to climate change is alarming, yet often overlooked."
The good news is that it's possible to have beloved Easter festivities without all that waste. For many Christians, the real meaning of Easter isn't buying and discarding a jumble of single-use plastics. Instead, the holiday is a time to reflect upon core Christian values of sacrifice and simplicity.
Eco-friendly Easter activities for kids
With a little creativity and planning, you can introduce fun Easter activities that don't involve spending money on wasteful plastic products. Instead, hop into an Easter celebration that's kind to your wallet and the Earth. Here are some ideas to get you started.
Outdoor Easter scavenger hunt
In a twist on classic Easter egg hunts, don't send your kids out searching for plastic eggs. Instead, organize an outdoor Easter scavenger hunt with fun riddles as clues. Have meaningful prizes at the end of the hunt.
Easter baking
Ditch the individually wrapped Easter candies and bake some Easter treats together as a family. Cookies, wrapped in paper or stored in jars, are a great gift to share with loved ones.
Dyeing hard-boiled eggs
Did you know that dyeing real hard-boiled eggs is way more fun? It's easy to use natural food dyes, like onion skin or turmeric. And because these dyes are natural, you can eat the eggs as part of your Easter menu, so nothing goes to waste.
Gardening
Easter is all about celebrating new beginnings. Planting seeds or seedlings with kids is an engaging activity that is also environmentally friendly.
DIY-ing instead of buying
DIY instead of buying your Easter baskets this year. Egg cartons, old newspapers and magazines can all be used to make Easter baskets and decorations.
"One of our family's favorite activities to do on Easter is crafting," says Siobhan Alvarez-Borland of Mimosas and Motherhood. "From keepsake handprint or footprint crafts to utilizing found materials from an outdoor nature hunt to create a spring collage, this family crafting time has become one of our most treasured traditions."
If your kids are old enough, encourage them to get involved in planning and choosing eco-friendly options for Easter. This will not only help kids understand the importance of sustainability, but it's also a great way to get them excited about celebrating holidays in a way that doesn't damage the planet.
Tips for reducing waste during Easter celebrations
No matter how you celebrate Easter, there are lots of ways to reduce waste. Start by taking stock of what you already have. You may turn up a box of Easter decorations you didn't know you owned, avoiding the need to purchase something new. Or, consider connecting with other community members who are also celebrating Easter to swap supplies.
When you're putting together Easter baskets, don't forget about your local thrift store. Thrift stores often have a plethora of wicker baskets available at low prices. These higher-quality reusable baskets can be saved and re-used from year to year, avoiding waste. If you own a shredder or a pair of scissors, you can easily create your own recyclable paper grass — an alternative to plastic Easter grass.
Visit your local retailers to check out eco-friendly alternatives to Easter-themed plastic products. Recyclable paper eggs, which are great for decorating the house or an Easter egg hunt, are becoming increasingly available in stores. Also, use eco-friendly basket fillers, like tickets to zoos or museums, seed bombs and wooden puzzles.
The positive impact of eco-friendly Easter fun
Initially, a low-waste Easter might seem like added pressure during an already busy time of celebration planning. But, as you implement the tips suggested in this article, you might be surprised at how sustainability becomes less of a chore and more of an integral part of your family values. You'll quickly appreciate the liberating feeling of having less plastic waste cluttering up your home post-celebration.
Developing sustainable holiday traditions reduces waste and minimizes your family's environmental footprint. When you engage in eco-friendly activities it's an opportunity for family bonding while also setting a great example for children. Avoiding consumerism on Easter is the perfect way to be grateful for what you already have, placing the focus firmly on Easter's true meaning.
Before you know it, as your kids enjoy an outdoor Easter scavenger hunt, you'll be hunting for more ways to keep your family's life eco-friendly beyond Easter — and the planet will thank you for it.
Tamara Tsaturyan is the owner and writer of Thriving In Parenting, a website focused on providing simple tips for busy parents — easy and healthy recipes, home decor and organization ideas and all things parenting.

title: Boy Scouts build barn owl boxes for Blackwater
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Boy Scouts build barn owl boxes for Blackwater

 March 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 394
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge Boy Scout Troop 209 spent part of a weekend busy at Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge mounting barn owl boxes and laying down gravel.The scouts, with the help of their parents and Blackwater's biologists, replaced two barn owl boxes and added an extra box to the refuge on Feb. 25. They also added more gravel to a ramp to level it and improve accessibility to a photo blind located off Wildlife Drive.
Boy Scout Keegan Hulett, 14, is on his way to becoming an Eagle Scout, and this project is a step toward that achievement.
He said the entire experience was "very fun."
Along with his fellow Scouts, Hulett was surprised about how long the owl boxes will last on the refuge.
"We thought it would last only two or three years," he said, "but apparently, it'll be set for the next 15 years."
Blackwater Wildlife biologist Holly Keepers said successful nesting rates have been decreasing for barn owls.
"By having these structures put up, we're giving the barn owls more options," she said. "And they're able to hopefully — in the future — have more nestlings and more babies than before."
Not only did the Scouts mount the boxes on the refuge, but they also built them.
Hulett's mother, Jeannie VanDyke, said the boys spent an entire Saturday at her dad's house building the barn owl boxes according to the specs that Blackwater sent them.
Keepers said the refuge really appreciates community service projects like these.
"We love projects like these at the refuge," she said. "But unfortunately it takes a lot of time and money, and wood is very expensive now. So having these projects, especially with people being able to come out and enjoy the day on the refuge, it was really, really nice."
Keepers said the new boxes are bigger and better than before.
The work to the photo blind ramp was an addition to the owl box project.
"Most (Boy Scout) troops are pretty large," VanDyke said. "So when Keegan went to the Scout board to tell them about the project that needed to be done, they weren't sure if it was enough for an Eagle project. So Keegan asked Blackwater if there was anything else the boys could do in addition to that."
Hulett encouraged others to consider becoming a Scout.
"Anyone who's looking to go into the Boy Scouts, you should definitely consider it," he said. "It's really fun."
