title: Edible Flower & Farm Tour entices the senses
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Edible Flower & Farm Tour entices the senses

 July 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 812
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Every year, ShoreRivers compiles an impressive roster of experiential events intended to highlight and connect area residents in obvious, and sometimes not so obvious, ways to the Bay, rivers and creeks.Wednesday's event, which was listed on their calendar as a, "farm tour featuring edible flowers," explored one of the less obvious interactions.
These partner-driven events, ShoreRivers Membership Manager Courtney Leigh said, take root in their symbiotic nature. The site for this day's gathering was Wildly Native Flower Farm in Chestertown.
"Shore Rivers believes that creating engaging opportunities for community members in the work that we do is going to help and restore our waterways," Leigh said, as she introduced the event host Liza Goetz, the owner of Wildly Native, to the attendees.
"Wildly Native Flower Farm encourages people to understand how the natural world, and particularly plants, are not only useful in pollination, they are excellent inhabitants. They are beautiful ornaments to bring joy into your worlds in your homes and your events," Leigh said. "But, they also believe in the power of plants as it pertains to human health and its enjoyment as it pertains to food and beverage."
The groups are kept small intentionally, making the day's gathering of nine seem just right. While small, the group did not lack Eastern Shore representation, as attendees came from as far as Kent Island, Oxford and Easton to participate.
Gathered under a white festival canopy surrounded by several of the farm's fragrant pastures, attendees began their experience by sharing their rationales for attending.
"I'm here because I just love to see the wildflowers and the native plants," said Carol Trippe, a Chestertown resident and Chair of the Chester Watershed Advisory Board. "And we just turned our back yard into a river-friendly yard, so it's great to see some native flowers, as well.
Trippe was joined by others with property-related project pursuits, or passions of the entomological sort.
"I just started raising monarchs, so I'd like to learn what might attract them," Connie Jones of Galena added.
Goetz's family history on this land located off of Broad Neck Road goes back generations, so she is keenly aware of the impact that running a farm can have on the environment, and, in particular, its surrounding waterways.
This, said Leigh, dovetails especially well with the ShoreRivers' Next Generation Land Stewards program, which she said aims to create cohorts with the newest generation of family-based land owners so that as land stewards they can be educated and empowered to manage their land in a way that's not just profitable for the farm and their business, but also conscious of how it impacts water quality.
Goetz has been working closely with Alicia Boyd, proprietor of local Humble Hearts Catering & Events, to create a native flower sampling experience, in which the group was then able to partake.
Varieties of marigolds and chrysanthemum were the most easily identified as components of the summer toast and goat cheese spread; the Dianthus barbatus, or Sweet William, as it is more commonly known, was among the most difficult to identify. A chilled tea made from a base of steeped orange geranium leaves, served as the beverage accompaniment to the samplings.
Of the edible flower aspect of her catering, Boyd said, "Everyone is excited about this venture, but it is a long process. There's a lot of compliance that comes along with it."
Boyd said that they work extensively with Cornell University, several local health departments, and the University of Maryland Extension to ensure the quality and safety of every native plant used to create their menus.
The tour continued with a short walk past the garden plots, outbuildings, and the family ancestral home to the farm's flower production barn where Goetz introduced the group to the people, processes and products associated with the hundreds of species and subspecies of native plants grown on the property. The small staff works within two levels of the barn under ceiling beams from which hundreds of variations of native plants are affixed for drying.
Goetz points to a large, plastic tray divided into many small pods filled with soil. It will soon be sitting on a workstation, where a staff member will use garden tweezers to convey the precious seeds to the pods for germination. Goetz said every native plant in the gardens started out this way.
The experience ended with a communal flower arranging session. Before any stem was placed in a vase, fresh, clean water was added to it from the farm's outdoor pump, reminding everyone how none of this works without life's most basic element.
Leigh concluded with a reminder that many ShoreRivers events are free to the public and there are still a good selection of events, including an expedition to the Chesapeake Culinary Center in Denton and a fly fishing lesson near Mill Creek, that will take place in the remaining calendar year for the community to come out and experience.
For more information, visit shorerivers.org.

title: Wave of defense tactics aim to save eastern hemlocks
author: AD CRABLE Chesapeake Bay Journal
content:
Wave of defense tactics aim to save eastern hemlocks

 August 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AD CRABLE Chesapeake Bay Journal | Section: News 
 
 1235
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The fight is far from over, but scientists are increasingly optimistic that once-ubiquitous eastern hemlock trees might, with help, bounce back from a 50-year assault by invasive woolly adelgids.The aphid-like insects, native to the Pacific Northwest and Asia, found their way to the eastern U.S. in the early to mid-1900s and have been spreading and killing hemlocks by the millions ever since.
But a combination of bio-controls, insecticides, habitat doctoring and a disease-resistant hemlock hybrid — plus the discovery of native trees that are somehow immune — may keep the beloved and valuable tree from disappearing in Eastern forests. That's an outcome that arborists would not have predicted with confidence 20 years ago.
"It's a long game, but it's a long game we are going to win," said Tammara Van Ryn, director of the Nature Conservancy's Adirondack Park Invasive Plant Program. The conservancy, along with the U.S. Forest Service, has embarked on a Trees in Peril program to find, monitor, research and breed pest-resistant hemlocks, along with efforts for similarly imperiled native beech and ash trees — even the nearly extinct American elm.
"I am sure the hemlock is going to stay on the landscape," she continued. "We've learned a lot of lessons from mistakes with the American chestnut that we're not repeating. We're using every tool to keep [enough] hemlocks alive to get to the point where we can breed more-resistant trees and get them out into the forest."
The primary tools that will buy that necessary time are chemical treatments, which keep the insects at bay for several years per treatment, and promising biological controls: nonnative insects that feed on the adelgids. Forest managers and scientists have been experimenting with predatory beetles for decades. Recently, they've added adelgid-eating silver flies to the experimental arsenal.
Woolly adelgids do their often-fatal damage by sucking nutrient-rich fluids from hemlock needles, weakening the tree and reducing foliage. The bugs, with two egg-producing life cycles per year, have rapid population growth.
In Pennsylvania, where the eastern hemlock is the state tree and represents about 15% of all forest trees, woolly adelgids are found in all 67 counties.
In Virginia, where the eastern U.S. infestation is thought to have begun, foresters estimate a loss of roughly 2% of its hemlocks annually. Shenandoah National Park has been particularly hard hit, though. According to the park trust, 95% of the property's mature hemlocks have died during the last 25 years.
In Maryland, the hotspots appear to be the state's four westernmost counties. Catoctin Mountain Park in Frederick County has lost a significant portion of its hemlocks, important for shading and cooling the park's trout streams, in recent decades.
Climate change could complicate matters. Substantial cold kills the woolly adelgid, so warmer winters generally work to its advantage — and may extend its range northward.
"For a long time, we had a series of really cold winters that kept adelgids at bay," said Justin LaMountain, a U.S. Forest Service silviculturist at Allegheny National Forest, which has hemlocks up to 300 years old. "Since 2017, we have had much milder winters and the pest has really expanded significantly to the point where we have an infestation [here]."
"It all comes down to the level of stress on a tree. As the climate warms or changes, it makes the trees susceptible to other stressors," said Rosa Yoo, forest health manager in the Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources' Bureau of Forestry.
Despite this new headwind, the once widely accepted possibility of hemlock extinction in the region is giving way to optimism, as promising advances emerge on several fronts in the fight against woolly adelgids.
"It is important to tackle these challenges on a landscape scale," LaMountain said. "Anything less than a collaborative effort is going to have a high probability of failure."
Unleashing predators and chemicalsThe newest biological controls to be thrown into the battle are two species of silver flies. The insects, each about the size of a grain of rice, feed on adelgid larvae that infest western hemlocks in the Pacific Northwest. The two species feed exclusively on woolly adelgids, and scientists conducted tests to make sure the nonnative insects wouldn't bring unintended consequences to East Coast forests.
The silver flies will not replace the predatory beetles that have been deployed until now. Instead, they will supplement them, giving the biological attack a seasonal one-two punch. Scientists have found that the beetles only prey on the first of the adelgid's two yearly generations, in the fall and winter. Silver flies eat the eggs of the second generation in the spring.
The Forest Service released 2,800 silver flies, provided by Cornell University, into the Allegheny National Forest in November 2023. The flies joined forces with an estimated 3,500 predatory beetles grown at Virginia Tech that have been unleashed there since 2020.
Other releases of silver flies are occurring in Bay drainage states. A location in Giles County, VA, is the first to host both species of predatory beetles and both kinds of silver flies.
In a huge development, new generations of silver flies are being found at release sites throughout the region, showing they are making themselves at home and surviving by eating adelgids. King William and Wythe counties in Virginia were the first to provide proof that both fly species were reproducing after a release.
As of January 2023, 46,000 silver flies of both species were released at 65 sites in the Eastern U.S.
"I'm optimistic that bio-controls will definitely provide some control of the woolly adelgid, but bio-control takes a long time for these populations to build up. We need to keep hemlocks alive in the short term," said Nicholas Dietschler, research support specialist with the New York State Hemlock Initiative.
One short-term fix that forest managers have recently turned to is "habitat adjustment" — clearing away other tree species to give hemlock stands more sunlight. Hemlocks are famously shade-tolerant, but, like nearly all trees, they grow better in direct sunlight. And adelgid growth appears to be less robust in direct sun.
Insecticide treatment is an even more immediate and widely practiced short-term approach. Like habitat tweaks, though, it is not practical for remote stands of hemlocks. Still, where it can be done, each injection of the right chemical into the soil under hemlocks, or directly into the trunk, has been shown to prevent infestation for five years or more.
Until recently, the treatments have mostly been used to save well-known groves of hemlocks and trees in public areas, such as around campsites and in parks. But efforts are increasing to treat mature hemlocks deep in the woods — particularly where the trees perform a crucial ecological service — like preserving wild trout habitat by shading and cooling streams.
There is no widely agreed-on order of battle for the multifaceted defense against the woolly adelgids, but a united front appears to be taking shape among federal and state agencies, universities and private partners in the Mid-Atlantic states. A tide of hope is rising that the eastern hemlock may not be doomed.
That's encouraging to people on the front lines of the battle, like the Nature Conservancy's Van Ryn. "The hemlock, if you will, is a tree of my heart," she said. "There is something majestic about the tree, and there is something almost magical about wandering among a hemlock grove."
Ad Crable is a Chesapeake Bay Journal staff writer based in Pennsylvania. This article first appeared in the April 2024 issue of the Chesapeake Bay Journal and was distributed by the Bay Journal News Service.

title: Maryland Conservation Corps graduates celebrated
author: MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES
content:
Maryland Conservation Corps graduates celebrated

 August 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES | Section: Life 
 
 316

 The Maryland Department of Natural Resources honored 39 members of the 2023-2024 Maryland Conservation Corps during their graduation program at Wye Island Natural Resources Management Area.The Aug. 1 ceremony capped the members' completion of 10 months of job training, conservation work and stewardship with the Maryland Park Service.
"Through the past 10 months, these dedicated young professionals have shared their passion for our natural resources and public lands through hours of plantings, training, projects and public engagement," said Maryland Park Service Director Angela Crenshaw.
"I am thankful for their hard work and hope they've grown both professionally and personally during their time with us," she said. "I am exceedingly proud of our graduates and excited for the many meaningful things they will accomplish in the future. I would also like to thank our wonderful Conservation Corps Team and everyone in the Maryland Park Service who helped support our corps members."
Maryland Conservation Corps members come from across the country, are between the ages of 17 and 25, and complete at least 1,700 hours of service.
This year's corps class improved more than 2,400 acres of parks and public lands; planted more than 9,963 native trees, bay grasses and plants; treated more than 7,902 trees against harmful insects and diseases; and taught environmental education programs to more than 23,750 students, youth and park visitors.
The program offers hands-on, real-world experience in a team-based environment in subjects ranging from aquatic systems to public lands management.
Many alumni of the program have gone on to conservation careers with organizations including the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, the National Aquarium, the United States Geological Survey and others.
The Maryland Conservation Corps, an award-winning AmeriCorps program, has been managed by the Maryland Park Service since 1984. The Park Service is now accepting applications for the next class, which begins in the fall.
More information and applications for the Maryland Conservation Corps can be found on the DNR website.

title: Scientists identify toxin found in Chesapeake Bay phytoplankton
author: UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE
content:
Scientists identify toxin found in Chesapeake Bay phytoplankton

 August 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE | Section: News 
 
 432
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — From a 60-year-old Karlodinium Veneficum (K. veneficum) culture kept at the U.K.'s Plymouth Laboratory, a research team led by the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science discovered the cause of the Chesapeake Bay's fish kill, which was originally blamed on another phytoplankton, Pfiesteria piscicida.Center for Environmental Science researchers determined that Pfiesteria was not, in fact, the cause of the Bay's fish-kill; rather, the karlotoxins found in K. veneficum were to blame.
In a paper recently published in Nature Scientific Reports, using surface plasma resonance and a suite of bioassays, the authors report the specific functions of membrane pores formed by these karlotoxins. Moreover, the formation is a highly targeted mechanism involving the cell membrane and sterol-specificity; cholesterol, in this case.
"What is so unique about this toxin is its mode of action, how it works," said Allen Place, a UMCES professor and expert in biochemistry who served as the primary investigator on the project.
"To consume other phytoplankton, it generates holes in their cell walls, creating a porous membrane through which other ions can flow," Place said. "This incapacitates and eventually kills its prey, which it then eats."
The team's analysis proves karlotoxins generate pores in membranes with desmethyl sterols — like cholesterol, phytosterols and ergosterol — that weaken membranes, disrupt motor function, cause cells to swell and eventually burst, all for the sake of capturing and devouring susceptible organisms.
They use the toxin as a defense mechanism, too.
"Think of a venomous snake that stores venom inside special glands — the venom can't harm the snake. In other words, it can't self-intoxicate due to the make-up of its anatomy, but it can certainly harm creatures it comes into contact with," Place said. "The same holds true for K. veneficum, and it's not unique to Chesapeake Bay; this has a worldwide distribution. And it's sensitive to environmental inputs such as global warming, so the higher the temperature, the more abundant this organism becomes."
Although the toxin has proven deadly to fish, shellfish, small sharks and even laboratory mice, it's important to note that the presence of cholesterol deactivates the threat, similar to how vinegar neutralizes lye.
There is little physical impact to people. The impact to the environment, however, could potentially be significant.
The University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science, based in Cambridge, leads the way toward better management of Maryland's natural resources and the protection and restoration of the Chesapeake Bay. From a network of laboratories located across the state, UMCES scientists provide sound evidence and advice to help state and national leaders manage the environment, and prepare future scientists to meet current global challenges.

title: Trappe council passes motion to store Lakeside's effluent
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Trappe council passes motion to store Lakeside's effluent

 August 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 501
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — On Wednesday evening, Trappe commissioners passed a motion to approve the sending of effluent from the Lakeside Wastewater Treatment Plant to the town's storage lagoon, provided the Maryland Department of the Environment OKs the request.Lakeside had been sending its effluent to Trappe's wastewater plant for discharge prior to discovering that MDE's approval was required to do this. Since then, Lakeside's effluent has been stored in Hurlock.
According to Lyndsey Ryan, Trappe's attorney, the plant, which finished construction in June, "has not gotten through the startup phase." As a result, Lakeside engineers are requesting the effluent be sent to Trappe's sludge lagoon, instead of to the town's treatment plant.
"The request in front of (council) is to either request to MDE to allow the effluent to be sent directly from Lakeside plant to Trappe for discharge, or to have the effluent transported to Trappe's holding storage until (MDE) decides that it's appropriate and not going to impact our operations," Ryan said.
The original method of transporting effluent to the Trappe plant was through diverting valves at a Trappe pump station. However, the town requested the use of tank trucks to transport treated effluent into the Trappe sludge lagoon, rather than directly into the Trappe collection system.
Ryan said this is so Steve Callahan, Trappe's water/wastewater superintendent, could maintain the amount of effluent that was coming into Trappe's plant on a "monitored basis."
Robert Rauch, Lakeside's engineer, is requesting the town temporarily store the partially treated effluent as Lakeside waits for final testing and approval to store it in its own treatment plant.
Rauch said the Lakeside Wastewater Treatment Plant is in the process of treating 120 equivalent dewelling units' effluent flow. Rauch said they are doing effluent testing up to three times a week to confirm it is consistent with all parameters of the permit and expects to have compliant effluent within a two-week period.
Commissioner Brian Schmidt stated that the Lakeside operator in charge of the effluent is working diligently to get it going and have it working per MDE specs.
Rauch described the situation as a "non-issue" since Lakeside has already paid for the 120 equivalent dwelling units of effluent flow to reside in the Trappe Wastewater Treatment Plant.
"We expect to have the first certified report by the middle or end of next week," Rauch said. "... We need to make sure that the town's in a position to cooperate with us in the event we have another week that we have to deal with. The treatment plant is working like a dream."
Further into the discussion, Ryan read an email from Trappe's engineer, also offering support of effluent being moved to the lagoon for storage rather than directly to the town's treatment plant since the treated effluent may not be good for the treatment plant.
After a discussion and more explanation on the request, the motion was approved by commissioners under the condition that MDE approves Lakeside discharging via truck directly to Trappe's lagoon. A letter has been sent to MDE seeking approval for this request.

title: Injured bald eagle rescued from Chester River
author: DOMINIQUE ELLIS FALCON Dellisfalcon2@washcoll.edu
content:
Injured bald eagle rescued from Chester River

 August 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOMINIQUE ELLIS FALCON Dellisfalcon2@washcoll.edu | Section: News 
 
 358
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Monday, staff from Washington College's Center for Environment and Society rescued an adult bald eagle from the banks of the Chester River.Director of the center's River and Field Campus, David Kramer, noticed a post on Facebook asking someone for help with an eagle who seemed to have an injured wing and foot and was hobbling around on a dock over the river. Kramer, who is an experienced avian rescuer, responded to the post and offered his services.
Quickly, he and two other center staffers hopped in a truck and made their way over to where the bird had been sighted.
After the bird tried to fly across the river and crashed into the water, they drove across the bridge and requested access to a resident's backyard to capture the raptor who had made his way onto the opposite shore.
Kramer was able to approach the bird swiftly, pin him gently and secure the animal's feet before lifting him up. The bird rode shotgun in center staffer Emma Cease's lap on the way back to the Center for Environment and Society's headquarters, where he was inspected and placed in a crate until he could be picked up by TriState Bird Rescue.
Kramer, who has years of experience rescuing, researching and working with bald eagles and other birds and is a listed rescuer with Tristate Bird Rescue and Moon Owl Raptor Center, urged people in the Chesapeake Bay region to call in the professionals if they spot an eagle or other large bird who is need of help.
"You can look up a few local rehabbers, and you can always call the Department of Natural Resources for help. If you don't have handling experience don't approach the bird," Kramer cautioned. "Bald eagles have three sharp ends, if they can get you with one, they will. The thing is to get the bird safely restrained. We want to limit injury to people as well as the bird."
Washington College's Center for Environment and Society is no stranger to bird encounters.
In the last year, staff at its Foreman's Branch Bird Observatory have caught, identified, banded and released over 13,000 birds representing more than 125 species.

title: GOP energy policy is bad news for Talbot County
author: JIM BRUCE
content:
GOP energy policy is bad news for Talbot County

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JIM BRUCE | Section: Columns 
 
 593
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The recently released 2024 Republican policy platform pumps its fists on energy as a central focus. Unfortunately, the policy recommendations obsess on problems we don't have, and ignore problems we do have. Talbot County will suffer from such policy.The GOP energy plank states: "We will DRILL BABY DRILL and we will become Energy Independent and even Dominant again."
The truth is that the U.S. is already "dominant" in world energy production. The latest annual statistics show that the U.S. is the No. 1 producer in the world for oil and liquid fuels, for natural gas, and for nuclear and renewable energy. China is No. 1 only in coal production, but we don't need or want more coal production. Natural gas and renewables are cheaper and far cleaner. There has not been a new coal-fired plant built in a decade in the U.S., and demand for coal dropped 8% just last year.
Talbot County would not benefit from more coal production and consumption, as the GOP wants.
By 2016, Maryland utilities had spent billions of dollars to clean up their polluting emissions, but Maryland had no control over the utilities in five states upwind from us who were only intermittently using their emission controls on coal-fired plants.
As much as 70% of Maryland's ozone air pollution during the May-October season was attributable to those out-of-state plants. (Ozone and nitrous oxide emissions from coal-fired plants exacerbate asthma in children and adversely affect the Chesapeake Bay.)
Maryland petitioned the federal EPA to require these out-of-state coal-fired plants to use their emissions controls continuously. EPA issued the order, protecting Maryland citizens from coal-fired utilities over which the state had no jurisdiction. EPA is vital to protecting Maryland air quality from out-of-state sources of air pollution.
Unfortunately, in addition to expanding coal production, Trump's allies call for weakening EPA and its regulations. This is all bad news for Talbot County if it means returning to the situation of earlier years in which prevailing winds brought air pollution from coal-fired utilities in other states.
While the GOP policy platform seeks to solve energy problems that don't exist, it inexplicably ignores real problems, in particular, climate change. The entire 16-page GOP policy platform covering all subjects never mentions climate change or global warming at all. In fact, the policy recommends "cancel the electric vehicle mandate ..." For the GOP, climate change is not a problem worth mentioning.
We in Talbot County will especially suffer the consequences of ignoring climate change. We sweltered this summer in triple digit heat indexes. In 2022, researchers at Penn State University projected the effect of climate change for sea level rise, changing temperature patterns, and changing rainfall patterns in counties in Maryland and four adjacent states.
They report that in 1980 to 2019 sea levels around Talbot County rose over 7 inches and will rise an additional half foot to 2.4 feet by 2070, inundating low areas in the 600-mile Talbot County coastline.
On average Talbot County experiences high temperatures reaching or exceeding 95 degrees on six days per year. Within the next 50 years we can expect 28–50 days in which temperatures reach 95 degrees. Annual rainfall in Talbot County will likely increase by an average of 2-3 inches. Across the Mid-Atlantic region stream temperatures increased roughly 2.5 degrees from 1960 to 2010. This trend reduces dissolved oxygen in stream water and threatens the survival of rockfish, oysters and soft-shelled crabs.
We in Talbot County should ask Republican candidates, is climate change truly not worth talking about?
Jim Bruce is a resident of St. Michaels and is a member of the Talbot County Democratic Forum.

title: Anglers report multiple sightings of tarpon in Maryland waters
author: JOE ZIMMERMANN Maryland Department of Natural Resources
content:
Anglers report multiple sightings of tarpon in Maryland waters

 August 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JOE ZIMMERMANN Maryland Department of Natural Resources | Section: News 
 
 749
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Scouting for red drum near the Hoopers Island Lighthouse on Aug. 1, Capt. Tom Weaver saw something roll in the flat, calm waters a couple hundred yards away.He looked for the wake and followed a disturbance in the distance. When he got close and shut the motor off, he saw huge shapes under the water. The fish looked familiar—and Weaver soon realized he recognized them from his years fishing in the Florida Keys.
"When you run out of Annapolis, you don't expect an hour and a half later to be running across a tarpon," Weaver, who runs a charter business Fish With Weaver, said. "My brain took a few minutes to process."
Tarpon are large, athletic fish renowned for how they fight the line, with both incredible stamina and an ability to leap out of the water, their bodies thrashing in the air.
In a video Weaver recorded, hulking 6-foot-long fish lurk motionless under the surface. They were tanks, he said, each maybe 80 to 100 pounds. He went after the group of seven or eight tarpon for a while and got a bite, though he didn't have the right gear to pull one in. "Really, we were not ready to see tarpon," he said.
Erik Zlokovitz, Maryland Department of Natural Resources' recreational fisheries outreach coordinator, said the department is getting more reports of tarpon, usually associated with warmer southern waters, in Maryland this summer.
"We have seen tarpon in Maryland's section of the bay historically, but the number of fish spotted recently is unusual," Zlokovitz said. "This year is the first time we've gotten multiple reports of schools of tarpon, and not just a stray fish."
Tarpon are known to come into the southern Chesapeake Bay in the summer, and anglers target tarpon in the coastal waters off the Eastern Shore of Virginia. But it's usually rare for anyone to encounter a tarpon in Maryland waters.
In 2019, DNR staff sampling for striped bass netted and released a small tarpon near Kent Island. Angler Brittany Growe hooked a 6-foot-long tarpon near Smith Island and the Virginia border in July 2020. Her fishing partner touched the leader before the hook pulled out with the fish next to the boat, making it an official catch and release.
Older references also note occasional sightings. In the 1927 publication for the U.S. Bureau of Fisheries "Fishes of the Chesapeake Bay," authors Samuel F. Hildebrand and William C. Schroeder wrote that tarpon "was reliably reported by fisherman in the southern parts of Chesapeake Bay" and referred to an earlier list of fish species in Maryland from 1878 that reported a tarpon caught off Crisfield.
Weaver said when he told people about his find, two other guides said they had also seen tarpon in Maryland in the last week. He saw a school of tarpon moving fast in the Bay last year too, and people he's spoken with have only seen tarpon in Maryland waters in the past two years.
Zlokovitz said it's too early to tell if the apparent uptick in tarpon is an "anomaly or the start of a trend."
Water temperatures have risen in the Chesapeake Bay in recent decades, and climate change is affecting Maryland's biodiversity. A number of warm-water fish species—from Florida pompano to cobia, cutlassfish, and pompano dolphinfish—are becoming more common in the Bay and the Atlantic coast.
Warming waters could be drawing tarpon farther north, or they could be traveling farther in pursuit of food sources like menhaden and shrimp, DNR scientists said. It could also be a larger northern migration this year. A surfcaster in Rhode Island caught a tarpon this summer.
Water temperatures have increased in the Chesapeake Bay over the last three decades, with most DNR monitoring stations showing an increase between 1 and 2 degrees Fahrenheit since 1999. This summer has been hot as well, with monitoring stations recording above average temperatures near Hoopers Island, according to DNR data.
When Weaver saw the tarpon, he thought they were "slurping on blue crabs" that were swimming nearby. Regretting that he didn't have fly rods on board, he pulled out the smallest paddle tails he could find and did his best to hook one. Next time, he's bringing crab flies and plans to be ready. He wants to catch a tarpon in Maryland, or even just get one to jump.
"I'm gonna have a dedicated tarpon setup on the boat—rig and fly," Weaver said. "I'm not going to make that mistake again."
Tarpon are generally considered undesirable for eating, and DNR officials recommend anglers only pursue tarpon for catch-and-release fishing.

title: Biologist speaks on fish vs. development
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Biologist speaks on fish vs. development

 August 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 420
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It would seem when developers plan projects — residential and commercial — the question that often goes unasked is, "What about the fish?"On Monday evening, those attending the meeting of the Friends of Mill Creek, held at Calvert Marine Museum, got a glimpse of data compiled over several decades by the Maryland Department of Natural Resources' Fisheries Ecosystem Assessment Division.
The presentation from division biologist Marek Topolski affirmed that the increase of "impervious surfaces" adversely affects water quality, which results in the dwindling of the fish population.
Retired educator and Solomons resident Ted Haynie, who is one of the organizers of the advocacy group, said talk of additional residential development within the creek's watershed has raised concern on several levels, including the environment.
Haynie said the watershed's impervious surface percentage is currently at 20%.
"What happens to the rain?" Haynie asked.
According to the state natural resources website, what happened to the Severn River watershed near Annapolis has been labeled the "worst case" example of development's impact on Maryland tidal fisheries.
Topolski noted that the 14-mile long Severn River was once abundant with yellow perch.
The "heyday" for perch fishing in the Anne Arundel County river — a tributary of the Chesapeake Bay — was in the 1950s and 1960s.
During the 1970s, development in the river's vast watershed impacted water quality and lead to abnormalities that diminished the spawning habitat.
Topolski said when a watershed reaches the 10% level of impervious surfaces it results in "a tipping point for bad things that fisheries management cannot compensate."
In 1989, a yellow perch fishery run by the state was closed.
"Good planning can conserve a well-functioning watershed for future fisheries," Topolski said. "We realize we can't do it ourselves. We need help and the help is the land use planner.
Topolski said the department's resource managers do work with local planners.
"We talk 'fish,'" he said. "We see things from the fish's perspective."
"What do we do about it?" Haynie asked. "We're at 20%. You've seen it; t's all downhill. There is hope there are things that can be done."
Monday's meeting also included an update from Mary Hoover, the American Chestnut Land Trust's Southern Maryland Conservation Alliance coordinator, on the results of the 2024 "water quality blitz."
This year, 128 sites were tested for nitrogen by 14 volunteer organizations in five counties. According to results posted online, water quality at 100 test sites was deemed good while six sites were found to have poor water quality.
"We have seen an improvement, but we need to do more testing," Hoover said.
To review the summary, go to www.acltweb.org/index.php/2024-blitz/.

title: Residents get update on Cambridge flood mitigation project
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Residents get update on Cambridge flood mitigation project

 August 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 587
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The City of Cambridge held the first of what it says will be multiple "periodic" public meetings to share progress and get feedback on its flood mitigation project along the shore of the Choptank River.The city's Make Cambridge Resilient Flood Mitigation Project Manager Larry White said the city will continue to reach out to the public throughout the entire design process of the project.
"This is the kickoff," he said. "There'll be other meetings where we get you up to date on what's transpired and what's come out of our studies."
The presentation, which was held at the Cambridge branch of the Dorchester County Public Library on Aug. 21, brought many residents who had questions about how the project, which will stretch from Gerry Boyle Park at Great Marsh to the mouth of Cambridge Creek, will affect their properties and the city in general.
The plan for the project includes three main elements: a living shoreline, earth and rock embankments and stormwater management to alleviate flooding.
The city is funding the two-phase project through the grants from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, a grant from the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, the Resilient Maryland Revolving Loan Fund and city budget funds. In June, it announced that the FEMA had awarded the city $1.7 million for the first phase of the project.
The city said FEMA is also reserving $16 million for the second phase of the project. The total $17.7 million in grant money is being awarded through FEMA's Hazard Mitigation Assistance grant.
During the meeting, representatives from the city, the state, the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science at Horn Point, and BayLand Consultants and Designers spoke about climate change, flooding and the project itself.
Maryland Secretary of Emergency Management Russell Strickland talked about the importance of mitigating disasters prior to them occurring. He said mitigation cuts down on the need for response and on the costs associated with recovery.
"So this would be what I would call a transformative mitigation project for the city," he said. "And it's important that it be projects like that because that will have a greater result and a greater benefit for more people."
Horn Point Lab professor Ming Li talked about sea level rise across the Chesapeake Bay and increases in flooding. He said working with nature can be better than fighting with it.
"So that's why there's a lot of interest in a lot of places all around the world to look at nature-based solutions," he said.
Megan Barniea, a BayLand senior project engineer, said no design decisions have been made yet, but the plan is to build upon those three main project elements of a living shoreline, embankments and stormwater management.
Horn Point Lab, which is supporting the project, will help to optimize the living shoreline design, assess flood risk reduction, monitor living shoreline performance and evaluate ecological co-benefits of the project.
Barniea said the project partners will be coming back to the public to get feedback on a 30% design plan. The plan, which she expects will be ready to show in early 2025, will include the footprint of proposed features, elevations and dimensions, and a construction cost estimate.
After the presentation, residents asked questions about the project, including how the project will affect private docks and public access to the waterfront.
White said the city and its partners will work with each property owner, and residents will keep access to their docks. He said there will be some public access to the living shoreline.
"I mean it can't be everywhere, but there will be access," he said.

title: UMCES receives grant for migratory bird conservation efforts
author: UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE
content:
UMCES receives grant for migratory bird conservation efforts

 August 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE | Section: News 
 
 462
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE — The U.S. National Science Foundation and the Paul G. Allen Family Foundation today announced a $1.12 million grant to the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science and the American Bird Conservancy.A partnership between UMCES Appalachian Laboratory researchers and the Appalachian Mountain Joint Venture will apply big data to conservation planning for the benefit of birds and people in the Appalachian Mountains.
The researchers will use remote sensing and interpretable machine learning to characterize aspects of forests and landscape structure that provide habitat for birds during migration through the Appalachian Mountains. They will apply this information to forest management planning through a collaborative process that balances the habitat needs of birds with the objectives of local human communities. The research and process will ultimately transform our ability to sustain healthy bird populations throughout the Appalachian region.
"Conservation planning to restore and sustain migratory bird populations has been occurring for many years," said Emily Cohen, an associate professor at UMCES. "But these efforts have been singularly focused on increasing habitats for birds during the breeding season, while habitat needs during migration have been largely overlooked. The focus of this project is to provide the information necessary to include migratory habitat needs, along with breeding, into planning efforts and then to develop those plans together with the communities living in those areas."
This research is one of 10 projects receiving funding under the Partnership to Advance Conservation Science and Practice program, a first-of-its-kind collaboration between NSF and the Paul G. Allen Family Foundation. Now in its second year, the program is designed to catalyze deep collaboration between researchers advancing basic science and conservation partners engaging in on-the-ground conservation.
The projects focus on a range of species—from migrating songbirds and grizzly bears to Venus flytraps and the Hawaiian honeycreeper—and the outcomes will have far-reaching implications for biodiversity and conservation, policy and the economy.
"The fundamental knowledge these projects create, even though related to specific species, will unlock innovative conservation efforts across a broader range of threatened species and ecosystems," said Lara Littlefield, executive director for programs and partnerships at the Paul G. Allen Family Foundation. "For instance, studying whether some microorganisms in mosquitoes can help limit the spread of malaria among birds in Hawaii could ultimately limit disease spread among other animals more broadly."
Each project extends basic science into on-the-ground conservation to address critical knowledge and data gaps, enabling greater real-world impact to benefit species and ecosystems.
"The unique partnerships this program creates forge a roadmap to broader conservation action by uniting the skills, expertise and tools needed to address the most urgent threats to our natural world," said Susan Marqusee, NSF assistant director for biological sciences. "These projects also will engage the public, policymakers, law enforcement and others in conservation through education, outreach and other broader impacts."

title: White House OKs Maryland wind energy project
author: KATHARINE WILSON Capital News Service
content:
White House OKs Maryland wind energy project

 September 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KATHARINE WILSON Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 959
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Offshore wind energy is coming to Maryland, and with it, union jobs.The Biden administration on Thursday approved Baltimore-based US Wind's project to build offshore wind turbines about 10 miles off the coast of Ocean City, Maryland.
The offshore wind farm could generate over two gigawatts of wind energy and power over 718,000 homes, according to the Department of the Interior.
President Joe Biden said in a statement that the wind energy industry had been "struggling to gain a foothold" in the years before he came into office.
"From manufacturing and shipbuilding to port operations and construction, this industry will support tens of thousands of good-paying and union jobs, provide reliable clean power to homes and businesses, strengthen our power grid against outages, and help reduce pollution — all while protecting biodiversity and marine ecosystems," the president said.
Maryland Energy Administration Director Paul Pinsky called the Biden administration's action "an important step forward in the effort to bring clean, renewable energy production to Maryland's coast."
"Today's announcement underscores the careful, comprehensive and collaborative environmental analysis that has gone into these projects," Pinsky said in a statement.
The Maryland project is the tenth commercial-scale offshore wind energy project approved by the Biden administration. Combined, the projects are projected to generate 15 gigawatts of clean energy, half of Biden's goal of 30 gigawatts of offshore wind-produced energy by 2030.
The Maryland project includes up to 114 wind turbines, four offshore substation platforms and a meteorological tower. There will be three phases to the US Wind project, two of which — called MarWin and Momentum Wind — have already received offshore renewable energy certificates from the state.
Energy is set to start flowing in December 2028 from the first phase of the project. The final project is expected to be completed in late 2027 or early 2028, according to the plan submitted by US Wind.
The approval is a win for Maryland environmental groups and the state government, which have been working for offshore wind power in the state for around 10 years.
Starting in 2013, the Maryland legislature passed a series of bills to set offshore wind energy projects in motion.
The state set a goal in 2023, through the Promoting Offshore Wind Energy Resources Act, to generate 8.5 gigawatts of power from offshore wind by 2031.
This goal has hit some road bumps along the way, including the withdrawal of Denmark-based Ørsted's planned offshore wind projects in January.
US Wind won the competitive lease sale of the 46,970 acres of federal ocean waters in 2014.
"By moving away from reliance on dirty fossil fuel energy and building renewable energy, Marylanders will be able to breathe cleaner air and benefit from new clean energy jobs," Maryland Sierra Club Chapter Director Josh Tulkin said in a statement Thursday.
Jamie DeMarco, the federal campaigns coordinator for the Chesapeake Climate Action Network, said in an interview with Capital News Service that the Maryland wind farm is a milestone in moving offshore energy generation forward in Maryland.
"This is a huge undertaking to build an entire machine to deploy offshore wind, but once that machine is built, it'll be able to hum and crank out new domestic energy, and clean energy that's going to help us clean the air and meet our climate goals," DeMarco said.
Offshore wind turbines have been coming online across the East Coast, DeMarco said, but this will be the first operational offshore wind facility in Maryland.
Environmental advocates aren't the only celebrating parties. Union officials are touting the jobs set to be created by the wind farm.
Almost 2,680 jobs annually over seven years could be created during the development and construction phase of the wind farm, according to the Interior Department.
US Wind's planned permanent offshore wind components production facility, called Sparrows Point Steel in Sparrows Point, Baltimore — the former home of Bethlehem Steel — is forecast to generate jobs for steelworkers.
The Baltimore Bethlehem Steel mill, which closed in 2012, was once the largest steel producer in the world. Sparrows Point Steel will bring steelworker jobs back to Maryland, DeMarco said, in a way that hasn't been seen since the closure of Bethlehem.
Jim Strong, the offshore wind sector assistant for the United Steelworkers International Union, told CNS Thursday that the facility is expected to bring in over 500 jobs. The project will help not only steelworkers, Strong said, but other union trades as well.
"It's about addressing our climate crisis, about creating new green energy jobs — these will be high paid union jobs," Strong said.
Strong has served as a liaison between the union and US Wind. He said that the Sparrows Point facility has the opportunity to become a "central hub" for monopile production on the Atlantic Ocean. Monopiles, steel cylinders, are used for wind turbines, bridges and other projects, he said.
US Wind is a subsidiary of Italian company Renexia SpA.
The project has some detractors, like Rep. Andy Harris (R-Maryland), who represents the Eastern Shore.
"Offshore wind industrialization comes at a heavy cost to our marine life and environment, and is an incredibly expensive way to generate electricity," Harris said on X in July. "We should never allow foreign owned companies to control our energy supply — much less harm our environment while doing it."
The federal Bureau of Ocean Energy Management's director, Elizabeth Klein, said in a statement that the Maryland project "reflects the best available science and invaluable insights from Tribes, government agencies, local communities, industry leaders, ocean users, and environmental groups gathered during our extensive environmental review process."
"As we continue to support the undeniable momentum we see along our coasts, our focus remains on fostering responsible energy development, while protecting marine life and ecosystems," she said.
Democrats in the state, including Gov. Wes Moore, have been supportive of the project. Moore signed a memorandum of understanding with the federal government in June supporting offshore wind production.

Nanticoke River 2023 report card shows improvements in Lower Nanticoke

 September 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 625
 Words 

 Read News Document

 VIENNA — Although many of the results from the 2023 Nanticoke River Report Card were similar to the 2022 report card results, the Lower Nanticoke region saw improvements last year.Nanticoke Watershed Alliance Deputy Director Beth Wasden said in looking over data from the past 15 years, it is clear that the Lower Nanticoke region — which spans from Riverton to Nanticoke — has seen continued growth.
"It's a very hopeful thing to see," she said. "And I'm certainly hoping that as we continue to examine data every year, that we'll continue to see improvements in the Lower Nanticoke and hopefully in other regions as well."
The 2023 report measured algae, nitrogen, phosphorus, water clarity, dissolved oxygen and the concentration of ions in the six regions of the Nanticoke.
Wasden noted that two of the watershed's six regions received Fs for total nitrogen measures. According to the report, excessive nitrogen in waterways can fuel algal blooms and cause low dissolved oxygen and fish kills. The report says that four regions — Marshyhope Creek, Delaware Headwaters, Lower Nanticoke and Lower Creeks — saw improved total nitrogen grades in 2023.
Wasden said although it may not sound good that two regions are getting Fs in this category, it's good to see improvement elsewhere.
"When you've had years and years of most of the regions scoring Fs in total nitrogen, it's a really bright spot to see some of those regions performing better," she said.
Wasden also talked about some of the negative results in the report card. She said that there continues to be impairment issues on some creeks. According to the report card, Barren, Quantico and Rewastico creeks continue to be "heavily impaired."
The report card also showed that the Upper Nanticoke and Broad Creek regions, which received Cs overall, scored the worst. According to the report card, this continues a long-term trend.
Wasden said everyone should care about the Nanticoke River because it is a big part of the Nanticoke River watershed.
"A lot of us enjoy participating or using the river, whether we're fishing or kayaking," she said. "Maybe we have a property along one of (its) waterways. Maybe we like going to a park that's along the river or one of the creeks. So it's a big part of our lives, and we should want to support clean water to have healthy wildlife and also healthy people to enjoy the water."
Wasden said that when the water is polluted, people might not be able to use it or go in it, which can "take some enjoyment out of our lives."
"Especially when you think about, for example, how hot this past summer was, just being able to get into a healthy body of water can really help you cool down," she said.
Laura McCann is in her second year as a creekwatcher with the Nanticoke Watershed Alliance. As a creekwatcher, McCann helps calibrate water testing equipment and collects water samples at two sites. She helps with testing, including measuring depth and clarity of the water and testing pH levels.
McCann said that along fertilizers can be detrimental to the river's health. She said that keeping the river healthy helps keep the environment healthy.
"If you don't watch that health, it can affect everything," she said.
McCann said she hopes the steady improvements in the river's health continue. She said putting out report cards and other outreach will help.
"Water reports, things like that, will help build education and help other people understand the importance of what we're trying to do," she said.
Those interested in learning more about the Nanticoke Watershed Alliance can visit nanticokeriver.org or visit them on Facebook or Instagram. Those interested in volunteering with the organization can register to become a creekwatcher next season. Wasden said registration will open in January and training will be in March.

title: Fish love oyster reefs, anglers should too
author: HERB FLOYD
content:
Fish love oyster reefs, anglers should too

 September 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HERB FLOYD | Section: Columns 
 
 551
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Fishing has always been a way to bring family together. As a young boy, my dad and I would go fishing as often as possible. Then, when I had a son, he joined us and the three of us fished together. When my son is in town, fishing together remains our top priority to this day. My wife also enjoys being on the water and we spend a lot of time on the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries fishing and boating together.The challenge and the anticipation of catching a fish on any given cast is one of my favorite things about fishing. What's not to love about spending the day out on the Chesapeake Bay, dedicating countless hours trying to entice a fish below the surface that you're not even sure is there or even hungry. Another important thing about fishing is understanding the proper and careful release after the thrill of the catch.
As a Maryland native, I've had the pleasure to explore some of the region's most unique fishing locations. The Chesapeake Bay itself is the country's largest estuary and an angler's paradise. But in such a big body of water, it's easy to feel overwhelmed trying to find the fish.
The key to finding fish is structure and their prey. Oyster reefs provide both and, therefore, attract fish and their food.
Maryland waters have more than 100 oyster reefs, both artificial and protected sanctuary reefs. The state also has five tributaries being targeted for large-scale oyster restoration by 2025. Although these protected sanctuaries are closed for oyster harvest, they make exceptional angling spots.
Fish and the critters they eat love using the complex structure of oyster reefs for habitat. Where oyster reefs have been lost, specially-designed artificial reef structures called reef balls are used to establish high quality, three-dimensional reef habitat as soon as they hit the water — a feat that would take a natural oyster reefs hundreds of years to achieve.
Better yet, the fish absolutely love them.
Striped bass, white perch, both red and black drum, speckled trout, spot, croaker, flounder, toadfish and even invasive species like blue catfish can be caught around oyster reefs. These invasives are getting much more popular to target for their abundance and fun fight. And eating them is one of the best ways to mitigate their threat to the Bay ecosystem.
For those looking for a new challenge, there's nothing like the upcoming Maryland Rod & Reef Slam to test your creativity and angling skills. This annual fishing tournament encourages anglers to target the greatest variety of fish species, rather than just fish size by fishing over Maryland's restored oyster reefs. From oyster toadfish to red drum, everything counts.
In previous tournaments, over 16 different species have been recorded, demonstrating the diversity of life that oyster reefs support. When I won the 2021 Rod & Reef Slam, I landed 11 different species including catching the only speckled trout.
I have fished several of the reef locations including Tilghman, Harris Creek, Tred Avon River, Clint Waters/Cooks Point on the Choptank River, Manokin River and Bill Burton pier. I use a variety of bait, but it's hard to beat a piece of bloodworm.
The week of Sept. 7, I'll once again be fishing for oyster restoration in the 2024 Maryland Rod and Reef Sam. I challenge you to join me.

title: Hummingbird enthusiasts soak up last weeks before birds fly south
author: Tom McCall
content:
Hummingbird enthusiasts soak up last weeks before birds fly south

 September 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: News 
 
 465
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Sandy Brown has 16 hummingbird feeders set up in her back yard, most of them bright red.This has been an endeavor of many years, and she delights with every chirp, swoop and the buzzing noise the birds' wings make.
"You could call it an obsession," Brown said.
"I have had them drinking from my hand this year for the first time ever. I keep a hummingbird diary. I could give you dates and times of when I have seen the most hummingbirds," Brown said.
She says she has never seen anything but ruby throated hummingbirds, and she takes keen note of their distinct plumage and behaviors.
"They are crazy and they have sword fights. You can tell when they are displaying aggressive behavior because their tails flare out," she said.
According to the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, in the summer, ruby-throated hummingbirds can be found throughout the eastern half of the United States and within parts of southern Canada. They are commonly spotted in Maryland during warmer months.
But their time in the area is coming to an end. In the winter, ruby-throated hummingbirds travel to Mexico and Central America, following warmer temperatures.
"If you had called a week ago, you would have been hit in the head by a hummingbird. They are starting to go away," Brown said. "The males go first and the females follow. It is mostly juveniles now."
For little birds, they drink a lot.
"I was refilling my feeders twice a day up until Monday or Tuesday. I saw a bit of a slowdown. I can count little fat guys like little Hindenburgs. They are loading up for the season," she said.
Wayne Bell, a birder and ecologist, leads groups to find birds. He gets out with muddy boots and a pair of binoculars often.
"We were on a bird walk on Sunday or Monday, and several people were saying they were having lots of activity at their hummingbird feeders," Bell said. "I have noticed the same thing. It is particularly interesting because there wasn't a lot of activity earlier in the year after the birds arrived from the south. They migrate across the Gulf of Mexico, so they have a long way to go."
"All of a sudden we seem to have a lot. That is due to juveniles hatching out. They are getting ready to migrate south and doing what some people call staging. They are tanking up on sugars and protein to get ready for their flight south," Bell said, later adding that the large number of sightings may indicate that it was a good year for hummingbird reproduction.
Though sightings are becoming less common, Brown has not put a lid on this year's hummingbird season yet. She leaves her feeders out until December, hoping to glimpse the last of the visitors on their way south.

title: Riverkeeper works to keep Chesapeake Bay, local waterways clean and healthy
author: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com
content:
Riverkeeper works to keep Chesapeake Bay, local waterways clean and healthy

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 525
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GALENA — This is Zach Kelleher's sixth season as the Sassafras Riverkeeper for ShoreRivers, but he fell in love with local waterways when he was a young boy growing up along the Eastern Shore.The most important part of his position, according to Kelleher, is collecting the water quality data and sharing it with communities so they can make informed decisions and be educated about issues like algal blooms and toxicity.
Easton-based non profit ShoreRivers, the organization under which the Riverkeepers work, is focused on a mission to "protect Maryland's Eastern Shore waterways through science-based advocacy, restoration, education, and engagement," according to their website. They cover the Sassafras, Chester, Choptank and Miles-Wye rivers to combat pollution and protect the waterways.
"Everything that I do as a riverkeeper and that we do at ShoreRivers is grounded in science and data, which allows us to be an unbiased source for the waterways," said Kelleher.
Through their bacteria monitoring program, riverkeepers take samples every week and post them via a variety of means to try to reach as many people as possible, because community members deserve to know that data and what to do about it, according to Kelleher.
"The more we can communicate that data effectively to a variety of audiences…the better off we are, the better off the rivers are," said Kelleher.
In regards to the Chesapeake Bay's recent C+ grade, which was the highest in over 20 years, Kelleher points out that the Bay is dealing with 300 to 400 years of colonization and habitat destruction, while the community only started being proactive about the Bay's health roughly 40 to 50 years ago.
"So I think it's very easy to be pessimistic about it, but I think it's also really important to be stubbornly optimistic about it," said Kelleher.
He noted that, for example, it takes 40 to 80 years for nitrogen to reach waterways after being applied to a field or backyard, because it goes through the groundwater, which means we're still seeing the impacts of nitrogen from many years ago.
"So it's going to take time," said Kelleher. "There's a little bit of a delay between the work that we're doing today and the impact on water quality, but all of the data and indicators do point that we are moving in that positive direction overall."
Kelleher also pointed out the importance of incorporating the various impacts of climate change into his work. For example, it's been dry the past two years, causing huge spikes in water salinity. Due to this, certain species are thriving and water clarity and quality are improving in some areas. Meanwhile, more freshwater-oriented systems like the Sassafras are struggling with the increased salinity.
Being a Riverkeeper is ever changing with the tides and seasons, Kelleher noted. In the colder months, Kelleher does a lot of policy and advocacy work involving the legislature at the state and federal levels. But when the spring and summer roll around, the water quality monitoring programs, invasive species removal programs and volunteer programs ramp up.
"The primary job of the Riverkeeper is to be the voice for the rivers but also the voice for the communities. And they're very closely tied together," said Kelleher.

title: Bay battle: Conservation groups join lawsuit against development
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Bay battle: Conservation groups join lawsuit against development

 September 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 602
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A coalition of environmental organizations and neighboring Queen Anne's County residents are heading to court to challenge a decision by county commissioners to designate potential development on what they deem to be an environmentally sensitive waterfront property on Kent Island.On Aug. 8, eight neighboring Kent Island residents, along with Queen Anne's Conservation Association (QACA), Chesapeake Bay Foundation (CBF), and Chesapeake Wildlife Heritage, filed a petition for judicial review in Queen Anne's County Circuit Court regarding a recent County Board of Commissioners decision to designate sensitive land as a growth area for the Chesterhaven Beach Partnership, LLP project. An Application for Appeal was also filed with the County Board of Appeals objecting to the County's action.
By a 3-2 vote July 9, the Commissioners agreed to reconsider a request from Chesterhaven Beach Partnership, to "re-include" 101 acres of property on Piney Creek Road owned by Chesterhaven Beach Partnership, LLP back into the Chester Growth Area.
The Commissioners also placed a condition on the property development that the reconfiguration of the 180 vacant lots be limited to 90 vacant lots without the need for Critical Area Growth Allocation.
Citing concern for legal density, the Commissioners previously rejected the project proposal in May 2022. At that time the applicant was asked to seek a declaratory judgment or equivalent court ruling to establish the grandfathering of the property lots for review at a later date.
According to a press release from the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, "The County's decision undermines Maryland's Critical Area law by circumventing requirements to obtain local and state land use change approvals known as growth allocation. It also sidesteps requirements in state law related to designating growth areas in local comprehensive plans."
Opponents of the proposed development voiced concerns that the project is located in the critical area and is an ecosystem that supports wildlife and includes natural water quality filters as well as contains major conservation investments in the area. That includes 1.6 miles of shoreline onon the Chester River and Piney Creek,
According to the release, passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 1984, the Chesapeake Bay Critical Area law protects land within 1,000 feet of high tide or tidal wetlands to minimize the negative impacts of new development on Bay water quality, habitat, and wildlife.
"This is a uniquely valuable property from an environmental standpoint," said QACA Executive Director, Jay Falstad. "To turn it into a residential subdivision, as a majority of the Commissioners are now willing to do, would be to violate both Maryland's Critical Area law and the County's own Comprehensive Plan. It is deeply disappointing that our Commissioners, who have done so much for land preservation in the County, have been persuaded to go along with something so contrary to the conservation ethic to which this county is committed."
According to Falstad, the coalition's lawsuit argues that the lots were never grandfathered under the Critical Area law and therefore, don't exist; as well as that the Commissioners violated the Comprehensive Plan by 're-including' the property back into the Chester-Stevensville Growth Area after the adoption of the 2022 Comprehensive Plan that excludes the property from the Growth Area.
"Queen Anne's County is trying to redesignate property for growth that the courts have ruled as ineligible for such a change," said Alan Girard, CBF advocacy director, "The decision circumvents state law that protects the public's right to inform County land use decisions. The consequences of the County's action could harm the Chesapeake Bay and the people and wildlife that rely on it."
A public hearing is scheduled for Oct. 16 at 5 p.m.
Stevens Palmer LLC, on behalf of Chester Haven Beach Partnership, could not be reached for comment.

title: Eastern Shore Land Conservancy awarded Chesapeake WILD Program funds
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Eastern Shore Land Conservancy awarded Chesapeake WILD Program funds

 September 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 574
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Eastern Shore Land Conservancy has been awarded $500,000 through the Chesapeake Watershed Investments in Landscape Defense Program to address salt marsh loss and preserve wildlife habitat corridors between Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge and the Nanticoke River.David Satterfield, the conservancy's director of land conservation, said the this funding will be used to protect the landscape along the Nanticoke River, which they view as a transition area for wildlife.
"The expectation is that with sea-level rise expectations showing significant land loss in Dorchester County, Blackwater itself is going to see some significant impacts," he said. "And the wildlife life that is there — that is important to our culture — is going to need a place to transition."
Satterfield said that the Nanticoke, particularly north of U.S. Route 50, is seen as "a highly resilient, important landscape" for that transition.
"So we sort of designated everything north of 50 as a priority funding area for conservation easements to protect for that purpose," he said.
Satterfield said salt marsh, a habitat found in areas of Dorchester County, is important for species like the saltmarsh sparrow — a species "on the edge of being listed as an endangered species."
"When it gets too flooded, you obviously can't have it," Satterfield said about the habitat. "So we're essentially just creating transition zones for that habitat type. Preparing the landscape for that transition."
According to a news release from Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.), the Eastern Shore Land Conservancy is one of eight organizations receiving federal funding through the Chesapeake WILD Program, which is a program administered by the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation in partnership with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to support conservation, stewardship and enhancement of fish and wildlife habitats in the Bay. The program was created through bipartisan legislation.
Funding for the eight organizations — which include the Maryland Department of Agriculture, the Alliance for the Chesapeake Bay and the Maryland Department of Natural Resources — total $2.7 million and will be used for habitat and wetland restoration projects throughout Maryland's Chesapeake Bay watershed, according to the news release.
The announcement of the grant awards was made Friday by Van Hollen, Sen. Ben Cardin (D-Md.), Rep. Steny Hoyer (D-Md., 5th), Rep. Dutch Ruppersberger (D-Md., 2nd), Rep. John Sarbanes (D-Md., 3rd), Rep. Kweisi Mfume (D-Md., 7th), Rep. Jamie Raskin (D-Md., 8th) and Rep. Glenn Ivey (D-Md. 4th).
"Protecting and preserving the Chesapeake Bay is vital to both our environment and to the many Marylanders whose livelihoods depend on it," the lawmakers said in the news release. "The Chesapeake WILD program is central to our efforts to restore wildlife habitat and improve the overall health of the Bay — and these federal funds will go to critical projects across the state to help achieve these important goals."
According to the news release, the Chesapeake WILD Program is awarding 30 new conservation and restoration grants for projects this year. The news release says the grants total $8.9 million in federal support and leverage $13.7 million in matching funds, which result in a total conservation impact of $22.6 million.
Satterfield said the more money government invests into conservation easement programs to protect private lands, the more work land conservation groups can get done.
"The more investment we get, the more work we get done, the more we secure this landscape against the threats that are coming for it, the better," he said. "So we're excited to get the WILD money out there and get our community protected."
