title: Lakeside permit challenged in appellate court
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Lakeside permit challenged in appellate court

 September 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 917
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — In its opposition to a permit to spray treated wastewater on land in Talbot County, the Chesapeake Bay Foundation argues it wants to protect the quality of county streams and rivers.On Sept. 11, the foundation faced off with the Department of Environment in the Appellate Court of Maryland, where oral arguments were heard in the case.
The arguments concerned wastewater discharge at the Lakeside at Trappe development and whether or not a permit should have been issued.
The Maryland Department of the Environment issued a permit in December 2020, that was revised in October 2022, authorizing the discharge of treated wastewater through spray irrigation on land from the Trappe East Wastewater facility owned by the Town of Trappe and Lakeside developers.
The foundation argues the approach the department has taken is inappropriate and violates federal and state law. But MDE maintains the permit meets or exceeds groundwater quality standards.
The Chesapeake Bay Foundation was represented by attorney Paul Smail. Smail made three arguments to Judges Stuart Berger, Michael Wilson Reed and Andrea Leahy questioning whether or not the permit will be protective of the state's waters, whether the department complied with the applicable law in approving it and whether that decision was supported by substantial evidence.
"This is a discrete groundwater discharge permit," Smail said. "This is a discrete issue, and there is only one question before the court: Whether or not this permit ensures compliance with water quality standards."
Smail argued under state law, Lakeside would need to assure 100% uptake of nutrients, meaning that all nitrogen and phosphorus from the wastewater discharge must be taken up by vegetation so as to not pollute nearby land and water.
According to Smail, the department has not provided substantial evidence that net-zero discharge can be assured in this case.
"It's simply an error in the law," Smail said. "We assert that monitoring after the fact does not (determine) whether or not the department can make the decision to improve this permit in the first instinct."
Leahy interjected and said she believed the department was basing its approval of the permit on studies showing the nutrient uptake was going to be greater than the amount of nutrient that would be present in the wastewater after it was treated.
Leahy and Berger questioned why, with that evidence, it isn't considered an appropriate basis for the department to approve the permit. Leahy also questioned why the proposed irrigation, with its advanced system, was not seen as better than alternatives.
According to Smail, the nutrient management plan is subject to change. Without knowing the concentration of nitrogen already in the groundwater, any addition of effluent is extra nitrogen in the system that would find its way to Miles Creek.
Smail said in a perfect world the spray irrigation, considered advanced technology, would be welcomed, but there is still so much unknown it would be irresponsible to proceed without more data.
MDE ARGUMENT
Attorney Matthew Patrick Clagett represented the Maryland Department of the Environment. Clagett said the central question is whether or not the department should have issued the permit as a state discharge permit or a federal discharge permit. He raised a related issue — whether or not the permit and the nutrient management plant prevents nutrients from reaching the groundwater.
"We think the court should reject those arguments because the permit authorizes discharge only to groundwater protected exclusively by state law and the permit protects the groundwater quality by incorporating the nutrient management plan that achieves to complete the uptake in nutrients as required by Maryland law," Clagett said.
Clagett later argued the department determined it is already going to meet or exceed the groundwater quality standards at the point of discharge via spray irrigation. He described it as a high quality discharge and added that some of the limitations in the permit are stricter than the state's groundwater quality standards.
Clagett said the permit requires the effluent to be further treated by the strictly monitored nutrient management plan, which will ensure the complete uptake in nutrients so no nutrients should reach groundwater, let alone surface water.
Judges Reed and Leahy raised potential problems with spray irrigation.
"If there was a weather event because of climate change, how would that be dealt with in the future? If there was a, let's say, a hundred-year storm or 50-year storm," Reed asked, "is that being considered?"
Clagett said the permit has specific requirements on when spray irrigation can be applied. The nutrient management plan is a flexible document, Clagett said. If the department expects to see an increase in rainfall in the next decade, the nutrient management plan will need to be updated every three years. Clagett called it a form of "adaptive management."
"There's no doubt here that the spray irrigation field is a separate but related component of the wastewater system," Clagett said. "It has to be actively managed … The permittee will have to be paying attention to ponding and when they can spray and what the monitoring data is showing as far as the nutrient uptake."
Smail said "adaptive management" would run "afoul" in the requirements with state law. He said it is understandable that if something is not working to make adjustments down the road but without knowing what's out there and without having a baseline of information, it could lead to issues.
"What we have here is monitoring after the fact, after the approval, and that is especially problematic," Smail said.
A final decision was not made during the hearing. The court will issue a written decision based on the briefs and the record from the circuit court.

title: Global warming: 'Russian roulette with our planet'
author: LENA GILL
content:
Global warming: 'Russian roulette with our planet'

 September 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LENA GILL | Section: Columns 
 
 599
 Words 

 Read News Document

 United Nations Secretary General Antonio Guterres recently exclaimed in a speech about global warming: "We are playing Russian roulette with our planet."We also have recently heard that this is the warmest year on record. In Arizona's Maricopa County around Phoenix there so far have been 100 straight days with triple digit temperatures. In 2023, 645 deaths caused by the heat were recorded in Maricopa County, a more than 50% increase from the previous year.
Floods are happening around the world as the warming of oceans cause an increase in rain becoming stationary over land for long periods. Drought in Canada and the U.S. West increases the risk of fires. California has again this summer had some very large fires to fight, and residents are forced to flee.
To reduce global warming, the Biden administration passed the Inflation Reduction Act, the most consequential climate legislation in the world accompanied by $369 billion in climate investments. The private sector stepped in with $190 billion investment in electric vehicles and batteries. In addition, Biden persuaded Republicans to join him in the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, which contains billions more to build out a network of electric vehicle chargers as well as many other pollution reduction features.
On its first day, the Biden administration also rejoined the Paris Climate Agreement of 2016 from which former president Trump had withdrawn the U.S. If Trump wins in 2024 he will again withdraw from this international agreement. Trump also has suggested to a group of oil and gas executives that if they give $1 billion in donations to his campaign, he will remove regulations by closing down the Environmental Protection Agency. Is this legal?
There is some good news for Maryland.
The White House recently approved Baltimore-based US Wind's project to build off-shore wind turbines 10 miles off the coast of Ocean City. This project has been in the works for more than 10 years. It will be able to power 718,000 homes. Consequently, it will meet part of the goal in the Maryland Climate Solutions Now Act of 2022 of a 60% reduction of greenhouse gas emissions by 2031 (from 2006 levels). It also will create tens of thousands of new jobs. Gov. Wes Moore has been supportive of this project.
I have seen similar projects in Europe and think that they look very elegant. About 50% of Denmark's electricity consumption came from wind power in 2022, up from 19% in 2009.
To reach the Maryland climate goal of net zero emissions by 2045, we also need to install solar panels on roofs and geothermal heating and cooling in the ground, if we do not have suitable roofs. South-facing roofs are ideal for solar panels. I had solar panels installed on my south-facing roof in 2020, and my energy bill for heating, cooling and electric lights as well as charging my electric car amounts to $13 per month for my two-floor house. I also sell my surplus electricity for about $100 per month. Since 2022, homeowners who pay for a solar panel installation are allowed a federal tax credit of 30% of the cost of the installation.
It is up to each one of us to do what we can to be greener. One way is to not allow Trump to win the election in 2024. Last time he rolled back 110 climate and environmental policies. He gutted pollution standards for cars and trucks and revoked a rule preventing coal companies from dumping strip mining debris in local streams polluting drinking water in Appalachia. By the end of his term, Trump had won the prize as the most anti-environment president in our history.

title: Chesapeake Bay is cleaner but will miss 2025 pollution targets
author: MENNATALLA IBRAHIM AND ANDREA DURÁN Capital News Service
content:
Chesapeake Bay is cleaner but will miss 2025 pollution targets

 September 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MENNATALLA IBRAHIM AND ANDREA DURÁN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 575
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Chesapeake Bay is cleaner than it used to be but is falling short of 2025 targets for reducing pollution, federal and state officials and most of Maryland's congressional delegation said on Wednesday."The short version is that it's going in the right direction. The longer story is that we're still behind," Adam Ortiz, administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency's Mid-Atlantic region, said at a Capitol Hill press conference.
The bay failed to meet the agreement's main target, known as the total maximum daily load, which measures the total pollution in the Chesapeake Bay, Sen. Chris Van Hollen, D-Maryland, said.
"The point of the 10-year plan is to create a pollution diet to reduce the amount of phosphorous, nitrogen and other pollutants in the bay," Van Hollen said. "That's a measurable target. That's how we know we're not going to hit it this year, so we need to redouble our efforts."
Despite missing the targets set in 2014 through 2025, Sen. Ben Cardin, D-Maryland, said he remained hopeful that the delegation can work together with experts at the EPA and other agencies to ensure the bay's health continues to improve.
Maryland Democratic Reps. Steny Hoyer, Dutch Ruppersberger, Kweisi Mfume and Jamie Raskin joined Cardin, Van Hollen, representatives from the EPA and the Maryland Department of Natural Resources.
The University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science gave the Chesapeake Bay an overall grade of a C+ in July, the highest grade the bay has received since 2002.
"I know that nobody would be thrilled with bringing home a grade of a C+, but the fact of the matter is, it is the highest grade we've seen in a long time," Van Hollen said. "We all want to do better, but I do want to stress that without the collective effort we see today, the bay would have died a long time ago."
The Chesapeake Executive Council signed the Chesapeake Bay Watershed Agreement in 2014 and established five strategies for the restoration and protection of the bay, its tributaries and surrounding lands.
Local, state and federal governments are required to enact the plan's management strategies and work with academic institutions, nongovernmental organizations, watershed groups and businesses and individuals, according to the 2014 agreement.
"You need cooperation between the federal government and the states, among the states, among state governments and private industry," said Van Hollen. "There are all sorts of sources of pollution today, and so we need to make sure everybody cooperates in producing pollution reduction."
Ortiz said that groups committed to improving the bay were in disarray when President Joe Biden's administration began almost four years ago.
"The states were suing the federal government, and states were pointing the fingers at each other for not making…progress," he said.
But since then, he said, the EPA has been able to bring the states together and hold them accountable.
"The Chesapeake Bay isn't just a bay," Cardin said. "The Chesapeake Bay has been one of the highest priorities for our Maryland congressional delegation. We've been focused on not only preserving but expanding our role and partnership with states, local governments and stakeholders."
Van Hollen emphasized the importance of identifying "measurable targets" of pollution reduction for long-term success, especially as climate change concerns surrounding the bay grow.
"I think we'll have to have a discussion about what the length of time for the next agreement should be. It may make sense to look at shorter time horizons," the senator said. "But you have to have a measurable target to hold people down."

author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com

Talbot County looks into restrictions on food processing residuals

 September 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 370

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Restrictions on the storage of food processing residuals are in the works for Talbot County.The county's Planning Commission and County Council held a preliminary work session Tuesday to discuss regulations for the residuals, which are animal waste from the food processing process.
Earlier this month, Caroline County passed a bill to restrict the storage of the residuals, which are often referred to as dissolved air flotation, or DAF, residuals. It came amid significant resident complaints of the noxious odors and bugs that stemmed from farming operations keeping the product in storage tanks.
Talbot County is looking to the neighboring county and hoping to be proactive.
"We think we need to get ahead of it," Planning Commission Vice Chairman Chip Councell said. He noted that Caroline and Wicomico counties were "behind the eight ball" in enacting legislation.
Councell said he met with the Talbot County Farm Bureau regarding potential restrictions.
"I think they would like to see some restrictions put on it, one being that any type of food residuals storage would have to be enclosed, so it couldn't be open-air," Councell said. "The storage of it would have to be used in that agricultural operation. A farmer couldn't store it for everybody in the neighborhood. He could store it for his operation only, so there wouldn't be commercial storage."
Councell clarified the county would focus on the storage of the residuals, not the land application. State legislation that went into effect July 1 created a formal permitting process for the usage of food processing residuals.
"There's a few bad actors out there that, frankly, I think see profit potential with handling the material," said Alan Girard, advocacy director at the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, during Tuesday's meeting.
While Wicomico County banned the storage of residuals, temporary storage for 45 days is allowed. In Caroline County, storage is allowed once a permit is acquired, as long as the storage tank has a closed top.
Councell said the 45-day allowance may be adjusted once the legislation begins to be drafted.
"I think 45 days might be a little bit tight," Councell said.
At the end of the work session, Planning and Zoning Director Brennan Tarleton said discussion of potential DAF legislation will be added to the Planning Commission's agenda in November.

title: Department of Natural Resources warns snakeheads may be breeding more than once
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content:
Department of Natural Resources warns snakeheads may be breeding more than once

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: Environment 
 
 199
 Words

 ANNAPOLIS — The invasive northern snakehead, recently given the name Chesapeake Channa, may be breeding twice each season, according to biologists with the Maryland Department of Natural Resources.This non-native fish species is on DNR's most wanted list. The department is urging anglers to catch as many as possible and to destroy them, if not eaten, rather than returning them to Maryland waters.
Joseph Love, a Maryland DNR biologist, wrote a report indicating that female snakeheads have been found with egg clutches in two different sizes, indicating two spawning seasons.
The average female Chesapeake Channa carries more than 63,000 eggs.
These fish have been in Maryland waters since 2002, when adult fish were released into a pond in Crofton. Rather than dying in unfamiliar waters, the fish thrived and have now spread to the Chesapeake Bay and the Susquehanna River. Love found the fish easily acclimate to different water temperatures and are voracious hunters.
"It is important to document life history traits of a species in different habitats because we know there is plasticity in the traits of fishes based on the environment," Love said. "This study fills a gap in what we know about Chesapeake Channa reproduction in the upper Chesapeake Bay."

title: Oxford Conservation Park project plans shared at event
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Oxford Conservation Park project plans shared at event

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News

 OXFORD — The hands-in-dirt work to complete the second phase of Oxford Conservation Park is expected to begin as early as February.During an Oxford Community Center Speaker Series event Thursday, Washington College Associate Director of Natural Land Stewardship Dan Small said they expect to start planting trees for the 30-acre project in February or March.
"And then around that same time, we'll start planting the wildflowers and the grasses on those 30 acres," he said.
The project will convert the South 30, or remaining 30 acres of cropland on the site, into habitat for wildlife.
This summer, Washington College's Natural Lands Project and the Eastern Shore Land Conservancy received funding from the Maryland Department of Natural Resources to partner with Talbot County to expand the park. Small said the project is funded for three years.
The event Thursday was organized by the Oxford Community Center and the Friends of Oxford Conservation Park. At the event, Small spoke about the details of the project and why it's important.
Washington College's Natural Lands Project aims to create a balance of productive farmland and wildlife habitat on public and private lands with a focus on implementing grassland, meadows and shrubland that support northern bobwhite, which are grassland birds also known as bobwhite quail.
Small said quail are an "umbrella species." He said creating and managing habitat that suits quail will, in turn, benefit a lot of other species. Small said grassland birds are suffering "serious population decline," so it is important to focus on quail.
The Oxford Conservation Park South 30 project plan will include a meadow, along with areas of cover for wildlife, which is intended to help grassland birds and other wildlife thrive.
Specifically, the plan is to convert about 24 acres of the 30-acre land into meadows and plant trees on the remaining 6 acres. Small said there will be hedgerows — or fences of trees and shrubs — on the land.
There are also plans to build a grass trail throughout the new meadow where visitors can walk and observe nature.
Small said they plan to plant 3,000 trees on the South 30. When it comes to the meadow, he said they will plant species complementary to what was planted on the existing 40 acres of the park, but the grasses will be shorter and planted at a lower rate to allow for more wildflowers.
"That has many benefits," he said about the wildflowers. "Obviously they're pollinators, but it's an increased food source and then just generally requires less management."
The project will also include follow-up work on the park's existing 40 acres to "bring it back to its original vibrant self," Small said. This follow-up work will include moving trees from areas they don't belong in, removing non-native species and thinning out grasses for wildflowers.
Small said the Eastern Shore Land Conservancy and the Natural Lands Project will oversee implementation with contractors and will continue to work with the county to offer management advice.
At the end of his presentation, Small cautioned that meadows don't look "the most scenic" the first year. He said it often takes a couple of years for the plant diversity to really come in.
Resident Pam Baker said the event was interesting and informative. Jim Brighton, who works in Oxford and visits the park often, said he thinks the project is "awesome."
"Dan and the work that he does is always top-notch," said Brighton, who is friends with Small. "And I'm very excited to see the changes that will be made."

title: Commissioners and ShoreRivers discuss bacteria issues 'swimmable' waters
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Commissioners and ShoreRivers discuss bacteria issues 'swimmable' waters

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 613
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — "In the middle of a drought, you're seeing that three-fourths of the Chester river is unswimmable," Kent County resident Crain Houston brought forward during the public comment section of the Kent County Commissioners' Sept. 17 meeting.Houston told commissioners he read that in a ShoreRivers "Swimmable Rivers" report published online Aug. 30.
He said on the Chester has 16 testing sites in total. Of those, 12 failed, indicating that bacteria levels at those sites made them unsafe. Commissioner John Price said he wished he could see a map to compare the failing sites with the four that weren't.
But Commission President Ron Fithian said in Rock Hall they're catching more crabs than he's seen in other years.
Fithian said when areas of rivers he called "bad water," crabbers would pull up pots with dead crabs in them. The crabs that aren't in pots would flee those toxic areas, making it a dead zone.
But there aren't many dead zones this time of year, he observed while crabbing during the week.
Fithian pointed out that in Ferry Point Park, the beach in Rock Hall, there was a swim at your own risk sign (now removed). He questioned why it was issued.
Houston commented he has not spotted many dead fish awash on shore either this year, another sign of healthier water.
With a drought and no signs of wastewater spillage, they wondered what could be the cause of the unsafe conditions found by ShoreRivers.
Price said they've always had a little trouble with bacteria, but these high numbers are concerning.
"I don't think anyone has an exact answer," Price said.
In an interview, ShoreRivers Chester RiverKeeper Annie Richards said she is not quite certain of the cause either, but she added some information about the ShoreRivers water quality monitoring program.
The organization runs two types of test it runs on the river. The first is the Tidal Water Health Program, which tests for nitrogen, phosphorus, clarity, temperature, salinity and dissolved oxygen. The other test is the one the commissioners were concerned with — The Swimmable Rivers program, which only tests for enterococci, an indicator species for E-coli.
Richards confirmed Houston's earlier assessment that all but four of 16 sites on the Chester failed this assessment.
She said the tests are administered weekly and involve volunteers drawing water samples every Thursday from Memorial Day to Labor Day. On Fridays, after going though the lab, the results are posted. The scoring, she said, is based on the Environmental Protection Agency's Healthy Beach Pass/Fail Rubric.
Seeing the results of Aug. 30, Richards said rainfall and runoff usually are the greatest cause for a high reading of bacteria.
Richards listed other possible sources for the high numbers could be illegal marine discharge (dumping from boats), failed septic systems, pet waste or wildlife waste.
She added bacteria is tricky because once it's in the water, it thrives in temperatures 80 degrees or above.
She produced ShoreRivers' map, comparing the failing sites with the four passing ones.
The four sites that passed were Quaker Neck Landing, Conquest Beach, Corsica River Yacht Club and Jackson Creek Landing, which all have similarities, Richards said.
"These sites are in deeper, wider sections of the river with better tidal flushing. In comparison, a place like Morgan Creek is our poorest performing site because it has a high land-to-water ratio," she said. "In these types of environments the impact of bacterial pollution are felt more acutely."
Richards said more testing is needed.
Fithian invited ShoreRivers to come to one of the commissioners' regularly scheduled meetings.
Houston thanked the commissioners for hearing his concerns.
"I know you all are being as proactive as you can be. It seems like this is the canary in a coal mine when you get this degree of unswimmable time," he said.

title: Herons on the Shore
author: JAY FALSTAD Nature Notes
content:
Herons on the Shore

 October 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JAY FALSTAD Nature Notes | Section: Herons On The Shore 
 
 624
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Here on the Eastern Shore, it's not uncommon for people to see that wonderful Chesapeake icon known as the great blue heron.The heron's large size, its blue/gray color, its long legs, neck and straight beak make this amazing bird a standout against other birds. From a distance, a blue heron in flight can look like a prehistoric Pterodactyl.
Just as distinctive as the bird itself, is its obnoxious call. James Michener described the heron in his book, "Chesapeake" as "fishing long-legs" and its obnoxious sound as "Kraaaaak." Both are perfect descriptions.
While the great blue heron is well recognized and well known on the Delmarva Penninsula, there are 10 other species in the heron class that inhabit — or at least visit — the Eastern Shore.
Some are more common than others. These include the bittern, black crowned night heron, green heron, great white heron, cattle egret, snowy egret, least bittern, yellow crowned night heron, little blue heron, and tri-colored heron.
Blue herons on the Delmarva Peninnsula mostly live here year-round — other herons use the Eastern Shore as a breeding ground and migrate back to southern locations like Florida or the islands during the winter months.
Most heron species have been present on the Eastern Shore for thousands of years. Herons are a prehistoric species, and the earliest evidence of the blue heron has been dated to 1.8 million years ago.
Interestingly, there's a new-comer in the group that has arrived just within the last 100 years — the cattle egret, which somehow arrived here from Africa, can often be seen in farm fields near livestock, munching on ticks and other insects. Like other herons, the cattle egret also likes small fish and frogs too.
The Eastern Shore's liquid landscape of marshes, streams and tidal waters provides ideal habitat for herons, which accounts for the frequent sightings.
All heron species are carnivores, eating fish, frogs, small snakes, ducklings, tadpoles, crayfish and mice. With their long legs and beaks, they stealthily walk along shallow waterways, often stabbing their food with their sharp beaks before gulping it down.
Culturally, herons have played an important role in both Native American and non-Native cultures.
Some Native Americans symbolized the heron with patience and good luck.
Between 1870 and 1920, the Eastern Shore was a major hunting ground for heron species to support the feather trade. In fact, the great white heron was almost hunted to extinction. During this era, it was considered high fashion for women's hats to adorn elaborate feathers.
Each women's hat often included three ounces of feathers, and it generally took about four birds to generate one ounce. As a consequence, tens of millions of herons were slaughtered over that 50-year period.
In 1918, the United States passed the Migratory Bird Treaty, which put in place some sweeping protections for many migratory birds. Those protections exist today, and in 2024, many heron populations are stable.
The great blue heron is so common now that the International Union for the Conservation of Nature declares the blue heron as a "least concern species".
All heron species are protected under the Migratory Bird Treaty Act.
Herons mate in the spring, and and many of their nesting sites are in trees near the water. Each colony of heron is referred to as a rookery. There are documented rookeries on public lands can viewed at Sassafras Wildlife Management Area near Kennedyville, Eastern Neck Island near Rock Hall, and Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge in Cambridge, among others.
If you're out and about, near a marsh or stormwater pond, in a marina or out on the rivers or Bay, look for a heron. They are truly majestic birds.
Jay Falstad is a Maryland Master Naturalist and Executive Director of the Queen Anne's Conservation Association. For comments, questions, or suggested topics about Eastern Shore nature, email him at jayfalstad@gmail.com

title: Chesapeake Bay cleanup at a crossroads: new path or stay the course?
author: JEREMY COX Bay Journal
content:
Chesapeake Bay cleanup at a crossroads: new path or stay the course?

 October 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JEREMY COX Bay Journal | Section: State News 
 
 1014
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As the Chesapeake Bay cleanup's leaders close in on a revised working agreement, many of the effort's most influential supporters are endorsing a major thematic shift: putting less emphasis on improving the estuary's seldom-seen deep waters and more on helping people and living resources in the Bay watershed."This is an opportunity for our movement to understand our successes and failures, and adjust accordingly," said Kate Fritz, CEO of the Alliance for the Chesapeake Bay, in a letter to the Chesapeake Bay Program, the multi-state and federal partnership in charge of reviving the Bay. "This means … intentionally including people and living resources at the center of the partnership's work."
That closely aligns with the recommendations of the Bay Program team that was tasked with drafting an update of the 2014 Chesapeake Bay Agreement. A draft was released for public feedback on July 1.
The team urged the program to "better incentivize practices that maximize benefits to living resources and people." This, they argued, could be accomplished largely through actions that target water quality improvements — long the effort's central focus — but only if local community concerns take precedent.
More than 80 people and organizations submitted comments on the draft agreement by the Aug. 30 deadline. The Chesapeake Executive Council — the governors of the six watershed states, mayor of the District of Columbia, chair of the Chesapeake Bay Commission and administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency — is set to vote on a final draft during its annual meeting in December.
The revised agreement is intended to serve as a top-line strategy for cleaning up the Bay and its 64,000-square-mile drainage basin beyond 2025, when the deadline for goals in the current agreement expires.
For decades, the partnership has centered its work on reducing nutrient and sediment pollution flowing into the Bay. The main goal has been to shrink the annual "dead zones," pockets of oxygen-starved water in the estuary's deepest waters where aquatic creatures struggle to survive.
Despite billions of dollars invested in the effort, pollution reductions have been modest and slow in coming, according to the Bay Program's own calculations. Some advocates and scientists fear that the cleanup risks falling out of favor with the public if it doesn't shift toward more visible quests, such as restoring shallow waters along the edge of the Bay and its tributaries.
"Without renewed attention to those things that matter the most to people, we run the risk of leaving potential living resource benefits unaddressed and potentially losing public support for our efforts," wrote Larry Sanford, chair of the Bay Program's Scientific and Technical Advisory Committee (STAC), on behalf of the panel.
But in remarks to STAC on Sept. 12, Sanford, a professor at the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science, described the new draft agreement as a "compromise" between two factions: those seeking a pronounced change in direction and those who want to stay the course.
For his part, Sanford said the program needs to maintain much of its existing work but also "go back to the original reason for the Bay Program, and that was what was happening to the living resources."
If that recalibration is to move forward, it will have to survive a big test later this fall when the agreement goes before the Principals' Staff Committee — senior officials from the Bay states and DC, who sounded a note of caution about that approach when they met in March.
Meeting water quality goals is a legal requirement, enforced by the EPA. The committee appeared concerned that de-stressing that goal could lead to potential lawsuits. Several members at the time also said they believed that those authoring the revised agreement had gone beyond what they had been authorized to do.
A group of agricultural industry groups in Virginia, including the Virginia Farm Bureau, signed on to a letter that said they "appreciate" the draft's call to better address climate change and public engagement. But they are concerned that such measures would "change the original intent and shared goals" of the 2014 agreement. The state in its current two-year budget has set aside a record $207 million to reduce farm-based pollution.
Meanwhile, several environmental groups touted how reorienting the program toward people and living creatures would support other important goals. Much could be achieved, for example, through tougher enforcement of state and federal water pollution control laws, according to a letter signed by Waterkeepers Chesapeake and several local waterkeepers.
"While the status quo elevates considerations of nutrient pollutants and the dissolved oxygen levels in the mainstem of the Bay, the path forward must elevate the role that enforcement of illegal pollution from point sources has on protecting humans and wildlife from toxic and carcinogenic substances," the waterkeepers said.
The needs of people and wildlife will be difficult to meet without more land conservation, said the Chesapeake Conservation Partnership, an alliance of land trusts and related organizations. Bay leaders, they added, should elevate land conservation to stand as a "key guiding pillar" along those already on that top tier: science, restoration and partnership.
The document being readied for the Executive Council's approval this December isn't the final revised agreement but rather a framework for a more detailed compact to be worked out in the future. The current draft doesn't call for a full revision of the agreement until the council meets in 2026.
Several commenters urged leadership to put the finalized agreement on a faster schedule. To wait until late 2026 could lead to a pause or slowdown in oyster restoration activities in key Bay tributaries, said Oyster Recovery Partnership Executive Director H. Ward Slacum. It should be ready by the end of 2025 instead, he said.
A group of about 40 retired Bay scientists and former public officials also weighed in. The coalition, calling itself "Chesapeake Bay Program Veterans," echoed the push to have the revisions in place in 2025.
And the program should look at the problems and benefits that arise from local, state and federal greenhouse gas reduction goals, they said. They suggested that the transition from fossil fuels to renewable energy, for example, is likely to reduce nitrogen pollution that enters Bay waters from the atmosphere.

title: Hurricane Milton tests Tampa Bay’s Indian blessing, ‘Bay of the Holy Spirit’ legends; Storm projected to hit near Sarasota
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News
content:
Hurricane Milton tests Tampa Bay’s Indian blessing, ‘Bay of the Holy Spirit’ legends; Storm projected to hit near Sarasota

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News | Section: News

 Anyone who grew up in or has lived in the Tampa-St. Petersburg area for a number of years likely knows about the Indian blessing that protects Tampa Bay from hurricanes.The blessing stems from the ancient Tocobaga Native American tribe which protects Tampa Bay against hurricanes. The indigenous tribe lived in the bay area with sacred sites in Safety Harbor in Pinellas County overlooking Old Tampa Bay.
On top of the indigenous tribe's blessing, Spanish explorer Hernando de Soto (during his search for the Fountain of Youth) encountered the Tocobaga in Safety Harbor in 1539 on Pentecost Sunday and named what is now Tampa Bay — Bahia Espiritu Santo (tBay of the Holy Spirit).
The Indian blessing and de Soto's Christian name for the bay have protected the Tampa area from hurricanes, according to local legends.
Tampa has not been hit directly by hurricane since 1921. There have been numerous contemporary examples of hurricane projected to hit Tampa Bay and then turning and deviating north or south — including Hurricane Ian.
Hurricane Milton is putting the spiritual legends to test. The hurricane is slated to hit Florida early Thursday with Tampa Bay potentially facing historic and catastrophic storm surges, 100 miles per hour winds and heavy rain.
The Category 4 storm has winds of 155 miles per hour and is expected to make landfall in Florida early Thursday morning.
But some of the latest updates from the National Hurricane Center and storm path models have Milton making landfall south of Tampa Bay potentially in Sarasota or south of Sarasota.
If those expectations hold true, that would bring the worst of the storm to the south of the Tampa area.
Tampa Bay could avoid biblical storm surge flooding is the storm lands to the south.
Still, Tampa and Pinellas County are in the wider path cone of the storm and are almost certain to see high winds, power outages, possible tornadoes, thunderstorms and downpours from Milton.
But it might dodge a more catastrophic storm surge bullet.
Tampa. St. Petersburg and Pinellas barrier islands did see major damage from Hurricane Helene as is barreled north.
The Indian blessing legend is not lost on Tampa Bay locals.
"I kind of believe it," said Kristen Hendry, who lives in Brandon near Tampa.
"I've seen weird things happen with other hurricanes. Storms will turn."
Hendry is not alone.
There are plenty of local references to the blessings against hurricanes on social media, breakfast diners and dog parks as local residents brace for Milton's impacts.
Still, having faith in the spiritual, if not keeping local residents from bracing from Hurricane Milton's impacts.
"We're definitely getting ready," she said.
Others are also bringing their faith and spiritual beliefs as Milton approaches from the western Gulf of Mexico with a potential historic hit on Florida.
Fathers Athanasios Haros and Pappa Fanis of the St. Nichols Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Tarpon Springs went to the shores of the Gulf of Mexico on Monday to bless the body of water in advance of Hurricane Milton and ask for spiritual intercessions and protections.
In a Facebook video, Haros said they were on the Gulf of Mexico shores to bless the waters and ask for blessing and protections.
Tocobaga indigenous tribe inhabited had burial mounds in the Tampa area specifically Safety Harbor, which sits on the northern end of Old Tampa Bay in Pinellas County.
Tocobaga encountered the Spanish in the 1500 and 1600s, had their populations decreased by diseases brought by Europeans, conflicts with other tribes and eventually emigrated to Cuba with the Spanish when Florida came under British rule from 1763 to 1783 before returning to Spanish control.
Tampa is home to one of the largest ports in the U.S. and U.S. Central Command at MacDill Air Force Base. Central Command runs U.S. military operations in the Middle East and Holy land including those involving the current war between Israel and Iranian proxies Hamas and Hezbollah.

title: Activists elated, Tradepoint frustrated as Hart-Miller Island won't receive dredged material
author: JOEL LEV-TOV jlev-tov@chespub.com
content:
Activists elated, Tradepoint frustrated as Hart-Miller Island won't receive dredged material

 October 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JOEL LEV-TOV jlev-tov@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 1010
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Tradepoint Atlantic will not be placing the material it dredges from deepening its harbor on Hart-Miller Island.Community activists cautiously celebrated the announcement on last week. Two council members and the county executive expressed disappointment. Tradepoint's Aaron Tomarchio told the Eagle he was frustrated.
"While there were many who understood the value of a win-win opportunity and the positive impact such a significant investment of $40 million could have in their communities," Tomarchio wrote in a letter to Baltimore County sent Thursday morning, "there remains a long-held sentiment that Hart-Miller Island should remain as-is."
The long-held sentiment continues, the executive vice president of corporate affairs wrote, despite the $40 million proposed community benefit agreement and "assurances" that the company is dedicated to placing the dredged material on the island safely.
Frank Neighoff, the president of the Chesapeake Bay Association and a member of the committee that would have advised the Baltimore County Council on how to spend the $40 million, said he was "very pleased."
Keith Taylor, the president of the Sparrows Point-North Point Historical Society, called the news "wonderful" but cautioned that the fight wasn't over.
Tomarchio told the Eagle that his company was "community-minded" and understood the community "did not" want to see the dredged material placed on Hart-Miller Island, created through the dredging of the Baltimore harbor in the 1980s.
"Is it frustrating that certain people lack vision? Yes," he said. "Is it frustrating that certain people are unable to let go of the past and look toward the future? Yes."
"But are we respecting the decision of the community?" he continued. "Absolutely."
And so the proposal to put the dredged material from the site of the former Bethlehem Steel Mill, where Tradepoint and Mediterranean Shipping Company want to expand the harbor into one capable of hosting the large container ships in a billion-dollar project, onto the island is dead in the water.
The Hart-Miller Island plan was just one of three proposals for what to do with the dredge.
THE PLAN
Tradepoint plans to move ahead with a "blended" option, where it would deposit the 4.2 million cubic yards of dredge, dug from the bottom of its harbor while deepening it to 50 feet by 2028, in four different sites.
Roughly a third of the cleanest dredge would be dumped into the ocean off the coast of Norfolk, a third of the dredge would be contained on its own property and the last third would be stored at an existing containment site run by the state across the Patapsco River in Cox Creek by Hawkins Point.
An environmental report the company commissioned, released to the public on Oct. 2, cleared the first hurdle for the third to be dumped into the ocean. The report found it clean enough to meet the Environmental Protection Agency's standards.
Another proposal called for building a new facility on the western part of Coke Point, taking away 100 acres of water — about 76 football field's worth — for a closed-off site with the dredged material, called a dredged material containment facility.
Scott Pappas, the president of the Fort Howard Community Association who sat on the committee advising what to do with the funds as well, said either of the two options that did not involve placing the material on public, recreational land was fine with him as long as the corporation followed the law.
"You've got to remember that Hart-Miller Island is a commonwealth, it's a state property that we as taxpayers of the state of Maryland, we own that," he said. "What they wished to do was to take their materials and put it onto one of our gems, one of our recreational places."
LAST-MINUTE CHANGE
So why the sudden change of heart at Tradepoint, after at least two months of pushing for the dredge to be placed on Hart-Miller Island?
"I think there was a combination of things that played a role in it," Tomarchio said.
Community feedback was one big pillar, he said. On Tuesday, Oct. 8, more than 90 people jammed into a small meeting room at the North Point Library to hear about Tradepoint's proposal to deposit the dredge on the island.
Many community members hadn't heard of the project. The number of attendees was more than twice that of any meeting with the committee, called the Hart-Miller Island Community Benefit Agreement Steering Committee.
About two hours after the meeting began, some members of that committee asked the community members to vote on whether the committee members should advise the County Council to accept or reject the $40 million Community Benefit Agreement.
It wasn't even close. 86 residents voted to reject the agreement, according to a Facebook post. Two voted to accept it. One voted undecided.
Less than 48 hours later, Tradepoint jettisoned the plan. That canceled a committee meeting later that day, set to be held at the Sollers Point Multipurpose Center.
Tomarchio derided the meeting as a "kangaroo court," claiming that Tradepoint was not invited.
"There was no opportunity to present the facts of what was actually going on and being proposed," he said. "So, of course, when you have a one-sided conversation happening, people are going to end up on that one side."
Taylor chuckled when asked to respond.
"Sometimes the community has to speak for itself," he said, "and I think that happened Tuesday."
The second pillar, Tomarchio said, was a realization that placing the dredge on the island wasn't nearly as simple as they had expected.
It would take about the same amount of time, he said the company realized, to build the new containment facility in Hart-Miller Island's North Cell as it would to place the dredge via the "blended" plan.
Now, with the plan to place the dredge on the island jettisoned, the $40 million that went along with that as compensation is gone as well. Tradepoint will not be paying the communities any money, whatever plan it goes ahead with.
Pappas isn't sorry to see the money go.
"What they were doing is compensating the community for their political support in order for them to have a fast track and a secure place to put their dread spoils from their construction and real estate development at Tradepoint Atlantic," he said.

title: Striped bass continue to struggle in the Chesapeake Bay
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Striped bass continue to struggle in the Chesapeake Bay

 October 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 626
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Young Striped Bass are struggling in the Chesapeake Bay, and experts across the field are working to find solutions for the economic and cultural impacts.This week, the Atlantic Striped Bass Management Board met and discussed the future of the species during the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission's annual webinar meeting.
Meeting attendees discussed the findings of an annual report released by the Virginia Institute of Marine Science and the Maryland Department of Natural Resources showing concerning results for the future of striped bass in the Chesapeake.
Allison Colden, Chesapeake Bay Foundation's Maryland executive director, said the Chesapeake Bay is an important nursery area for striped bass.
"It's safe to say the majority of striped bass all along the coast are spawned here in the Chesapeake Bay," Colden said. "So we are the epicenter for where all of these fish are born before they make their way, grow up and make their way out of the Chesapeake Bay and migrate all along the Atlantic coast."
According to Colden, data about the status of the population shows juvenile striped bass face various barriers before making it to adulthood.
This survey goes back to the 1950s and is one of the longest-running for the species on the Atlantic coast. The results of this year's survey show the sixth consecutive year of below-average numbers.
The data collected is done through an observation of fish that spawned in the spring, then grew over the summer. The sample used a net, which is called in from the shoreline at various sample sites throughout the Maryland and Virginia portions of the Bay.
The information gathered is used on an annual basis to create an index and from year to year, show many fish are caught at these set sample sites over a long time frame.
During the Atlantic Striped Bass Management Board meeting, several attendees shared concerns over the decline in striped bass and the effect new regulations to protect the species will have on the Chesapeake Bay economically.
In the past, the commission implemented several additional regulations in order to help raise the striped bass population. Most recently, new limits for size and the number of fish that can be harvested were issued in January. The Maryland Department of Natural Resources also prohibited fishing for striped bass from July 16 through July 31, when temperatures are highest and fish are most vulnerable.
Mike Smolek, president of the Upper Bay Charter Captains Association, shared during the meeting the hit his industry took as a result of the regulations. Smolek shared that six pack boats "have been hit the hardest," and business for these boats is down by 80%.
"We cannot endure any more closure days. If we do, all of us might as well just go out of business."
During the meeting, the board stated that based on the results of the survey, rebuilding the striped bass population by the intended 2029 goal is unlikely without additional management action.
The commission determined that at least an additional 15% reduction in fishing mortality would be necessary for the stock to have a 50% probability of rebuilding to sustainable levels by 2029. Options to achieve that reduction were not available at the time of the meeting.
The board voted to meet again in December to consider further action, saying additional time will allow technical staff to develop options for new limits that can be implemented in the 2025 fishing season.
Colden said protecting the species through new regulations is important, but it is just a piece of the solution to keep the species and industry going.
"Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, they only have control over one piece of the puzzle," Colden said. "... When it comes to improving conditions within those nursery and spawning areas at Chesapeake Bay, it's something that's a lot more complex and long-term."

title: 'Our piece of wilderness': Delaware park marks 40th anniversary
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
'Our piece of wilderness': Delaware park marks 40th anniversary

 October 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 890
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Ask Gary Schroeder what White Clay Creek Preserve means to him, and he'll answer with a story."In a two-day period, I watched a bald eagle bring food to its nest. I watched an osprey come by, not eight feet away from me, and catch a fish and fly off," Schroeder said. "I saw a mother American mink with two of its little babies running around, and I walked around the corner of the trail and saw two hen turkeys and all their little babies, and there were just turkeys flying everywhere."
"Those are experiences I would not have, had this become developed," he added.
Schroeder's story encapsulates what he and other park advocates envisioned for the land when DuPont donated it to the states of Delaware and Pennsylvania 40 years ago.
"I think it is a refuge to some extent," David Koppeser, president of the Friends of White Clay Creek State Park said. "[Visitors] feel that it is a place they can step into nature, either on their own or with other people, and they can just get away from it all and they can enjoy nature as it existed for so long in this area."
Both the state park in Newark and the preserve in Landenberg, Pa., held events Saturday to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the donation that led to the creation of the two-state park. Groups from both sides hiked to the state line for a ceremony reminiscent of the one held to celebrate the founding four decades ago.
The events that led up to the creation of the park began in the 1950s when the DuPont company began buying up land in Delaware and Pennsylvania with the intention of damming the White Clay Creek to create a 12 billion gallon reservoir to serve its factories and the surrounding community. The reservoir would have flooded more than 1,000 acres of forest, meadow and farmland.
Environmental activists, led by Dorothy Miller, Don Sharpe and others, launched a massive community effort to stop the reservoir. By the 1980s, DuPont had given up on the idea, and in 1984, the company donated the land to the states — approximately 1,200 acres in Pennsylvania and 500 in Delaware.
In Delaware, the land was added to existing parkland and eventually became known as White Clay Creek State Park, which after further acquisitions is nearly 4,000 acres today. The adjoining land in Pennsylvania formed White Clay Creek Preserve.
A bi-state council, made up of six people from each state, was set up to advise the states on how to manage the land. From early on, the members were adamant that the land remain a passive park that is as natural as possible, said Schroeder, who served on the council and later founded Friends of White Clay Creek Preserve.
He recalled that the council fought against Pennsylvania's initial plan to build campgrounds, picnic areas, big parking lots and other facilities.
"The goal was to have a place that was a natural area, because we're in the middle of the mid-Atlantic area, we're surrounded by tens of millions of people and we have this gem here," he said.
State officials eventually got on board, and the preserve's strongest supporters still take pride that the land lives up its name as a preserve.
"We don't have basketball courts. We don't have tennis courts. In fact, I think there's only two picnic tables," said Scotty Crowder, president of the Friends group on the Pennsylvania side. "It's really about the streams, the hiking trails and enjoying nature as it was here."
The Delaware side does have some recreational amenities like a bandstand, picnic area and nature center, but most of it remains natural as well.
A new nature center is slated to be built near the existing one that is housed in the historic Chambers House on Creek Road near Hopkins Road. The current building is small and can't accommodate large groups.
The new 6,800-square-foot building will include classrooms, exhibition space, public restrooms and an outdoor classroom space. It will be used for school groups, summer camps and other nature-focused programming.
Koppeser credited the state park's enduring popularity to the community members who so passionately fought for the park four decades ago.
"They had a vision that was decades into the future," he said. "Save whatever you can because if you don't save it, it'll be gone, and the future generations won't have this resource available to them."
Schroeder added that the bi-state cooperation was key, as well.
"We made a very conscious effort to treat it as a single ecosystem and not get too distracted by where the state line was," he said. "I think that was critical for the success here."
Sarah Sato, an environmental education specialist who runs programs on the Pennsylvania side, said decades of community involvement have made the park and preserve what they are today.
"It's been really cool to see all of the different people who use the park and hear how much they care about the park, because the whole reason this place was preserved was because people cared," Sato said. "It makes it a special place, because they actually want to be here and they care about it."
Ed O'Donnell, of Newark, is a member of White Clay Fly Fishers and enjoys fishing in the park nearly year-round.
"It's our piece of wilderness, surrounded by suburbia and cities," O'Donnell said. "You can get lost in White Clay and not think about."

title: Environmentalists push for ban on Maryland’s industrial chicken farms
author: MADISON KORMAN Capital News Service
content:
Environmentalists push for ban on Maryland’s industrial chicken farms

 October 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MADISON KORMAN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 819
 Words 

 Read News Document

 An environmental group is urging Gov. Wes Moore's administration to impose a moratorium on Maryland's industrial chicken farms when the current permit comes up for review next summer.But Maryland chicken farmers say they're taking all the precautions they can to protect the environment, while also running one of the state's biggest industries.
A debate between the two sides is starting to heat up this fall, as the state Department of the Environment holds a series of listening sessions to get the public's point of view on the matter.
The state's job is to make sure business is operating in a way that complies with state and federal requirements protecting the environment, according to the agency. They make revisions to the statewide animal feeding and operations permit every five years.
Animal waste is an ongoing concern for the state, mainly on cattle production in northern Maryland and poultry in the Eastern Shore counties, according to a report last fall from the University of Maryland. Most nitrogen and phosphorus in manure comes from poultry litter, according to the report, and that nutrient output is expected to rise with increases in the weight of chickens over the next ten years.
This fall, state officials are listening to testimony on the subject at meetings online and in person, as people on all sides of the question weigh in.
"Our primary goal is to make sure that we maximize public participation in the process, so we are seeking input before a draft permit is written," said Jay Apperson, deputy director of communications for the state Department of the Environment. "We want to hear from all stakeholders, including farmers and nearby communities."
Apperson said the department will analyze the comments and begin drafting a statewide permit that will be released early next year. A second public comment period will follow after that and the permit will be subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency approval before becoming final.
Environmentalists worry about pollutionThe Food & Water Watch, an environmental group, would like to see a total moratorium on new large chicken farms. They also want to limit the expansion of existing ones under corporate contracts on the eastern shore, home to one of the state's biggest farming industries.
The group believes those farms threaten local communities, as well as the Chesapeake Bay.
Advocates with the FWW say the population of chickens in Maryland is too dense. There are about 488 poultry-concentrated animal feeding operations in Maryland, raising around 330 million chickens a year, according to the state agency.
The regular review presents an opportunity to look into the density, said Rebecca Wolf, senior food policy analyst at the Food & Water Watch. She also questions whether poultry farms are fully complying with regulations on water pollution.
"It's a really good chance to take a look at a lot of these issues, to take a look at pollution, to take a look at the concentration," Wolf said. She also said officials should "review how state agencies are falling short on monitoring the chicken waste problem and actually pursue some real effort to hold the industry accountable and make Maryland air and water safer for communities."
The agency says they've increased the number of inspections from 163 in the fiscal year that started in 2021 to 263 in 2023, and that they're on track to do 288 this year.
"The Maryland Department of the Environment maintains a strong program to enforce environmental regulations pertaining to poultry operations," Apperson told Capital News Service in an email. "A high percentage of violations that are found are associated with record-keeping requirements as opposed to water quality issues."
Farmers defend the safety and cleanlinessChicken producers defend their business, one of the most vibrant and prosperous in Maryland. Hundreds of people depend on the industry for their livelihood in Delaware, Maryland and Virginia, according to the business group that represents them.
"There are more than 1,200 Delmarva family farmers who raise chickens on independently owned farms," said James Fisher, a spokesperson for the Delmarva Chicken Association, citing the group's own annual surveys of the five chicken companies operating on Delmarva. "There are more than 18,000 chicken company employees."
"There are hundreds of allied businesses on Delmarva that sell products and services to the chicken economy," Fisher said. "It is an essential part of our culture, our workforce, our economy here in Delmar."
Fisher said farms have worked to reduce the pollution despite the increase in the number of chickens.
"Farmers raise their own families on their farms," Holly Porter, the group's executive director, said in a statement. "So air and water quality is very important to them."
"Simply canceling the Maryland chicken industry, as some activists say they want, would bankrupt hundreds of farms and destroy thousands of jobs with chicken companies and allied businesses," Porter said.
It would also make chicken more expensive and harder to find, she said.
The revisions to the state permit are due by July of next year. State officials will continue their review in the coming months.

title: A 'smart buoy' is coming to St. Michaels harbor
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
A 'smart buoy' is coming to St. Michaels harbor

 November 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Environment 
 
 325
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — On Wednesday evening, Andrew David Thaler carried a large wooden device with yellow cords piled in its interior and a yellow and black top into the St. Michaels commissioners meeting.Thaler, a member of the St. Michaels Climate Change/Sea Level Rise Commission, smiled as he eagerly presented the "smart buoy."
With the permission of the commissioners, the Climate Change/Sea Level Rise Commission will put the buoy in the harbor to monitor water levels and flooding.
"What this buoy will do is it measures sea state, so we get sea surface temperature, we get wave action on the surface," Thaler said. "And then we'll also have a pressure gage at the bottom of the mooring, which we'll be able to use to assess tidal head. So that'll give us both the actual tidal cycle coming into the harbor, as well as any storm surges coming up from the bay."
According to Thaler, one of the long-term goals of the commission is to look into the viability of having the town's own tide gage.
The reasoning behind this goal is to gather specific data of St. Michaels tide pH. Currently, the data gathered for nuisance flooding, tidal surges and storm surges come from three sites. The sites are gages from Cambridge, Annapolis and Clayburn. Which are too far from St. Michaels to accurately gather information for the town.
Thaler said last year the commission applied for an equipment grant from So Far Ocean, a company that makes smart buoys. The presented device will gather data in real time and is solar powered.
Thaler said the location of the smart buoy will not interfere with boat traffic and will be located in the lagoon between Honeymoon Bridge and Mill Street. It comes at no cost to the town.
After the presentation, the St. Michaels commissioners thanked Thaler and the Climate Change/Sea Level Rise Commission for all their efforts. Commissioners will vote on the use of a smart buoy during a future meeting.

title: Will a cleaner Chesapeake Bay mean more fish and crabs? It’s complicated
author: KARL BLANKENSHIP Bay Journal
content:
Will a cleaner Chesapeake Bay mean more fish and crabs? It’s complicated

 November 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KARL BLANKENSHIP Bay Journal | Section: News 
 
 1994
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For decades, Chesapeake Bay cleanup efforts have been driven by a simple equation: Cleaner water equals more fish and shellfish.The 1983 Chesapeake Bay Agreement, which launched the state-federal restoration effort, made that clear as it sought to reverse the Bay's "historical decline in the living resources." It would do so, the agreement said, by addressing pollution flowing into the Bay.
The living resources goal was reiterated in the next two cleanup agreements in 2000 and 2014, and the pollution goal has been refined to measurable targets for reducing nutrient pollution in the water.
But would achieving those goals actually result in more fish, crabs and oysters?
It's complicated.
Bay scientists caution that the link between nutrient reductions and increased fish abundance is highly uncertain. In a report last year, they warned of a need for "grounding" the public's expectations about the recovery of aquatic life, even if cleanup goals are met.
In the May 2023 Comprehensive Evaluation of System Response report, the Scientific and Technical Advisory Committee of the state-federal Chesapeake Bay Program cautioned that other factors — such as temperature, salinity, river flows and structural habitats — play important roles in determining fish abundance. Compared with those, the water quality role can be small.
"Considerable uncertainty," they wrote, "will accompany any effort to predict how fish and shellfish populations respond to changes in water quality alone."
Striped bass and some other fish species might benefit from reducing nutrient pollution in the Chesapeake Bay, but reducing it might not help others, such as menhaden.
Scientists who worked on the report are quick to say that doesn't mean the Bay Program should walk away from its nutrient reduction commitments. Rather, they say, it points to the need to better understand the relative importance of water quality improvements and other factors, such as habitat restoration, in boosting aquatic populations.
That could inform efforts to balance spending on nutrient controls with other things to produce the greatest benefit for the widest variety of species.
"We're really saying this is an evolution, not a revolution," said Kenny Rose, a fisheries scientist with the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science who was the lead author of the living resources section of the CESR report.
The best place to figure that out, according to the report, is in shallow water areas that fringe the Bay and the tidal portions of tributaries that are disproportionately important for a wide range of creatures.
That recommendation has spurred recent interest within the Bay Program to focus increased pollution reduction and habitat restoration work on a handful of targeted nearshore areas.
The challenge of changeIt would be a significant change in direction — and it would also pose significant scientific challenges.
Historically, nutrient reduction actions have generally been aimed at improving the deepest parts of the upper Bay, where water quality is the worst.
But the CESR report warns that cleanup progress has been slow, the Bay has not responded as rapidly as expected, and that the deepwater goals may not be fully attainable.
It also pointed out that, when it comes to helping aquatic life, focusing most nutrient reduction efforts on deepwater areas could detract from other actions that would more directly help aquatic life.
That has triggered interest in creating a "tiered approach" to reducing nutrient pollution. In that approach, some shallow-water areas with a high potential to show results would get greater priority, even if their impact on deeper water would be relatively small.
Those nearshore areas would, in effect, become incubators for understanding how — and whether — alternate approaches to Bay restoration might produce better results for fish and shellfish.
That doesn't mean that all emphasis would be removed from deepwater areas, said Lee McDonnell, chief of the science, analysis and implementation branch of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Chesapeake Bay Program Office.
Some focus on those areas is important because when oxygen disappears there, it triggers conditions that release nutrients stored in the sediment, making overall Bay water quality even worse.
"We can't ignore the deep water [or] deep channel and say everybody's going to focus on shallow water," McDonnell said.
At the same time, he said, there is a public expectation that cleanup actions will result in tangible benefits.
"We're asking for behavior change in people, and their expectation is that they should be able to see some kind of change and experience it," McDonnell said. "There's a much better chance of doing that in the shallow waters than in the deep trench."
Shifting more resources to shallow water could slow the rate of progress in deepwater areas, but many scientists say the change is worth the trade-off if it results in quicker, more tangible benefits for aquatic life.
"This tiered implementation is not saying you're taking your foot off the gas of the pursuit of a long-term goal," said Penn State ecologist Denice Wardrop, one of the lead authors of the CESR report. "But at the pace we're going, you need an interim goal because you're going to be losing living resources on the way to the long-term goal. And you don't need to."
Finding the balanceChief of the science, analysis and implementation branch of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Chesapeake Bay Program Office Lee McDonnell, Wardrop, Rose and a handful of others have been meeting for months to figure out how to identify shallow areas to be prioritized — and how to assess whether their actions are making a difference. It's a complex task.
Reducing nutrient loads in the Bay system have long been seen as a way to help living resources. The nutrients spur algae blooms that cloud the water and block sunlight from reaching underwater grass beds, which provide important habitat for juvenile fish and crabs, waterfowl and other species.
When the excess algae die, they decompose in a process that removes oxygen from the water, sometimes causing oxygen-starved "dead zones" that plague the deepest parts of the upper Bay each summer.
The nutrient reduction goals assigned to each Bay state and major tributary aim to improve those conditions, allowing more sunlight to reach underwater plants and largely eliminate dead zones.
That would certainly allow underwater grass meadows to expand and would benefit bottom-dwelling organisms, such as clams and worms, that can suffocate if oxygen levels get too low.
The increased oxygen is intended to help fish and crabs as well, but whether that would lead to greater abundance is unclear.
For one thing, those species can simply move if water conditions get bad. And many, such as striped bass, blue crabs, shad and others, spend most of their lives — or at least important life stages — outside the Chesapeake. Conditions in those areas often are more important in determining their abundance.
Further, reduced algae production isn't always a good thing. While excess amounts can trigger poor oxygen levels, algae is also an important food, especially for fish in their early life stages, as well as for some adult fish, like menhaden, which are themselves an important food for larger fish and birds.
Indeed, a 2017 EPA study found that while species like striped bass and oysters might benefit from the improved water quality, the reduced algae production might hamper populations of others, such as Atlantic menhaden.
The CESR report also stated that "living resource abundance may eventually decrease as nutrient loads continue to decrease and [water quality goals] approach full attainment."
"[There are] always going to be winners and losers," said Tom Ihde, a researcher at Morgan State University's Patuxent Environmental & Aquatic Research Laboratory, who also worked on the CESR report. "If you're managing menhaden populations versus the blue crab, you're concerned about very different things."
Ihde has worked on complex computer models that try to tease out how various species respond to different variables. In a 2017 paper, he examined the responses of nearly 50 aquatic species to a variety of ecological changes.
He found that achieving the clean water goals only had a small impact on most species — though some, like blue crabs and white perch, showed benefits.
That influence was dwarfed by the impact of temperature increases. Achieving water quality goals does little to offset that problem for most species, he found.
That shouldn't be totally surprising, Ihde said, because temperature affects everything in the system, such as growth rates, the timing of reproduction and food production.
"It's not that the nutrient reductions are not having an effect," Ihde said. "It is, and we're seeing change. But it's that temperature is much more of a change."
It's never just one thingOther factors — salinity, the amount of freshwater flowing into the Bay during spring spawning periods, fishing pressure, disease and loss of structural habitats — are also important in influencing species abundance.
A recent Bay Program report looked at the habitats of forage fish, which are small species eaten by larger fish and birds. The researchers found that shoreline hardening played an important role in predicting their abundance. The most sensitive forage species go away when just 10% of an area's shoreline is covered by bulkheads or rip-rap. And many comparatively tolerant species disappear when that amount reaches 30%.
The CESR report noted that benefits of water quality improvements "will be modest" if such factors are limiting populations.
But, it said, pairing water quality work with other actions — restoring wetlands, replacing hardened shorelines with living shorelines or building oyster reefs — might yield better overall results.
In recent years, state and federal agencies have worked to restore large oyster reefs in 11 Bay tributaries.
Monitoring has shown that underwater grasses are rebounding in areas near the reefs, very likely a result of oysters filtering the water. Other studies have found that oyster reefs help remove nutrients from the water.
"We feel pretty confident that doing large-scale oyster restoration leads to ecological benefits," said Bruce Vogt of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Chesapeake Bay Office. "We have very clear evidence that the oyster reefs are cleaning the water and produce better clarity."
Fish abundance is also higher near the reefs, though Vogt said it is less clear whether the reefs are boosting fish reproduction or merely attracting fish from other areas.
That is the type of question that scientists say could be cleared up by targeting some shallow water areas for more intense work and monitoring the results.
Still, understanding impacts in a given area — and predicting whether positive signs in one area would be repeated in others — is no easy task in a system as large and complex as the Chesapeake.
"Not all oyster habitats are equal, and not all seagrass habitats are equal," said Mark Monaco, a senior scientist with NOAA's
National Centers for Coastal Ocean Science and an author of the CESR report. "How do those relationships hold up across the Bay in specific areas? And would an enhancement in habitat restoration actually move the dial in a particular area?"Getting to a tipping point
The good news, Monaco said, is that a lot of data is available. Fish surveys and studies have taken place in the Bay for decades. They've never really been integrated with information on habitats, water quality and other variables that can impact fish, but that work has begun.
It will take at least two years to glean needed information from that data and identify shallow water areas for emphasis, according to those working on the process.
And there are a lot of basic details to work out along the way: What does "shallow water" actually mean? Is that two feet deep or six feet deep? What species and what life stages should be included in an analysis? How big of an area would be targeted?
The hope, said McDonnell of the EPA Bay Program Office, is to find shallow areas near an ecological "tipping point" where a realistic amount of action can turn an area of poor habitat into fair habitat, or a fair area into a good area, and produce faster improvements for the species that live there.
"If we're going to have this tiered implementation, it has to be grounded in science," he said. "If we're going to do something different than we're doing now, there ought to be a reason for it. I'm hoping this is our good reason."
