title: State expands drought watches, warnings
author: Staff Writer
content:
State expands drought watches, warnings

 November 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 239
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland Department of the Environment is issuing drought watches and warnings across the state and urging citizens and businesses to reduce water usage when possible.This follows six months of lower-than-average rainfall and virtually no rain this autumn. No state-issued mandatory water restrictions are in place at this time.
"We've had a very dry year overall, and monitoring shows an impact on water availability statewide," Maryland Department of the Environment Secretary Serena McIlwain said in a release. "While there is no immediate water shortage, we encourage residents and businesses to use water wisely as we continue to monitor the situation."
Drought warnings are in effect for Eastern and Southern Maryland.
Watches are in effect for Western and Central Maryland, including the area served by the WSSC Water system. Systems served by the city of Baltimore are not under any warnings or watches. While there is less demand compared to the peak demand in the summer, the state has increased its monitoring and oversight of water supply conditions.
There is also a statewide burn ban in effect since Nov. 1.
On the Eastern Shore, a drought warning is in effect based on monitoring that shows lower-than-normal precipitation, stream flows and groundwater levels in shallow aquifers. Although most domestic wells in the region are deep enough to avoid any impacts, there could be impacts to shallower wells.
In Southern Maryland, a drought warning is in effect based on monitoring that shows lower-than-normal rainfall and groundwater levels.

title: Statewide drought deepens, burn ban continues
author: FROM STAFF REPORTS
content:
Statewide drought deepens, burn ban continues

 November 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: FROM STAFF REPORTS | Section: State News 
 
 509
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland Department of the Environment is issuing drought watches and warnings across the state and urging residents and businesses to reduce water usage when possible.This follows six months of lower-than-average rainfall and virtually no rain this autumn. No state-issued mandatory water restrictions are in place at this time.
"We've had a very dry year overall, and monitoring shows an impact on water availability statewide," Maryland Department of the Environment Secretary Serena McIlwain said in a release. "While there is no immediate water shortage, we encourage residents and businesses to use water wisely as we continue to monitor the situation."
There is a statewide burn ban in effect since Nov. 1.
On the Eastern Shore, a drought warning is in effect based on monitoring that shows lower-than-normal precipitation, stream flows and groundwater levels in shallow aquifers.
Although most domestic wells in the region are deep enough to avoid any impacts, there could be impacts to shallower wells.
Despite some much-needed rain recently, the burn ban remains in effect for all of Maryland.
On Nov. 6 around 2:30 p.m., Waldorf Company 3 was dispatched to the area of Slater Lane, off Poplar Hill Road, to investigate the report of smoke.
Upon arrival, it was determined this was a large area brush fire and additional resources were requested, according to a release from the Waldorf Volunteer Fire Department.
The brush fire was indicative of the larger problem at hand — a drought that brought some of the driest weather that the region has seen within 130 years.
"While most of the state experienced varying amounts of rain earlier this week, fuel and drought conditions continue to be well above normal seasonal highs," a release from the Maryland Department of Natural Resources said last week. "These conditions coupled with low humidity and gusty winds expected in the next several days will once again raise fire danger across the state."
A return to normal seasonal patterns with cooler temperatures and frequent showers will be needed to lift the burn ban, the department said.
"We do not make these determinations lightly and understand this may require some people to adjust their plans," Department of Natural Resources Secretary Josh Kurtz said. "However, a ban of this magnitude is necessary to protect the lives and property of Maryland residents and visitors, as well as the state's natural resources."
Since Oct. 1, Maryland Department of Natural Resources units and partner agencies have responded to 50 wildland fires in the state that burned an estimated 117.8 acres of land.
As of Nov. 12, five of those fires are contained and actively staffed, 15 are contained and monitored by patrol, and 30 are out.
According to the National Integrated Drought Information System, a program under the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, 3.1 million residents of Maryland are in areas of drought.
That is roughly half the population of the state, according to census data.
Other states in the mid-Atlantic region are experiencing wildfires, according to DNR. One such blaze near the border of New York and New Jersey has burned roughly 3,500 acres as of Nov. 12, underscoring the importance of Maryland's burn ban.

title: Chesapeake recreation area passes Senate panel
author: ANDREA DURÁN Capital News Service
content:
Chesapeake recreation area passes Senate panel

 November 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA DURÁN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 694
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — The Chesapeake Bay area is one step closer to becoming part of the national parks system.The Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee on Tuesday passed the Chesapeake Bay National Recreation Area Act, moving it onto the Senate floor.
The measure, sponsored by Maryland Democratic Sen. Chris Van Hollen, would create the Chesapeake National Recreation Area in Maryland and Virginia and make it part of a network of sites overseen by the National Park Service.
"In Maryland, we know the Chesapeake Bay is a national treasure," Van Hollen said in a statement. "And creating the Chesapeake National Recreation Area will celebrate that fact while also bringing major benefits to the Bay."
"Not only will this open up more equitable public access to the Bay, the (Chesapeake National Recreation Act) will also mobilize additional federal support for restoration, shine a light on the untold stories of its history, and support greater economic opportunity in the region," the senator said.
One of the key goals of making the Chesapeake National Recreation Area part of the national parks system is to boost national pride in the bay and its history, amplifying the stories of historically underrepresented groups such as Indigenous and Black people.
"Today's bipartisan, unanimous vote was a big step forward in our efforts to pass this historic legislation," Van Hollen said.
In 2021, Van Hollen and Maryland Rep. John Sarbanes, a Democrat, created a working group to help draft the language for the legislation. The working group included Maryland Sen. Ben Cardin, a Democrat, Virginia Democratic Sens. Mark Warner and Tim Kaine, and Reps. Bobby Scott, D-Virginia, Rob Wittman, R-Virginia, and various conservation groups. Van Hollen and Sarbanes introduced the measure in the Senate and House, respectively, last year. However, the idea of the Chesapeake National Recreation Area dates as far back as the 1980s.
"The Chesapeake Bay is an extraordinary national treasure and a vital resource for our region," Sarbanes said in a statement. "I am thrilled that the Chesapeake National Recreation Area Act has advanced out of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee — a crucial milestone in our efforts to safeguard the Bay for the well-being and enjoyment of future generations."
Since the measure's introduction, several interested parties have submitted letters to Van Hollen in support of the legislation, including Rep.-elect Johnny Olszewski, Jr., Annapolis Mayor Gavin Buckley and Baltimore Mayor Brandon Scott.
"Thanks to Sen. Van Hollen's leadership, this is a great day for the Chesapeake Bay, with another step forward in the four-decade effort to establish National Park Service recognition for the nation's largest estuary," Chesapeake Conservancy President and CEO Joel Dunn said in a statement. "The Chesapeake Bay is as spectacular as Yellowstone or Yosemite, as great as the Great Smokies and as grand as the Grand Tetons."
The Chesapeake Recreation Area Act would make the park service take on a larger and more administrative role.
Currently, the National Park Service can partner with and provide assistance to local and regional organizations involved in the bay through the Chesapeake Gateways program and administers some sites along the watershed, including some national monument sites.
If the legislation is enacted, the park service would administer the Chesapeake Gateways and Watertrails Network, which encompasses about 200 places located within the Chesapeake Bay watershed.
However, the bill states that the Department of the Interior, through the National Park Service, would only acquire land and land-based resources within the recreation area boundaries from voluntary transfers by landowners. The bill also specifically states that the park service has to work with the Department of Transportation to minimize traffic around the bay as well as create an advisory board made up of nine representatives each from Maryland and Virginia.
The management and acquisition of sites would come from the park service's annual budget under the Department of the Interior, which is approved by Congress.
"Establishing the Chesapeake National Recreation Area expands resources for environmental protection and makes it clear that the United States cherishes the Chesapeake, the birthplace of American identity," Dunn said. "As a great gift to future generations, this legislation ensures public access to our nation's largest estuary while providing for the needs of those who live here and depend on the Bay for their livelihood."

The primary emphasis is on environmental preservation and the role of the National Park Service in managing natural resources.

title: Dorchester Circuit Court orders Valley Proteins must revise permit
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester Circuit Court orders Valley Proteins must revise permit

 November 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 481
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Dorchester County Circuit Court judge has remanded a wastewater discharge permit for the Valley Proteins plant in Linkwood.According to court documents, Dorchester County Circuit Judge William Jones said the permit needs to be revised to include terms that "ensure any discharges from the facility will conform to Maryland and federal law and ensure compliance with water quality standards in the Transquaking River watershed."
The opinion comes more than a year after the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, Dorchester Citizens for Planned Growth, Friends of the Nanticoke River, ShoreRivers and Wicomico Environmental Trust challenged the state's permit.
A news release from the Chesapeake Bay Foundation said the organizations challenged the permit in February 2023 because the permit failed to "meaningfully reduce" Valley Proteins' wastewater discharge, which contributes to "unhealthy water quality" in the Transquaking River, Higgins Mill Pond and Chesapeake Bay.
With the court's decision, the Maryland Department of the Environment will have to revise the permit.
Valley Proteins, an animal waste rendering facility in Dorchester County that processes poultry byproducts, is owned by Darling Ingredients. The Texas-based company acquired the plant in December 2021.
The Chesapeake Bay Foundation called the ruling "a huge win for clean water and the health of the Chesapeake Bay's tributaries."
Chesapeake Bay Foundation Maryland Advocacy Director Alan Girard said Valley Proteins contributes to the nitrogen discharged in the the Transquaking River watershed. He said the original permit didn't ensure the river and Higgins Mill Pond are safe for swimming, fishing and wildlife habitat.
Friends of the Nanticoke River President Jay Martin said in the news release that his organization is "encouraged" by the court's decision.
"The court has sent a clear message that we need more comprehensive oversight to ensure our waters are safe and healthy for all species that rely on them," he said.
Matt Pluta, Choptank riverkeeper and director of riverkeeper programs at ShoreRivers, said the decision "recognizes the value of clean water."
"Higgins Mill Pond and the upper Transquaking River are valuable resources that have repeatedly been neglected, and we hope that — through this remand — the state will seek opportunities to meaningfully protect and restore them and reverse the long history of pollution impacts," he said in the news release.
This is not the only time Valley Proteins has gotten into hot water for its practices.
In June, the Maryland Department of the Environment fined Darling Ingredients $15,000 for repeated pollution violations at its Linkwood facility. According to a news release from the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, department inspections revealed 51 violations made between August 2023 and March 2024 by the owner of Valley Proteins.
In 2022, the facility was put under a consent decree with the Maryland Department of the Environment, the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, ShoreRivers and Dorchester Citizens for Planned Growth. The consent degree ordered the facility owners to pay $540,000 in civil penalties to the state for its more than 40 violations of a discharge permit issued by the state.

title: 71-year-old spends season in Glacier National Park
author: Tom McCall
content:
71-year-old spends season in Glacier National Park

 November 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: News 
 
 480
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County resident Cheryl Krebeck spent a good chunk of her 72nd year in Montana's Glacier National Park. From April to October, she lived on the west side of the park in the northern Rockies.This curious woman loves to travel and is not letting a little arthritis get in the way.
"Traveling has been my passion, but when I turned 70, I decided I wanted this decade to be my most exciting," she said.
"I want to do more than just visit for a week or two," she said. "I really wanted to get to know this park. I went online, applied and got a job. I was hired to work in a hotel that was built in 1910 by the Great Northern railroad. I was a front desk person from 6 a.m. to 2 p.m."
When she was not making coffee and being a concierge for guests, she had regular challenges — like figuring what to do when a guest accidentally set off bear spray inside the hotel.
When she was not working, she got out into the park.
"Your best friends are the ones who have the same days off as you. You don't want to hike alone — there are a lot of grizzlies out there. That is what you are concerned with. Mountain lions could get you. I never saw one, but I had the feeling they were there," she said.
The more remote part of the park is the east side. When the snow subsides in mid June, the Sun Road opens and connects the two sides of the park.
"You see sharper peaks, more glaciers and more snow on top of the mountains. Most of my animal sightings were on the east side. Partly because there are less people," she said.
She hiked the Highline Trail up at Logan Pass. It reaches 6,600 feet.
"It was high for me. I saw a black bear on that hike. It was nice it was not a grizzly," she said.
Another aspect of the journey was that she was much older than most of her fellow workers. A lot of college students take a summer to do this.
"When I look back to being 19 years old, I don't think I had an appreciation for what 70 might have felt like. Some of the first hikes I went on were with young people. They were kind. It really added to it," she said.
Krebeck thinks her traveling has given her a big sky kind of attitude. She loves being outside and inhaling. She is thinking a trip to the Amazon is next.
"It is a big world out there, and I feel like I have a perspective because I have traveled. Sometimes you meet closed-minded people and can tell they haven't been anywhere. They haven't talked to anybody from anywhere else. There is a big old world out there, and it is worth checking out," she said.

title: Maryland gives go-ahead to wind project despite objections from Ocean City residents
author: Sofia Appolonio Capital News Service
content:
Maryland gives go-ahead to wind project despite objections from Ocean City residents

 November 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Sofia Appolonio Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 388
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Top state officials approved a permit last week needed to begin an offshore windmill project in the Delmarva Peninsula, despite objections from Ocean City residents worried about the environmental impact on local wetlands.The application, proposed by Baltimore wind company US Wind, requested to expand a 353-foot long pier in West Ocean City used by local fishers. The permit is part of the company's plan to build offshore wind turbines and bring renewable energy to Maryland.
Supporters and opponents of the proposal spoke before the Board of Public Works for nearly two hours on Wednesday, some of them delivering passionate pleas. The board voted unanimously to approve.
Secretary of the Maryland Department of the Environment Serena McIlwain argued in favor of the proposal, saying it passed department review.
"We made our decision based solely on the size of the pier in linear feet, the impact to the waterway and sediments and other technical questions that we always ask for permits," she said. "And [the proposal] met everything."
Multiple Eastern Shore residents, officials and community leaders expressed their opposition toward the potential negative economic, environmental and cultural impacts of the proposal.
They said they felt their concerns for local businesses and fishers were not addressed thoroughly during the application process.
Ocean City Mayor Richard Meehan said that despite offers of compensation, fishers — locally referred to as "watermen" — would prefer to retain access to the pier and continue their livelihood with fishing.
"We believe it's more important to our local area and the state of Maryland that our fishing can remain a vibrant part of our economy rather than being displaced for a foreign developer's project," he said.
"Compensation will eliminate the fishing industry and will eliminate jobs," he said. "Is that really the goal of the state of Maryland?"
Comptroller Brooke Lierman, a member of the Board of Public Works, expressed her sympathy for concerned residents but stated that the decision on the wetlands license only concerns the existing pier. The permit is not to approve the operation of wind turbines or any future plans with offshore wind.
"We are not permitted to look at what this is actually being used for," Lierman said. "We are looking at what is actually happening regarding the physical structure. What this pier will be used for is not dispositive, and it's not even something we take into account."

title: Plumpton Park Zoo could be growing by 2... giraffes
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content:
Plumpton Park Zoo could be growing by 2... giraffes

 December 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: State News 
 
 354
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RISING SUN — Plumpton Park Zoo has the opportunity to get not one, but two female giraffes for its male giraffe, Kazar, who has been the lone giraffe at the zoo since May 2023.Kazar arrived at the zoo at 1416 Telegraph Road in Rising Sun as a mate for Annabelle in Dec. 2021. Annabelle was brought to the zoo in May 2018 with the plan to have her mate with Jimmie, the elder statesman to Plumpton Park.
At the age of 25, however, Jimmie had to be euthanized because of declining health. He was the oldest giraffe in captivity at the time. Annabelle succumbed to an incurable infection in May 2023.
"We've been fundraising for a new giraffe since we lost Annabelle," said Cheryl Lacovara, director of Plumpton Park Zoo. She said the zoo needs about $175,000 more to purchase females available from facilities in Louisiana and Arizona.
"The daddy at Louisiana is getting really amorous, and they don't have the facilities to keep them separate," Lacovara said recently. A veterinarian familiar with Plumpton Park's conservation efforts has recommended that female should be relocated to Rising Sun.
The staff at a conservation center in Arizona heard about the zoo's conservation efforts and wants to participate. That's how Plumpton Park will get that second giraffe.
Since becoming owners of Plumpton Park Zoo in 2010, Cheryl and Nicholas Lacovara have been working with international conservation organizations on efforts to preserve this species of giraffe known as reticulated.
According to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife these giant animals are threatened by loss of habitat, poaching, climate change and other issues, which have shortened the wild population by 77% since 1985. It's being called a "silent extinction" because it is happening slowly and without notice.
There are eight species and two sub-Saharan species of giraffe — Kordofan and Nubian — are now classified as critically endangered. The reticulated giraffe — which includes Kazar, Jimmie and Annabelle — is considered endangered but because of its dwindling wild population may soon be reclassified as critically endangered.
Lacovera is hoping to get help from the community to raise the needed funds to bring two females to the zoo.

The permit is part of the company's plan to build offshore wind turbines and bring renewable energy to Maryland.
Supporters and opponents of the proposal spoke before the Board of Public Works for nearly two hours on Wednesday, some of them delivering passionate pleas. The board voted unanimously to approve.
Secretary of the Maryland Department of the Environment Serena McIlwain argued in favor of the proposal, saying it passed department review.
"We made our decision based solely on the size of the pier in linear feet, the impact to the waterway and sediments and other technical questions that we always ask for permits," she said. "And [the proposal] met everything."
Multiple Eastern Shore residents, officials and community leaders expressed their opposition toward the potential negative economic, environmental and cultural impacts of the proposal.
They said they felt their concerns for local businesses and fishers were not addressed thoroughly during the application process.
Ocean City Mayor Richard Meehan said that despite offers of compensation, fishers — locally referred to as "watermen" — would prefer to retain access to the pier and continue their livelihood with fishing.
"We believe it's more important to our local area and the state of Maryland that our fishing can remain a vibrant part of our economy rather than being displaced for a foreign developer's project," he said.
"Compensation will eliminate the fishing industry and will eliminate jobs," he said. "Is that really the goal of the state of Maryland?"
Comptroller Brooke Lierman, a member of the Board of Public Works, expressed her sympathy for concerned residents but stated that the decision on the wetlands license only concerns the existing pier. The permit is not to approve the operation of wind turbines or any future plans with offshore wind.
"We are not permitted to look at what this is actually being used for," Lierman said. "We are looking at what is actually happening regarding the physical structure. What this pier will be used for is not dispositive, and it's not even something we take into account."

title: New Cambridge solar ordinance will have 'immediate effect'
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com

New Cambridge solar ordinance will have 'immediate effect'

 December 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 561
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Along with passing an ordinance regarding solar energy systems on wooded lots, the Cambridge City Council has directed city staff to look into removing community solar from a 350-acre maximum on solar permitted in the city.During a City Council meeting on Dec. 9, the council unanimously approved an ordinance amending the city's Unified Development Code for solar energy systems on wooded lots. Specifically, the amendment allows small-scale solar and community solar on wooded lots as long as the solar project complies with the city's Forest Conservation Ordinance or the state's Model Forest Conservation Ordinance.
Before the ordinance was passed, Cambridge Planning and Zoning Director Brian Herrmann said it was consistent with the city's comprehensive plan and the Planning and Zoning Commission had approved it in early November.
Herrmann said the ordinance would apply to sites that are at least 40,000 square feet. He said requirements of the ordinance include that the area cleared on the wooded lot cannot exceed 10 acres and impacted trees must be replanted at a 2-to-1 ratio or a fee be paid in lieu.
Small-scale solar energy systems are typically located on a homeowner's property, Herrmann said.
"It's essentially generating electricity where it is used," he said.
Community solar energy systems provide power to the residents of a community. Herrmann said that in Maryland, 40% of the output of a community solar system must serve low- to moderate-income residents.
During the meeting, Tony Kupersmith, a lawyer representing a renewable energy company, said the company he represents has a community solar project on Leonards Lane and this ordinance is "critical" for that project.
"So I get to let you know that what you do tonight would have an immediate effect for an actual project that is ready to go forward, that wants to go forward, and the only issue right now holding us up is the wooded lot issue," Kupersmith said before requesting the council adopt the ordinance.
Herrmann told the council that the city's 350-acre solar maximum — which it is close to reaching — limits the impact of this ordinance.
"We have two projects in the final stages of the development review process," he said. "If those two are to go through, we're going to be at 325 acres. So there's only about 25 acres left before we actually hit this amount. So I guess you can see we're not talking about a lot of solar systems that are going to be built even if this does pass."
Commissioner Brian Roche asked why community solar is included in that 350-acre maximum that also includes medium- and large-scale solar energy systems. He said it should be excluded.
"We don't want to see our entire land base covered with solar panel projects, but the way I understand community solar is really it is to the benefit of people that cannot either put it on their roof (and) they want to collaborate ... or they otherwise may not be able to have it," he said. "To me, I would strike that out from that maximum."
Roche asked that only medium- and large-scale solar energy systems be included in the 350-acre maximum and not community solar energy systems.
City Attorney Patrick Thomas said that because Roche's request goes "beyond the scope" of the ordinance on the table, it would need to go through a separate text amendment process. He said a separate ordinance to address the maximum could be prepared.

title: New Southern Maryland wildlife refuge hailed as future of conservation
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
New Southern Maryland wildlife refuge hailed as future of conservation

 December 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 539
 Words 

 Read News Document

 If you were a bird migrating along the Atlantic Flyway, your rest stop options now include Southern Maryland.Secretary of the Interior Deb Haaland and U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service Director Martha Williams joined partners and community members in Charles County on Dec. 13 to celebrate the establishment of Southern Maryland Woodlands National Wildlife Refuge as the 573rd and newest unit of the National Wildlife Refuge System.
A newly acquired 31-acre parcel in Nanjemoy is the first of several donations that will become part of the new refuge and provide a crucial protected habitat for threatened and endangered species and expand outdoor recreational opportunities for the 10 million people who visit, live and work in the Washington-Baltimore metropolitan region, a release from the Fish and Wildlife service said.
"Today, we mark an incredible milestone in locally led conservation efforts as we welcome the Southern Maryland Woodlands National Wildlife Refuge into our National Wildlife Refuge System," said Haaland. "Across the nation, the Biden-Harris administration has partnered with local communities, partners and tribes to protect treasured places, bolster climate resilience, and ensure current and future generations have public lands and waters to enjoy and recreate. Our collective work will ensure the health and enduring legacy of the National Wildlife Refuge System."
"This is the future of conservation," Williams said at the establishment ceremony on Dec. 13. "This is a time of hope. … We have seen nature heal when we give it a chance."
The Southern Maryland refuge marks the sixth addition to the Refuge System under Haaland.
The department has also announced the expansion of several existing national wildlife refuges, which will allow for the voluntary conservation of up to 1.13 million acres of important wildlife habitat, the release said.
Charles County Commissioner President Reuben B. Collins II (D) said that by conserving these lands Southern Maryland can help provide sanctuary for those who seek somewhere to get away from the hustle and bustle of daily life.
The 31-acre parcel near Nanjemoy is the first of several intended donations by The Nature Conservancy that over the next few months will permanently protect and conserve more than 300 acres of interior forest and riparian wetlands habitat, supporting northern long-eared bats, forest-interior songbirds, box turtles and several species of salamanders that are of conservation concern, the release said.
Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.) said, "Now, we're going to have that kind of amazing place right here in Southern Maryland."
More than half of Maryland's forests and wetlands have been lost in the conversion of important natural areas to other land uses, with more than 1 million acres developed since 1973. The region's population is projected to surpass 20 million people in the next 10 years, according to the release.
"There's no better time to do it," President and CEO of the Chesapeake Conservancy Joel Dunn said. "A recent report shows a 73% decline in the average size of modern wildlife population throughout the world … which is very disturbing."
"I am thrilled to welcome the Southern Maryland Woodlands National Wildlife Refuge into the National Refuge System," Haaland said. "We must address inequitable access to nature and its benefits for underrepresented communities."
Recreation at national wildlife refuges supports regional economies with approximately $3.2 billion per year and supports more than 41,000 jobs, the release said.

While economic and governmental aspects are mentioned, the core theme is environmental conservation.

title: A map geek’s quest to clean the nation, 1 watershed at a time
author: Alisha Camacho Capital News Service
content:
A map geek’s quest to clean the nation, 1 watershed at a time

 December 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Alisha Camacho Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 1411
 Words 

 Read News Document

 By 11 a.m., Jon Merryman had collected 45 tires, 38 bags of trash, packs of shingles, a mattress, a playpen and remnants of an accident swept under a guardrail near College Park, Maryland.Merryman, 62, was frustrated and restless. The Nov. 6 election hadn't gone his way. A veteran and a man of action, he turned to a lifelong passion to cope: picking up trash.
Over the following days, he cleaned up roadsides in 22 counties spanning Virginia and West Virginia.
"I call it channeling my anger," Merryman said, tone dropping.
Physical work helps him maintain his emotional and mental health. When he returned home to Catonsville, Merryman felt more rejuvenated and ready to face what came next. For him, cleaning up litter is a way to reclaim control, one piece of trash at a time, in a world that can feel overwhelming.
"I want people to feel like one person can make a difference," he said.
Merryman traces his passion for protecting the environment to campaigns from his childhood. Campaigns like "Smokey the Bear." "Woodsy the Owl." The 1970s commercial "Keep America Beautiful: The Crying Indian."
While controversial today, the "Keep America Beautiful" ad had a simple message for 7-year-old Merryman: "People start pollution. People can stop it." Inspired, he planned a post-Halloween mission to clean up wrappers and litter. With a full bucket, Merryman marched down to a storm drain, thinking that's where the trash should go.
"Thank God an adult was there," he said. The passerby explained how storm drains lead to rivers. He didn't know it yet, but Merryman would dedicate much of his adult life to rectifying this mistake.
The makings of a soldierMerryman's cousins, conservationists on Maryland's Eastern Shore, took him under their wings and ignited a passion for studying the environment. They invited him on bird banding and counting trips. Merryman remembers the sky filling with "rivers of birds" for 15 minutes at a time. Clicker in hand, he counted birds until his hand grew weary.
"You're witnessing the miracles of being on earth when you see stuff like that," Merryman said.
His cousins later dissuaded him from becoming a marine biologist.
"They got me geared up for this life of studying animals, then said, 'Oh, you don't want to do that. It's a life of chasing grants.'"
Merryman entered the University of Delaware as a biology major. Switched to geology. Jumped to civil engineering. His GPA plummeted. He pivoted to part-time status while working for the university. Eventually, he found his footing in geography while programming educational software. Also minored in photography.
His first summer out of college, Merryman worked as a volunteer ranger at the Grand Canyon, giving talks, leading groups and picking up trash in front of the visitor center. "Funny thing is, that's what I love to do now: pick up trash."
The staff liked him and encouraged him to apply for a seasonal park ranger job, but then Congress slashed funding, so the job didn't exist.
Merryman took on seasonal jobs. While working in the Everglades, he saw a billboard promoting the army's college fund.
It offered $20K for two years of service.
"Great option," he thought. He enlisted in the army and spent six years in the National Guard.
'My wife puts up with a lot'When Merryman returned to civilian life, he worked in instructional technology. "As it turns out, there's a lot of commonality between arranging the elements of a map and arranging the elements on a computer screen," he said.
But his passion for the environment remained. One day, while working at Lockheed Martin, Merryman came across a trash-strewn creek and park. He spent five years turning it into a sustainable habitat.
His hobby of picking up trash also found its way home. "My driveway was full, I mean seriously, full of scrap metal," he said. He sold the metal from cleanups to fund his kids' robotics team. "The things we do," Merryman chuckled.
Through it all, he said, it took a lot of patience from his wife, Kirsten. "The spouses that put up with it are angels, too. They are. My wife puts up with a lot."
Turns out, so do his kids.
Litter everywhere in the middle of nowhere
A common conundrum Merryman encounters is people acknowledging a problem but not taking responsibility. "Someone else is doing the littering. It's those people," they think.
Merryman became determined to show that littering is everyone's problem. During a road trip with his son to Los Angeles, an idea emerged, and they cleaned up trash in one county per state, adding two counties for Texas.
When they arrived "in the middle of nowhere" in Turkey, Texas, Merryman found "litter everywhere." He wanted people to realize that we are all responsible for this pile of trash because of all the things we buy and the resources we use.
To illustrate the extent of trash pollution, he started placing green dots on a map of counties he'd clean up.
"I'm a map geek," Merryman said. He had been tracking all the counties he visited for years, a hobby shared by fellow geographers. Now, he aims to pick up trash in every county for as long as possible.
Recently, he picked his daughter up from school in Ithaca, New York. As they left Ithaca and crossed over into the Chesapeake Bay watershed, an idea "dawned on me," he said.
He'd picked up trash in counties between Ithaca and Baltimore, having done this drive many times. "I put those on the map," Merryman said when he realized he was nearly halfway done. "I bet I could do them all" in the watershed.
He now focuses on watersheds rather than state lines. Water carries pollution across borders, so "state boundaries don't matter as much as the watershed," he said.
On Dec. 1, 2024, Merryman reached his goal. He picked up trash in all 206 counties in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. Bringing his total count to 524. One-sixth of all counties in the United States.
Sharkey d'SharkOn February 2, 2022, at 2:22 p.m., Merryman retired — a moment he carefully planned. "I walked out the door," said Merryman. "I just thought it was funny."
A few months later, Merryman found his retirement buddy, Sharkey d' Shark, on the side of the road. The abandoned toy-turned-sidekick became a playful way to engage others in cleanups.
Sharkey has a social media presence. "It's a lot easier to have a back-and-forth conversation with Sharkey," Merryman said, "as opposed to writing posts and getting crickets in response."
Merryman hopes Sharkey can help educate and inspire younger generations to partake in cleanups. For now, "about 90% of Sharky's fans are middle-aged women," he laughed.
Nature is innocentWhen not traveling to pick up trash, Merryman volunteers with Lights Out Baltimore, searching for dead or injured birds hit by windows due to disorienting artificial lights.
"Nature, as far as I'm concerned, is all innocent," Merryman said. Migrating birds navigate at night using the moon and stars, but lights lead them to windows. "There's a reason it's happening. It's not because the bird's stupid," he said. The birds can't see the glass.
Not long ago, Merryman found an old Facebook post when he first joined the group and held a bird for the first time in decades. Now, he's active in several Facebook groups where he educates others about window strikes. Sharing photos of the dead birds tends to upset people, especially those who have already seen them.
On the one hand, Merryman speaks to newcomers who aren't aware of this issue and spreads awareness "over and over and over again." On the other hand, some people complain and don't want to see the photos.
"I'm sorry if it makes you feel squeamish," Merryman said, his tone serious. He paused. "Actually, I'm not. I'm not sorry," he said with a wry laugh. "I hope that it will make you care about it."
It is a difficult line to walk — getting people to care without turning them away. "I'm just not good at drawing that line personally," he admitted.
But he is good at showing up and doing the dirty work. "I'm happy to be the grunt, the foot soldier."
Merryman has a plan for the rest of his retirement. He is going to pick up trash in every county in the United States. Until he physically can't anymore. Then he hopes to write a book.
So far, he's crossed off Arizona, Vermont, New Hampshire, Maryland, Virginia, Delaware, and New Jersey while nearing the finish line in Pennsylvania and Virginia.
Maybe he won't reach his goal. "But I'm gonna die trying." And maybe the world will be a little cleaner, with a few more birds in it.

title: ShoreRivers welcomes new board members

ShoreRivers welcomes new board members

 December 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Business

 EASTERN SHORE — ShoreRivers has added three new members to its Governing Board: Jack Broderick, Ann Swanson and Loribeth Weinstein.As a grassroots nonprofit organization, the work and support of board members is imperative to the organization's efforts for thriving rivers on the Eastern Shore, ShoreRivers said in a press release.
"ShoreRivers extends deep gratitude for the wise counsel, encouragement, and vision of these exceptional community members," the release said. "... These new voices will bring a wealth of expertise to ShoreRivers, including equal opportunity and civil rights, social and economic justice, grantmaking and local governance, and environmental policy and conservation. Paired with a deep commitment to clean water and healthy Eastern Shore communities, these new members will strengthen the organization's robust science-based advocacy, restoration, and education efforts."
Broderick is a retired federal manager and longtime community activist and leader on Kent Island who serves on numerous local and state boards and committees, including the Maryland 250 Commission and the Bay Bridge Reconstruction Advisory Group.
A former captain in the U.S. Army, he retired in 2021 as the director of equal opportunity for the National Guard Bureau, U.S. Department of Defense, after 34 years of combined Federal military and civilian service. Broderick lives on Cox Creek and enjoys crabbing, fishing, hunting and spending time on the water.
The former executive director of the Chesapeake Bay Commission, Swanson has spent four decades as a leader in Chesapeake Bay restoration and been recognized for her work on a regional, national and international scale. Swanson was the catalyst for the early formation of the Chester River Association and the Sassafras River Association — two of ShoreRivers' legacy organizations.
In recognition of that, and her tireless efforts on behalf of the Bay and its landscapes and communities, she was the winner of ShoreRivers' inaugural Award for Environmental Stewardship in 2019.
Weinstein spent her career at the helm of nonprofit and philanthropic organizations addressing issues of gender parity and social and economic justice. Now retired, she served for two decades as the CEO of Jewish Women International, an organization committed to protecting the rights of women and girls, and is a founder of the Washington Area Women's Foundation, a philanthropic organization that has provided more than $16 million in grants to organizations in the Washington, D.C., region since 1999.
She has a love of Eastern Shore waterways that inspired her to deepen her commitment to environmental stewardship, and is also a Master Gardener.
In addition to its new members, the board also recently elected its Executive Committee for 2025, which consists of Marian Fry, chair; Barbara Boyd, vice chair; Frank Lewis, treasurer; Maura Bollinger, secretary, and Gene Lopez, at-large.
ShoreRivers also celebrates several long-time board members whose terms end this year: Meta Boyd, Bruce Abel, Ron Rothman and Philp Webster.

title: Rock fish advisory board sides with no action for now
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Rock fish advisory board sides with no action for now

 January 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 995
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON DC — On Dec. 16, during an Atlantic State Marine Fishery Commission meeting, through the Atlantic Striped Bass Management Board, a decision was reached to keep the current recreational fishing regulations in place for 2025.The motion passed with two parties opposed — Maine and New Hampshire.
No changes were made, unlike in January of last year, where the commission approved new rules limiting recreational anglers, permitting only one fish per person within 19 to 24 inches, a decision not popular with many anglers on the Eastern Shore.
The commission arrived at the decision of no-action early in the afternoon, choosing to "initiate an addendum to support striped bass rebuilding by 2029 in consideration of 2024 recreational and commercial mortality (dead fish), while balancing socioeconomic impacts."
Capt. Rob Newberry, chair of the Atlantic Fishery Association who has appeared before Kent County Commissioners numerous times over these issues, is not convinced the commission needs to take any action now or in the future. As one of many that attended the Dec. 16 meeting virtually, he outlined the reasons for the board's December ruling.
"They weighed in on the side of caution. They'll collect more data and make a decision Oct. 23-25, their annual meeting, with changes applying to 2026 season," he noted.
Ultimately they will reduce limits in recreational and commercial, adjusting seasons, setting limits and no-harvesting or no-targeting closures.
Newberry described it as "kicking the can down the road."
Board Chair Megan Ware told Shore Daily News in a recent interview: "We understand that many will be disappointed in the board's decision to initiate an addendum versus taking immediate action. However, after deliberating for more than three hours about the path forward, the board came to the conclusion that the best course of action is to proceed with an addendum which will allow for clarity on 2024 removals and additional analyses."
The Dec. 16 board meeting was led by Ware in collaboration with presenters Tyler Grabowski, chair of the Technical Committee, and Emilie Franke, the FMP coordinator.
In the virtual meeting, Grabowski presented a list of options that would possibly lead to at least a 14% reduction to the fisheries to reduce mortality rates under the status quo based on current projections.
These included shortening fishing seasons, changing recreational slot limits, (fish size) adding closures in specific regions (like the Bay) and discussions of no-harvest and no-target. He used Marine Recreational Information Program data highlighted in their assessment report.
"I want to thank the TC (technical committee) board for their heroic effort of getting these to us for our meeting," Ware said, recognizing their time restraints.
Franke presented, previously responding to over 2,000 pages of the public comment summary and advisory panel report, since they do not have an acting chair there.
Board members were advised to focus on questions only to enable their vote.
As of Sept. 10, Franke reported they received comments from 40 organizations, 976 comments through four form letters and 1,621 individual comments. Of those, 2,853 supported taking action and 517 wanted no action.
Questions and comments were posed like how much of a reduction, how the reduction be split among commercial and recreational fishers, how to split reductions between states(equity), how to change size limits, among many other topics of concern.
There were two options on the board then: addendum and motion to action.
The amended action option was offered by board member Adam Nowalsky of New Jersey, seconded by Emerson Hasbrouck of New York, calling for action in 2025 to achieve a 9% reduction and decrease the commercial quotas by 5%.
Board members decided on the addendum instead, matching with the 2024 Stock Assessment Update that indicates while the resource remains overfished it is not currently experiencing overfishing.
Newberry is not hopeful of this resolve. His solution is more simple, not requiring much deliberation at all. Get out of the commission, he stated, and pull back the $750,000 a year to be a part of the compact; Maryland can establish their own fishery board.
In Newberry's opinion, the commission's metrics for measuring rock fish mortality is not accurate. For one, he stated, Maryland's commercial fishermen operate under a three-tiered system when it comes to reporting, and is reliable. But how can the commission report numbers reliably for over 200,000 or more recreational anglers?
"Have you ever met a fisherman honest about his catches," he joked but made the larger point the measuring methods cannot be trusted.
During the board meeting, the states that tended to side with Maryland on many issues were Delaware, New Jersey, New York, Virginia, Rhode Island and Connecticut, he said.
But North Carolina, Florida and Maine were opposite of Maryland on many issues.
Newberry said that states like Maine, not having a rockfish fishery allocation, should be disqualified from voting.
Furthermore, he claimed that the commission as it currently operates is unconstitutional, and lamented that it is grown to such a bureaucracy as it has today, what was originally founded to ensure fish for the public and fish oil to use for our military weapons.
"The opinion of the Delmarva Fisheries Association, Maryland Charter Boat Association and our legal council is that ASMFC has been unconstitutionally been applying regulations on the commercial and recreational fishers since 1984."
In 1984 there was a decision to enforce fisheries, but was never ratified by Congress, Newberry said. Newberry was referring to the passage of the Atlantic Striped Bass Conservation Act, which gave the ASMFC authority to require states to adopt measures to manage striped bass, in response to the collapse of the Atlantic striped bass population in the 70s and 80s.
He warned of the compact between states, that operates under majority rule, mentioning failure to comply is enforced by federal government through the Department of Commerce.
Department of Natural Resources science writer Joe Zimmermann said there are no plans nor discussions for getting out of the commission.
He referred to some sources the public can see how the Maryland Department of Natural Resources contribute to the ASMFC data: The Maryland Department of Natural Resources contributes data, such as the Maryland young-of-year striped bass index at maryland.gov/dnr.

Lakeside permit challenge rejected by Maryland Appellate Court

 January 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 580
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — The Maryland Appellate Court has rejected a challenge by the Chesapeake Bay Foundation arguing that a groundwater discharge permit does not comply with water quality standards.The Maryland Department of the Environment issued the permit to the Town of Trappe in 2020, authorizing the spraying of treated wastewater on land from the Trappe East Wastewater facility owned by the Town of Trappe and Lakeside at Trappe developers.
The spray irrigation is part of a plan to service the Lakeside at Trappe development, which is proposed to bring more than 2,000 homes to the area when complete.
In an opinion filed by Judge Stuart Berger on Dec. 23, the court found the permit incorporates a nutrient management plan that meets the requirements needed for use on the property.
"The Department determined that the measures included in the Permit and (nutrient management plan) would achieve the assurance of complete uptake of nitrogen and phosphorus from the effluent as required by EN § 9-1110 (requirements for the facility that 'assures' 100% uptake of nitrogen and phosphorus in the effluent). That determination was supported by substantial evidence and the decision to issue the Permit was well within the Department's discretion," the opinion states.
Additionally, the opinion said Maryland law requires the department to encourage the use of reclaimed water as an alternative to discharging wastewater effluent into the surface waters of the state.
The Chesapeake Bay Foundation was represented by attorney Paul Smail, vice president for litigation and general counsel for the foundation. In a statement sent to the Star Democrat, Smail said though the decision was not in the foundation's favor, the foundation is still considering different options moving forward.
"The decision is disappointing, and we are weighing our options," Smail said. "Maryland's General Assembly explicitly requires zero net discharge as a condition of land application of treated wastewater from community sewerage systems such as this. If the legal requirement of no additional pollution cannot be guaranteed under all circumstances, then Lakeside at Trappe's treatment system simply should not be permitted."
The foundation initially filed a lawsuit in February 2021 challenging the permit with partners. In September 2023, the foundation appealed the Talbot County Circuit Court's decision to uphold the department's discharge permit with the Appellate Court of Maryland.
Smail argued that under state law, Lakeside would need to assure 100% uptake of nutrients, meaning that all nitrogen and phosphorus from the wastewater discharge must be taken up by vegetation so as to not pollute nearby land and water.
The foundation argued the approach the department has taken is inappropriate and violates federal and state law. But the department maintained the permit meets or exceeds groundwater quality standards.
Attorney Matthew Patrick Clagett represented the Maryland Department of the Environment. Clagett said the central question is whether or not the department should have issued the permit as a state discharge permit or a federal discharge permit.
Additionally, he said the court should reject arguments made by the foundation because the permit authorizes discharge only to groundwater protected exclusively by state law, and the permit protects the groundwater quality by incorporating the nutrient management plan as required by Maryland.
Chesapeake Bay Foundation shared in a statement its concerns with the appellate court's decision.
"The court's decision to uphold the permit allows (the Maryland Department of the Environment) to continue permitting land application of municipal wastewater on an ad hoc basis without an appropriate regulatory framework that assures a zero net discharge to reduce nutrient pollution to our waterways, as required by Maryland law," the foundation said.

title: Marine fishery insider explains rockfish decision
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Marine fishery insider explains rockfish decision

 January 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 516
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Maryland officials are standing firm with Atlantic coast partners in their mission to rebuild striped bass (rockfish) populations by 2029 despite pushback from local fishing industry leaders over current restrictions.The Atlantic State Marine Fishery Commission voted Dec. 16 to maintain existing recreational fishing regulations for 2025, with only Maine and New Hampshire opposing.
"The stakes would be too high" to abandon interstate cooperation, said Maryland Department of Natural Resources Associate Director Mark Luisi, responding to industry calls for Maryland to establish its own commission. The decision affects fishing limits across multiple states from Virginia to Delaware.
Luisi, a native of south New Jersey, has been working at the governor's office for 25 years now, and is a board member on the ASMFC, sitting as the proxy on the administrative side under Lynn Waller Fegley, DNR director, Fishing and Boating Services.
Serving alongside Luisi, are governor appointee Russell Dize, a certified licensed captain from Tilghman, and Maryland Delegate Dana Stein and proxies David Sikorski, executive director of Coastal Conservation Association Maryland and Allison Colden, executive director of the Chesapeake Bay Foundation.
Capt. Rob Newberry, chairman of the Atlantic Fishing Association, challenged the commission's data collection methods, particularly for recreational fishing. He praised Maryland's three-tier commercial tracking system but argued recreational catches lack similar oversight.
His emboldened message to the ASMFC was "leave us alone," in hopes Maryland would establish their own fishery commission, breaking from the compact of Atlantic states formed in 1942 by Congress.
Newberry was not satisfied with the decision from ASMFC, claiming they were kicking the "can down the road," then called in question the reliability of their recording methods which will determine how many fish anglers catch in 2026.
Luisi emphasized there are no plans for Maryland to abandon the ASMFC. He said the stakes would be too high, and too many states depend on the organization. What affects Virginia, for example also affects neighbors, Delaware and Maryland and so on.
So, since breaking from ASMFC is not an option, Luisi said he strives for accuracy and understanding, hearing concerns from stakeholders as they move to the goal of rebuilding the stock (Atlantic striped bass, or rockfish population) by 2029.
Luisi defended the commission's approach, noting that rockfish's status as the East Coast's most popular sport fish — with over 200,000 recreational anglers — provides reliable data through dock surveys.
"It just provides an estimate," Luisi said, "and I'm pretty confident of the numbers we get in rockfish."
The commission uses computer modeling similar to weather forecasting to predict mortality rates. Their latest assessment found waters "slightly overfished," leading to last year's limit of one rockfish per person.
According to Luisi, to control population levels, regulators can only:
Limit or close seasons.
Set size limits.
Control the number of fish that can be kept.
"Outside of that, such as environmental factors affecting population, we can't control effort," Luisi concluded.
Despite Newberry's claims, Luisi insisted these regulations are not there to hurt the fishing industry. On the contrary, the surveys encourage fishers to be "right in the middle" of the decision-making process.
The commission will decide on further action at their October meeting, following eight months of stakeholder discussions.

title: Eastern Shore Delegation discusses birds, trails and historic preservation
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Eastern Shore Delegation discusses birds, trails and historic preservation

 January 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: General Assembly

 The Eastern Delegation of the Maryland General Assembly brought forth topics pertinent to constituents, including the avian influenza recently swooped into the area and developments of community connectivity at its first weekly delegation meeting of this session Jan. 17.Secretary of Natural Resources Josh Kurtz presented updates regarding avian influenza outbreaks and noted the Department of Natural Resources has expanded its long-term contract with the USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service to provide more wildlife technicians to dispose of dead birds that could be carrying the disease.
Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) noted disappointment with DNR's recent response to the avian influenza and reiterated better communication is needed for concerned citizens to get help they need without a runaround.
Kurtz noted the Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control was also following a similar model and the two states are now working to stay consistent in informing the public on available tools.
Kurtz noted additional DNR developments for the Eastern Shore, including working with Caroline County on a public lands bill to assist Program Open Space funding.
Funds that come into DNR's "user pay, user benefit," model go directly to programs to benefit the community, he said.
DNR recently received one million dollars from the Middle Chesapeake Sentinel Landscape Resilience Project for easement purchases near Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge and Fishing Bay, according to Kurtz.
DNR also received a grant from the Environmental Protection Agency for $43 million to improve forest management on 1,000 acres of the Eastern Shore and help develop a regional forestry management plan, he said.
TRANSPORTATIONFocusing on long term strategic planning to improve operating rail lines, the Maryland Department of Transportation is moving toward the establishment of a public-private partnership, according to Jaclyn Hartman, assistant secretary of transportation investments.
The Eastern Shore has a total of 92 miles of rail line, with 65 in active use. The rail lines are currently owned by the Maryland Transit Administration and operated by the Maryland and Delaware Railroad Company, Hartman said.
With the current operating lease is expiring, MDOT is thinking strategically about how to secure a long term operator and improve service delivery and maintenance on those routes.
Moving to a public-private partnership will ensure one entity has authority, rather than it being split between the operator and the state. The partnership will instigate long-term plans for the rail lines, "and unfortunately that's one of the things that we're kind of lacking today," Hartman said.
For the maintenance of the rails, MDOT would establish a private financing, expecting the private operator to invest some of its own money in the rail lines with the ability to keep those revenues in the future as a return on investment.
MDOT considered the project a win-win opportunity that most closely resembled the successful Seagrit Marine Terminal public private partnership established in the Port of Baltimore in 2008, Hartman said.
In the next couple of months, MDOT will begin industry outreach and move forward on requests for proposals for the private operator.
MARITIME MUSEUMPresenting an outline of program facilities preserving the cultural legacy of the state, Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum officials sought the Eastern Shore Delegation's help replacing aging HVAC systems in two buildings filled with irreplaceable artifacts.
Pete Lesher, chief historian for the museum, noted since 1965, CBMM has been dedicated to visitors and locals alike, preserving the environment and cultural heritage of the area as a tourism center, as well as a community museum.
CBMM preserves 90,000 objects of historical significance and tell local stories of the Bay at its campus in St. Michaels.
The museum also serves as a key economic driver for the Eastern Shore, bringing in visitors and millions of dollars to the area, said Jeff Vogel, CBMM Government Relations Committee chair.
Recognizing it was an exceedingly difficult budget season, Del. Chris Adams (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) noted CBMM was more than a local asset, but a landmark of history for the state.
TRAIL NETWORKSeeking to connect the area and strengthen community through the Maryland Eastern Shore Trail Network, Owen Bailey, director of land use and policy of the Eastern Shore Land Conservancy, and Patti Stevens, chair of the Worcester County Bike and Pedestrian Coalition, presented visions and goals to connect communities through a safe and sustainable trail network.
The mission of the Eastern Shore Trail Network Group is to galvanize a coalition of communities to support, plan, promote and advocate for diverse trail systems, Bailey said.
Smaller municipalities in particular on the Eastern Shore wanted more trails but lacked capacity, expertise, and funding to plan, develop and design, according to Bailey.
While the Eastern Shore represent 30% of the state's landmass and areas of recreation and economic development impact, it only included about 9.2% of the state's roads-separated trails, Stevens said.
This deficit came to light with updates to MDOT's five-year bike and pedestrian plan, according to Stevens.
Interactive mapping across the state marked trails as green and while urban areas like Baltimore and Annapolis had so many green off-road trail markings "it looked like plates of robust pesto spaghetti," Eastern Shore counties merely had "little flecks of parsley," according to Stevens.
Trails have benefits to economic development as well as to health, and as a safe transportation alternative, Stevens said.
Del. Steve Arentz (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) said electric bicycles are good options for mobility but speed can be issues on trails and should be addressed.

 Local officials in Rockhall have been putting their heads together to figure out how they can improve on their green space. Last year, the Town of Rock Hall began working with ShoreRivers, a nonprofit organization promoting healthy waterways.Last March, ShoreRivers submitted a grant to the Chesapeake Bay Trust to seek funding for concept-level designs for two community parks that when implemented, will control storm water, enhance community enjoyment, encourage habitat and biodiversity and reduce runoff in the Chester River and Bay. The effort would fuse community needs and environmental benefits, according to the press release from ShoreRivers.
Over the summer, that grant was approved.
In November, Parks and Recreation members held a community visioning session, welcoming Chester RiverKeeper, Annie Richards and coworkers Katie Drummond, landscape architect and Community Restoration Coordinator Jennifer Klug Vaccaro.

title: Models are changing
author: Staff Writer
content:
Models are changing

 February 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 195
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The world is slowly coming to realize that carbon dioxide emissions are not a threat. Fifty years ago scientists theorized what rising levels might cause. They put ideas into models.Early models predicted temperatures would rise 0.2 to 0.5 degrees Celsius per decade. Other models predicted changes in weather conditions and ice melt.
Now, after more than 40 years recording data, it is seen that neither the temperature rise nor the changes that were predicted have occurred. The latest IPCC report now says that the actual rise is 0.008 degrees per decade and that the contribution of carbon dioxide to the temperature is uncertain. The IPCC is now making significant changes to models.
The latest IPCC report also notes that plant life is spreading and crop yields improving. Slow incremental warming and more carbon dioxide are manageable and beneficial. The early hypotheses of threatening outcomes have been disproven. There is no doubt that human activity is changing the mix of matter in the atmosphere. It is also clear that earth systems are either unaffected by the change or benefitting from it.
It is time to end climate change funding and use the funds to address real problems.
PAYNE KILBOURN
Neavitt

title: ShoreRivers working to protect Bay rivers
author: ANNIE RICHARDS
content:
ShoreRivers working to protect Bay rivers

 February 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANNIE RICHARDS | Section: Columns 
 
 588

 Now that the Maryland General Assembly has reconvened for the 447th Legislative Session, ShoreRivers' advocacy efforts are in full swing.The organization's advocacy work, which is led by the Riverkeepers, is fundamental to creating systemwide change to protect local rivers against the major issues that impact water quality on the Eastern Shore.
This is a pivotal year for the State of Maryland and all Chesapeake watershed states, as government leaders work with the Environmental Protection Agency's Chesapeake Bay Program to revise and strengthen a new Chesapeake Bay Agreement that will guide restoration work in years to come. ShoreRivers and fellow clean water advocates see 2025 as an opportunity to bolster Maryland's efforts to implement this new agreement by advocating for strong policies that protect our natural resources and local rivers.
Findings from the Chesapeake Bay Program's CESR Report (A Comprehensive Evaluation of System Response) continue to influence ShoreRivers' priorities and complement the Bay agreement's vision for restoration goals for years to come.
These efforts are no small challenge, as fiscal pressures loom large this session due to a $2 billion-plus deficit facing the state coupled with current financial instability at the federal level. This pressure, combined with Maryland's focus and attention to meet renewable energy goals, means that ShoreRivers and our members will be working harder than ever to shine a spotlight on Eastern Shore water quality — and the policies we need to protect and restore our rivers.
Key efforts this year include the following, though additional bills and legislation are likely to be added to this list as they are introduced and prove to be in line with ShoreRivers' mission of protecting Maryland's Eastern Shore waterways through science-based advocacy, restoration, education and engagement.
The Nearshore Farming and Finance Act (SB898/HB1175), a bill that will increase nutrient application setbacks and improve incentive programs for nearshore habitat restoration on agricultural operations within the critical area. This bill will also establish the state's first incentive payments for leased land agricultural operators.
The Maryland PFAS and sewage sludge bill (SB732/HB909), which will establish testing requirements to identify PFAS concentrations in biosolids and set enforceable limits to prevent further contamination, protecting Maryland's food and water sources and ensuring a healthier future for all.
A bill to improve on–dite sewage disposal systems in climate vulnerable areas (HB671), which will limit septic siting within the 500-year floodplain, and ensure that low-income households have access to Bay Restoration Funding to make necessary improvements to failing or poor performing units in climate vulnerable areas.
Defending important funding sources through budget advocacy will be another important priority for ShoreRivers this session. With conflicting pressures from the Bay Program's goals of accelerated restoration work and a budget deficit pressuring Maryland legislators and advocates to "do more with less," ShoreRivers is committed to defending historically beneficial environmental funds such as the Bay Restoration Fund, the Coastal Trust Fund, the Chesapeake Bay Trust, State Aided institutions and Program Open Space, and funding appropriated through the Tree Solutions Now Act 2021.
At ShoreRivers, we engage in legislative advocacy because addressing non-point source pollution — or "runoff pollution," the leading contributor of pollutants to our rivers — is often most effective by updating policies that address modern challenges and support restoration goals.
By combining locally driven restoration efforts with river-friendly policies, we are encouraging the behavioral changes needed to improve land use practices and better manage the landscapes responsible for nutrient and sediment runoff. ShoreRivers looks forward to a productive legislative session with members of the General Assembly and fellow environmental advocates. Visit shorerivers.org to learn more about this important work.

title: Environmental nonprofits forging ahead despite federal funding uncertainty
author: Konner Metz
content:
Environmental nonprofits forging ahead despite federal funding uncertainty

 February 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 581
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Isabel Hardesty, executive director of ShoreRivers, said the days following the White House's freeze on federal grants and loans last month brought "disarray" and "chaos."The freeze, enacted by President Donald Trump's budget office Jan. 27 via a memo calling for officials to bring federal spending more in line with "the will of the American people," was rescinded two days later. But it left some local nonprofit organizations pausing on certain projects or without funds to run business as usual.
As Hardesty looks toward the next four years of the current administration, she says the uncertainty faced by nonprofits such as ShoreRivers will only persist.
"We don't have a lot of faith in this being the only attempt to renege this funding," Hardesty said.
For ShoreRivers, $2 million in federal funding for 2025 could potentially be impacted by any freezes in the future, over a quarter of its total budget. Nearly $270,000 of this year's budget is currently affected, according to ShoreRivers.
Most of the money passes through ShoreRivers and goes to local companies and businesses. Those small businesses or groups are often the ones completing projects, such as stormwater improvements, wetlands restoration and educational programs.
"Where it gets tricky is where we have funding from federal sources, and we have subcontracted with construction companies or other design teams, and they are working on projects on the ground," Hardesty said. "We're having to think ahead. If we have access to the federal funding now, can we go forward with this one phase?"
Eastern Shore Land Conservancy President and CEO Steve Kline says millions of dollars would be in flux if the administration enacts future holds on federal funding. Despite what some may think, Kline says ESLC stewards its dollars diligently.
"These dollars are not being wasted," Kline said. "They are going, in nearly every case, to local small businesses that are moving dirt. They are doing real benefit for the natural resources that we all appreciate."
The conservancy sent stop work orders to small businesses in the days after the initial pause. In a newsletter to the community, Kline explained that projects such as conservation easements were temporarily paused.
Those pauses affected the everyday construction worker or equipment operator, Kline and Hardesty both say. In an email newsletter, Kline emphasized that those community members may think twice before spending their hard-earned money. ShoreRivers' Hardesty echoed the same sentiment.
"That's the biggest message that we're trying to get to people," Hardesty said.
Since most grant programs are reimbursement-based, Kline said Eastern Shore Land Conservancy is constantly considering its own financial sustainability. If the nonprofit pays a contractor to carry out work for a project, it may take some time before the grant money is reimbursed.
"You're carrying some cash exposure in the meantime," Kline said, "even when they work well."
He said that cash exposure only worsens as concerns grow over whether reimbursements will continue to operate in a smooth manner.
However, amid the widespread concern nonprofits are experiencing, Kline said work isn't stopping at the Eastern Shore Land Conservancy. Community support is critical and Kline's team is keeping "a laser focus on the books."
"In terms of keeping the lights on and the staff working, that's something we really depend on our individual donors for in the community," Kline said. "We try not to depend on grants for staff time. And as a result, we have a pretty lean, nimble staff. There's not a lot of bloat in our staff."
"We're going to continue this work no matter how high the tide gets," Kline said.
