title: Craving more energy, Maryland looks to nuclear power
author: RACHEL MCCREA Capital News Service
content:
Craving more energy, Maryland looks to nuclear power

 February 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: RACHEL MCCREA Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 933
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — In a legislative session dominated by energy issues, some state leaders are exploring the idea of more nuclear energy as an option for power generation in Maryland.Bills introduced by Gov. Wes Moore and Democratic leadership would open the door to building new nuclear energy projects in Maryland. The governor's bill would also count nuclear energy towards the state's clean energy goals.
"To address resource adequacy and reduce greenhouse gas emissions, I think there's a large number of people who say we should pursue this as aggressively as we can," said Paul Pinsky, director of the Maryland Energy Administration.
The state's clean energy goals and worries about having enough power are putting pressure on lawmakers to consider building more nuclear. Maryland already has one nuclear power plant, which provides about 40% of all energy produced in the state.
Both the ENERGIZE Maryland Act and the Next Generation Energy Act would create a procurement process for new nuclear projects. The ENERGIZE Act is being sponsored by state leaders in the House and Senate at the governor's request, and the Next Generation Energy Act is part of an energy package introduced by Maryland General Assembly leadership.
"Alongside the state legislature and other stakeholders, the Moore-Miller Administration is continuing to explore all available options, including nuclear energy, to help meet Maryland's environmental and clean energy goals," the governor's office said in an emailed statement. "The governor understands the need for sustainable and cost-effective infrastructure to ensure the reliability of our grid and build the economy of the future in our state, which is why this session he has introduced the ENERGIZE Act, to help create more in-state clean energy generation, invest in Maryland's workforce, and help Maryland ratepayers."
The ENERGIZE Act would also classify nuclear as clean energy. It may not be a renewable source of energy, Pinsky said, but nuclear doesn't emit greenhouse gases, and the bill would count it towards the state's clean energy goals.
"I think if you're looking for affordable and reliable and clean energy, nuclear does check those three boxes," said House Minority Whip Del. Jesse Pippy (R- Frederick).
Del. Chao Wu (D-Howard, Montgomery) is a co-sponsor of the ENERGIZE Act and supports nuclear as a source of clean, affordable energy.
"I think by managing nuclear power safely, we can offer a better future for our residents,'" Wu said.
Not everyone is supportive of new nuclear energy in the state.
"Maryland should be alarmed that state leaders want to build out these astronomically expensive and dangerous nuclear plants in Maryland to meet the state's energy needs," said Jorge Aguilar, the southern region director for the nonprofit Food & Water Watch.
These plants would be expensive to build and produce hazardous nuclear waste, he said. He thinks Maryland should be pushing the grid operator to approve renewable energy projects faster.
"I think Maryland leaders really need to double down on truly clean energy, like wind and solar, as well as batteries," he said. "Not nuclear."
Wu says that the state has been safely managing its nuclear energy for decades.
"We have nuclear power in Maryland already," he said. "It's not that we're doing something new."
Del. Lorig Charkoudian (D-Montgomery) said that new nuclear power may be built in Maryland if these bills pass. She's uncertain when any new projects would be built, though, because modern nuclear technologies are still too new.
"I think at some point it will probably be available, and if we pass these bills, I suspect it will get built here at some point," she said.
Charkoudian supports other bills about long-term energy planning and analysis to get a better idea of when new nuclear installations could be up and running.
New nuclear technologies include small modular reactors, or SMRs. They're supposed to be quicker to build and take up less space, Pinsky said, though none are operating in the United States yet.
Charkoudian is sponsoring the Abundant, Affordable Clean Energy Act, which focuses on building quickly deployable energy projects like battery storage and solar. It also supports relicensing the state's nuclear plant.
"It is clear to me that we need to keep our current nuclear plants running and relicensed," she said.
Resource adequacy — making sure energy supply matches demand — has been part of this push to explore nuclear.
The grid operator, PJM, "has made a whole lot of mistakes," said Sen. Jim Rosapepe (D-Prince George's, Anne Arundel), leading to high rates and worries about energy reliability.
He's co-sponsoring the Decarbonization Infrastructure Solutions Act that would classify nuclear as renewable energy and set up a procurement process.
"Nuclear is not the solution. Nuclear is potentially a part of the solution," he said, one of many options for the state to consider.
High energy prices have led lawmakers to consider more nuclear energy, said Adam Dubitsky, the consulting state director of the Maryland Land & Liberty Coalition. He supports relicensing the nuclear power plant in Calvert County and exploring new nuclear development in the state.
"It's really only been over the last couple of months in Maryland that families and businesses have seen their electric bills go through the roof. As a result, politicians are scrambling to find a solution," he said.
Pippy said that recent state energy policy is at fault because its emphasis on environmental goals caused energy producers to leave Maryland. Maryland's current energy situation represents "self-inflicted wounds," he said, and he hasn't heard of any proposed short-term solutions.
"I think Marylanders are at a point where they're fed up," Pippy said. "They expect their government to assist them in providing affordable and reliable energy."
"When you consider nuclear, the fact that it is reliable, affordable, and clean energy … I think that's certainly something that we should look at," he said.

title: ESLC talks land values at Dorchester County Council meeting
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
ESLC talks land values at Dorchester County Council meeting

 February 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 608
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — When it comes to acreage and land value, Dorchester County is expected to be one of the most affected counties by sea level rise and storm surge in the year 2100, according to the Eastern Shore Land Conservancy.During a Dorchester County Council meeting Feb. 18, Eastern Shore Land Conservancy Land Use and Policy Director Owen Bailey presented data on land value throughout the Eastern Shore. Bailey said the data was acquired with the help of Urban3.
The land trust estimates that an average of three feet of sea level rise in 2100 would mean the loss of 270,000 acres of the Eastern Shore and $2 billion in property tax values.
"And then when you add in storm surge, then that really puts into perspective the financial distress that our communities are going to face in the future with the loss of properties and property tax revenues," Bailey said.
After Bailey showed a map that accounted for storm surge in 2100, County Council President Lenny Pfeffer pointed out that more than half of Dorchester County's land is projected to be gone.
Bailey said Cambridge alone is projected to lose 280 acres and $63 million in value by 2100.
Throughout his presentation, Bailey advocated for concentrated development on the Shore to increase property value. At the same time, he spoke about the importance of maintaining the value that could be loss to sea level rise.
Bailey said the efficiency of land use can be measured by looking at value per acre.
"You take the appraised value of each parcel and you divide it by how many acres it sits on," he said.
When the Eastern Shore Land Conservancy applied this to the Eastern Shore, it noticed historic downtowns are "much more productive than the more suburban, car-focused development" that has been popular since the 1950s. This means that those downtowns, which often are more vulnerable to sea level rise, bring in more property tax revenue per acre than more sprawling areas of the Eastern Shore.
Bailey said that before the Bay Bridge was built in 1952, only 10,000 acres of land — valued at approximately $560,000 per acre — had been developed on the Shore. An additional 163,000 has been developed at less than half of that value since.
With the additional developed land, there has been a need for more sprawling infrastructure, he said.
"So we've built all this infrastructure," Bailey said. "But we haven't really built the value to help us with the maintenance of that infrastructure, which is why a lot of our jurisdictions, pretty much all of our jurisdictions, are struggling with how to keep up with that kind of maintenance."
Bailey said many historic communities on the Shore, which bring more value per acre, are built on waterfronts, meaning sea level rise will most likely affect them.
"So we're encouraging every town to think about how are you going to account for that," he said. "How can you either move that property, protect it or replace that value somewhere else in our community?"
Along with concentrating development, Bailey recommended the county look at zoning restricting the county from allowing value to grow.
"This is something we're encouraging every jurisdiction to take a look at," he said. "It's not our job to tell you what to do. We just want to provide the data and perspective. ... Use your land wisely."
At the end of the presentation Dorchester County Council Vice President Mike Detmer asked if the land trust had any recommendations specific to Dorchester County zoning ordinances.
Bailey said they have been focusing on municipalities, looking at zoning in historic districts.
"And how can we ease up on that zoning just to allow that historic pattern to continue," he said.

title: Ingleside Mine extraction expansion moves forward
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Ingleside Mine extraction expansion moves forward

 February 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 373

 CENTREVILLE — The Queen Anne's County Planning Commission granted concept plan approval and favorable recommendation to the Board of Appeals for a 19.5 acre expansion for phase four of the Ingleside Mine during their February meeting.Located at 1720 Bridgetown Road, the project site comprises two parcels totaling 305 acres in the Agricultural Zoning District, where major extraction is a conditional use, according to Steve Johnson, senior planner.
The Bridgetown Development Company, LLC is proposing 6.4 acres of impervious area and 2,262 square feet of floor area, which is far less than the maximum permitted, he said.
Mining operations are exempt from forest conservation, according to Johnson. Of the 4.4 acres of woodlands, the applicant will clear 2.3 acres and authorization has been received from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to disturb one bald eagle nest located within the on-site forest wetland to be removed, he said.
And the Maryland Department of the Environment has authorized the disturbance of a non-tidal wetland and its buffer, Johnson said.
A 30-foot wide, seven foot tall berm will be planted along the perimeter of the expansion area with loblolly or white pines and eastern red cedar trees, he said.
As the project's stream disturbance falls within drainage to Long Marsh and Mason Branch known to support several endangered mussels, the applicant must adhere to all best management practices for sediment and erosion control and avoid altering hydrology in the area, as stated by the Maryland Department Natural Resources, according to Johnson.
An annual compliance inspection in November found no violations with the current operation and environmental health has approved the expansion, Johnson said.
The applicant anticipates approximately 13.2 million cubic yards of material would be removed by the operation in 47 years, equating to an annual removal rate of about 277,000 cubic yards. The finished depth of the mine is expected to be 50 to 55 feet, he said.
Upon the completion of the operation, four ponds will remain with locations for two future residences, Johnson said.
The project's history has been underway since 2015 and Charles Schaller with Baker Donelson on behalf of Bridgetown Development Company noted the expansion is simply a continuation with no changes proposed.
Planning Commission Chair Sharon Dobson noted the mine has been a well maintained project for removing materials.

title: Hate seeing a new development
author: Staff Writer
content:
Hate seeing a new development

 February 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 389
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It makes me sick that people no longer care about the small town they've known all their lives or the land their family has worked on for generations.Easton gives in to the demands of strangers who fall in love with the small-town charm but desperately want to change it into the city they left. Future generations will be unable to admire the beauty of rural areas because they will be destroyed. I have lost faith in the mayor, the Town Council, and the County Council. It is almost as if they are failing in their part of working for the community, making them not earn my vote for the next election year. They care more about the opinions of people who have decided to move here after only visiting once or twice a year rather than people who have lived here their entire lives, going back generations.
They could learn from the Eastern Shore Land Conservatory, Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation Foundation and the Town of Oxford. As a rural community, we must protect farmland, wildlife, wetlands, trees, etc.
It should be a law that any farmland put up for sale should be bought by farmers, not by developers who want to ruin it. Or use the Farmland Protection Policy Act, a law created to protect farmland from non-agricultural uses. The last thing the Eastern Shore needs is another development meant to destroy the rural beauty, environment and small-town charm.
The building of developments can wreak havoc on the environment by causing habitat loss, pollution, resource depletion and water quality issues. Many people in rural communities depend on the environment for their jobs, such as watermen, farmers, hunters, etc. Besides ruining the rural landscape and environment, the influx of city people will cause traffic issues and increase living costs in a small town.
I hate seeing a new development being built because it means this rural and beautiful part of the Eastern Shore will be gone forever and never return. Sometimes, I wonder if the town I grew up in will be here for future generations. With all the city people coming in and making unnecessary changes, will Easton still be the small town I grew up with? Because if it's not, I don't want to live in it. And it would break my heart to say goodbye to my home. Forever.
LILLI TIBBITT
Easton

title: Bat bill could affect conservation, land management activities on the Shore
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Bat bill could affect conservation, land management activities on the Shore

 February 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 686
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — For Maryland Forests Association Executive Director Beth Hill, a cross-filed bill in the Maryland General Assembly dealing with bats is "a win-win situation.""We're trying to do what's best for the bats and what's best for the forests," she said.
The legislation, if passed, would allow for the establishment of habitat conservation plans and the issuance of incidental taking permits for multiple species of bats. It has support from a variety of organizations, including the Maryland Farm Bureau, the Rural Maryland Council and the Maryland Department of Natural Resources.
Maryland Sen. Mary Beth Carozza (R-Somerset, Worcester, Wicomico), who is sponsoring the legislation along with Sen. Katie Fry Hester (D-Howard, Montgomery) and Sen. Mike McKay (R-Garrett, Allegany, Washington), said she is excited about the bill.
"This plan will contribute to bat conservation efforts, but at the same time doesn't prohibit the other activities in the forest," she said.
Hill said under federal law, incidental takings of endangered species are legal with a habitat conservation plan. She said although the likelihood of a forest-harvesting, or tree-cutting, operation harming a bat is very unlikely, the issue needs to be addressed.
"We harvest less than one percent of our forest land in Maryland every year," she said. "But we still need to address the likelihood that there could be a bat in the area."
The bats species listed in the legislation include the Indiana bat, the tricolored bat and the northern long-eared bat.
Hill said these bats are known to exist in every county in the state. In Dorchester County, the northern long-eared bat and the tricolored bat are found at Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge.
All three of the bat species have experienced declines in population due to white-nose syndrome, which is a deadly disease that affects birds across the continent, according to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. The Indiana bat and northern long-eared bat are considered endangered species by the federal government. A proposal was announced by the Fish and Wildlife Service in 2022 to list the tricolored bat as endangered.
The proposed bill essentially adds these species to a list so that habitat conservation plans can be established for the bats and the Maryland Department of Natural Resources can issue incidental take permits. A hearing for the cross-filed bill in the House of Delegates, House Bill 894, was held Wednesday. A hearing is scheduled in the Senate March 4.
At a Dorchester County Council meeting Feb. 18, the council voted in favor of sending a letter of support for the bill.
"This is really something that could have a big impact, particularly on our local forestry industry," Council Vice President Mike Detmer said.
Carozza said that on the Eastern Shore, the forest industry is often less discussed than the farming and fishing industries. She said although a very small amount of Maryland's forests are harvested every year, the industry has an economic impact of $3.3. billion and supports close to 13,000 jobs in the state.
Hill said the Maryland Forests Association — which advocates for forest, wildlife and natural resource management — believes in forest conservation. She said forest management plans in the state, which include harvesting, often have to do with wildlife and habitat improvement projects.
Carozza said it is "significant" that this bill has such "broad support" across Maryland.
"To me, what is really key, and what I think will help ensure passage, is that you have the Maryland Department of Natural Resources," she said.
While the Department of Natural Resources is in support of the bill, it would like another bat species, the small-footed bat, to be added. Gregg Bortz, who is with the department, said the small-footed bat is considered endangered in Maryland, but not by the federal government.
Hill said the Maryland Forests Association is behind the Department of Natural Resources' request for the addition of the small-footed bat to the legislation.
"We want to do the best we can to help this species rebound and continue to have a good plan to keep our forests healthy and vibrant," she said. "We stand ready to work with DNR on a plan for all that."
This article has been updated to correct a description of federal policy surrounding incidental takings.

title: Scarcity v. abundance at the Talbot County Free Library
author: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library
content:
Scarcity v. abundance at the Talbot County Free Library

 February 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library | Section: Life 
 
 1012
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When I set out to write about a little boy growing up in a monastery in the seventh century and the friendship he forms with a hermit who lives on a nearby mountain, I read all the books I could find on monastic life and the so-called "Dark Ages," and I went on retreat as often as possible at a Cistercian abbey in Virginia's Shenandoah Valley. But I still wanted to know more.So, telling myself it would give me a better feel for what it would be like to live in a monastery that kept the silence (and that it would also be a lot of fun), I decided to hike up into the Blue Ridge Mountains and spend a three-day weekend camping alone on the slopes overlooking the Shenandoah River.
Climbing into the Blue Ridge that day, so many years ago now, I began to hear a strange popping noise in the trees around me, as if a gentle rain were falling down through the woods. But there was no rain, the sky overhead was clear and blue.
It took me a while to work out what the sound was. Eventually, I realized it was frass, the excreta of caterpillars. The entire mountainside had been invaded by Gypsy moths, millions upon millions of them.
Frass consists of dry, harmless pellets, no real bother to me, and all the caterpillars meant the trees were full of birds. So I hiked on, enjoying the birdsong.
That was probably the only time in my adult life that I have gone three whole days without speaking aloud once. I remember I even tried to silence my mind, put a stop to the ceaseless interior blather that we tell ourselves is thinking but in my case often seems to be little more than passing, inconsequential billboards.
It was an interesting experience, and I think it helped me write the book.
When, some 10 years later, I finally placed the last period at the end of the last sentence in "The Oblate's Confession," I found myself thinking there ought to be a way to mark such a milestone. So I decided to hike back up into the Blue Ridge to see if I could find my old campsite.
And I did, but the place had undergone a complete change.
The Gypsy moths were gone, but the damage they had done was clear. As far as the eye could see, not a single oak or walnut remained alive, and most were no longer standing. Light now flooded the mountainside, and the dense forest I had known had been replaced by an airy wood of serviceberry, not a single tree more than twenty feet tall. But that's tall for serviceberries, which out here on the Eastern Shore are usually called shadbush, with the emphasis on the second syllable.
I knew about serviceberry, had planted a couple in my backyard to attract birds, but I had never seen any like these before. Each was as tall and as healthy-looking as a mature dogwood, and they were all loaded with ripe, delicious fruit. It seemed a second Eden.
Which, interestingly, is sort of the point of Robin Wall Kimmerer's new book, "The Serviceberry." Of course, I checked the thing out thinking it would be a natural history of the tree, and there is some natural history in the book, but it mostly ends up being about, of all things, economics.
Before you turn to the opposite page hoping to find an article about something more appealing, let me add that Kimmerer is interested in the contrast between the economics we were taught in school and the economics of nature.
School taught us that competition is the driver of a healthy economy. Similarly (and not surprisingly considering the way one school of thought tends to influence another), the traditional view of nature has been that competition drives evolution. By this way of thinking, survival of the fittest explains both humanity's rise to global dominance and Elon Musk's.
But Kimmerer points out that new research in both biology and economics is finding that competition drives success only when the unit being measured is the individual. She writes, "When the focus shifts to the level of a group, cooperation is a better model, not only for surviving but for thriving."
A Distinguished Professor of Environmental Biology at SUNY and an enrolled member of the Potawatomi tribe, Kimmerer sees in my experience with the serviceberries on that mountainside all those years ago an example of what she calls a "gift economy." Instead of looking upon resources like water, land and minerals as commodities, her people survived for millennia by seeing them as gifts to be shared.
She quotes a South American hunter-gatherer who, when asked why he didn't store the surplus from his hunt instead of giving it away at a village feast, replied, "I store my meat in the belly of my brother."
Kimmerer believes the difference between a gift economy and our market economy is the latter "incentivizes scarcity." In a market economy, she says, when a resource becomes scarce, the wise investor buys up access to that resource and then doles it out to the public at a profit. What had been a shared resource — say open range or timber — becomes a commodity. The individual benefits at the community's expense.
At a time when humanity's acquisitive, extractive nature seems to be in danger of chewing up every last morsel of food, fuel, and land left on the planet, I found Kimmerer's notion of a gift economy appealing. But is it also achievable? In a country that was founded on private property rights, is it possible to reset the template, to change from a land of individuals to one of community?
Of course in some areas of modern life such a shift wouldn't be necessary. The perfectly human instinct to share remains alive and well in modern institutions like food banks, Toys for Tots, and Habitat for Humanity. Indeed, I was able to read Kimmerer's book and consider its thesis thanks to one of the greatest proofs of our culture's surviving desire to share: our local public library.

title: Plastic Free QAC seeks support for county-wide bag ban
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Plastic Free QAC seeks support for county-wide bag ban

 March 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 410
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Seeking to strengthen environmental advocacy across Queen Anne's County, Plastic Free QAC Founder Bente Cooney presented the results of surveys conducted to identify how businesses have adjusted to the Bring Your Own Bag ordinance and sought County Commissioner support in implementing a county wide plastic bag ban Feb. 25.Every year hundreds of single-use plastic bags litter the environment before clogging the Chesapeake Bay and since 2018 the non-profit grassroots has been raising awareness about the hazards of single use plastics in the county, Cooney said.
Centreville's plastic bag reduction ordinance launched Jan. 1, 2024 and seeks to reduce litter pollution and encourage shoppers to bring their own bags, by prohibiting retailers from providing plastic carryout bags that are not reusable, and requires retailers to charge 10 cents per carryout bag.
The goal is not for shoppers to have to pay for a paper bag, but to bring their own reusable bag, or use no bag at all, Cooney said.
Shopper surveys tracked bag usage at four Queen Anne's County grocery stores and Target.
Five months post-ordinance, 80% of shoppers in Centreville used reusable bags or no bags, compared to 13% in 2020, she said, "highlighting the ordinance's effectiveness in changing behavior."
According to surveyed Centreville shoppers, less than one in five bought ten cent paper bags. "The greater majority didn't need to, as they found other ways to transport groceries," she said.
In contrast, Safeway and Food Lion in Stevensville maintained 71% plastic bag usage.
Plastic Free QAC also surveyed shopper's attitudes while giving out free reusable bags and results found 75% in support of a county-wide ordinance, with 12% opposed and 11% neutral, Cooney said.
According to Cooney, survey results found a majority of businesses and residents were adapting well to the change and 23 out of 29 Centreville businesses were in support of expanding the Bring Your Own Bag ordinance county wide.
"Queen Anne's County celebrates and depends on the Chesapeake Bay, and this is yet another opportunity for us to lead by example," she said.
It was also noted each year, boating season brings significant environmental challenges and combined county efforts are once again working to minimize the impacts of single use boat shrink wrap.
With an estimated 5,000 recreational boats in the county, Queen Anne's County is also once again working with Plastic Free QAC and the Marine Trades Association of Maryland to provide free recycling bags for shrink wrap.
More information about Plastic Free QAC and shrink wrap initiatives can be found at https://www.plasticfreeqac.com/home.

title: Striped bass restrictions head to Supreme Court
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@kibaytimes.com
content:
Striped bass restrictions head to Supreme Court

 March 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@kibaytimes.com | Section: Local News 
 
 911
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — A coalition of Maryland fishing associations and charter boat operators have escalated their legal battle against new striped bass fishing restrictions, filing an emergency petition with the U.S. Supreme Court seeking to block the regulations. Captain Robert Newberry, chairman of Delmarva Fisheries Association stated, "We will take this case to the highest court until this matter is resolved — it is far from over."The Delmarva Fisheries Association and the Maryland Charter Boat Association, along with two individual commercial fishermen, argue that the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission's (the Commission) recent measures impose "drastic, unwarranted, and illegal limitations" on striped bass fishing in the Chesapeake Bay and along the Atlantic coast. The petition, filed March 4, claims the restrictions violate the U.S. Constitution and could jeopardize the livelihoods of many small businesses.
The case follows months of legal disputes in lower courts, where the plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction to halt the Commission's 2024 striped bass management plan, known as Addendum II. The plan, approved in January by a 14-2 vote, reduced commercial quotas, shortened fishing seasons, and limited recreational anglers to catching just one striped bass per day instead of two.
Maryland and New Jersey voted against the measure, but Maryland ultimately implemented the restrictions under pressure from the Commission and federal agencies. The Maryland Attorney General's Office acknowledged in a letter that failing to comply could trigger a federal moratorium on all striped bass fishing in state waters.
When confronted with having to cut the catch limitation in half, Assistant Director and Fisheries Manager at the Maryland Department of Natural Resources and proxy to the Marine Fisheries Commission Michael Luisi, warned the Commission that limiting Maryland's charter boat clients' catch to one fish a day "will put people out of business."
Documents filed with the court by the plaintiffs state Luisi was "pointedly correct in this assessment but the ASMFC and its federal and other illegally voting partners as well as other member states, including Maryland at that point, decided that its guesstimate on fish-spawning futures five years into the future was more important than the impending demise of these family-run, small businesses."
Newberry said, it is was "extremely perturbing that Governor Moore and Attorney General Anthony Brown turned their backs on us in the seafood industry in Maryland and also all of us here on the Eastern Shore." Moore never weighed in on this constitutional issue affecting those in the seafood industry, but will "spend millions of taxpayers dollars defending the citizens of Maryland against the so-called constitutional violations of President Trump," Newberry said. "We have not only been left behind, we have tire tracks on our backs from where we have been run over, and left behind."
"The economic damage is undeniable," said Brian Hardman, president of the Maryland Charter Boat Association. "We've seen a 75-85% decline in business, boats being sold off, and captains leaving the industry. The Commission rushed through regulations without considering the devastating impact on local livelihoods."
Hardman continued, "...the 2025 numbers are continuing to be off by the same ratios or worse; that an unprecedented 53 charter boats have been sold or listed for sale since 2024; and, that 43 "for hire" Charter Boat businesses have already been forced to close their doors with another 11 companies losing money at a rate that will soon bring about the same result."
The legal challenge focuses on alleged constitutional violations, including the 10th Amendment's prohibition on federal overreach, the 5th Amendment's protection against government takings without just compensation, and the 14th Amendment's due process clause. The plaintiffs also argue that the Commission, originally established as an advisory body, has unlawfully assumed regulatory powers without proper state and federal oversight.
Despite warnings from industry representatives that the new rules would cripple the state's fishing economy, the Commission stood by its decision, citing concerns about overfishing and the need to rebuild the striped bass population by 2029. However, critics claim the commission relied on faulty data, pointing out that the agency's own projections have fluctuated — from a 97% chance of population recovery in 2023 to just 15% in 2024, before rebounding to 50% in 2025.
In a statement, the Commission defended its methodology, emphasizing that conservation measures are necessary to prevent further declines in the striped bass stock.
"The science may be imperfect, but the consequences of inaction could be severe," said a Commission spokesperson. "We understand the economic hardship this creates, but the long-term health of the fishery must come first."
Yet the plaintiffs stated, there are in excess of 240 million striped bass in U.S. waters and the annual number of fishing removals is approximately six million.
The Supreme Court previously declined to hear an emergency appeal in May, citing a lack of prior appellate review. The plaintiffs now return to the high court after exhausting their legal options in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, which ruled in February that the lawsuit should be dismissed because the plaintiffs had sued the Commission rather than the state of Maryland.
With the 2025 fishing season set to begin in May, the petitioners are urging the Supreme Court to issue an injunction that would restore previous fishing limits while the legal battle plays out. Without relief, they warn that more charter businesses will shut down, further damaging Maryland's historic fishing industry.
"The Supreme Court is our last hope," Hardman said. "We're not asking for special treatment—just the right to keep our businesses afloat."
A decision on the emergency petition filed March 4, could come within weeks.

title: Environmental leaders warn Oxford Conservation Park, other projects at risk amid potential state cuts
author: Konner Metz
content:
Environmental leaders warn Oxford Conservation Park, other projects at risk amid potential state cuts

 March 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 457
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Proposed budget cuts by the state could significantly endanger the work done for park maintenance and improvements projects, conservation experts warn.The Eastern Shore Land Conservancy says potential cuts to Maryland's Program Open Space and the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Trust Fund could devastate projects such as Oxford Conservation Park, which is undergoing a 30-acre expansion.
Larisa Prezioso, the conservancy's enhanced stewardship manager, said Oxford park improvements are at a "critical point."
"If you don't intervene now, this is going to be a much more expensive and labor-intensive project down the road," Prezioso said.
"We can make the new portion of park," she added, "but I think some of the maintenance concerns of the existing park area might suffer from not having additional financial support."
The calls to protect Program Open Space and other land conservation programs have come from many local organizations, including ESLC and the Chesapeake Bay Foundation.
Advocacy has peaked as the state's Department of Legislative Services recommended cutting funds for land preservation to help offset the state's nearly $3 billion deficit this fiscal year.
"There are many ways to modify the transfer tax formula to offset general fund expenditures," a budget analysis to the Department of Natural Resources reads. "Perhaps the most straightforward way is to eliminate, for fiscal 2026 through 2029, the funding allocated for land preservation."
Owen Bailey, director of land use and policy for the Eastern Shore Land Conservancy, said the recommended cuts "floored" the organization.
"It's sort of fighting for the survival of this type of industry," Bailey said of their advocacy. "Maryland's been a leader in the United States for conservation and for developing parks and open spaces, and there's a whole industry that's sort of grown up around this."
Funding for Program Open Space and the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Trust Fund largely comes from the transfer tax and gas and car rental fee taxes, respectively.
Bailey says it feels like the state would be breaking its promise — a promise to offset those industries with funding for open space and conservation — if it were to accept these recommendations.
"There's value in these programs, value that sometimes is hard to calculate," Bailey said. "It's sometimes hard to get across in a budget hearing. But there's still value."
Oxford Conservation Park was a community-led effort to transform old farmland into a habitat for wildlife with trails for residents to enjoy. As expansion and improvement efforts continue during uncertain budgetary times, Bailey and Prezioso worry for what else may be negatively impacted by state cuts.
Bailey said one would be "hard pressed" to find a park or playground in Maryland without a sign noting it received funding from Program Open Space.
"These cuts mean that the next Oxford Park project won't happen," Bailey said.

title: Reintroducing fire to the land
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Reintroducing fire to the land

 March 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 514
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Fire is a natural process.According to The Nature Conservancy, many native plants and animals across the state have evolved to withstand periodic episodes of natural fire.
Occasionally, in the absence of natural fire, it is necessary to artificially reintroduced to the land through various preservation agencies.
On March 10, a burn in Nanjemoy finally had the correct moisture and wind conditions to take place after being delayed since roughly November 2024.
The controlled burn at Nanjemoy Creek Preserve was conducted Monday to help a stand of native white oak trees by opening up the forest floor and providing more space for acorns to germinate. It will also provide nitrogen for the soil and promote the return of some native plant species, including wildflowers, members of The Nature Conservancy said.
"This will work out great," Deborah Landau, director of ecological management at the conservancy, said before two concurrent burns took place. "A controlled burn is when we're bringing fire back to the landscape."
A controlled burn was conducted in Nanjemoy last year, but the process can be a bit complicated to get off the ground as there is a written, specified prescription for the land where strict conditions must be met.
"For myself, really I just try to focus and pay attention to the lead of the team," Risharda Harley, one of the members in charge of ignitions that day from the Accokeek Foundation, said. "As I'm in there working, I try to take time to not have my head down and appreciate what's going on."
Micah Selengut, another igniter, said that he takes careful attention to look out for his team members and potential hazards.
"We're here to bring back fire to the land, which hasn't had fire in a really long time. It's a huge deal," Selengut said.
Gabe Cahalan, one of the chiefs in charge of the burn, said that usually smaller trees get killed and the mid-story of the forestry will be thinned.
"Thick bark trees are pretty fire resistant," Cahalan said, addressing a group and answering their questions Monday morning. "Invasives can come back. … We do get a flush of wildflowers sometimes."
Fire increases a forest's biodiversity, making it more resilient. When a stand of trees includes many different species rather than a few, they are less likely to be wiped out by threats like pests or disease, according to the conservancy.
Crews from different organizations fly in from all over the country to participate in the burns, with some coming from North Carolina, Louisiana and as far as California.
Before any burning was done, crews swept parts of the forest floor with leaf blowers to help keep the burn from going out of control.
A test burn was conducted around 11:30 a.m., and when the conditions looked desirable, the real burn began.
Working along Port Tobacco Road directly outside the Nanjemoy Volunteer Fire Station, the crew worked its way to the intersection of Beaver Dam Road where they essentially burned a triangle between the two roads, carefully avoiding residences nearby.
Any hazards were quickly addressed by crews and a high-pressure hose.
Now, it's a waiting game to see what will spring from the ash.

title: Advocates urge Congress to keep funding Chesapeake Bay cleanup
author: WHITNEY PIPKIN Chesapeake Bay Journal
content:
Advocates urge Congress to keep funding Chesapeake Bay cleanup

 March 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WHITNEY PIPKIN Chesapeake Bay Journal | Section: News 
 
 1315
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON, D.C. — The director of the Choose Clean Water Coalition began the group's lobbying day luncheon in Washington, DC, by asking how many members had been affected by federal funding freezes and cuts so far this year. Almost half of the people in the room raised a hand.The coalition, representing more than 300 organizations that work on clean water in the Chesapeake Bay region, goes to Capitol Hill annually to urge lawmakers to keep funding the Bay's cleanup.
"But this year … is different," the coalition's director Kristin Reilly said to invited legislators, their staff and nearly 100 advocates at a luncheon in a legislative office building on March 5. "This year, we're not just here to advocate for future funding. We are, for the first time ever, also here to advocate for current funding — funding that has already been appropriated."
The Trump administration has frozen the release of hundreds of millions of dollars of funding that had been previously appropriated for environmental work in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. Funding for a handful of those programs has since been restored, while others appear to have been permanently defunded.
But many more funding sources remain in limbo, with nonprofits waiting for a memo to update them after being told that their funding was "under review."
President Donald Trump's executive orders have expressly directed federal staff to curtail funding and programs supporting certain DEI (diversity, equity and inclusion) and climate initiatives. But the funding cuts are also reaching other areas, including programs that benefit wildlife habitat, reducing flooding and help farmers pay for costly water quality improvements on their land.
One of the president's orders specifically targeted the disbursement of funds appropriated under the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) in 2022. The act included an additional $19.5 billion to help farmers improve soil health, reduce runoff into waterways and complete energy projects. Nonprofits that assist with these programs report interruptions of longstanding grants they've received from the U.S. Department of Agriculture or other federal agencies, many of which were then supplemented with IRA funds.
Other programs have been terminated, according to memos received by grant recipients. The U.S. Forest Service canceled a $75 million grant to the Arbor Day Foundation to support a Community Roots program focused on planting trees in urban areas. The Rappahannock Tribe and the nonprofit Friends of the Rappahannock were scheduled to receive $300,000 from that grant to pay for forest management and conservation job training on the tribe's ancestral lands on Virginia's Northern Neck.
"We had fully secured contracts, and we had already started doing some work," said Bryan Hoffman, deputy director of the Friends of the Rappahannock. "We are going to get reimbursed for most of what we spent up until Feb. 21, but this was supposed to be a three-year agreement."
Hoffman said the friends group has seen another $1.5 million frozen from the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation, money that was headed to a group of nonprofits helping farmers implement pollution-reduction practices on their land.
Two environmental justice-related programs within the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency have been terminated, grant recipients report. But grantees receiving funds through the EPA's Environmental Justice Problem Solving Cooperative Agreement were notified in late February that their program was reopened, according to Choose Clean Water.
It's still unclear how many federal employees working for agencies such as the National Park Service or the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association in the Chesapeake watershed have been affected by probationary firings. The firings impacted not only new employees but also some with decades of experience who were considered probationary because they had been recently promoted to new positions. Others may have left their jobs in response to the U.S. Office of Personnel Management's "fork in the road" buy-out offer.
Choose Clean Water and other nonprofits are cobbling together anecdotes and numbers from peers they've worked with in the field — and members of Congress seem to be, too. Speaking at the coalition's luncheon on March 5, Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-MD) asked nonprofits and state agencies whose federal funds have been frozen or who have lost contact with agency staff to continue reaching out to his office. He contended that both the grant freezes and the firings were unlawful.
"When Congress on a bipartisan basis passes a law that allocates funding to important funding purposes, presidents … don't get to pick and choose which funds they release and which they don't," Van Hollen said to the group.
The next day, March 6, a federal judge in Rhode Island ruled to extend an existing court's block on the Trump administration's attempt to freeze payments for federal grants and other congressionally approved government programs. It's not clear exactly how or when such efforts would result in the flow of funds being restored. Other lawsuits contending that even probationary federal employees cannot be fired without cause have also gotten traction.
Even if the majority of frozen funds are eventually disbursed, advocates say damage has already been done to organizations' relationships with local farmers, tribal members and private landowners who make the clean water work possible.
"To have this happen is so devastating for those relationships that have taken years to cultivate," Reilly said. "I'm extremely concerned about the long-term impacts [that the funding freezes] will have."
Reilly and other advocates also have to focus on future funding appropriations. Among their requests to lawmakers during the lobbying day was that the EPA's Chesapeake Bay Program office continue to receive an annual appropriation of $92 million, two-thirds of which would be passed through state and local communities "for on-the-ground restoration work."
Early in the first Trump administration, the president's budget suggested zeroing out all funding for the Bay Program, which at the time came to $73 million.
"But by the end of the [first] Trump administration, we worked on a bipartisan basis to restore that funding and increase it from $73 million to $85 million," Van Hollen said at the luncheon.
Van Hollen also introduced an additional funding stream through the Chesapeake WILD (Watershed Investments for Landscape Defense) Act in 2019. Advocates are requesting that the program, which focuses on public lands and wildlife, continue to be funded at $15 million.
One of Van Hollen's longtime partners in the effort to fund the Chesapeake Bay cleanup has been Congressman Rob Wittman (R-VA), who also serves as vice chairman on the House Natural Resources Committee. Advocates at the luncheon were eager to hear from Wittman, who had booked the room for the event but arrived just minutes before it ended, to see whether the Bay remained a priority amid so many proposed federal spending cuts.
In his remarks, Wittman acknowledged the need to rein in federal spending but seemed to hold the line on Bay funding priorities. He also said level funding for the Bay Program would likely be protected in the short-term under a continuing resolution for the federal budget through later this year.
"As we look to try to bend the spending curve down, it's very clear that there is a federal role for the Chesapeake Bay," he said. "There is a constitutional mandate to say we are going to do this as an interstate effort … and the federal government has a statutory obligation in that realm under the Clean Water Act to do those things."
Wittman also acknowledged the challenges ahead and the fact that the Bay Program's funding has been at stake in the past. During the 119th Congress, he will co-chair a Chesapeake Bay watershed task force in the House with Sarah Elfreth (D-MD), Andy Harris (R-MD) and Bobby Scott (D-VA) to continue pushing for Bay restoration funds.
"In the past, there've been efforts to say, 'No, we shouldn't fund the Chesapeake Bay Program," he said. "And our response is, "[buzzer sound], wrong answer."
Whitney Pipkin is a Chesapeake Bay Journal staff writer based in Northern Virginia. She can be reached at wpipkin@bayjournal.com. This article was originally published March 7, 2025 on bayjournal.com and distributed by the Bay Journal News Service.

title: Maryland faced the coldest winter in six years
author: NATALIE WEGER Capital News Service
content:
Maryland faced the coldest winter in six years

 April 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: NATALIE WEGER Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 543
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As the cherry blossoms bloom and the days grow longer, Marylanders face the end of the winter season. This past winter brought about 13 inches of snow and temperatures dipping down to the single digits.But how did this year's Maryland winter compare to those in the past?
As March comes to a close, Capital News Service analyzed the state's winter snow and temperatures over past decades. For the purpose of this analysis, Maryland winter is defined as December to March.
Here's what we found.
How have Maryland winter temperatures changed over the years?
This past winter marked the coldest season the Baltimore/Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport national weather station has reported in six years.
BWI reported the average temperature between December and March so far as 39.3 degrees Fahrenheit. Last winter, the average temperature was 42.9 degrees. And six winters ago, the average temperature reached 38.5 degrees.
Winter temperatures reported at BWI have remained largely variable
Despite this year's cold winter, all 48 contiguous states across the nation have experienced winter warming throughout the past few decades.
Average winter temperatures across the 48 states have increased by about 3 degrees since 1896, according to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. The agency's website stated that the increase, which aligns with reductions to snow and ice season, can generally be attributed to global warming.
"The same general trend that we've seen is still present," Alfredo Ruiz-Barrada, an associate research professor in the University of Maryland's atmospheric and oceanic science department said. "The trends in temperature are increasing."
When does Maryland typically see the most snowfall?
Although January is nationally known as the snowiest month, BWI has recorded February as the snowiest month in Maryland over the past two decades.
Since the winter of 2004-2005, the weather station has recorded about 140 inches of total snowfall in February and around 130 inches in January.
Average snowfall reported at BWI has fluctuated over the past two decades
February often sees the most snowfall in Maryland because it's the state's coldest month, according to James Hyde, a manager from the University of Maryland's atmospheric and oceanic science department. The state sees more snowfall in February because of influences from the Atlantic Ocean, he explained.
What has Maryland snowfall looked like over the past two decades?
Maryland has seen a handful of blizzards over the past two decades.
The most notable was in February 2010, when a snowstorm dubbed the "Snowmageddon" made history as it swept over the East Coast. The blizzard, which produced over 32 inches of snow, was the heaviest single-snowfall recorded by the Washington Dulles International Airport weather station.
But this past winter, BWI only recorded around 9 inches of snow in January and around 4 inches of snow in February. Still, this is the most snow that Marylanders have seen in three years. In the winter of 2021-2022, BWI reported roughly 14 inches of snow.
It is difficult to predict when the next blizzard will hit Maryland, since temperature and humidity conditions have to be just right, according to Ruiz-Barradas.
Yet Hyde said there is good chance another blizzard will hit Maryland within the next decade. Although Maryland has gotten "less snowy" since the 1800s, he said, big blizzards typically still occur every five to seven years.
The area is also seeing a gradual decrease in "minor events," or two- to six-inch snowstorms, Hyde said.

title: Menhaden population affects ecosystem
author: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com
content:
Menhaden population affects ecosystem

 April 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 535
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Following a screening of the brief but revealing documentary "The Biggest Fish You've Never Seen," which details the over harvesting of menhaden in the Chesapeake Bay, local experts discussed what long term impact the situation could have at an event last week in North Beach.Representatives of the Chesapeake Legal Alliance and Southern Maryland Recreational Fishing Organization spoke on March 31 about the importance of menhaden, often referred to as the most important fish in the Chesapeake Bay, and the constant battle to prevent the Commonwealth of Virginia from over harvesting the fish through a lawsuit and petition to the Virginia Marine Resources Commission.
"This petition seeks relief in the menhadens' harvesting practices and regulations," said David Reed, attorney for the Chesapeake Legal Alliance, an Annapolis-based group whose mission is to protect and restore clean water and promote healthy, resilient ecosystems in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. "Science, empirical evidence and observations tell us that our bay's ecosystem is in danger if we continue with the current rate of menhaden harvesting."
According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, menhaden constitute the largest landings, by volume, along the Atlantic Coast of the U.S. Menhaden are harvested for use as fertilizers, animal feed and bait for fisheries including blue crab and lobster. They are a major source of omega-3 fatty acids, so they are also used to develop human and animal supplements.
In actuality, Maryland already had strict restrictions in place regarding harvesting of menhaden, also known as mossbunker or bunker, which are small, oily, bony filter-feeding fish that play a vital role in the ocean's food chain.
Scientists worldwide consider the menhaden "the most important fish in the sea" due to their importance to the health of the ocean and coastal economy.
"Menhaden play a critical role in marine ecosystems as a forage species," local nature conservationist Sal Icaza said at the panel discussion held at the Twin Beach Library. "They provide a vital link between lower and higher tropic levels. Menhaden are also crucial in nutrient cycling because their filter-feeding activities remove excess nutrients from the water column. They help maintain water quality and prevent an over saturation of runoff resulting in lack of oxygen to aquatic life."
Icaza is primarily concerned with the impact that the over harvesting of menhaden already has on the local osprey population. With Virginia granting the green light to companies to harvest the menhaden in the lower Chesapeake Bay in large quantities, the number of osprey, which feed on the fish, in the bay and neighboring estuaries continues to plummet.
"In 2019 on Poplar Island, Maryland, there were more than 50 young ospreys produced in 28 nest platforms," Icaza said only days before the fourth annual Maryland Osprey Festival took place at its new home in North Beach. "Sadly, last year there were only three osprey chicks that survived in two nest platforms out of 28 pairs attempting to nest."
Both Reed and Icaza noted the petition and prevailing suit seek to accomplish several things, including to enact a moratorium on harvesting menhaden in the bay; require no less than 40% of harvest from federal waters; codify a one-mile shoreline buffer; establish a permanent one nautical mile shoreline buffer along Virginia's shoreline; and establish proper industry oversight.

title: Planned salmon farm's discharge permit challenged in Cecil County court
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content:
Planned salmon farm's discharge permit challenged in Cecil County court

 April 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: Business 
 
 563
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ELKTON — The Chesapeake Bay Foundation has filed a petition for judicial review in Cecil County Circuit Court against AquaCon, the Norwegian company that plans to build a land-based salmon farming operation at the Bainbridge Development Corporation property in Port Deposit.According to CBF, there are concerns about the Maryland Department of the Environment's discharge permit, which would allow AquaCon to send 1.9 million gallons of post-production water back into the Susquehanna River daily. Paul Small, CBF Vice President for Litigation, pointed to similar companies in Florida and Canada that have not had the best results on the native habitat, with reports of fish kills in North America and fires and potential water contamination in Denmark.
"Land-based salmon farms are relatively new and unpredictable," Small said. "Knowing the prior failures of these types of plants, and that the Susquehanna River is already overloaded with nutrient pollution, MDE's permit must protect against these risks."
In court papers, CBF noted that the company modeled its discharge permit paperwork after a similar operation in Maine that — to date — has not begun production or its permits have expired.
AquaCon, based in Oslo, Norway, announced last August that it plans to build its Recirculating Aquaculture System (RAS) facility on 160 acres of the former US Navy training base where it would draw water from the Susquehanna, grow salmon in large indoor pools and sell the fish to wholesalers and the restaurant industry.
Toni Sprenkle, Executive Director of BDC, was excited that the first tenant of the property had been announced. She was assured that there would be no environmental impacts.
"This is a very good use for Bainbridge," Sprenkle said in August. "There are unique attributes with this. It's close to the Susquehanna River so it can pull large amounts of water."She added that the company recycles and treats that water on site and when it is finally discharged it would "come out cleaner than it went in."
CBF begs to differ. In the court documents, the foundation argues that not enough is known about the science of these operations, pointing the fragility of the river and the harm that could come with discharges of nitrogen, phosphorous and sediment. This could mean the degradation of oxygen levels, grasses and impact recreational and commercial fishermen as well as hunters.
"The Susquehanna River is already overloaded with nitrogen and sediment pollution that runs off of farms and suburban developments," said Gussie Maguire, CBF Maryland Staff Scientist. "While we have made tremendous progress reducing that pollution, development pressure continues to strain the health of our waterways. MDE must adequately consider this risk for new, experimental projects like AquaCon."
Just before being released to market, these salmon are moved to purge tanks where they will slough a protein that — if left in place — would make the fish unpalatable. That protein, geosmin, is not included in the discharge permit, according to CBF.
The discharge permit requires the company to have net-zero discharge. However, it allows AquaCon to purchase credits to offset the amount of its nitrogen, phosphorous and sediment.
AquaCon had plans to build its RAS plant in Caroline County but residents of the Federalsburg community fought back claiming the plant would endanger the Atlantic sturgeon population in Marshyhope Creek. In October 2022, AquaCon agreed and withdrew its pending Maryland Department of the Environment discharge permit application. Sprenkle pointed out that Marshyhope Creek is a smaller body of water.

title: 'Serious local consequences': Trump cuts could hit wildlife refuges
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
'Serious local consequences': Trump cuts could hit wildlife refuges

 April 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 674
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Trump administration announced in February that the U.S. General Services Administration plans to close more than 2 million square feet of office space used by the Department of the Interior nationwide.The list includes ranger district offices, historic buildings, and museum spaces, with 33 National Park Service facilities on the list. Among the affected locations is the Blackwater Wildlife Refuge in Cambridge, which could, in turn, threaten the future of the Eastern Neck Wildlife Refuge.
In response, Bill Burton, president of Friends of Eastern Neck, and vice president Bonnie Ford are calling on business leaders, as well as county and town officials, for support.
At the Kent County Commissioners' regular meeting on March 15, Burton and Ford made their requests, receiving a positive response.
Commissioner John Price said, "Eastern Neck Island is a wonderful place. I often visit it with my grandkids, and we are as concerned as you are about the future."
Price motioned to prepare a letter "sooner rather than later" to support Friends of Eastern Neck. The letter would address the budget situation and call for a meeting with Maryland Rep. Andy Harris and Senators Chris Van Hollen and Angela Alsobrooks, who serve on committees that could help preserve the refuge.
"Rep. Harris is our priority, given his role as majority party leader," Ford said.
The letter received unanimous support from the commissioners.
Ford pressed for swift action, noting, "Time is of the essence" due to the upcoming reconciliation process within the government. Her concerns center on two areas: the Department of the Interior's budget and potential reductions in staff.
The Blackwater Refuge, located 12 miles south of Cambridge, is 10 times larger than Eastern Neck and is currently operating with a skeleton crew. Ford explained that many staff members with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service there are retiring early, but the goal remains to maintain staff who work on the ground.
For the past two years, some Blackwater staff have driven four hours to Eastern Neck Island to maintain the grounds. Further cuts could end these visits, Ford said.
Kent County plays a significant role in maintaining the refuge, including upkeep of roads to Bogles Wharf and the Ingleside Recreation Area.
Ford added that more cuts could affect the over 70,000 annual visitors to Eastern Neck, many of whom travel from out of town to enjoy the 100-year-old hunting lodge, gift shop, museum, bookstore, and trails.
She warned that without U.S. Fish and Wildlife oversight, volunteer work and community outreach programs through Friends of Eastern Neck would be severely limited or halted.
A full closure would have devastating consequences, Ford said. Invasive plants would go unchecked, migratory waterfowl populations would be at risk, hunts would end, litter would accumulate, and the island could be subject to vandalism.
"This is a national issue with serious local consequences," Ford told commissioners.
The group is once again calling for unity to protect the area, referencing the refuge's establishment in the 1960s. A decade earlier, a developer had subdivided a large tract into 293 lots for a housing development. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service acquired the island between 1962 and 1967 to preserve its valuable wildlife habitat.
Eastern Shore wildlife refuges feature bald eagles, osprey, swans, ducks, geese as well as other species of birds, reptiles and butterflies.
"Our community spoke up to preserve the land more than 60 years ago," Ford said. "We need to do it now, while we can still make a difference."
To expedite the process, Burton and Ford prepared a packet and a template for the commissioners to review, which they were happy to do.
Burton and Ford also encouraged members of the community to reach out for support at 410-639-7056 or visit friendsofeasternneck.org
"Tell your local lawmakers what Eastern Neck National Wildlife Refuge means to you and our community," they said.
Friends of Eastern Neck is a non-profit organization with about 300 members and 400 volunteers. Their mission is to support the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service in preserving and protecting the area. Volunteers assist with the butterfly garden, the contact station (open Friday to Sunday), lodge repairs, and education programs for both children and adults.

title: Airport modernization project recycling materials from Black & Decker
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnet@chespub.com
content:
Airport modernization project recycling materials from Black & Decker

 May 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnet@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 466
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The demolition of the Talbot County Business Center, the former Black & Decker building, played a big part in the next phase of Easton Airport modernization."We are recycling, reclaiming, reusing almost everything that we possibly can from that building," Easton Airport Manager Micah Risher said.
Construction of Runway 422 involves shifting the runway 1,000 feet to come into compliance with FAA regulations requiring a 1,000-foot runway safety area on each end of a runway.
The new portions of the runway will use crushed cinder block and brick from the Black & Decker building.
"It's gonna be used as the sub base of the new airfield," Risher said. "I'm very proud of this, the fact that we are using all of this stuff in the new runway."
The demolition and recycling of the Black & Decker building is nearing completion. Easton Airport is awaiting a permit to pull up the concrete slab.
According to Easton Airport's website, an environmental assessment was started in 2006 to plan for future safety improvements, modernization and to determine how the airport would conform to new FAA airport design standards.
"After an exhaustive 12-year assessment, Easton Airport's plan was approved in 2018," the website reads. "The Airfield Modernization Program design process and work on enabling projects moved forward soon after."
The modernization project, now in its second phase, includes upgrades like LED lights, multiple new on-ramps, and creating two 1,000-foot grass fields at each end of Runway 422. The airport will grade the area level to each end of the runway that runs roughly north and south.
In the process of leveling out the grass fields, Easton Airport included a 13-acre wetland site to help avoid pollution in the Chesapeake Bay and to help process stormwater at the airport.
"We made a lot of improvements already in Phase 1," Risher said. "We put in these long, shallow ditches that will run into this wetland down here, and that will just act as a natural filter to clean stormwater runoff as it leads to the problem.
"This project has so many positive environmental improvements," he said.
Those improvements include removing 13 acres of pavement.
"That's going to help the runoff situation," Risher said. "When rain hits pavement, it just runs right off fast. When it hits natural land, it's absorbed, it slowly goes through."
Phase 2 is expected to be completed this fall, he said.
While Phase 2 plays a big part in the next steps of the modernization, Risher said Easton Airport has another vision he hopes can be achieved during the modernization project.
"We don't have a time frame yet, but plans are absolutely in the works to put a small community park out here once it's all said and done," Risher said. "I've had that vision for years, where people can come in and see the airplane, like an aircraft viewing area."

title: QAC plastic bags: a 'carry all' of community voices
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QAC plastic bags: a 'carry all' of community voices

 May 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 527
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — A proposed ordinance regulating plastic bags in Queen Anne's County drew community members to the Queen Anne's County Commissioners on May 13 to voice their opinions.If enacted, the county ordinance would require customers to bring their own bags to retail locations and prohibit establishments from providing plastic carryout bags. Additionally, it would impose a fee of at least 10 cents on each paper bag and reusable carryout bag provided to a customer.
Environmental groups such as Queen Anne's Conservation Association, ShoreRivers, Plastic Free QAC, and the Chesapeake Watershed Semester at the Gunston School highlighted the excess of plastic bags as a major source of litter and its detrimental effects on health, wildlife, and the environment.
Chester RiverKeeper Annie Richards said the ordinance could set a precedent for state policy and help "turn the tide" on plastic pollution.
Small businesses such as Sunkissed Flower Farm in Stevensville, Fat and Happy Farms in Grasonville, and Lowery's Farm in Chester supported the ordinance, noting that plastic bags often become a nuisance in machinery.
Members of the Queen Anne's County Watermen's Association, voicing support for the ordinance, stressed the impact of discarded plastic bags on the Chesapeake Bay, a vital resource for local livelihoods and recreation.
A Kent Island High Schooler voiced concern for the long-term and yet-unknown overall impact of plastics and encouraged the lessening of their use as soon as possible.
Reiterating data previously presented to the commissioners, Bente Cooney, Plastic Free QAC founder, noted the growing number of businesses already embracing paper over plastic and encouraged a mindset less focused on "bag bans" and more on "bring your own bag."
Neil Bates, a member of the Kent Island Four Seasons Environmental Club, said, "I know this is a hard change, but it's one worth making."
The League of Women Voters of Queen Anne's County, represented by President Elizabeth Hammond, voiced support for the ordinance, backing its solid waste management position on reduction, recycling, and conservation.
Voices in support of the county-wide ordinance also cited the success of the Town of Centreville's elimination of single-use plastic bags, enacted in 2024. Initially met with some natural resistance and hesitation, Centreville Town President Ashley Kaiser said in a letter to the Commissioners that town residents have since adjusted well, leading to improvements in the Chesapeake Bay, local farms, and the overall shore environment and quality of life.
The Maryland Retailers Alliance (MRA) has long been in favor of a "ban and fee structure" for retailers to keep bag fees, according to MRA representative Sarah Price.
While not a money-maker for businesses, the fee structure directly offsets the costs of more expensive paper bags, she said.
To ease transition and provide consistency for the community, the MRA urged the commissioners to mirror Centreville legislation, notably allowing pharmacy and restaurant bags to be exempt from the 10-cent fee, according to Price.
Opposed to the ordinance as it was currently drafted and requesting full restaurant exemptions, Brendan Mahoney of the Restaurant Association of Maryland said paper bags for restaurant takeout can get messy, especially when carrying steamed crabs, and reusable totes may not be food-safe.
Public comment remains open, and decisions are expected at the County Commissioners' next meeting on May 27 at 5:30 p.m.

title: Eastern Shore legislators push for Gov. Moore to veto solar bill
author: Konner Metz
content:
Eastern Shore legislators push for Gov. Moore to veto solar bill

 May 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 626
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Eastern Shore legislators, House Republicans and agricultural advocacy groups in Maryland are making one last effort to nix controversial solar energy legislation by asking for a veto from Gov. Wes Moore.Senate Bill 931, the Renewable Energy Certainty Act, was passed by the General Assembly in April. It aims to increase the state's solar generation by streamlining the regulatory process for solar projects. Fencing, setback and vegetation requirements would be standardized.
House Republicans and the Eastern Shore Delegation both wrote letters to the governor urging him to veto the bill. While Moore (D) hasn't publicly signaled whether or not he's considering a veto, some believe it could be in play given he hasn't yet signed the legislation.
"I've heard it is possible," said Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) in an interview Wednesday. "I'm hopeful that he would see the opportunity and the wisdom and just say, 'No, not yet.'"
Qualms with the solar legislation largely relate to a reduction in the control local governments would have over solar project approvals, and the increase in Public Service Commission authority.
The legislation outlines a cap on how much land the Maryland Public Service Commission can grant to solar projects in each county — 5% of land designated for agriculture and forests.
Republicans attempted but failed during session to lower that cap.
Del. Chris Adams (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said Thursday that Eastern Shore counties could have thousands of acres up for solar development even with the 5% cap.
At a legislative wrap-up discussion in Easton Wednesday, Mautz said solar interests came into Annapolis and "cleared the decks."
"They wanted to set up their own regulatory system, they wanted to set up their own siting system," he said. "And they wanted to run this through the Public Service Commission."
"It puts an X on the Eastern Shore," Mautz added. "We are the prime target for solar investment."
The Chesapeake Climate Action Network, an environmental nonprofit that's one of the bill's many advocate groups, encouraged supporters to contact Moore's office and lobby for no veto. Brittany Baker, the organization's Maryland director, said rumors of a veto were floating.
"The rumor mill was churning, and no one had a concrete answer here or there," Baker said.
Baker said in addition to streamlining processes that otherwise vary greatly across the state, the bill is set to codify best practices. And it could help local farmers who are looking to remain economically viable, she said.
"It provides another way for people to be able to stay on their farms and make revenue," Baker said.
PUSH TO VETO
The governor's office didn't comment specifically on whether Moore is considering a veto, but did provide a statement.
"As Governor Moore reviews the hundreds of bills put forward this session, he will continue to work with the State Legislature, local leaders, and all partners involved to ensure that we are signing legislation that will make Maryland safer, more affordable, more competitive, and the state that serves," the statement read.
Baker said despite rumors, the Chesapeake Climate Action Network believes Senate Bill 931 will become law.
"We're pretty sure at this point that the governor will not be vetoing this bill," she said.
Mautz acknowledged a veto is a tricky, party-line situation. He said it would be messy, but "less messy" than what happens down the line if the bill becomes law.
"For the governor to veto it, he's going to cross his own party," Mautz said. "He's going to cross some of his own advocates. It's going to be extremely controversial."
Adams acknowledged that vetoes are rare. But he said the bill not yet being signed may signal "at the minimum, that the governor's paying attention."
If Moore doesn't sign the Renewable Energy Certainty Act by May 27, it automatically becomes law. The governor's next slate of bill signings is scheduled for May 20.
