title: The 'bester' river, the Chester River: RiverKeeper presents local State of the Rivers address
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
The 'bester' river, the Chester River: RiverKeeper presents local State of the Rivers address

 May 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 654
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Chester Riverkeeper Annie Richards hit the stage at Cult Classic Brewing in Stevensville to highlight updates and the future of the Chester River during a as part of the ShoreRivers State of the Rivers presentation series May 1.Inspiring industry and culture, the Chester River stands, er, flows, as a backbone of the community and RiverKeepers through ShoreRivers have a mission to protect and restore Eastern Shore waterways through advocacy restoration, education and engagement, all grounded in science, Richard said.
Covering four major watersheds, Sassafras and Bayside Creeks, Chester, Miles Wye and Eastern Bay, and Choptank, between April and October, Riverkeepers of ShoreRivers conduct tidal sampling of 14 sites from Cecilton to Cambridge.
Testing for multiple water quality parameters including nitrogen, phosphorus, temperature, salinity, algae, and clarity, these indicators reveal the overall health of local waterways and the progress toward protecting and restoring local rivers, she said.
The 2024 health grade for the Chester River was a "C+" and while the overall grade stayed the same as last year, there has been a tremendous amount of change in the parameters that make up the grade, she said.
The Chester River has seen a 3% increase in its overall water quality index over the last 10 years, she said. The Corsica River saw a 17% overall improvement from last year.
The dominant land use surrounding Chester is agriculture and when it comes to natural resources protecting the waterway, the Chester is in a deficit as Kent and Queen Anne's counties that make up the entirety of the Chester Watershed are "tied for the least treed counties in Maryland," she said.
Agricultural and septic systems play a contributing role in pollution which in turn is exacerbated by increased rainfall due to climate change.
According to the Comprehensive Evaluation of System Response (CESR) report from the Chesapeake Bay Program, stormwater runoff is the fastest growing pollution source across the state, Richards said.
Phosphorus and clarity often correlate as phosphorus has to bond to sediment in order to move into the waterway, and both phosphorus and clarity levels improved throughout the Chester and most other watersheds this year, Richards said.
How swimmable are local waterways? The Swimmable ShoreRivers Program promotes public access and recreation and monitors for bacteria and the accumulation of forever chemicals, she said.
Rainfall flushes bacteria from the land into waterways and bacteria levels were notable this year despite low rain, she said.
Providing opportunities for students and connecting with the community, ShoreRivers and partners work collaboratively to increase awareness of issues, inspire behavior change, and implement practices for healthier river systems, Richards said.
Critical Area Commission Chair Erik Fisher noted that the critical area is a 1,000 foot ribbon of land around all the tidewater in the state.
The goals of the commission lie in minimizing impact of runoff on water quality and conserving habitats while also accommodating growth with attention to adverse affects, building reliance to coastal hazards and provide resources for landowners
While it is a state wide commission, the Critical Area Commission has a distinct focus on local action, he said.
Through over 40 years of state and local partnerships the commission has reviewed thousands of development projects and worked to preserve contiguous forest.
Future rising tides will impact nearshore habitats in the critical areas and marshes will shift, increasing rainfall and hotter and saltier environments, according to Fisher. Looking at general growth patterns, the Commission is working to update maps continuously to help local communities factor equity and climate change data into future projects, he said.
The future of the Chester River starts with the community and everyone who uses the water, Richards said.
Highlighting open participation, ShoreRivers' community engagement includes advocating for better public access to waterways and local participation is encouraged every step of the way to ensure quality waterways for generations to come, Richards said.
"When you recreate [engage] with your environment, that fosters environmental stewardship. You can't love what you don't know," she said.
More information about ShoreRivers, including upcoming events can be found at https://www.shorerivers.org.

title: Moore signs two energy bills, including debated solar legislation
author: Konner Metz
content:
Moore signs two energy bills, including debated solar legislation

 May 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 515
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Gov. Wes Moore (D) signed two prominent energy bills into law on Tuesday, bills largely opposed by Eastern Shore Republicans during this year's Maryland General Assembly.Senate Bills 931 and 937 were part of an expansive energy package lawmakers wrestled with this session. While Moore vetoed the package's third bill, due in part to budgetary reasons, he put pen to paper for the others.
The Renewable Energy Certainty Act, or SB931, aims to increase the state's solar generation by streamlining the regulatory process for solar projects. Specifically, it provides the Maryland Public Service Commission with approving authority for projects under the 2-megawatt threshold.
Tuesday, Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City) said the legislation creates "a clear path forward for solar and battery storage projects to eliminate local barriers and allow local government to join in community solar programs."
"It is essential that we have more affordable and cleaner, Maryland-made energy," Ferguson said.
But Eastern Shore legislators, as well as county representatives, don't see it the same way.
Republican legislators unsuccessfully pushed for Moore to veto the bill amid concerns it strips away local control over solar project approvals and places too much authority at the hands of the Public Service Commission.
Caroline County Commission President Travis Breeding said it will override the county-instituted 2,000-acre solar cap.
Per the legislation, the Public Service Commission can grant solar project approvals on up to 5% of land designated for agriculture and forests. County leaders say the amount of land prone to solar development could quadruple.
"It's going to change the landscape, it's going to change the look of the county," Breeding said in an interview, citing concerns on food production and agricultural jobs. "It's going to change our economy."
Breeding noted the commissioners are "pursuing solutions at the federal level" in the form of reaching out to Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.). Breeding hopes there can be federal restrictions on solar project subsidies so developers "cannot offer these lucrative deals to entice landowners."
SENATE BILL 937
The Next Generation Energy Act, or SB937, focuses on ratepayer relief after a winter of skyrocketing energy bills — a trend Ferguson said was a "wake-up call" and not just a "temporary spike."
Ferguson noted $200 million will go toward ratepayer refunds — an average of $80 per household, Ferguson said, split between winter and summer payments.
The bill looks to increase in-state generation by trimming permitting processes as coal and oil plants reach their ends.
"We know that older coal plants and oil plants are being retired based on private action, and we have not built up enough alternative energy to fill it fast enough, and so the General Assembly had to act," Ferguson said.
Del. Chris Adams (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said the bill's framework doesn't do enough to incentivize nuclear energy or in-state generation. Adams and other Republicans have also disagreed with Democrats on the premise that the bill provides necessary relief to ratepayers.
"Maryland is still ... dependent on other states to bring us energy," Adams said in an interview last week. "It's expensive, and that sole political decision is what's creating the ratepayer difficulties that we're experiencing and will experience moving forward."

title: Petition launched against state solar bill
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com

 GREENSBORO — A statewide effort is underway to challenge a new law that could allow significant expansion of solar energy projects on agricultural land in Maryland.Jay Falstad, executive director of the Queen Anne's Conservation Association, is spearheading a petition for a statewide referendum that, if successful, would place Senate Bill 931 on the ballot for the next general election.
The petition needs to gather 30,000 signatures by Monday, June 2, for the referendum to be considered. If approved, it would challenge the Renewable Energy Certainty Act, which Falstad and other opponents believe threatens the state's agricultural lands.
"We have a long way to go," Falstad said, acknowledging the uphill battle of gathering signatures within a short time.
The Renewable Energy Certainty Act, or SB931, aims to increase the state's solar generation by streamlining the regulatory process for solar projects. Specifically, it provides the Maryland Public Service Commission with approving authority for projects under the 2-megawatt threshold.
May 20, Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City) said the legislation creates "a clear path forward for solar and battery storage projects to eliminate local barriers and allow local government to join in community solar programs."
"It is essential that we have more affordable and cleaner, Maryland-made energy," Ferguson said.
But Eastern Shore legislators, as well as county representatives, don't see it the same way.
Republican legislators unsuccessfully pushed for Moore to veto the bill amid concerns it strips away local control over solar project approvals and places too much authority at the hands of the Public Service Commission.
The bill increases any pre-existing cap on solar development within a county's priority preservation areas, or agricultural land to 5%. Falstad and the Farmers Alliance for Rural Maryland argue that it opens the door for the widespread conversion of agricultural land to solar farms.
"The position of the Farmers Alliance is that no agricultural acre ought to be taken up for solar projects when you have other surface options available," Falstad said. "If we're going to hold true to that principle, then why would we accept 5% and many tens of thousands of acres?"
Dozens of people stopped their Memorial Day activities to sign Falstad's petition at the North County Park Monday.
Falstad has made his way around the Mid-Shore, collecting signatures and raising awareness about the issue. He plans to visit Centreville, Kent Island and Federalsburg in the coming week to continue rallying support.
Despite the challenge of the tight timeline, Falstad remains determined.
"So the overall number of acres of farmland consumed for solar projects on the Eastern Shore alone is tens of thousands of acres. In Kent, Queen Anne's, Caroline, Talbot County, it's well over 10,000 acres alone, and that type of impact will surely have implications," Falstad has said.
The petition and referendum aim to challenge a significant provision of Senate Bill 931 that could allow the conversion of more agricultural land to solar production, which Falstad argues could have far-reaching repercussions for Maryland's agricultural community and the businesses that rely on it.
To sign the petition you must be a registered voter. If interested contact Falstad at jfalstad@yahoo.com.

title: 'Green School' programs in Caroline County bring joy to students
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chesoub.com
content:
'Green School' programs in Caroline County bring joy to students

 May 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chesoub.com | Section: News 
 
 611
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — As of this year, Two Caroline County public schools have been certified as Green Schools by the Maryland Association for Environmental and Outdoor Education.Denton Elementary joined Greensboro Elementary in gaining the certification this year. Both schools went through a two-year application process through MAEOE to be come Green School certified.
Although directors for programs at the schools said the program was intense, they said the help they received from the community was surprising and made the process go much smoother.
"You have to work together, and we divided and conquered," said Julie Strange, pre-k teacher at and program coordinator for Green Schools at Denton Elementary. "You have to contact people at the board office. You have to contact contact your cafeteria. You have to contact people I didn't even know did jobs.
"It's an intense process, but again, eye-opening how helpful everybody was and that there are people for everything."
Within that application for the program there are different subcategories for which the schools must show evidence they met the objective.
The application also comes with a curriculum that must be completed by the students, and the school must provide one example of outdoor or environmental instruction per grade level.
"Through our curriculum and standards, we're able to teach these kids sustainability practices and how to take care of the Earth, just learning about the Earth through those environmental literacy standards. It's one of my passions. I really enjoy doing it," said Zellie Kneller Kidigarden, a teacher and program director for Green Schools at Greensboro Elementary.
Throughout the application process, the elementary schools have been able to produce multiple projects that help compost, save energy and grow fresh foods.
One project at Denton Elementary involves collecting breakfast bags in the morning after breakfast. According to Strange, the school lets third graders create boxes and put recycle signs on them to put in their classrooms to collect bags in the morning.
"Every day, we get breakfast in plastic bags per child, and our school is about 650 kids. So that's 650 bags that go in the trash every day," Strange said. "The kids were so excited about it, and they did it... the kids are responsible for putting their bag in there when they're done their breakfast instead of throwing it in the trash."
One of the projects Greensboro Elementary conducts is planting in multiple gardens.
"We do strawberries, herbs in our garden tower and then we have our pollinator garden. Our Environmental Club also planted native plants everywhere in our swales. Before the end of the school year, we're going to plant native plants in our courtyard," Kneller said.
Kneller credits community partners for being helpful in their pursuit to becoming a green school.
Some of the organizations Greensboro Elementary has partnered with are Pickering Creek Audubon Center, Chesapeake Bay Foundation, Tuckahoe State Park, Wetlands on Wheels and many more.
"I'm so grateful that we're a community school because being a community school allows us to work with... stakeholders in the community, and we get wonderful things from all the members in the community," Kneller said.
Greensboro Elementary has been a green school since 2021 and will go through a renewal next year. The school has been able to secure multiple grants that will lead to future projects, including tree planting and much more.
Both Kneller and Strange believe every school should be Green School certified.
"It's really, really, really important work and every school should be green school certified," Kneller said. "It is life-changing for a lot of students and adults and I would say everyone because this is the planet that we live on and everyone needs to learn how to take care of it because we don't have anywhere else to go."

State must do more for beaches

 Maryland's coastlines are eroding at an alarming rate. While Ocean City receives regular beach nourishment to rebuild its beaches, many other vulnerable areas, like Assateague Island and parts of the Chesapeake Bay, are often overlooked.These places face the same threats from rising sea levels and stronger storms, but they receive far less support and funding.
Beach nourishment is not just about preserving popular tourist spots. It plays a crucial role in protecting wildlife habitats, nearby communities, and public infrastructure. If we only focus on one area, we risk losing much more of Maryland's shoreline than we realize.

title: Floating solar panels could power Chestertown’s future
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Floating solar panels could power Chestertown’s future

 June 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 576
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — A quiet corner of Chestertown may soon become home to a cutting-edge floating solar array, thanks to a newly approved lease agreement between the town and Third Pillar Solar, a renewable energy company working on a large-scale project atop the town's wastewater lagoon.The site, located off John Hanson Road, already houses the town's wastewater treatment plant and serves as a popular birding location, with more than 160 species reported.
The Town of Chestertown is working with Tom Dietz, the environmental committee's energy adviser, on the project, which is still in the design phase.
If constructed, the solar array would feature 7 megawatts of floating solar panels anchored to the lagoon and connected to Delmarva Power. The system would be built and operated by Third Pillar Solar, a U.S.-based company specializing in floating solar arrays on municipal and industrial water bodies.
At its June 3 meeting, the Chestertown Council approved a lease agreement allowing Third Pillar to proceed with development. The same night, Dietz's plan to begin project design was approved.
Project developer Michaela Hunt Hess attended the meeting to answer questions, though council members and Mayor David Foster had few, having already heard from Third Pillar Vice President of Development Ned Horneffer at previous meetings.
At the May 5 meeting, Horneffer presented a detailed overview of the project. He said the company, now about 20 employees strong, has grown rapidly, attracting professionals from major firms and securing backing from Glentra Capital, a private investment firm committed to fully funding the project.
Horneffer said the project has two phases: development and construction.
During development, Third Pillar will work with Delmarva Power to identify an interconnection point. In this phase, the company will pay the town $15,000 annually in rent, with increases of $3,000 per year.
If Delmarva determines the project is viable, Third Pillar will move into construction. At that point, the company will seek a certificate of public convenience and necessity from the Maryland Public Service Commission, a process Horneffer said typically takes about a year.
Once construction begins and energy production is confirmed, the rent paid by the company will increase to approximately $81,000 annually, based on $12,000 per megawatt.
Third Pillar will cover the cost of any infrastructure upgrades required by Delmarva, estimated between $1 million and $3 million.
A decommissioning bond will be issued to the town as insurance in case the project becomes obsolete or is not completed.
Town Manager Larry DiRe asked whether the town would receive solar energy credits. Horneffer said no, but noted Chestertown could benefit by becoming an anchor subscriber to the energy output.
Foster raised questions about environmental impact and bird activity. Horneffer said that birds are often drawn to the floating panels and that the company may install deterrents, such as washers, to manage that.
Foster noted that the project involves a 42-year lease agreement — a long-term commitment for the town.
Before construction can begin, the next step will be approval of a transmission easement to run cables from the site. Horneffer said he would return to the council for that authorization.
He emphasized that Third Pillar would assume all project risk — owning, operating and maintaining the system, and subcontracting construction and maintenance to Maryland-based companies.
Floating solar arrays have gained support in Maryland as an alternative to projects that use farmland. Horneffer said Third Pillar is developing similar projects across Maryland, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, and hopes to add Chestertown to that list soon.
"We look forward to working with you all going forward," he told the council.

 ST. MICHAELS — At the May Commissioners of St. Michaels meeting, the commissioners received an update on San Domingo Creek.Roy Myers, chairman of the Climate Change and Sea Level Rise Commission, and Anna Johnson, project engineer and Bay Land representative, gave a presentation on San Domingo Creek and Back Creek Park Living Shoreline.
The presentation consisted of the findings from a mitigation study as part of the San Domingo Creek area study. The study found that the bulkhead, a wall-like structure that serves as a barrier to the creek, was severely broken down and leaning seaward.
According to Johnson, the best solution is to build a living shoreline.
"Given the calm environment of San Domingo Creek, likely the best solution for this area is the build a living shoreline," Johnson said.
The proposed solutions were to make a pebble and sand fill with marsh plantings, cut the bulkhead and cover with upland plantings, and add protection structures with soft launch.
To pay for this project, the town received a grant from the Department of Natural Resources Resiliency Through Restoration Division for $204,776 to design and construct a 100-foot living shoreline with climate-resilient natural features along the San Domingo Creek and Back Creek Park.
Bay Land and DNR have been working together since the town received the grant in October.
Commissioners President Jay Hudson said the presentation was helpful.
"I think the presentation was was great. I think she (Johnson) covered a lot of things that needed to be covered as far as proposed materials and plantings," Hudson said.
One conversation brought up during the meeting was about what materials should be used for the Kayak launch area. Hudson said the town will look at alternative materials.
"I think what was left was that we were going to be looking at alternative materials for the kayak launch," Hudson said. "Because there was some astroturf, there were some concerns about small pebbles marring the the plastic of the kayak, we're looking into alternative kayak launch materials that would be able to be submerged in water but also protect the integrity of of those vessels."
According to Hudson, in late August, about 60% of the design documents and construction will be done. By November all of that will be completed. Hudson said the commissioners will be receive another update in January.

title: AI's potential benefits are extraordinary, but so are downsides
author: MICHAEL DAVIS
content:
AI's potential benefits are extraordinary, but so are downsides

 June 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MICHAEL DAVIS | Section: Columns 
 
 841
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Buried in the 1,038 pages of the One Big Beautiful Bill Act is a dangerous clause that prohibits any state from regulating artificial intelligence for 10 years. Even Marjorie Taylor Greene is against it, as well as other Republicans: Sens. Blackburn (R-Tenn), Tillis (R-NC), Hawley (R-Missouri), Rounds (R-SD) and Young (R-Ind.).Recently, Trump rescinded federal regulatory controls on AI that were imposed by a Biden executive order. Because language in the budget bill goes further and eliminate all state regulation of AI for 10 years, this would leave an AI regulatory vacuum with only Trump in a position to regulate AI by executive order or by initiating federal legislation.
AI involves making and spending hundreds of billions of dollars. The company that developed ChatGPT-4, OpenAI, is valued at $300 billion, making it one of the most valuable private companies in the world. Anthropic, a relatively small AI company that developed Claude.ai is worth $60 billion. Other companies involved in AI are Microsoft, Amazon, Meta and Google. Microsoft invested $13 billion with OpenAI. Trump recently announced a $500 billion private investment in AI infrastructure.
AI's potential benefits are extraordinary. There are also serious concerns about predictable negative consequences if there is no government oversight at the federal or state level. One major concern about AI is how the companies creating AI programs have exploited people and physical resources. The companies have a disgraceful history of hiring impoverished people in Africa and Venezuela to review the worst images posted on the internet so these AI companies can block the images from the rest of us.
Another concern is how AI contributes to energy and land exploitation. Trump brags about the $500 billion private investment in AI infrastructure that will start this year. Unregulated, AI requires massive amounts of electricity to power computers in data centers. Even before Trump announced the $500 billion in infrastructure for AI, designs were underway for data centers requiring as much power as is needed to run two to three cities as large as San Francisco.
One gross estimate is that by 2030 8% of all electricity generated in the U.S. will be used for AI. There is no national planning underway for managing that new power load.
Data centers also require vast quantiles of fresh water to prevent overheating. The supply of freshwater in the world is plummeting to critical levels due to shifting weather patterns, growing needs by agriculture, industrial pollution and saltwater incursion. In 2022, Google was designing a data center in Chile that was going to use several million gallons of fresh water every day — enough for tens of thousands of families. The Chilean government intervened to stop the project.
AI companies aggressively hide the data about environmental exploitation. Independent researchers are banned from company sites. In-house researchers are prevented from publishing data on the environmental impact of AI. They also project rosy scenarios that have not happened, such as claiming AI will solve climate change. But the environmental damage by data centers will happen long before those fixes are, if ever, in place.
The unaddressed impact of AI on employment is huge. One AI executive predicted that by 2030, AI will be able to do every entry-level white-collar job. Under this scenario the unemployment rate will be as high as 20%. Companies will no longer need to hire new medical diagnosticians, engineers, computer programmers, business managers, research scientists, writers, artists, accountants, musicians, and so on. That will be a disaster even if it takes twice as long for AI, say 10 years, to achieve this.
Our own Andy Harris should worry. Today there are AI-programmed anesthesiology machines that could easily put him out of work. Those machines are not used on humans only due to Federal Drug Adminsitration (FDA) regulation.
In its short life, AI has a controversial history. AI programs have created graphic child pornography in texts and pictures, created deep fakes, written Nazi propaganda, created propaganda that influenced elections around the world and convinced several people to kill themselves. Even more alarming, this year an AI program spontaneously wrote code to prevent someone from turning it off.
The AI companies don't want their programs used for these abuses, but they have not been able to stop it. The companies have set up internal safety organizations with a mixed record of successful control. In March 2023, industry leaders in AI issued an open letter saying all progress on AI should stop for six months to give governments time to develop regulations. Over 13,500 programmers cosigned the letter. The pause did not happen.
There is essentially no government regulation of AI, but states could jump in and protect against AI abuses. The provision in the One Big Beautiful Bill Act, if the Senate accepts it, would prevent state regulation for a decade, leaving Trump with immense and exclusive power. This doomsday scenario is not fear mongering. It is playing out in real time. In the history of the world, no profound technology has ever been so quickly introduced with no institutional guardrails whatsoever. Politics aside, AI regulation is necessary to protect the common good.

title: Blue crabs are on a decline
author: Aamaly Hossain somdnewsintern@chespub.com
content:
Blue crabs are on a decline

 June 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Aamaly Hossain somdnewsintern@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 491
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Blue crab populations in the Chesapeake Bay dropped to the second-lowest number on record, according to a recent survey from the Chesapeake Bay Foundation.The 2025 survey showed the overall population has declined to an estimated 238 million crabs — just above the all-time low of 226 million crabs recorded in 2022. This marks one of the most severe declines since surveying began in 1990.
"The red flags are flying for blue crabs," said Allison Colden, the foundation's Maryland executive director, in a statement by the foundation. "With more than five years of below average crab numbers, it is clear that changing conditions in the bay are undermining the current management of this important species."
A statement released earlier this month by the foundation attributed the population drop to multiple environmental pressures, including climate change, habitat loss, invasive predators and polluted water.
The health of blue crab populations is closely tied to underwater grasses — a critical habitat for the crustacean's youth stages. When these grasses disappear, juvenile crabs are left vulnerable.
The rise of invasive species like blue catfish, a vicious predator, has also added pressure.
Additionally, climate change and polluted runoff are further stressing the population, specifically young and spawning crabs.
"Blue crab numbers are crashing just as the Trump Administration dismantles programs restoring water quality and underwater habitat like grasses vital for crabs," Keisha Sedlacek, the Chesapeake Bay Foundation's federal director, said in a statement.
Earlier this year, bay residents through a survey told the foundation that they believe blue crabs are the species in greatest need of protection.
The foundation is calling for stronger conservation measures. Among its recommendations include Maryland and Virginia reducing their harvests.
Local and state watermen associations did not return requests for comment.
The foundation urged Maryland to enhance protections for female crabs and reduce imports of Virginia-harvested crabs. Meanwhile, Virginia should explore ways to limit male crab harvests, which have increased in recent years.
"Given the continued decline of males in the population, Virginia should look for ways to reduce harvest of male crabs, which has been a growing part of our crab harvest," Chris Moore, the foundation's Virginia executive director, said in a statement.
The group also urged for fully funded programs and agencies such as the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and Environmental Protection Agency, which support clean water initiatives essential to crab habitat.
"Saving the bay and its iconic species like crabs has always been a bi-partisan effort," Sedlacek said. "Congress must work together to ensure federal investments in restoration continue."
Maryland and Virginia are currently conducting comprehensive stock assessments of the blue crab population, the first since 2011. Results are expected in late 2026.
"Managers must heed those assessment results, and act swiftly to protect the opportunity for the next generation to experience the joy of a summertime crab feast," Colden said.
Despite the ongoing efforts at the state level, Sedlacek said decisions made by Congress are essential for the future of blue crabs.
"We cannot backtrack on blue crabs or the bay," she said.

title: Estuarine center's annual bay report card shows lackluster grades
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Estuarine center's annual bay report card shows lackluster grades

 June 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 585
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Recently, the University of Maryland Center Estuarine Sciences released its 2024 Chesapeake Bay and Watershed Report Card.The 19th annual report, which a news release stated is "the most comprehensive annual assessment of the Chesapeake Bay and its watershed," gave the Chesapeake Bay an overall grade of C (50%), and a C+ (57%) for the health of the Chesapeake Bay watershed.
The overall bay score, which dropped five points from a year ago, also saw decreases in almost all indicator scores.
"My first takeaway is that we did have a bit of a downturn from previously, but if you look at the data from the mid-1980s the scores are improving," UMCES Integration and Application Network Director Heath Kelsey said. "They are not improving really fast, but it is improving over time and it's important for people to know that."
Kelsey continued, "A lot of things have happened in the watersheds of the Chesapeake Bay in that time period [such as population increase, development and agriculture] and all those things can impact a watershed. The fact that we are still making progress, even slow progress, is remarkable."
The report stated one possibility for the downturn is recent extreme rainfall patterns combined with heat. While parts of the watershed experienced drought, brief but intense downpours also caused runoff into bay waters.
"The thing we're always fighting is runoff," said Friends of Mill Creek Coordinator Ted Haynie, whose Calvert organization tests 150 sites each year, including 26 watersheds. "When rain falls, the longer it has to leech into the ground, the better it is to keep the nutrients where they belong, instead of when you have these heavy rainfalls everything just rushes into the water. Retention is the biggest thing."
The university estuarine center stated that long-term improving trends can be attributed to management and restoration efforts at the regional, state and local levels, the upgrading of wastewater treatment plants and the implementing of programs to reduce nutrient and sediment input. State efforts include seagrass restoration, oyster plantings and watershed planning.
Dissolved oxygen (A+), total phosphorous (A), total nitrogen (C+) and Benthic community earned top grades, followed by low grades for aquatic grasses (D+), chlorophyll (D-) and water clarity (F).
"We've seen a downward trend in water clarity for quite a long time," Kelsey said, "and there's been a lot of discussion about what does that mean and what's causing that."
"I think we thought we were making some good progress," Haynie said, "but it never seems like enough."
Both agree that impervious surfaces — which are any hard surfaces that carry rain along with pollutants, fertilizer, chemicals, pesticides, oils, greases and plastics to name a few — into the water systems are key.
"The better option is for that rainwater to soak into the ground," Kelsey said.
Haynie said there are ways to increase the grades, but it will take work.
"It is doable, but how much willpower do people have?" he asked. "It does take personal sacrifice, and you do not have to live on the water to have a personal responsibility in the health of the bay and our surrounding waterways. I don't have a lot of faith in people's willingness to sacrifice anything."
"Even though our scores are going up, they're going up very slowly and I wouldn't consider that to be on track," Kelsey said. "We all want the Chesapeake Bay to be in A-plus condition and we're a long ways from that. We've demonstrated that we can have an impact from the things that we do, so I don't think it's a pipe dream at all."

title: New service turns food waste into fertilizer for Chestertown
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
New service turns food waste into fertilizer for Chestertown

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News

 CHESTERTOWN — The Town of Chestertown, in partnership with Washington College, will soon add composting — the natural process of recycling organic matter into fertilizer — to its services for residents.Jenny Lee Freebery, chair of the Chestertown Environmental Committee, announced the project during a March town council meeting. She thanked the community for its support in reducing carbon emissions, recycling, composting, maintaining animal habitats, creating pollinator-friendly areas and supporting alternatives to fossil fuels.
Now that the drop-off site is being prepared, Freebery updated Kent County News on the project's progress.
Between the Chestertown Armory and the Semans-Griswold Environmental Hall at Washington College, 485 S. Cross St., two 95-gallon bins will be placed, courtesy of Shore Soils, a composting company in Stevensville owned by Ryan Silbaugh.
After touring the Shore Soils facility, Freebery said she was impressed by the clean, odor-free and environmentally friendly operation.
"There was no smell, no indication of vermin," she said, noting that Silbaugh's method includes aerating the organic matter — even meats, bread, cheese and chicken bones — to speed up decomposition.
What happens to all that nutrient-rich compost?
"The town gets it back," Freebery said, explaining that it will be used to grow plants in parks and other beautification projects.
Commercial haulers will pick up the bins weekly, replacing them with fresh containers to ensure a clean process. Freebery said the bins will be visible from the road. Fencing and signage will be added in the coming days.
Freebery expressed optimism about the program's environmental benefits.
"Food waste takes up one-third of people's garbage," she said. "Composting reduces landfill space, lowers the carbon footprint and prevents food from breaking down into methane gas. We're turning our food into a reliable resource."
Items labeled compostable will be accepted in the bins. However, the following are not permitted: oil, Crisco or grease; glossy or coated paper; plastic bags, wrappers or foil; charcoal; synthetic tea bags; plastic-coated cardboard; plastic food packaging; sugar or sauce packets; produce stickers; rubber bands; treated or painted wood; pet waste or cat litter; gloves; and Styrofoam.
Learn more about the composting operation at shoresoils.com.

title: 'Barge-r' than life: Wye River Oyster Program ensures 21 million oysters in Wye River
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
'Barge-r' than life: Wye River Oyster Program ensures 21 million oysters in Wye River

 July 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 537
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE RIVER — A small but mighty group of citizens, friends and neighbors dedicated to the preservation of the Chesapeake Bay, Wye River Oyster Program volunteers raised donations to plant 21 million spat-on-shell oysters to cover three acres of the Wye River bottom June 29.Focusing hyper local efforts, the Wye River Oyster Program is a non-profit, community initiative to restore oyster populations in the local Wye River.
The Chesapeake Bay is "the only water system like it in the world," and residents who live on the water are a unique community, regularly sharing information about the water and its resources, organizer Steve Burleson said.
Dedicated to the preservation of the watershed, the ball began rolling about a year ago, according to Burleson, when citizens gathered to see what additional initiatives could be done to further restoration efforts.
While conservancy groups are invaluable in education and advocacy, Wye River Oyster Program volunteers sought to have more direct and local impacts and discovered the Wye River as an oyster sanctuary right in their own backyard.
With little more than an idea and a talking point, the Wye River Oyster program hatched, with all-volunteer efforts ensuring 100% of donations go toward purchase of spat on shells, he said.
"This way we know exactly where the money is going," he said.
Every little bit helps, especially with the growing uncertainty of federal funding, he noted.
Primarily through word of mouth with other water enthusiasts, Wye River Oyster Program quickly raised money to partner with Ricky Fitzhugh of Seed to Shuck Ventures, and cover three acres of the Wye River bottom.
Based in Cambridge, Seed to Shuck's hatchery spawns new oyster larvae for spat on shell production and restoration projects on the Bay.
Seed to Shuck is an active partner with federal and state agencies, conservation organizations and watermen to plant new growth in oyster sanctuaries, public fisheries and private leases in Maryland and Virginia.
Each canister is home to approximately 675 bushels of oysters and the initiative planted three canisters, which makes up one barge, Burleson said.
According to Maryland Department of Natural Resources (DNR) estimates, about 15% of spat on shell grow to market size, and the DNR has been incredibly supportive of the initiative, he said.
An essential aspect of an entire ecology, oysters naturally filter pollutants and excess nutrients in the water and their reefs help restore submerged habitat, providing shelter and breeding grounds for a variety of marine life, according to Burleson.
By restoring oyster beds to historic areas, the Wye River Oyster Program aims to achieve significant improvements to the water quality of the Wye River for the benefit of the community and the ecosystem of the Chesapeake watershed.
Community interest throughout the entire initiative has been highly engaging, and supportive, Burleson said.
Several boats with numerous volunteers and river enthusiasts took to the water to watch the planting Sunday, June 29. The shell is washed off the boat onto the waiting river floor below the surface.
The Wye River Oyster Program seeks to make plantings an annual tradition and encourage more neighboring rivers to join in initiatives to locally support their waterways, according to Burleson.
The Wye River Oyster Program Fund is a non-profit of the Mid Shore Community Foundation.
More information about Seed to Shuck Ventures can be found at seedtoshuck.com.

title: Replenishing reefs and the region
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Replenishing reefs and the region

 July 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 559
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The St. Mary's River in Southern Maryland received about 25,500 new — and very welcome — residents last week when members of the Supporting Oyster Aquaculture and Restoration program planted oysters on an established sanctuary about a mile from the St. Mary's College of Maryland docks.SOAR, as the program is known, buys oysters from local growers that could not otherwise be used for sale to help build and support reefs in the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries.
"Oysters are incredibly valuable to the Chesapeake Bay ecosystem as the three F's," St. Mary's River Watershed Association Executive Director Emma Ewing said, referring to filtering, fish and food. "They filter water, provide habitat for striped bass, white perch and blue crabs, and people love to eat oysters and a lot of people rely on oysters for their job and their livelihoods."
Ewing added that each adult oyster can filter up to 50 gallons of water a day.
Tall Timbers-based Shore Thing Shellfish was contracted to load, move and deploy the oysters, as well as for assistance with site selection and ongoing monitoring.
The program was started by The Nature Conservancy and the Pew Charitable Trust during the coronavirus pandemic to help growers who were impacted by restaurant closures.
"Oysters are an iconic species for the Chesapeake," The Nature Conservancy Chesapeake Bay Director Amy Jacobs said. "They are [overlooked] and even though we've made great progress through restoration we're still at a very, very small percent of what we used to have historically, so the more we can support oyster restoration and get more oysters in the water and allow for the growth of both aquaculture and wild harvest and restoration through sanctuaries, and have all those work together, the better the bay is going to be."
The conservancy provided funding for the oyster purchases through the SOAR program and worked with the Maryland Department of Natural Resources along with local partners and stakeholders.
"You want to make sure different year classes [of oysters] are in the water at all time," The Nature Conservancy SOAR Lead Dan Sweeney said, "because if one year-class gets infected by some mortality event, having [them from multiple classes] will help replenish and grow more baby oysters."
A news release said the June 30 replanting was a "great opportunity to highlight the importance of oysters to Maryland both economically and ecologically, and the role that local growers can play in their restoration."
Oyster growers Jon Farrington of Johnny Oyster Seed Company in St. Leonard, Phillip Stephens of Loose Stones Oyster Company in Hollywood and Joseph C. Gardener supplied 85 bushels of oysters, which equates to about 25,500 oysters.
"I'm always a big proponent of the environmental work that oysters do and so when we can farm oysters and make money on them, whether they're being sold for food or restoration purposes, it's all good," said Farrington, who called oysters "habitat engineers."
According to Ewing, the St. Mary's River Watershed Association began planting oysters in the river in 2013 and it became an oyster sanctuary in 2017.
"I'd say [the oysters make] a big difference," Ewing said. "Talking to the guys on the waterfront who are out here every day they say the water's clearer and we've definitely seen more fish, blue crabs. This area right here the 5-acre reef site is an extremely popular fishing and crabbing area because of all the oysters we've put in this area."

title: Global warming seen in Dorchester County forests
author: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service
content:
Global warming seen in Dorchester County forests

 July 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service | Section: Local News 
 
 1074
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The oak trees on Mike Tidwell's street in Montgomery County are dying, so he wrote a book about it."In the last few years, I just have become very conscious of the fact that our biggest trees in Takoma Park were dying," said Tidwell, founder and director of the Chesapeake Climate Action Network. "I read in the city newsletter and heard from arborists that this mass tree mortality was linked to extreme weather, triggered by climate change. I thought that was sad and amazing."
Tidwell's new book, "The Lost Trees of Willow Avenue," looks beyond Takoma Park. It examines extreme weather events and climate change happening across the state. And other experts agree that the impact is vast, including on the Eastern Shore, where more dead trees can be found in the "ghost forests" of Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge.
These things are happening because temperatures in Maryland have never been warmer.
Since the 20th century, temperatures in the state have risen around 2.5 degrees Fahrenheit, according to the National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration. But it's more than just heat. Federal data shows the state is experiencing increasing precipitation, a higher probability of summer droughts, more extreme weather events and flooding accompanied with rising sea levels.
The impact of climate change on the state is as varied as its landscape. From vast forests and rolling farms that line the Eastern Shore to the 80.9 square miles of Baltimore City scattered with heat islands, different areas of the state will be affected by climate change in vastly different ways.
To hear Tidwell and other environmental experts tell it, the state's poorest communities will face the greatest climate challenges. Communities on the Eastern Shore — where farmlands are becoming wetlands — and Baltimore's city neighborhoods are at particular risk.
"There are certain communities, especially marginalized communities that won't have the resources to adapt," Tidwell said. "We just have to stabilize the climate before we face those truly nightmarish impacts."
The changes Maryland is likely to face are detailed in the federal government's fifth National Climate Assessment — but the Trump administration deleted all that data from the internet on June 30. However, the Local News Network at the University of Maryland's Philip Merrill College of Journalism downloaded all that data months ago and used it as the basis of this story and the accompanying county summaries.
Here's a closer look at what's happening to the climate, and what's expected to happen, across the state:
EASTERN SHOREThe remnants of Harriett Tubman's birth home sit in a dying forest in Dorchester County.
"They found the original foundations of her home and you now can't even get there because it's in the middle of a ghost forest," said Kate Tully, a researcher and associate professor at the University of Maryland College of Agriculture and Natural Resources.
Ghost forests — which are either partially or completely dead — can be found throughout the lower Eastern Shore in Dorchester, Somerset, Worcester and Wicomico counties. These ghost forests result from saltwater intrusion, or what Tully refers to as "invisible floods," where seawater creeps inland as temperatures and waters rise.
"That's essentially when the salt burns the tree from the inside out," Tully said.
High tides, droughts and groundwater pumping all contribute to this increasingly common phenomenon. Eventually, land plagued by saltwater intrusion turns into either marshland or open water.
As a result, Tubman's home — only discovered just a few years ago in the Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge — is now inaccessible.
In the lower Eastern Shore, there are over 70,000 acres of forest classified by the state as ghost forests, with 90% of those acres classified as severely or very severely impacted. For a forest to fall under these classifications, at least half of its trees would be dead.
But saltwater intrusion isn't just killing forests.
"There are farmers that are being highly impacted by the saltwater intrusion and the loss of productivity of their land," said Elliott Campbell, director of the science and research division of the Watershed and Climate Services at Maryland's Department of Natural Resources.. "There's not really a way to, like, get the salt out."
Farms along the Eastern Shore, including northern counties such as Cecil, Kent, Talbot and Caroline, are known for growing corn and soybeans, used primarily to feed livestock, Campbell said. But these crops don't grow well in salty soil, and Campbell said there is no perfect alternative.
While there are vulnerable farms throughout the entire shore, Tully said Black communities in the lower Eastern Shore are being disproportionately impacted by saltwater intrusion.
"We've already lost so many Black farms in Black communities on the Eastern Shore," Tully said. "There's actually a whole history that's already gone underwater that we will never get back."
In the Antebellum period, the lower Eastern Shore became home to many free Black people escaping slavery from Virginia and other Southern states. The tributaries of the Chesapeake Bay helped provide a living for many formerly enslaved people. But Tully said these communities — and their deep-rooted history — will disappear soon if they're not already underwater.
The Chesapeake Bay region is the United States' third-most vulnerable area to sea level rise behind Louisiana and South Florida, according to NOAA's National Centers for Environmental Information.
Because the low-lying, largely flat area is so vulnerable, the effects of an increasing climate are much more intense than in other parts of the state. The Chesapeake Bay has already risen from 1.3 to 1.5 inches each decade over the past 100 years, and increasing temperatures would drastically increase precipitation.
The land isn't the only thing vulnerable to climate change. Throughout the entire Eastern Shore, the fishing industry is changing.
"One very clear example is that we never had a shrimp industry in the state until the last couple years," Campbell said.
Campbell also said blue crabs populations, which do well in warmer waters, will thrive. But the effects on the bay aren't all positive.
Warmer waters will kill fish at an increasing rate, Campbell said. Similarly, an increase in carbon dioxide in the atmosphere increases the acidity in the ocean water, which can deplete oyster populations.
As for the Eastern Shore's farmland and ghost forests, Campbell said the best case for this land experiencing saltwater intrusion is for it to transition into wetlands. The state has a pilot program to help farmers with that transition.
"In some cases, you see marshes forming under those forests," Campbell said. "But in some cases, they eventually will transition to just open water and you lose that ecosystem."
Capital News Service reporter Rachel McCrea contributed to this report.

While it touches on agriculture and racial disparities, the core theme is environmental degradation and climate-related ecological shifts.

 Eastern Shore Land Conservancy recently welcomed Alexander Gilchrist and Natalie Birrell to the organization's board of directors."ESLC is fortunate to be bolstered by a diverse and skillful board of directors," said Jim Mullin, ESLC board chair. A recently retired economist, Gilchrist coordinated agricultural trade and assistance programs between the U.S. and the newly independent states of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union at the USDA's Foreign Agricultural Service. A resident of Chestertown and self-proclaimed naturalist, Gilchrist will join the board's conservation programs committee.

My sister lived in Salisbury and Tyaskin and my youngest son lived and worked on Tilghman Island. I am honored to be associated with ESLC, and hope I can find some way to add value to their already excellent work."
Natalie Birrell brings 36 years of financial services industry experience to the ESLC board of directors' finance, investment and audit committee. President and partner of Anchorage Capital Group LLC, Birrell is responsible for overseeing Anchorage's day-to-day operations and is a voting member of its Legacy Funds Investment Committee.

Natalie recently served as the chair of the board of directors for the Managed Funds Association, the trade association for the global alternative asset management industry.
"I am honored to join the board of ESLC," Birrell said. "Although I have called the Eastern Shore my home for less than a decade, I have quickly come to appreciate the deep sense of place, community and stewardship that define this region. I am excited to support ESLC's work in protecting the land, the heritage and the way of life that makes the Shore so special for those who have lived here for generations and for those of us who are grateful to have found our way here."

title: State struggles to meet ambitious climate goals
author: RACHEL McCREA Capital News Service
content:
State struggles to meet ambitious climate goals

 July 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: RACHEL McCREA Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1547
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As the planet logs some of its warmest years on record, Maryland is trying to make good on some of the most ambitious climate goals in the country. But the state is struggling to keep up with deadlines it set for itself.Maryland is halfway to its goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions — the primary driver of climate change — by 60% by 2031, though progress has been at a standstill since 2020. It has another, more ambitious goal on the horizon: net zero emissions by 2045.
The state also is trying to transition to renewable energy, aiming for half of its electricity to come from renewables by 2030. That includes a significant chunk from solar energy, though experts say reaching these goals is proving difficult.
Federal opposition to state climate action poses a problem, too. In an April executive order, President Donald Trump directed his administration to halt the enforcement of state climate laws, calling them a threat to national security, the economy and "American energy dominance."
Adding it all up, environmentalists see Maryland's climate ambitions as laudable — but threatened.
"Maryland is not on track right now for either its renewable energy goals or for its climate goals," said Josh Tulkin, director of the Maryland Sierra Club. "That doesn't mean that it can't be on track, though, because there's a lot of positive programs that will help improve people's lives and reduce pollution and help with the climate."
Reducing emissions
Maryland's plans for emissions reductions are among the nation's most ambitious — but the state is struggling to keep up with its ambitions.
A 2022 state law says by 2031, Maryland must reduce its greenhouse gas emissions 60% compared to 2006. By 2045, it must produce net zero emissions of the gases that cause global warming.
Getting to a 60% reduction by 2031 would require programs to cut emissions of carbon dioxide — the main driver of climate change across Maryland's economy — and cost $1 billion a year, according to the state's Climate Pollution Reduction Plan.
Maryland reduced its emissions 30% by 2020, halfway to the 2031 goal, according to the state Department of the Environment's greenhouse gas inventory.
But the state hasn't made progress since then. Though emissions vary across economic sectors, state officials are expecting to see a slight increase in statewide emissions from 2020 to 2023. This is because transportation emissions — the largest category — have increased 6% since the end of the 2020 COVID-19 lockdown as emissions from electricity have dropped 10%, according to preliminary state data.
Meanwhile, the state hasn't found a source for the $1 billion annual investment needed to reach its emissions goals.
"We don't have cash coming in the door," said Kim Coble, executive director of the Maryland League of Conservation Voters. "So that will slow down the implementation and meeting those reduction goals, no doubt about it."
On top of that, the state just passed legislation to speed up permitting for new natural gas power plants amid concerns about high energy prices. That could worsen greenhouse gas emissions, though natural gas-fired power plants are cleaner than coal or oil plants.
Coble said she believes the state remains committed to its goals, but she's pessimistic about meeting them on time because of money issues — including the Trump administration's impact on climate funding.
The federal administration has made cuts to state climate grants and dismissed climate researchers. It's also started rolling back environmental regulations as it tries to reinvigorate the country's fossil fuel industries.
"Under the [Joe] Biden administration they had billions of dollars going toward it, and I would have been far more optimistic," Coble said. "But that money is in jeopardy, and those of us working in this field … don't even know if it's going to get deployed and how, what that looks like."
Renewable energy
Maryland has been moving toward renewable energy for decades, but as of right now, it's not on track to hit the goals set by the General Assembly six years ago.
Half of Maryland's electricity consumption is supposed to come from renewable sources by 2030, according to a 2019 law. Within that half, 14.5% of consumption must come from solar power.
But the state is falling behind.
"At this rate, we won't meet the 14.5% [solar] carveout by 2030," Paul Pinsky, director of the Maryland Energy Administration, said at a briefing earlier this year.
He was introducing a report published by the Maryland Energy Administration, which concluded renewables in Maryland and the surrounding region aren't growing fast enough to keep up with state goals.
Experts also point to issues with the state's system of incentivizing renewable energy. Electricity suppliers can either provide renewable energy by buying "credits," or pay a fine that goes to a state fund for clean energy grants.
But in 2023, the latest year for which the state has data, renewable energy credits met less than half of the state's goal and fines made up the rest. That's a big drop from previous years, and the state said it happened because it was less expensive in 2023 for electric utilities to pay the fine than to pay for renewables.
A 2024 executive order from Gov. Wes Moore set another goal: 100% clean, in-state energy by 2035. The order told the Maryland Energy Administration to create a plan to get there.
Reaching that goal by 2035 is "extremely, extremely unlikely," Pinsky said at the briefing.
Maryland is struggling to build renewable energy within state borders for a number of reasons.
It can be expensive and difficult to build large-scale facilities like solar farms in Maryland, said Evan Vaughan, executive director of the Mid-Atlantic Renewable Energy Coalition's advocacy arm, MAREC Action. Land constraints, high land prices and a crowded transmission grid complicate such efforts, he said.
A backup in project approvals on the regional electricity grid has also caused difficulties.
"While the state certainly does have a strong and growing renewable energy supply today, it does have some unique challenges," Vaughan said. "You find … common trends across a lot of the smaller, land-constrained states on the East Coast in particular."
Another law sets a goal of 8.5 gigawatts of offshore wind power by 2031, equal to over half of Maryland's total energy sales in 2023.
However, that buildout is in peril. The Trump administration paused leasing and permitting for new offshore projects earlier this year. On top of that, Rep. Andy Harris, State Sen. Mary Beth Carozza and Ocean City Mayor Rick Meehan have asked the secretary of the interior to halt a federally approved project off Maryland's Atlantic coast. There has not yet been a formal response from the Trump administration.
Without new leases for offshore wind, the state won't be able to achieve its goal, according to the Maryland Public Service Commission. The Trump administration's "One Big Beautiful Bill Act," passed in July, will end tax breaks for renewable energy projects such as wind and solar.
Adding it all up, advocates and experts agree Maryland is not where it needs to be.
"You keep on hearing people say, 'Maryland is a leader in clean energy,'" said Adam Dubitsky, consulting state director of the Maryland Land & Liberty Coalition, a conservative clean energy advocacy group. "And it is simply not true."
Incremental progress
So, in light of the state's progress and aggressive goals, can Maryland meet its climate and energy goals on time?
"I am not sure," said State Sen. Malcolm Augustine, a Democrat from Prince George's County who serves as president pro tem of the Senate and chair of an energy subcommittee. "But what I do know is that we're going to work hard to try to achieve that."
The energy package the General Assembly passed this year moves the state in the right direction, he said. It doesn't mean the state is backing off its goals but finding a "more achievable route."
The goals remain state law and Maryland still takes climate change seriously, said State Sen. Brian Feldman, a Democrat from Montgomery County and chair of the Education, Energy and the Environment Committee. He was a lead sponsor of this year's solar siting bill and sponsored the 2019 law that boosted Maryland's renewable energy goal to 50% by 2030.
But some advocates felt there wasn't enough of an emphasis on climate action during the spring legislative session.
"Climate didn't stay in the conversation the way it should have," said Tulkin, the Maryland Sierra Club director.
The future is still cloudy for state climate action, though, thanks to the Trump administration's slew of changes to federal climate and energy policy. Among a host of other actions from the administration, a Trump executive order directs the U.S. attorney general to identify and stop state laws addressing climate change, emissions or environmental justice issues.
Pinsky wrote in response that the move was "worse than irresponsible" and disruptive, accusing the administration of interfering with state matters during a global crisis.
Even so, other climate advocates note Maryland is moving in the right direction despite the challenges it faces.
"What we need to do is just keep taking steps forward," Coble said. "We just keep chipping away at it, and if we continue to take two to three steps forward every year, it is a whole lot better than doing nothing, that's for sure."

title: Cambridge commissioners remove solar cap
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Cambridge commissioners remove solar cap

 July 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 483
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge City Commissioners adopted an ordinance at last week evening's meeting to amend the city's unified development code to exempt medium, large and community solar energy projects from the town's current 350-acre cap.The move essentially removes the cap, which was implemented in 2014, paving the way for a community solar project from Pivot Energy, a Denver-based renewable energy provider and independent power producer. Commissioners unanimously voted in favor of the ordinance to remove the cap.
The plan for community solar was first introduced to commissioners in December, 2024, when Pivot Energy's lawyer Anthony Kupersmith said getting rid of the cap would be critical to the project's success.
Cambridge City Planner Brian Hermann presented Pivot Energy's community solar proposal to commissioners again last week. "The community solar projects are designed to provide opportunities for residents of the community who don't own their house, or are living in the woods and have shade, or don't want to look at solar panels," Hermann said.
Community solar is a way for multiple individuals to share in the benefits of a single solar installation, according to the U.S. Department of Energy. "The term refers to the pooling of resources to develop a community-scale solar energy project that provides the benefits of solar energy to a group or neighborhood," the USDE website states.
After around an hour of questions from commissioners, Mayor Lajan Cephas thanked the gentlemen from Pivot Energy and attempted to move on to the next agenda item, but Commissioner Roche had one more question he 'demanded' be answered before voting on the ordinance.
"So at the end of the day, how do we know, and how does the state know that this power is actually for its intended purpose, which is to lower the utility rates of, in many cases, income constrained individuals, or the community, where it's located?" Roche asked.
Kupersmith told Roche this word isn't neutral and lends authority to regulatory oversight from the Public Service Commission through an application, bonding, subscriber certification and annual reporting to ensure benefits, especially for low- and moderate-income customers.
Hermann and Pivot Energy representatives were uncertain of how many acres they will need for the new community solar project, but it will exceed the current cap. Kupersmith and Pivot Energy Development Project Manager John Shields made it clear that if the city does not remove the cap, Pivot Energy is willing to go to the state, which can supersede the city's code.
Commissioners asked if there were decommissioning protocols for the end of the project's life or in case of damage. The decommissioning plan and bond would follow the city's existing zoning rules and Public Service Commission standards.
When it comes to what exactly the community solar project will look like, Pivot Energy is keeping its options open.
Shields said at the current moment, there is not a drawn-up project plan. "We'd rather kind of look at it more holistically if we can," Shields said.

title: EPA faults state on offshore wind permit process
author: Lily Tierney
content:
EPA faults state on offshore wind permit process

 July 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 525
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has identified that the Maryland Department of the Environment was mishandling a key offshore wind permit by misinforming the public about how to appeal it, prompting both technical corrections and political firestorms.The dispute centers on a permit for US Wind's proposed wind farm off the coast of Ocean City and could temporarily delay or complicate the project's future. According to the EPA findings, MDE improperly issued a federal air permit under the Outer Continental Shelf Air Regulations and MDE has been ordered to reissue the permit with corrected appeal instructions or face legal backlash.
Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.) said that the EPA's ruling was a "major victory for the Eastern Shore, the environment and our local economies that are existentially threatened by this project."
Harris cited environmental risks of offshore wind projects as disturbance of the sea bottom and ocean ecology, toxic hydraulic and lubricating fluids that could leak and the risk of turbine damage.
Harris said a similar project in New Jersey led by Atlantic Shores led to the developer abandoning the project after the appeals. These appeals came after President Donald Trump signed an executive order after taking office in January that froze new federal wind leases and permits while reviewing existing projects.
According to Harris, constituents are concerned over the impacts on Ocean City and commercial fishermen saying U.S. Wind has not honored its promise to keep turbines at least 17 miles offshore and allegedly now plans to build turbines as close as 10 miles.
"Writ large, the problem with Maryland is that we have not had a good energy policy for years exemplified by the fact that we have to import 40% of our power from surrounding states, including West Virginia and Pennsylvania, which generate their electricity from fossil fuels," Harris said. "So it's unclear to me why we would attempt to brag about, you know, going to 100% renewable energy when we know that's probably not possible."
Maryland agencies like MDE may not be fully equipped to handle federal delegations for such projects and ultimate authority is retained by federal agencies. Because of this, companies like Atlantic Shores in New Jersey canceled its project and plans to come back when the political climate is more favorable, according to a PBS news report.
"We received the letter and are reviewing it now. MDE is committed to ensuring all our permit processes are transparent and in accordance with the law," Jay Apperson, deputy director of communications for MDE said in a statement to the Star Democrat.
Harris said he is categorically opposed to offshore wind energy but is not opposed to alternative sources of clean energy like geothermal and small modular nuclear reactors, which he said are much safer alternatives.
"Such as the Vienna Power plant that is scheduled to close in five years, and obviously has permitting to generate power there. Locations like that might be ideal for small modular reactors," Harris said.
While the EPA identified procedural issues with how MDE directed the public to appeal the permit, Harris characterized the letter as validation of broader concerns about the project's approval and local opposition. US Wind did not respond for a comment.

title: Article was work of propaganda
author: Staff Writer
content:
Article was work of propaganda

 July 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 301
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The article of 11 July on global warming has factual errors and ungrounded assertions. Temperatures in the state have not risen 2.5° F since the 20th century. The 20th century ended 25 years ago, and temperatures have not risen 2.5° F since then. NOAA reports a temperature increase of 2.5° F since the mid-19th century.An increase in carbon dioxide in the atmosphere does not increase the acidity of ocean waters. Ocean and Bay waters area buffered solutions with an alkaline pH. Increased carbon dioxide absorption may cause a slight decrease in alkalinity, but cannot turn Bay water acidic.
The article states that federal data shows the state is experiencing increasing precipitation, higher probability of summer droughts and more extreme weather events. The fifth National Climate Assessment data was taken down because the data had been massaged to prove the assertions that droughts, floods, extreme weather events and higher precipitation levels were on the rise, when they have not been.
The article asserts that warmer waters will kill fish at an increasing rate, while noting that crabs will thrive and shrimp are migrating into the Bay. The "will kill fish" assertion is without basis.
The article asserts that low-lying flat areas make them more vulnerable to the effects of an increasing climate. What on earth is an "increasing climate?" Mr. Tidwell notes that "we just have to stabilize the climate." Regional climates are beyond the control of humans, and they are inherently unstable. His statement is pablum.
It is apparent that the Chesapeake Bay is experiencing geological changes as evidenced by rising water levels and brackish water intrusion into land that affects flora. These were well described in the article. Attributing these effects and other imaginary effects to man-made global warming, as the article does, makes it, as a whole, a work of propaganda.
PAYNE KILBOURN
Neavitt
