title: Spotted lanternflies are everywhere — what you can do
author: MARY BURKE Capital News Service
content:
Spotted lanternflies are everywhere — what you can do

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARY BURKE Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 776
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Over the past few months, invasive spotted lanternflies have emerged in massive numbers across Maryland.Originating in Asia, the spotted lanternfly is an invasive pest that feeds on a variety of plants. The lanternfly was first detected in the United States in Berks County, Pennsylvania, in 2014. It is suspected that the species was accidentally carried into the United States through an international shipment of stone.
Although the insect first appeared in the United States over a decade ago, it has only been seen in Maryland since 2018. Since then, the species has spread throughout 20 out of 23 counties in the state, according to the Maryland Department of Agriculture.
What harm do they pose?
Spotted lanternflies are not directly dangerous to humans. Although their flitting around can be irritating, the insects do not sting or bite. There also has not been evidence of spotted lanternflies being poisonous to eat or being dangerous to pets.
However, because they feed on plant sap, spotted lanternflies pose a threat to the well-being of a number of plant species in Maryland. Grapes are particularly at risk of harm: their feeding risks killing off grapevines. They also enjoy feeding on maple and willow trees.
When feeding, lanternflies excrete honeydew, a substance which is known to grow fungus. This "sooty mold" fungus will not directly kill a plant, but in large quantities, may stifle photosynthesis by blocking its access to sunlight. The fungal growth may also prevent crops from being sold.
"They're seeing damage, almost permanent damage, to things underneath of the trees," Jessica Boyles, the coordinator for the Maryland Department of Agriculture's spotted lanternfly response program, told Capital News Service.
Boyles mentioned that she has heard reports of damage to landscaping, siding, and outdoor equipment such as grills and furniture due to honeydew and sooty mold.
Excess honeydew may also pose another threat: attracting unpopular stinging insects, such as wasps, hornets and honeybees.
Why are they everywhere?
Spotted lanternflies are notorious for hitchhiking to new places on cars and trains.
Because each female typically lays between 30 and 50 eggs, lanternfly populations can explode in just a few years. These egg masses can be hard to spot, closely resembling mud splotches.
Without native natural predators, lanternfly populations can develop under the radar over several years until they emerge in unignorable numbers.
"It really wasn't all of the sudden," Dr. Michael Raupp, a professor of entomology at the University of Maryland, said.
"They were really here for several years, but at low levels," Raupp stated. "Now, because they've had time for their populations to increase, we're seeing them everywhere."
What can you do?
Contrary to popular belief, some experts say that killing an individual spotted lanternfly does little to curb the insect's population growth.
"The thing that regulates their population are predators, parasites and diseases," Raupp said. "So, by stepping on some spotted lanternflies, it's kind of like spitting in the ocean and thinking you've turned back the tide."
Instead, Maryland's Department of Agriculture recommends installing circle traps, which capture spotted lanternflies without using chemicals that may put other insect populations at risk.
These traps wrap around trees to funnel spotted lanternflies into a dead-end container, and can be either purchased or made at home. It may also be helpful to dispose of egg masses if you see them.
Spotted lanternflies prefer to feast on the Tree of Heaven plant, which is another invasive species from Asia. Removing a Tree of Heaven (roots and all) from your yard can help avoid attracting the insect.
Lastly, checking your vehicles before traveling can also help to prevent the spread.
"Make sure that you don't bring spotted lanternfly with you on your daily commute," Boyles said.
Ultimately, however, experts forecast that spotted lanternfly populations will eventually subside once they begin to face more predation and disease.
"Eventually, Mother Nature will take care of this, as she does with many of our invasive species," Raupp said.
Some areas have already begun to see population declines due to an increase in predators and disease.
"We now have more than 1,000 observations of indigenous vertebrates and invertebrates eating spotted lanternflies," Raupp said.
Some of these predators include spiders, mantises, chickens and pheasants.
This is not to say, however, that stomping lanternflies is futile.
"If you're killing one…you are making sure that that spotted lanternfly can't essentially quadruple its numbers," Boyles said.
As lanternflies continue to lay eggs up until the first frost, often in December, it can still be worth it to squash the pests, experts say.
Why bother reporting?
Currently, the state's Department of Agriculture is still accepting reports of spotted lanternfly sightings across Maryland.
Although officials acknowledge that total eradication of the species is unlikely, reporting helps the agency to allocate resources to areas experiencing large populations of lanternflies.
"That information is vital," Boyles said. "It does help us."

title: One seedling at a time: Nonprofit gives away native plants, empowers youth
author: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com
content:
One seedling at a time: Nonprofit gives away native plants, empowers youth

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 544
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Esther Bonney turned her grief into growth by starting a nonprofit that aims to spread native plants.Nurture Natives, a youth-led nonprofit organization, empowers young people through native biodiversity, restoration and education.
About a year and a half after losing her older brother to suicide, Bonney, a La Plata resident and founder of Nurture Natives, joined 4-H with the Charles County Pollinator Masters Club to study and dive into being outside with pollinators and native plants.
"I felt pretty lost," Bonney said. "Then 4-H came into my life … and I joined it not knowing that it would be such a beam of support."
After attending the National 4-H Youth Summit on Agriscience, members were encouraged to design a project that would solve an agricultural issue, Bonney said. One of the issues that came up during conversations with farmers in Southern Maryland was invasive plant species.
Nurture Natives was created to address this agricultural issue and the broader environmental issue of invasive species.
These sustainable efforts helped the National 4-H Council select her as one of the 2026 4-H Youth in Action Award winners. Nurture Natives has planted 2.4 million native seeds, distributed 70,000 seedlings and engaged more than 10,000 young people to help protect native plants and pollinators, according to a release from 4-H.
"Pollination is what keeps our world functioning," Bonney said. "Pollination is so key to both our agriculture and our environmental systems."
Jeremy Tidd, owner and founder of Bona Terra, looked for ways to give back to the community and get more engagement about his native plant nursery when he decided to start giving seedlings away for free as part of a grant application, he said. Bona Terra grows 30 native plant species and is working to give away one million seedlings a year.
"There's no shortage of seeds in the world," Tidd said.
Bona Terra became involved with Nurture Native's mission when Bonney called local nurseries to put pamphlets on display racks, Tidd said. Bona Terra invited Nurture Natives to the nursery.
"They saw that I was giving away seedlings and they wanted to volunteer," Tidd said.
Bona Terra and Nurture Natives partnered to decide how to run seedling giveaway events and what training sessions to offer, Tidd said. They had their first training in March.
"Every time the world changes it's because we've taught the next generation," Tidd said. "Young adults … were taught … that we had to do something about it and now it's just accepted, common knowledge."
Nurture Natives is at the intersection of environmental stewardship and youth mental health, Bonney said. The organization is meant to help young people find meaning through environmental action who feel disconnected from nature or who feel powerless when hearing about the biodiversity crises.
"You might notice a lot of people who have a passion for gardening are older," Bonney said. "A discussion that has been pretty consistent … has been how do we bridge this gap?"
Bonney is a freshman at the University of Maryland, College Park and hopes to continue to grow Nurture Natives as a fellow with the university's Do Good Institute, where she will work on expanding the nonprofit's initiatives, she said.
"The coolest thing about the seedlings is it has made people brave," Tidd said. "This is a learning opportunity. Plants are amazing and have so much to teach us."

title: Survey shows below-average juvenile striped bass numbers
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Survey shows below-average juvenile striped bass numbers

 October 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: News 
 
 300
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For the seventh consecutive year in Maryland and fourth consecutive year in Virginia, young striped bass numbers are well below the long-term average, according to results from an annual survey released Wednesday.The survey by the Virginia Institute of Marine Science and Maryland Department of Natural Resources estimates striped bass recruitment, which includes reproductive success and early survival rates.
"Consistent, record-low levels of recruitment, combined with past overfishing of striped bass, are extremely concerning for the iconic species," the Chesapeake Bay Foundation said in a press release about the results.
Not enough young fish are surviving the many challenges in the region, including warmer water temperatures, food availability, and invasive predators like blue catfish, according to the release. This could delay or jeopardize rebuilding the striped bass population by the 2029 target — a goal set by fisheries managers at the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission.
According to the survey, the 2025 young-of-year index for Maryland was four fish per sample. This is slightly higher than last year's index of two, but significantly lower than the state's long-term average of 11. In Virginia, the index was 5.12 fish per sample. This is slightly higher than last year's index of 3.43, but still below the state's historic average of 7.77.
To address concerns for striped bass, the fisheries commission is considering stronger protections for the species. At their next meeting on Oct. 29, ASMFC's Striped Bass Management Board will vote on Addendum III — a response to the 2024 striped bass stock assessment and recommendations made by ASMFC's Technical Committee. The analysis determined that striped bass are overfished, and that without additional action, it's unlikely the species will rebuild to their target numbers by 2029.
Eastern Shore watermen have vocally opposed changes outlined in Addendum III, which would trim total removals and could add more closures.

title: Sewage seeping onto streets sparks Cambridge flood debate
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Sewage seeping onto streets sparks Cambridge flood debate

 October 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 506
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge city commissioners met for a work session Monday to review a presentation from the "Make Cambridge Resilient" team and to ask questions about the project — and there were many.The initiative is a shoreline and stormwater flood risk-reduction project, but some commissioners and elected officials have expressed concerns about its scope and goals. The design phase is now 30% complete, but without secured funding and support from the city, county and elected officials, the effort may stall.
Current goals include:
Designing and constructing a living shoreline.Creating a stormwater system with nature-based water storage and control features.Gathering public comments.Institutionalizing floodplain management and flood risk reduction.Developing a green infrastructure plan.Implementing additional nature-based solutions.Reactivating and maintaining the stakeholder group.Providing support to property owners to identify risk-reduction strategies.
During recent City Council meetings, Commissioner Brett Summers raised concerns about toilet paper in the street, an issue caused by floodwater entering the sewer system through manhole defects. Director of Public Works Wayne Suggs said during the meeting that three spots remain where sewage and floodwater are still connected.
Suggs said three elements must be addressed to control these issues: top-down flooding, pump station capacity limits and creek water entering the system.
The Trenton Street Pump Station, which takes in most of the city's stormwater, is 97 years old and failing. When floodwater enters wastewater lines, it is pumped to the nearly century-old station, which doesn't have the capacity to handle it. As a result, toilet paper and sewage rise onto the streets.
"So can this project help us with that problem — and when?" Summers said.
Project Manager Larry White responded that adding pumps at the end of streets, repairing older infrastructure and constructing a living shoreline will help with sewage issues, but the project itself does not cover wastewater.
The city has published a bid to rehabilitate the Trenton Street Pump Station, but it's a $7 million project.
"Even if we moved and we awarded the bid tomorrow for Trenton Street, it will be 18 months before that system can be brought online," City Manager Glenn Steckman said.
Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said a mutual understanding of the project's goals is lacking and needs to be developed.
Del. Tom Hutchinson (R- Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) expressed concerns about the project, saying there has been mixed feedback from constituents and comparing the initiative to the "failing" Strand Beach project in Oxford.
Other concerns included insufficient outreach — particularly to Black and Hispanic communities and city park users — a lack of coordination with state agencies such as the Department of Natural Resources and the Maryland Department of the Environment, and long-term maintenance responsibilities.
Hutchinson said he contacted stakeholders listed on the project's website and many raised similar concerns.
"I had the opportunity to talk to DNR Secretary Kurtz, and he wasn't aware of the project," he said.
Some stakeholders, including Debbie Cornwell with the Maryland Department of Planning, expressed concerns about transparency.
Commissioners agreed to make the council chambers available for future public "Make Cambridge Resilient" meetings to improve transparency, but no further action was taken during the work session.

title: Easton flower show bursts with holiday spirit
author: SUBMITTED
content:
Easton flower show bursts with holiday spirit

 October 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SUBMITTED | Section: Life 
 
 273

 Talbot County Garden Club held its "Holidays!" Flower Show on Friday, Oct. 17 at St. Mark's Parish Hall in Easton. The show assembled horticultural entries, representing 175 of the best specimens currently growing in local gardens and numerous design entries, creatively expressing the joys of the coming holiday season — Halloween through New Year's.While entries came primarily from club's talented gardeners and designers, members of seven other Eastern Shore clubs also participated. And Young Gardeners (kindergarten to eighth grade) shared their enthusiasm and creativity with floral craft and design entries — TCGC's first flower show to include competition by youngsters.
Flower show prizes were awarded in 12 different categories by officials, who assessed entries according to National Garden Club rules. Many plant-loving friends and neighbors attended.
Boots Michalak chaired the flower show. She was assisted by a team that included horticultural experts Trish Reynolds and Pam Keeton, plus design expert Ingrid Blanton and Young Gardeners chair Gretta McDonald.
The Talbot County Garden Club has worked to enhance the beauty of the local environment since 1917 by supporting civic greening projects, maintaining public gardens and other public spaces, sharing a deep knowledge of gardening, encouraging the conservation of natural resources and fostering the art of flower arranging.
Noteworthy projects include overseeing the gardens of the Talbot Historical Society, Talbot County Free Library in Easton, and the Fountain and Children's Gardens in Idlewild Park. The club has donated plantings along Easton's Rails to Trails and at the Easton post office and Christ Church. The club hosts outreach activities for students, people living with disabilities and the elderly, among others. There are currently 118 active, associate and honorary members.
